webTitle: Cup overflows with photo shoots and chat-show appearances

fields.headline: Cup overflows with photo shoots and chat-show appearances
fields.trailText: There is something about a shiny football trophy that excites the English criminal classes. But anyone hoping to thieve the FA Cup these days would have trouble keeping up with the old trophy's PR programme.
fields.body:
There is something about a shiny football trophy that excites the English criminal classes. The Jules Rimet Trophy, the Northern League championship trophy and the "first World Cup", the Sir Thomas Lipton Trophy, have all been carried off down the years.

First to go was the original FA Cup. The "little tin idol" was snatched from the shop window of W Shillcock, a Birmingham boot-makers, in 1895 ("It must not be forgotten," a Victorian humorist noted the following day, "that even when stolen three times it does not become the property of the thief").

Any contemporary smash-and-grab merchant hoping to repeat such a feat would be hard pressed indeed. Nowadays not only does the FA Cup zip about the country at a speed that would leave Michael Schumacher trailing in its wake, but barely a minute of its day goes unrecorded by the cameras. It is the Liz Hurley of sports prizes (though, admittedly, the star of Bedazzled has never been brandished above the head of an Essex meat porter in the middle of Smithfield Market. Well, not that we know of, anyway).

Last week the most famous creation of the Bradford silversmiths Messrs Fattorini and Sons was tiresomely ubiquitous, photographed everywhere from Morecambe Bay to the Thames Barrier. Such was the Cup's rampant pursuit of publicity it was a surprise not to see it pop up on the campaign trail with Ehud Barak or at the wedding of Aled Jones. The days of cameo appearances on Friends and Star Trek Voyager are surely not far away.

Once the FA Cup was treated in an altogether less starry fashion. Buried away for much of the year, it was often roughly handled when it did make an appearance. In 1980, for example, the then holders West Ham reportedly sent it to the BBC studios stuffed in a pillowcase in the back of a black cab.

These days, though, PR is everything and the venerable trophy is on a media treadmill that would exhaust Madonna. Surprisingly the responsibility of ferrying it about falls to one man.

I encountered this singular figure on a frosty evening several years ago at a non-League ground in northern England. The FA Cup was standing proudly by the entrance before an Axa banner, surrounded by a half a dozen fans, a television crew and a flock of those hyperactive, girning urchins who seem to follow TV cameras about as lapwings trail the plough.

All was normal until a journalist moved to place an empty Styrofoam cup down on the table next to the silver trophy. "Don't put that there," a deep and sonorous voice reprimanded him from the shadows. "It will leave a ring on the velvet that will never come off."

The speaker stepped into the glow of the floodlights. He was six feet in height with sleek dark hair and skin the colour and texture of a calf-skin catcher's mitt. Fans of 1980s soap operas could not but be reminded of Cecil Colby from Dynasty.

"Who are you, then?" the journalist asked. "I," the tall stranger explained gravely, "am ... the Keeper of the Cup." "Is that a full-time position, then?" someone asked. The Keeper nodded. It seemed that he and the Cup were as inseparable as Martin Johnson's eyebrows. "When I am finished here I will drive to Swansea," he replied. "Probably breaking my journey at a Travelodge in the vicinity of Worcester."

Sensing perhaps that this sounded a little less than glamorous, he added: "I value the anonymity. I arrive after dark, park near the front entrance and slip swiftly inside with my overnight bag and, of course ..." He nodded affectionately in the direction of his glimmering ward.

"I carry it in a plain wooden box," he said. Then he lowered his rich voice to a conspiratorial whisper. "On occasion I have walked through vast crowds bearing the Cup and not a single person has had the slightest inkling that it was among them."

The Keeper of the Cup's dedication and hard work are to be applauded, of course, but the concomitant publicity has to some minds at least stretched the magic of the Cup a little too thinly. No one would want the Cup to disappear into the midlands night as its predecessor did in 1895, but I'm sure I'm not alone in feeling that a few months out of the limelight would only add to its mystique.

webTitle: Use me or lose me, says Given

fields.headline: Use me or lose me, says Given
fields.trailText: Liverpool and Arsenal are expected to lead the chase to sign Newcastle goalkeeper Shay Given after he yesterday handed in a written transfer request.
fields.body:
Liverpool and Arsenal are expected to lead the chase to sign the Republic of Ireland international Shay Given, after the Newcastle goalkeeper yesterday handed in a written transfer request.

Given has failed to regain his first-team place from Steve Harper after missing United's Boxing Day win over Leeds with a dead leg. The 24-year-old signed a new four-year contract at St James' Park in September but his inability to win a recall despite last week's 4-2 humbling at Tottenham prompted his request.

"The board have told me that they will give me a decision later in the week and in the meantime I will train with enthusiasm," said Given, who was signed for £2.5m in May 1997. "I thought that my consistency in the 20 or so early-season games would have meant an early recall. When this did not happen and I was given no explanation, I felt I had no other way of making my feelings known.

"There are many players who would not have reacted in this way, but I am a passionate and committed player, desperate for Newcastle to do well."

If United comply and circulate his name, the Tyneside club will have over £16m of defensive talent available for transfer, including the £3.25m French left-back Didier Domi and the £6m Spanish centre-half Marcelino.

Carlisle's former chairman Michael Knighton has denied he still controls the Third Division strugglers via Mamcarr, the Gibraltar-based company which claimed to have bought his controlling interest last week.

Rumours abound in Cumbria that Mamcarr, whose directors remain anonymous, is an acronym of Michael And Mark, Chevonne, Albert, Rosemary and Rory - the former owner, his eldest son, daughter, father, wife and younger son.

"That is absolute rubbish," said Knighton, who last year was banned from acting as a company director by the Department of Trade and Industry. "I am not a director of Mamcarr and I have no intention of becoming one. Neither am I the beneficial owner of Mamcarr. I know people are asking whether I am controlling the football club via an offshore vehicle and I can categorically tell you that I am not."

webTitle: Spackman joins Barnsley for a 'proper job'

fields.headline: Spackman joins Barnsley for a 'proper job'
fields.trailText: Barnsley yesterday confirmed the appointment of Nigel Spackman as their manager, replacing Dave Bassett.
fields.body:
Barnsley yesterday confirmed the appointment of Nigel Spackman as their manager, replacing Dave Bassett.

Spackman has combined television punditry with scouting for England since leaving Sheffield United in 1998. "I felt that the time was right to get a full-time job, a proper job, and that's why I'm here," he said.

Barnsley have slumped since reaching last season's play-off final and Spackman said: "If we can finish in the top half of the league it will be a good end to the season and then hopefully over the years we can get the club back in the Premiership."

West Ham, who have been seeking defensive cover since selling Rio Ferdinand to Leeds in November, yesterday confirmed they were close to bringing Blackburn's Christian Dailly to Upton Park.

Dailly would cost around £2.25m, with Marc Keller going in the opposite direction. "Talks will be held with the rel evant parties in the week and we hope a deal can be concluded," said West Ham's managing director Paul Aldridge.

The club will also meet Rangers' Lorenzo Amoruso, another defender. In such a hectic schedule Harry Redknapp, their manager, must also find time for Steve Lomas, who is confused after West Ham accepted £3.7m bids for him from Everton and Manchester City. "I hope to see him in the next day or two," said Lomas. "Hopefully things will then be sorted out one way or the other."

West Ham's FA Cup game at Manchester United has been moved to Sunday January 28 to allow for TV coverage. It will be shown on ITV at 2pm.

Sky will show two fixtures over the weekend, with Leeds's home tie with Liverpool to be played at 12pm on January 27 and Chelsea's visit to Gillingham at 4pm the following day.

Sky will also show the third-round replay between Dagenham & Redbridge and Charlton on Wednesday January 17 at 7.45pm.

fields.headline: Lazio lose patience with Eriksson
fields.standfirst: England on standby as latest defeat puts Swede under pressure
fields.trailText: England could still have their coach elect Sven-Goran Eriksson in charge for the game against Spain next month after a day of farce unfolded at Lazio yesterday.
fields.body:
England could still have their coach elect Sven-Goran Eriksson in charge for the game against Spain next month after a day of farce unfolded at Lazio yesterday.

According to one report, Eriksson has already agreed to resign after another defeat on Sunday, at home to lowly Napoli.

At a meeting with Eriksson at lunch-time, the Lazio president Sergio Cragnotti was reported to have asked the coach to quit. The pair then agreed a pact: Cragnotti would support Eriksson for the rest of the day but Eriksson would announce his resignation today, citing the poor run of results and the fans' loss of confidence in him.

But yesterday evening Eriksson, after gaining the backing of some of his key players, met Cragnotti at the president's house to try and convince him that he should stay and that he could get the team back on its feet.

Cragnotti agreed to think about it and give his answer today. But it appears that the Lazio vice-president and former Italy manager Dino Zoff yesterday signed a three-year contract to replace Eriksson as coach.

Certainly Lazio's tone had altered noticeably after yesterday's meeting. Whereas before they had firmly put down and been rather offended at speculation that he might leave early to take up his England post before the due date of July 1, yesterday the reaction was far more ambivalent.

"Eriksson can stay with the team if he wants to," said Cragnotti. "It's up to him."

In another interview the president talked about the situation staying as it is "for now". And later he added: "We've discussed what happened yesterday. I can only say that for our part there is no news."

The "for our part" only increased speculation that there may be yet some news from Eriksson.

Lazio may have decided to delay the announcement because they did not want to see it splashed across the papers on the club's 100th birthday today. Yet Zoff, who is the club's vice-president, was uncharacteristically bold in flying his colours. "If they asked me, I would be available to help the team to the limit of my abilities," he said.

In any event, the Football Association must be hoping that the current situation does not continue for long. It controversially appointed the national side's first foreign coach on the basis of his international success. But Lazio's slump - five wins in their past 12 games in all competitions - has put a dent in his reputation.

Lazio lost 2-1 at home to Napoli on Sunday. "The players still had Christmas cake on their feet," said Cragnotti pointedly.

For the sake of England's chances in their crucial World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania in March and against Greece in June, the FA would like Eriksson here as soon as possible.

The FA's chief executive Adam Crozier still intends to meet Lazio and Eriksson this month to firm up details of when the Swede can take up the post. Privately, though, he would surely like this meeting to become unnecessary.

Yesterday the FA's executive director David Davies preferred to remain diplomatic. "We want Sven-Goran Eriksson to do well and we are disappointed when Lazio do not win," he said, and added: "Adam Crozier will be meeting with them in the next couple of weeks and we will attempt to resolve any uncertainty about the future."

According to sources close to the club, the Lazio hierarchy do not blame Eriksson for the mess; the coach can do little about injuries to key players and lack of form from others.

The fact that the Italian champions have just pur chased the former Manchester United winger Karel Poborsky and will sign Udinese's Italian international midfielder Stefano Fiore next week suggests that all hope has not yet been abandoned of turning the season around.

Replacing the coach in mid-season is not an easy task in Italy, where they are allowed to coach only one club per season. One of Lazio's preferred candidates, Marcello Lippi, is ineligible under this rule.

But personal pride aside, Eriksson must be starting to wonder whether he needs the hassle. The fans are increasingly on his back, and the atmosphere at the club is growing more fractious by the day.

Recently, at the Lazio training ground, when a TV crew tried to film club officials taking down a banner telling Eriksson to go, one club official attacked the camera crew. He later apologised.

On Sunday, Lazio fans and the police fought with visiting supporters. Eighteen people were hospitalised. Napoli fans' cars were attacked and at least one burned. Coaches carrying Napoli fans were also attacked.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: FA loophole means no justice for Vieira

fields.headline: FA loophole means no justice for Vieira
fields.trailText: The FA has decided that Carlisle midfielder Richard Prokas will walk away scot-free after his two-foot lunge at Arsenal's Patrick Vieira on Saturday.
fields.body:
The Carlisle midfielder Richard Prokas will not face punishment for his two-foot lunge at Patrick Vieira after the Football Association, for fear of undermining referees, ruled out changing its system of calling on a video advisory panel.

In a decision that has left Arsenal privately stunned, Prokas will walk away scot-free from the tackle that left Vieira with a shattered shin pad and a gash below his right knee during Saturday's FA Cup third-round tie, even though the referee Steve Lodge later admitted he would have sent him off had he been better placed to see the incident.

The Barnsley official initially deemed the incident "a fair, 50-50 challenge". Had he missed the tackle entirely the FA could have referred the matter to its video panel. "But we can't because the referee has actually seen it and chosen how to deal with it," said the FA spokesman Adrian Bevington.

"Under our disciplinary rules there's nothing we can do regarding this particular matter. It's unfortunate that the referee clearly feels he would have made a different decision had he had the benefit of the television angle."

The FA is anxious not to reduce referees' roles by overturning their decisions with the help of video evidence. As a result, the third eye can only be used to consider events that the match officials have missed or cases of mistaken identity and wrongful dismissal.

Meanwhile Vieira has launched an attack on the FA as he awaits news of his own punishment, courtesy of the video panel, for his clashes with Olivier Dacourt and Eirik Bakke during Arsenal's 1-0 defeat at Leeds on November 26. The 24-year-old, who has not been booked since August, faces a three-match ban for the challenges, which were missed by the referee Dermot Gallagher.

Though the FA insists Gallagher did not see either incident, Vieira told the French magazine Onze Mon dial: "The referee said that he was perfectly placed and saw what went on, and also said similar incidents happen in games all the time.

"But afterwards a commission watched the video of the match and decided to charge me. This is typical English-style stupidity. It would really stick in my throat to earn a suspension as a result, and it would also have serious implications as far as referees are concerned. It would call their honesty and ability into question.

"If a referee says he has seen everything and it is all fine, then you get punished because of a video, that is total rubbish. It is like saying that referees are good for nothing beyond strutting round like penguins."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Ricard sours Bradford spirits
fields.standfirst:
Middlesbrough march on as Jefferies shows surplus stars the door
Big three on the way out at Valley Parade
fields.trailText:
Bradford 0 - 1 Middlesbrough
Terry Venables Middlesbrough revolution continues as Bradford manager Jim Jefferies gives his surplus stars the boot.
fields.body:
The toast of Teesside is still one Terry Venables - pundit, coach and, most significantly, talisman. Before the former England coach came galloping to their rescue late last year, Middlesbrough would probably have lost this tight and rather listless tie.

But a renewed sense of purpose has precipitated a change of fortune and a diligent second-half performance was sufficient to see them safely through to a home fourth round meeting with either Wimbledon or Notts County.

As for Bradford City, they can now devote their time and efforts to defending their Premiership status.

An intriguing and distinguished roll of dishonour it was too. Among those deemed incapable of adding to the Yorkshire's club's grim, arguably futile, fight for Premiership salvation were Benito Carbone, Dan Petrescu, Lee Sharpe, Gunnar Halle and, of course, Stanley Victor Collymore.

All will now be invited to find gainful employment away from Valley Parade, an exercise which, if successful, would save a hard-up club around £100,000 a week in wages.

"My first-team squad is now too big and it's important we cut the wage bill," said Jefferies. "What we have to do in the remaining months of the season is play as a team, a collective unit, rather than as a group of individuals."

Robert Molenaar went closest while the adrenalin rush was at its most pronounced, his fine header from an Eoin Jess corner thumping against the base of a post. Dean Saunders really should have scored after collecting the rebound but these days he is profligate rather than prolific.

But, at least the ageing Welshman is still an enthusiast and midway through the opening half he steered a firm drive just wide of the mark after the Middlesbrough defence stood idly by.

Although the Bradford defence shook like needles on a discarded Christmas tree every time Alen Boksic was in possession, they held firm without apparent discomfort.

For a team with manifold problems, Bradford's football was remarkably precise and patient; slowly but surely it would seem that lessons are being learned. But, no matter how attractive your approach play all is irrelevant if there is no cutting blade up front.

The better of their openings invariably fell the way of Dean Windass, who steered in shots from wherever it was he was standing after establishing control of the ball. The closest he came was shortly after the interval when his ferocious drive from just outside the penalty area almost embarrassed goalkeeper Mark Schwarzer who spooned the ball away to relative safety.

And then rather perversely, Middlesbrough emerged from their bunker to score. It was a magnificent goal out of keeping with the mundane proceedings, Hamilton Ricard arrowing a sublime shot into the top corner from 20 or so yards.

Benito Carbone

Stan Collymore

webTitle: Recommended CD-roms:  Essential French and English Poetry Plus

fields.headline: Recommended CD-roms
fields.trailText: Key stages 1 and 2: Essential French, Key stage 4: English Poetry Plus
fields.body:
Essential French

Vector Ltd, £19.00 + VAT, 0161 8283000

Age 5-11 yrs

Designed to provide the knowledge needed to introduce French at key stages 1 or 2, using audio and visual computer-based resources. Children manage their own progress and test themselves.

Units cover pronunciation of letters and numbers; telling the time; money, days, dates, weather and basic phrases. It is a very simple piece of software - children can use it with the minimum of help.

Essentials provides a practical way of introducing young children to French. Although it lacks work-sheets and a record-keeping facility, it is easy to use and motivating.

 Read a full evaluation of this program at www.teem.org.uk

English Poetry Plus

(Chadwyck Healey, £265, 01223 271253)

Age 14-16yrs

Aimed at KS4 students who require detailed analysis of a range of poems. 5,000 poems from 300 English-speaking writers are included; a particular strength is the comparative study of major poets pre-1914. Different media are complementary and of excellent quality. The search facility helps pupils not only to compare but also, through the note-making facility, to synthesise information, so they are encouraged to think through their own ideas.

This is an appropriate and convenient study aid, highly recommended. A copy held in the library would be of benefit to groups of up to three students studying at their own pace.

webTitle: Livingstone's warning as new Underground head starts work

fields.headline: Tube barrier
fields.standfirst:
Mayor's warning as new Underground head starts work

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Mayor's warning as new Underground head starts work.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone warned ministers yesterday that he would not accept cosmetic changes to the government's part-privatisation plans for the London Underground, as the former New York subway chief Bob Kiley, right, arrived by tube to begin his first day as transport commissioner for London.

Speaking with the TUC general secretary, John Monks, at a rally against the tube sell off, the London mayor said that his decision about whether to accept any revised government plan for the tube would depend entirely on Mr Kiley's assessment.

His remarks follow suggestions that Tony Blair is considering whether to readmit Mr Livingstone to the Labour party if he accepts a modest rejigging of the government's scheme to split up the Underground and hand over stations, track and signalling to the private sector.

Mr Livingstone said he welcomed such "positive" hints. "But my future relationship with the party will not be determined by cosmetic changes to the government's public-private partnership plan, but by Bob Kiley's recommendation as to whether any new proposals will deliver a safe and efficient tube".

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Gemma
fields.trailText: My husband and I were in Singapore in September, and I am writing to recommend that you go on the night safari at the zoo. It was the highlight of our trip. We went after a particularly heavy downpour and it felt like we had the place to ourselves. The sound of the bullfrogs was magical.
fields.body:
I have just started following your adventures and see that you will probably be in Singapore at the moment. My husband and I were there in September visiting friends and I am writing to recommend that you go on the night safari at the zoo. We both agree that it was the highlight of our trip to Singapore and Malaysia. We went after a particularly heavy downpour and it felt like we had the place to ourselves. The sound of the bullfrogs was magical.

Do take the train to Kuala Lumpur from Singapore too. We did the return journey by bus and travelling by road means that you miss the beautiful scenery experienced by rail. Our train was four hours late, however, as in places there's only a single track. Be warned too that the air-conditioning can be rather cold!

Good luck with the rest of your travels. Those of us stuck in a rather drab (and cold) winter are very envious!

fields.headline: Fair deal?
fields.standfirst: In 2001-2 Edinburgh will spend nearly £1,400 more on each student than Westminster - and £1,600 more than Cardiff. Stephen Court reports on the disturbing fallout of devolution
fields.trailText: 9 January: In 2001-2 Edinburgh will spend nearly £1,400 more on each student than Westminster - and £1,600 more than Cardiff. Stephen Court reports on the disturbing fallout of devolution
fields.body:
Consider yourself lucky if you were born in Scotland and plan to study at a Scottish university. The Scottish Executive will spend about a quarter more on your education than will be spent on students in England and Wales. You won't have to pay up-front tuition fees . Some of you will be eligible for a non-repayable grant to help with living costs. And, for students on standard full-time first degree courses, you will have four years at university, compared with three years in other parts of the UK.

Other attractions could include having the television chef Clarissa Dickson Wright as the rector of your university, if you go to Aberdeen, or sharing a lecture theatre at St Andrews with Prince William.

The sharpest funding differences in the UK are shown in the unit of funding resource for each full-time equivalent student. Next year, the unit of resource for all expenditure (recurrent and non-recurrent) in cash terms will be £5,360 for each student in England, £5,138 in Wales, and £6,744 in Scotland . Information for Northern Ireland was not available at the time of writing.

The unit will rise by slightly over 5% in England and Scotland , but only 3.5% in Wales. Once you have taken inflation at 2.5% into account for next year, the Welsh increase is only a lit tle bit above the rate of inflation.

In terms of the unit of recurrent funding alone, which gives a clearer picture of what is actually being spent on the education of each student, spending next year in Scotland will be around 2% above inflation, spending in England will be 0.4% above inflation, and spending in Wales will be around 0.4% below inflation - a real-terms cut, in other words.

This in itself is a remarkable improvement on the past decade and more, which has seen consistent real-terms cuts in spending for each student in the UK. But why is spending per student more than a quarter higher in Scotland than in England or Wales? Why are the recurrent increases higher for Scotland than for England and Wales?

It is not that Scotland has a proportionately lower number of students. In fact, 46% of young people in Scotland participated in higher education in 1997-98, compared with 32% in England and Wales, and 44% in Northern Ireland.

The answer lies in post-devolution funding decisions, and in the historical differences in spending baselines in each country, which may have been accentuated by the application of the so-called Barnett formula. This formula was introduced in 1978 as a means of linking levels of change in funding in England to funding in Scotland , Wales and Northern Ireland. It is based on population levels. The accuracy of the formula, and the extent to which its application may have benefited non-English parts of the UK - particularly Scotland - is a matter of controversy. But whatever the reason, spending per student in Scotland is way ahead of England and Wales.

What must be galling to students in England and Wales is the fact that, while the amount spent on them lags behind Scottish students, they - like students in Northern Ireland - are having to pay up-front tuition fees for full-time undergraduate courses.

Recent student support measures from David Blunkett's Department for Education and Employment mean that in 2001-2 only half the undergraduates in England and Wales will be liable to pay fees. But that's still 50% more than in Scotland , where fees were abolished from autumn 2000.

The fissures in the UK caused by Scottish students in England, Wales or Northern Ireland having to pay fees, and English, Welsh and North ern Ireland students in Scotland also having to pay fees - unlike EU students - underline the impact of devolution.

Students north of Hadrian's Wall aren't getting away scot-free: they will have to pay a graduate endowment of £2,000 once they are income-earners. But this is about a third less than tuition fees elsewhere in the UK over the three years of a typical first degree. Since it is contingent on income , the Scottish endowment will be easier to pay than the up-front lump-sum tuitionfee. And the burden on Scottish families while they are supporting studentsthrough higher education will be smaller.

And what is more, from 2001-2 non-repayable cost of living bursaries, to a maximum of £2,000 a year, will be available to young students from poor families in Scotland . And about 30,000 mature students entering higher education for the first time will benefit from discretionary bursaries.

It's a matter of attitude, as much as anything. The Scottish Executive, in last year's report Scotland : The Learning Nation, said: "The fear of debt is a possible disincentive to students from lower income families entering higher education. A key objective of our new scheme is therefore to reduce the amount of loan students need to take out over the period of their study."

Because of this, the executive is prepared to find resources from elsewhere to compensate institutions for the loss of tuition fees and fund a limited reintroduction of maintenance grants.

Some vice-chancellors in England have questioned whether the position in Scotland is sustainable. The Scottish Executive estimates that the cost of these changes for HE and FE will be about £50m a year, 2% of the total budget for the Department of Enterprise and Lifelong Learning in 2001-2.

It should be manageable - particularly since the additional cash funding for higher education in Scotland from grant and fees in 2001-2 will be £53m (and £24m in 2002-3 and £27m in 2003-4). In the long run, the cost of the abolition of fees will be offset by the full projected income of £16m a year from the graduate endowment scheme. Since the Scottish participation rate is near the government's 50% target, less extra funding will be needed than in England and Wales.

With devolution, it is likely that levels of public spending will increasingly diverge. A Treasury report notes: "Responsibility for United Kingdom fiscal policy, macroeconomic policy and public expenditure allocation across the United Kingdom will remain with the Treasury. As a result, the devolved administrations' budgets will continue to be determined within the framework of public expenditure control in the United Kingdom. However once overall public expenditure budgets have been determined, the devolved administrations will have freedom to make their own spending decisions on devolved programmes within the overall totals."

While education and employment secretary David Blunkett adopts a policy in England of ameliorating the impact of the introduction of tuition fees and the end of the maintenance grant, views in other parts of the UK are changing. The Welsh Assembly's education and lifelong learning committee is conducting a review of higher education in Wales. The review asks: "How can we ensure that no student is deterred from taking up or completing his/her studies due to financial hardship?" This includes assessing whether students should contribute financially towards tuition. The results of the review will be available in the spring.

Meanwhile the minister for education and lifelong learning in Wales, Jane Davidson, is setting up an independent enquiry into student hardship and funding in Wales, to tackle problems in the current system of student maintenance and support.

The Northern Ireland Assembly's committee for higher and further education, training and employment has proposed a system similar to Scotland 's, with the abolition of up-front tuition fees , graduate contributions to tuition, and means-tested non-repayable cost of living bursaries. Although higher education minister Sean Farren has not gone along with abolishing tuition fees , it may be that the example of Scotland and developments in Wales will create sufficient pressure to make him change his mind. That could just leave England as a bastion of the Blunkett-inspired system of tuition fees and no maintenance grant. But with a general election in the offing, who knows what will happen?

 Stephen Court is senior research officer at the Association of University Teachers

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Nick
fields.trailText: When you get to Bali, beware of the south of the island at night (especially Kuta) as it is full of tourists, and with the vast hoardes come drug touts (often disguised as taxi drivers), prostitutes and pick pockets.
fields.body:
When you get to Bali, beware of the south of the island at night (especially Kuta) as it is full of tourists, and with the vast hoardes come drug touts (often disguised as taxi drivers), prostitutes and pick pockets. When I was there last August, my friends and I were walking down the main street to our hotel in Kuta when a guy on a motorbike tried to snatch my Indonesian friend's bag from her shoulder in broad daylight. We also found that when we wanted peace and quiet on the beach we were constantly pestered by hawkers trying to sell us everything under the sun.

Don't let this advice deter you, though; there are many great things to experience when you are there, as I am sure you will find out for yourself. If there is one last piece of information that I could give you, it is to stay away from the satay turtle, as they are endangered and killed in the most atrocious of ways.

We also found that when we wanted peace and quiet on the beach we were constantly pestered by hawkers trying to sell us everything under the sun. Don't let this advice deter you, though; there are many great things to experience when you are there, as I am sure you will find out for yourself. If there is one last piece of information that I could give you, it is to stay away from the satay turtle, as they are endangered and killed in the most atrocious of ways.

webTitle: In brief: Lottery-funded films flop at box office

fields.headline: Lottery-funded films flop at box office
fields.standfirst: Plus: Hollywood's A-list actresses scrap for role in feline remake; Mike Myers to play Austin Powers one more time
fields.trailText: Plus: Hollywood's A-list actresses scrap for role in feline remake; Mike Myers to play Austin Powers one more time
fields.body:
 You wouldn't want to place a bet on any Lottery-funded films breaking even, let alone making any money. Only one out of the fourteen films funded by the Lottery has ever made a profit according to Heat magazine. 1999's film adaptation of Oscar Wilde's An Ideal Husband (pictured), which starred Rupert Everett and Minnie Driver, managed (but only just) to make it into the black, while all the others came in at a loss.

 Gwyneth Paltrow, Heather Graham and Renee Zellweger are apparently battling it out to star in the Hollywood remake of the 1996 French comedy, When The Cat's Away, in which Garance Clavel played a lonely bachelor girl whose life is transformed when her cat runs away. Although Heather Graham was originally penned in to star in the £30m remake which will be set in New York, both Paltrow and Zellweger have now declared an interest. An insider told ananova, "Heather thought she had this wrapped up if Miramax got the deal but they are also very close to Gwyneth and see Renee as possibly the best female comedy star around."

 Hollywood rumours suggest that Mike Myers will reprise his role as Austin Powers for one last time. Myers is apparently in talks to star in a prequel to the two previous Austin Powers films and is keen to get veteran Avengers actors Patrick Macnee and Honor Blackman to play his parents.

fields.headline: Q&A on D&T
fields.standfirst: Questions answered on spreadsheets, scant resources and database use
fields.trailText: Questions answered on spreadsheets, scant resources and database use.
fields.body:
What opportunities are there for using ICT in D&T?
ICT can be used effectively at all stages of the design and make process and in all four focus areas. In electronics, for example, software can help create a more accurate printed circuit board, while in food technology a nutritional database enables more effective modelling of a new food product. Computer Aided Design (CAD) software used with equipment for Computer Aided Manufacture (CAM) enables students to achieve high quality products in both resistant materials and textiles.

Can I use my school's generic software in D&T?
Using spreadsheets enables students to model the cost of producing individual products and larger batches. The wide variety of graphing tools provide a means of accurately presenting the results of surveys and questionnaires undertaken as part of research, and radar graphs are particularly effective in creating product profiles. In addition, spreadsheets are a useful project management tool, used to create GANNT charts and other, more detailed time plans. PowerPoint and word-processing software greatly enhance the look and feel of project work, particularly when digital images of made items are incorporated into portfolios.

I only have access to one computer in my room, how do I use it effectively?
This is a common classroom management issue that needs careful organisation. It is important that the computer is used all the time, so it may be best to set a focused task, related to the main design and encourage an activity that all students need to complete. Many computers have an outlet for a large screen monitor that will support whole class teaching, enabling opportunities for demonstration. It may also be helpful to book a network room for very focused teaching and then encourage students to practice new skills in the D&T lessons.

Where can I find out more?
Look on the Design and Technology Association's websites, including three specific sites to support Cad/Cam, electronics and food technology. The Virtual Teachers Centre also has useful information on using ICT in D&T, together with a database of work that other teachers have shared.

fields.headline: A portable future
fields.standfirst: In the portable versus computer room debate, John Davitt says small is beautiful
fields.trailText: In the portable versus computer room debate, John Davitt says small is beautiful.
fields.body:
Computer rooms are on the way out. If you are about to build one out of an existing classroom or a reformatted toilet or cloakroom, don't worry: it may well be right for your school at this stage. But make no mistake that in five years' time, we'll consider it strange. Because then we will not be taking the student to the computer but fitting computers to the classroom.

Just what is a computer anyway? Portable technology like the Lego brick is actually a powerful programmable computer; mobile phones will soon be smarter than many desktop PCs in terms of processing power; and the latest Apple iBook doubles as a video-editing suite when you plug in a camera yet it's as mobile as a large handbag.

It looks sensible to plan for a future which is portable but also needs to be collaborative and mediated, bringing ICT to all classrooms and putting these tools into teachers' hands.

There are several strands to the successful classroom integration of ICT, some technological, some philosophical. Schools should start to plan now for ICT that is accessible throughout the school, not just in a single room. The options include ordinary networks or wireless connections.

Cornwallis school, Maidstone, now has a wireless network for over 100 Acer laptops. The Isle of Man recently invested in 600 wireless AirPort cards fitted to Apple laptops for teachers, which allows teachers to move through the class and still access the internet or the classroom printer.

"Ninety-five per cent of primary schools have laptops wirelessly connected to school networks," says John Thornley, an Isle of Man ICT adviser. "The benefit is sheer convenience. In a history lesson a teacher can walk around class, call up work from the school server, review it with a child, and move on to the next pupil."

A key part of the island's ICT strategy over the past five years has been to put portable computers into the hands of the teachers and the success of this shows the power of computers as a teacher's resource.

To make the biggest difference the message is clear: send a computer to the front of every class, preferably with a large screen display or a data projector and pop a portable into every teacher's satchel.

Once teachers can teach, using the power of ICT from the front of the classroom, everything changes. Maybe it's not just "hands on" but "eyes up" as the teacher takes the whole class through effective use of new software. Students have learned nuclear physics without direct experiment, but where ICT is concerned we seem to think it requires hands on at all times and it shouldn't.''

Research also suggests ICT is used best when children work in pairs rather than alone at a computer. It's probably also better to use a computer when they need to rather than because it's 2pm on a Thursday for their lesson in the computer room.

"We are now trialling the wireless system with pupils," says John Thornley. "When you march them off to the computer room there is discontinuity; this way the ICT comes to the child."

As more children have computers at home, the more perplexed they will be at a special lesson in their honour. For those without a home PC it may well be better if it's part of the classroom rather than a bi-weekly orchestrated event. Some schools will fit clusters of computers in corridor cloakrooms, some will run a large distributed network around school and others will buy class sets of cut-down laptops like the AlphaSmart (TAG) which let students write, edit and print using infrared connections on a small portable device costing less than £190.

As computers spread through school, a thematic approach will emerge with machines grouped according to curricular purpose and integrated according to school design. Two machines for control work in the technology room, three machines (portable or otherwise) with midi keyboards in a music area will become the order of the day.

Schools should stand up for the right to be flexible in the integration of ICT in the classroom. It's worth noting that the most innovative practice comes from those for whom the strictures of the national curriculum are optional.

From here on in, start centralised but plan localised.

It's not an argument of laptops versus computers rooms but a case of integration versus isolation. For each school planning its path, it is important that it is guided primarily by how it wants to use ICT as a learning tool rather than building a room just to jump through an Ofstedian hoop.

At the BETT show and beyond

TAG (stand F50): Alphasmart word processor

Compaq (stand G40): robust notebooks like the Armada

Acer (stand E22): whole school groups with wireless laptop networking

LEGO (stand E66): Computer in a small yellow brick

Apple (stand E34): AirPort wireless networking for all Apple computers

webTitle: D&T first-hand: Products of our time

fields.headline: Products of our time
fields.standfirst: Paul Johansson is head of technology at Featherstone high school in West Yorkshire
fields.trailText: Paul Johansson is head of technology at Featherstone high school in West Yorkshire.
fields.body:
My basic philosophy is to create what we call ICT-rich design and technology. We don't have a discrete ICT course at key stage three, so we tend to use it as a problem-solving tool and deliver it through the curriculum.

In year eight, for instance, all the pupils do a project to make a clip-together toy, which they design on CAD software then machine out of a flat piece of Perspex.

In year nine the children make their own board game, using the computer to generate designs for the board and playing cards, and for the packaging for the outside.

It's all about using a computer as a means of production, about enabling pupils to do fancy or intricate work they couldn't otherwise do. Using ICT concentrates on their thinking skills rather than hand skills. Modelling in 3D, for instance, is interesting and enjoyable and you can create lots of fantastic images, but turning them into an actual product you can make on the machine is a different matter. It's quite a high-level activity, and the machine is capable of producing high-quality junk if you let it. It won't make judgments as to whether something is good, bad or indifferent.

That said, we don't always use the computer. In year seven, for instance, we do a basic timber-processing project to help the pupils gain some more traditional skills. It's important to get the balance right so it's not just about pushing buttons. Also, as a teacher, you've got to be careful how you plan the computer side, otherwise you end up with a backlog of projects waiting to be milled and lots of children sitting around doing nothing.

fields.headline: Charting new territory
fields.standfirst: Finding your way to the best internet sites can be bewildering. Nick Austin from Teachers Evaluating Educational Multimedia maps out a pathway
fields.trailText: Finding your way to the best internet sites can be bewildering. Nick Austin from Teachers Evaluating Educational Multimedia maps out a pathway
fields.body:
Your school has just completed its New Opportunities Fund training, your online PC is wired up in the corner of the classroom and you have a nagging feeling that you should be putting your new skills and hardware into action. You've no money for buying software and, quite frankly, Access looks a bit complex for year one then you think "Internet!"

You've heard there is a reservoir of resources "out there", wherever that is. All you have to do is log on, run a quick search and turn up dozens of valuable websites.

Barely able to contain your excitement, you visit www.google.com, a speedy and reliable search engine, and type in "literacy". In just 0.1 of a second your screen is full of website addresses - 1,480,000 of them - which just might stretch you during your one non-contact half hour of the week.

How do teachers source and use websites effectively? Finding reliable titles is a problem: there are too many and, unlike print publications, you can't flick through in a few minutes to get a feel for them. You can pick them up from colleagues, professional associations, educational journals, newspapers such as the Guardian, and the Teem (Teachers Evaluating Educational Multimedia) website, which contains evaluations and case studies of websites written and researched by teachers.

If you're new to the net, what should you be looking for and how do you spot worthwhile resources for your children? You have already adopted a range of critical skills when you research and buy other resources for school: now it's time to develop them for working on the internet.

This brief guide might be a useful tick list to use when you are looking at a new site:

 Who published it? The internet is ruthlessly democratic in the presentation of information, with no perceived hierarchy. Is the site produced by a reputable organisation, or by an amateur hobbyist or by an organisation pursuing its own agenda?

 Is it up-to-date? A website offering information on political history might be of limited value if it hasn't been updated for a couple of years, whereas an art website with free painting downloads isn't so time-sensitive.

 How quickly does it download? Once accessed, it might contain fantastic resources, but have you got time to watch a fancy moving icon on screen as the class grows increasingly restless? Sharp, well-defined images are wonderful but not if they slow down the lesson.

 Is it really an educational site with classroom relevance or does it contain wonderful ideas that aren't relevant to the national curriculum?

 Will your children be able to navigate the site with ease? Some icon buttons might not be clear to users or they might not always appear on the screen as the child scrolls up and down.

Watch out for these features, too:

Do you need downloadable plug-ins to make the site work? Is the site linked to other sites? This can be a strength and a weakness: you might discover yet more information but your children might wander off into uncharted territory of unsuitable material. What's the reading level? Is it consistent with the content? Is there evidence of bias? There may be some tempting PSHE and RE sites to visit, but who has written them - and why?

This looks like a formidable list to work through but, after a while, you'll automatically check for them.

But what of that search for literacy materials? Is it possible to reduce our options from nearly 1.5m matches to something more manageable? A search using "KS1 literacy hour resources" yielded 381 matches, which if they were books on a library shelf would still represent rather too many to read in one sitting. But by reading the short descriptions under each address you quickly recognise the ones which may be of value to you.

Try out a few likely looking sites and, if you like them, add them to your favourites. Now try them out against the checklists above and find ways of integrating them into your teaching.

Teem helps by providing evaluations and case studies of websites written by Teem-trained teachers. They work to a framework which enables all aspects of the site to be written about in the evaluation; the case study tells of the classroom context in which the site was used.

 For more information on Teem, visit www.teem.org.uk, email info@teem.org.uk, or call (01223) 505207. Teem is at Bett 2001, stand L4.

fields.headline: CD-Roms
fields.trailText: The best CD-Roms for DT teaching on the market.
fields.body:
Pro/DESKTOP (PTC, free from DATA)

Enables students to start work in 2D to capture ideas rapidly and explore design possibilities while, simultaneously, the 3D design is automatically captured in the background. Dynamic drag handles promote rapid 3D-model experimentation and make it easy to interact with your models. You can resize the parameters of any feature of the solid model by grabbing its handle and instantly see the results, and perform kinematic studies in 3D to further investigate clearances, interferences, and range of motion.

PIC-Logicator (Economatics, £125 + vat)

Allows pupils to create control systems with flowcharts by dragging commands onto the screen and drawing routes between them. Offers a full range of control operations including switching outputs, sequences, timing, counting, using feedback from digital and analogue sensors, subsystems, along with logical and mathematical functions.

Flowol (Data Harvest, £69 + vat)

Offers easy access to control programming, using sequences for instructions for a variety of activities in which you can operate flashing lights, control a fairground ride, run a sequence of sub-routines to drive a robot arm, use feedback from a switch to run a pelican crossing, and use a number of switches and sub-routines to run an automatic level-crossing or car park barrier. The software includes a comprehensive tutorial which explains the symbols and how to create flowcharts, progressing from a simple sequence to more complex programs.

Packaging Designer (D&T Online, £15)

Contains all the packaging information pages from the D&T Online site, and all the packaging net designs, and so is useful for those departments without internet access. It will work with a Java-enabled web browser on any computer platform. Allows easy modification of dimensions, and calculates the volume of the completed package and the surface area of the material.

2D Design (Techsoft, £195)

Most drawing/design packages tend to fall into one of two camps, either traditional draughting (mechanical, architectural drawing, etc), or graphic design (illustrations, advertisements, etc).2D Design takes the best of both approaches to create a versatile, easy-to-use package which combines technical draughting, graphic design and Cad/Cam. It is suitable for all ages.

ArtCAM (Delcam, free from DATA)

ArtCAM Pro allows users to easily create impressive, high quality 3D products starting from 2D bitmap or vector-based artwork, transforming ideas into finished products far more quickly than is possible using conventional methods. Provides a more artistic approach to the design of 3D models and is ideally suited to cross-curricular applications, eg designing moulds in art, manufacturing them in D&T, and measuring volumes in maths.

Control Insight/Junior Control Insight (Logotron, £79 + VAT)

Builds on a "systems" approach to electronics, allowing children to build control systems diagrammatically by linking together graphical objects, which are assigned the properties of input sensors, insight modules and output devices. The design can then be tested as a simulation on the screen without the need for peripheral hardware. It can then be built as a physical model, connected to the computer via an interface and controlled by the computer program. Comes with 12 sample projects, including dream bedroom, inventor's workshop, kitchen gadgets, funfair, car park and the haunted house. These allow children to find out what is happening in the model, and then to make changes to make it run better.

Allows easy modification of dimensions, and calculates the volume of the completed package and the surface area of the material. 2D Design (Techsoft, £195) Most drawing/design packages tend to fall into one of two camps, either traditional draughting (mechanical, architectural drawing, etc), or graphic design (illustrations, advertisements, etc).2D Design takes the best of both approaches to create a versatile, easy-to-use package which combines technical draughting, graphic design and Cad/Cam. It is suitable for all ages. ArtCAM (Delcam, free from DATA) ArtCAM Pro allows users to easily create impressive, high quality 3D products starting from 2D bitmap or vector-based artwork, transforming ideas into finished products far more quickly than is possible using conventional methods. Provides a more artistic approach to the design of 3D models and is ideally suited to cross-curricular applications, eg designing moulds in art, manufacturing them in D&T, and measuring volumes in maths. Control Insight/Junior Control Insight (Logotron, £79 + VAT) Builds on a "systems" approach to electronics, allowing children to build control systems diagrammatically by linking together graphical objects, which are assigned the properties of input sensors, insight modules and output devices. The design can then be tested as a simulation on the screen without the need for peripheral hardware. It can then be built as a physical model, connected to the computer via an interface and controlled by the computer program. Comes with 12 sample projects, including dream bedroom, inventor's workshop, kitchen gadgets, funfair, car park and the haunted house. These allow children to find out what is happening in the model, and then to make changes to make it run better.

fields.headline: Focusing on 3D
fields.standfirst: Paul Gell is head of design technology at Horbury school in Wakefield, which has 1,100 pupils
fields.trailText: Paul Gell is head of design technology at Horbury school in Wakefield, which has 1,100 pupils.
fields.body:
As a pilot school for the DfEE/Data Cad in Schools project we're quite well equipped compared with two years ago. We now have 10 laptops and a Denford milling machine, as well as video conferencing facilities and six dedicated PCs for the workshop.

Naturally, Cad is a big part of what we do. Years seven and eight use Techsoft's 2D Design software as an introduction on how to use a CAD system, and we set year eight some traditional woodwork tasks to make bookends, first drawing them on the computer then programming our milling machine to actually cut out the product.

We also have a sticker machine, where you can draw an idea on the computer, press a button and have it cut out for you, which we use in year seven to introduce them to the principles of Cad.

We tend to use Prodesktop as a Cad/Cam trainer for year nine onwards, starting with tutorials that show them how to use the software and draw in three dimensions, and then how to machine their results. Years nine and 10 have used this process to design mobile phones, drawing them in scale on Prodesktop, then getting the machine to cut them out in foam or wax. The emphasis is on manufacturing with a practical outcome.

We've seen real benefits from our approach, including a higher success rate at GCSE. Cad helps the children produce prototypes and focus on the design process, as well as giving them the benefit of speed of production. It enthuses kids to actually produce things - our various dinner clubs are very popular - and very quickly gives them confidence in idea production. We don't want them hung up on technical drawing; we're trying to get them to understand this is now industrial work.

webTitle: Design and technology focus: Your vote does count

fields.headline: Your vote does count
fields.standfirst: Emily Moore on an initiative to get children interested in the next general election
fields.trailText: Emily Moore on an initiative to get children interested in the next general election.
fields.body:
The general election is on the horizon - but how relevant is it to youngsters not old enough to vote and unable even to utter the word politics without yawning? With citizenship entering the national curriculum, holding a Y Vote mock election is one way for students at all key stages to get their teeth into this election.

Y Vote is the student mock election run by the Hansard Society (the educational charity set up to promote parliamentary democracy) and BBC Newsround. In 1997, over 3,500 schools got involved. This time around, Y Vote is being supported by learn.co.uk - the Guardian's educational resources website which is creating a comprehensive Y Vote website.

"A lot of schools have been saying they want a high profile activity that introduces pupils to the key aspects of citizenship," says Raji Hunjan, Hansard's education coordinator. "The Y Vote mock election really does the job. It's from February 2001, the plan is to bring school mock elections alive with inspiring online lessons (linked to the national curriculum), two online debates, background resources from the Guardian Education archive - including a graphic of the Guardian Guide to Parliament - and interviews with people involved in the real election - from politicians to canvassers to spin doctors."

Recent research from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation suggests that young people may be bored with politics - but at the same time, even the least interested have political concerns, whether they realise it or not. Many have taken part in activities such as signing petitions or attending demonstrations to support local campaigns. It's this interest that Y Vote aims to capture.

The first online debate will be on fox hunting. "That's just the subject to get the kids going in my school," says Mike Firth, who teaches history at Alderman Blaxhill school in Colchester. "We have kids from rural areas and from the town, from public and private housing and a large percentage from army families. There will be strong opinions on both sides and I'll be encouraging my students to get involved."

The internet is a valuable tool to find out more about politics. But surfing the web costs money and can be time-consuming. Learn.co.uk/yvote will include an extensive weblinks section with every address you'll need - from political parties to pressure groups. "It's going to be a great resource to have all the top political sites at your finger tips," says Firth.

Through the Y Vote website, young people will not only be able to view party websites - politicians watch out - but create their own! Learn.co.uk/yvote is running a competition for the best Y Vote mock election party website design. Winners in all three categories will receive a web design studio from Macromedia (each worth £800), and 15 runners-up will be able to choose from the following software - Macromedia Flash 5, Dreamweaver, Fireworks or FreeHand.

 For more details, go to www.learn.co.uk/yvote where you can also register for the mock election with Hansard. Registration costs £15 and includes the invaluable Hansard Y Vote Teacher Pack - providing you with the templates and resources (from ballot papers to Y Vote stickers) to run a successful mock election.

fields.headline: A piece of cake
fields.standfirst: Computer-aided design has revolutionised teaching, with a huge impact on subjects such as design and food technology
fields.trailText: Computer-aided design has revolutionised teaching, with a huge impact on subjects such as design and food technology.
fields.body:
Of all subjects on the curriculum, design and technology has arguably been the most affected by ICT. Gone are the days when boys would whittle away bookends in the woodwork room while the girls learned to whip up a Victoria sponge in home economics; with the help of advanced technologies, today's schoolchildren are learning life skills that will stand them in good stead in the workplace as well as the home.

"ICT has opened a whole new board game in schools generally," says Richard Hammond, education officer at Becta, "but within design and technology there are just so many different applications for computers."

Product design and manufacture is perhaps proving the most fertile area, particularly since the arrival of Cad/Cam technology (computer-aided design/computer-aided manufacture) in the classroom. Through the auspices of the Design and Technology Association (Data) and its DfEE-funded Cad in Schools project, more than 2,000 schools have the sophisticated Prodesktop drawing package, allowing children to design products in three dimensions.

"This product, in particular, has revolutionised secondary-level design and technology," says Hammond. "Prodesktop is a professional tool and the work children produce using it is of outstanding quality, especially when coupled with access to a computerised milling machine. Where in the past they would be churning out little clocks or CD racks or lamps which looked very much like they had been made in school, now they are producing things you could actually sell in a shop."

The beauty of Cad is its versatility. Within textiles, for instance, the software allows pupils to compose a design on the computer, then have it immediately embroidered by a sewing machine. And Cad provides access for all abilities. "Even children who can't draw can go on a computer and knock out a professional design and produce excellent results," says Hammond.

Beyond design, ICT can enliven more mundane, logistical activities. A typical key stage three activity, such as developing a system to control a car park, comes alive with software that incorporates the elements of barrier control and car counting into a virtual reality model, allowing pupils to see the results of their decisions. "Indeed, with some of the more sophisticated packages, you can actually build a model of a car park and the software will then control it," says Hammond.

Another growing area for ICT is in food technology. A nutritional database, for instance, enables children to get more accurate analysis and results more quickly, explains Jenny Jupe, deputy chief executive at Data. "Before we had computers, kids had to use nutritional tables, a bit like logarithms, which were subject to inaccuracies and very time-consuming to use. With a nutritional database they can perform 'what-if' activities, such as substituting different ingredients to reduce the sugar content and see what effect that has on calories or nutrients in a product. And when they're developing products it helps them produce labelling information for the packet, such as the nutritional value per portion and serving."

As well as using a digital camera to keep a record of the food they produce, children can also use spreadsheets to log data on factors such as temperature during cooking or freezing, or to model food costings or sensory analysis. "They can analyse different areas, such as a product's taste, texture, mouth feel and so on," says Jupe, "then judge their product against those criteria and record their results using a spreadsheet. It helps them to develop different products and then to test them to see how they match up to their original spec."

At the cutting edge of food technology, virtual reality gives children experience of industrial production and processes.

The advent of stricter health and safety regulations has made it very difficult to take children around companies and factories, according to Hammond. "But they still need to know about all the systems involved in food production.

"As a result several companies have now produced packages that give you a virtual tour of a production line and control of the whole system and that actually carry out various safety checks."

Indeed, one of the main thrusts of ICT in design and technology is to reflect the realities of the workplace, he says. "We're trying to get rid of this outdated image of oily rags in engineering and a pinny in food technology. Even in textiles everything is now controlled by ICT. We're trying to reflect this in teaching, by showing children what happens in the real world."

Despite the inroads that ICT has made into the workshop and classroom at the school, Hammond insists that children have plenty of opportunity to get their hands dirty.

"ICT is a very important part of the national curriculum, but there is still a lot of work that is not ICT-based. Children still have to use traditional skills to try things out, such as making a cake as a sample before going into batch production, and so they're still getting access to a lot of hands-on experience."

fields.headline: Websites
fields.trailText: Emma Haughton rounds up the best DT sites on the net.
fields.body:
Design and Technology Association (DATA)

Publications, resources, information on the association's CAD/CAM initiative, and a chance to join Validate, an informal network of educators interested in the values of D&T education. You'll also find details on training and professional development, and a useful primary section with dedicated projects and resources.

The Nuffield Foundation

The Nuffield primary design and technology project is currently developing materials for red-hot D&T teaching. Check up on its progress, look at other schools' work, or download sample classroom materials.

Cad in Schools

A visually ambitious site introducing the DfEE-sponsored Cad in Schools initiative, which aims to ensure all UK secondary schools have access to CAD/CAM facilities, and offers free copies of PTC's Prodesktop software. Includes a showcase showing off pupils' achievements.

D&T Online

A highly practical resource offering free materials, information and software on electronics, packaging, environments, food, pneumatics, mechanisms, and manufacturing projects. Largely targets key stage three and four, but also suitable for key stage two.

Food Technology

A comprehensive examination of all aspects of food technology for key stage four students and teachers, including food science, processes, business, and ICT in product development and manufacturing. Offers online analytical tools, direct links with industry professionals and case studies supported by video clips.

Technology Insight

Everything you ever wanted to know about design and technology in an industrial context, including virtual visits to production lines, ideas for teachers, advice for students on how to improve their work, and other resources and links.

J Sainsburys Plc

Details on how to enter the Sainsburys Food Awards Scheme for schools, as well as lots of information for those studying food technology. Includes product development case studies and a teachers' guide.

Denford Limited

This world leader in computerised milling machines and software offers details on using videoconferencing to help students grasp various aspects of information and design technology, plus an education section with projects and course materials.

Textiles Online

A thoughtful site that introduces pupils to textile production processes and their impact on the environment. The useful teachers' notes section has online activities, and you can also download documents with ideas on how to use the site in lessons.

British Nutrition Foundation

Food technology activities across all the key stages, as well as nutritional facts and information. You can also access details of the BNF's awards for GCSE and A-level students.

fields.headline: Creating a fairground
fields.standfirst: Carolyn Bryan is technology coordinator at Springdale junior school in Wolverhampton, which has 277 pupils
fields.trailText: Carolyn Bryan is technology coordinator at Springdale junior school in Wolverhampton, which has 277 pupils.
fields.body:
Springdale has a computer room with 12 networked computers and two internet-linked computers. It also has a stand-alone computer in each classroom, so there's considerable opportunity to use ICT in design and technology.

Indeed, we've done a number of projects over the last few years. One of the main ones involved work on the subject of fairgrounds.

I made a CD-Rom detailing some rides and posing questions which the children used to find out more about how fairground rides work and to produce leaflets advertising the rides. They also designed and made models of their own rides, using pulleys and motors, which they could then link to a control box to make the rides go backwards and forwards. Some children decorated their rides with clip art produced on the computer to give the ride a quality finish.

We've also just completed a project on the gazebo and pergola which the parents are building in the playground, including a competition for the children to come up with a design. Year five used a spreadsheet to map out the costs of the bricks, cement and other materials. It was a useful exercise because it used a real-life project that was relevant to the children.

We have tried to introduce ICT into food technology projects, too. When year three were studying sandwich snacks, they developed a questionnaire to find out people's preferences before designing their own snacks. The children put the results of their survey in to a database, and used it to create graphs and other ways of analysing their results. That's the beauty of ICT. It helps you link lots of elements in a project together, while making some of the tasks a lot easier.

webTitle: Revision: No need to panic - yet

fields.headline: No need to panic - yet
fields.standfirst: With GSCEs looming, students will be turning to revision software in droves. Here Nick Austin selects some of the better packages around
fields.trailText: With GSCEs looming, students will be turning to revision software in droves. Here Nick Austin selects some of the better packages around.
fields.body:
In schools around the country, the corridors are resounding to the clink of small currency falling to the floor. It's the sound of the penny dropping, as year 11 students realise that mocks are upon them and unless something radical happens between now and the summer - such as the earth spinning off its axis - GCSEs will be sat. Now it's for real; the exams that seemed so far away at the beginning of September are hurtling into view with alarming speed.

But help is at hand - not only from revision clubs, extra lessons and closely focused exam-orientated teaching, but from a plethora of software and websites. There's just one health warning: no matter how good the software, students will only benefit if they do some serious learning themselves.

If you need more than just revision materials, Europress's range of software leads the student through the entire course besides offering revision activities. Don't go here for last-minute power-cramming; even at this relatively late stage of year 11, subject-specific packages are worth working through methodically. Europress offers many strong features such as clear, explanatory animation (useful for describing scientific processes), audio, a word processor for taking notes, a calculator and a formula sheet.

For the assiduous student who thrives on structure, the Oxford Personal Revision Guide series (from the Learning Company) offers a high level of support. Students are given self-assessments, from which they can access information and support at the most suitable level. A succession of short, achievable units are introduced and tested, with outcomes recorded. But both the Oxford and Europress packages need time and effort.

The Aircom range covers 13 GCSE subjects presented in a friendly environment for students to work in - the English program is set in Rowan Crescent, with activities based on the people and events there. The pace is leisurely but the content is detailed and has teeth, and is completed by good graphics, real interactivity and well-grounded advice. Carefully structured programs allow students to dip in to the sections they need; they do not have to work sequentially through each topic.

Letts Revise for GCSE series (GSP) has a range of revision aids, such as mock exam papers (which teachers can use for whole-class teaching), detailed comments from examiners and focused help when questions are answered incorrectly. Advice always refers the user back to the question and points to the correct evidence to use in framing answers. Many teachers might find this a useful range, too, given the resources it contains.

In comparison, Revise Now 2000, a single disk covering science, geography and business studies, suffers by trying to cover too much ground in too little detail. If multiple-choice questions are what you want, try it - but don't expect too much explanation if you answer incorrectly.

The BBC's Bite Sized series uses all the tricks of multimedia. Interestingly, three products being launched this spring will be stripped down for closer targeting and more content.

On the web

The web offers free materials but beware of sites that are publishers' marketing vehicles. The BBC site has proved extremely popular in the run-up to mocks and will no doubt be very popular this spring and summer.

What makes it good? According to one avid user, it's its range - a one-stop shop for every subject. But take care - with so much on offer it's easy to flit from subject to subject. Try short, intensive sessions with this site: locate your subject, find the topic, look at the activities and do them offline. One student liked the way he could click rather than write his way through the activities - worth noting, given the amount of note-taking students do at home.

But does ICT suit everyone's learning style? There is evidence that some children are happy to load up or log on and work for a couple of hours at a time, which is something they have found difficult with books and hand-written notes. But like any resource, CD-roms and websites are only part of the solution. So treat them as part of a package of revision and consolidation.

 Nick Austin is an educational consultant and freelance journalist.
