For the assiduous student who thrives on structure, the Oxford Personal Revision Guide series (from the Learning Company) offers a high level of support. Students are given self-assessments, from which they can access information and support at the most suitable level. A succession of short, achievable units are introduced and tested, with outcomes recorded. But both the Oxford and Europress packages need time and effort. The Aircom range covers 13 GCSE subjects presented in a friendly environment for students to work in - the English program is set in Rowan Crescent, with activities based on the people and events there. The pace is leisurely but the content is detailed and has teeth, and is completed by good graphics, real interactivity and well-grounded advice. Carefully structured programs allow students to dip in to the sections they need; they do not have to work sequentially through each topic. Letts Revise for GCSE series (GSP) has a range of revision aids, such as mock exam papers (which teachers can use for whole-class teaching), detailed comments from examiners and focused help when questions are answered incorrectly. Advice always refers the user back to the question and points to the correct evidence to use in framing answers. Many teachers might find this a useful range, too, given the resources it contains. In comparison, Revise Now 2000, a single disk covering science, geography and business studies, suffers by trying to cover too much ground in too little detail. If multiple-choice questions are what you want, try it - but don't expect too much explanation if you answer incorrectly. The BBC's Bite Sized series uses all the tricks of multimedia. Interestingly, three products being launched this spring will be stripped down for closer targeting and more content. On the web The web offers free materials but beware of sites that are publishers' marketing vehicles. The BBC site has proved extremely popular in the run-up to mocks and will no doubt be very popular this spring and summer. What makes it good? According to one avid user, it's its range - a one-stop shop for every subject. But take care - with so much on offer it's easy to flit from subject to subject. Try short, intensive sessions with this site: locate your subject, find the topic, look at the activities and do them offline. One student liked the way he could click rather than write his way through the activities - worth noting, given the amount of note-taking students do at home. But does ICT suit everyone's learning style? There is evidence that some children are happy to load up or log on and work for a couple of hours at a time, which is something they have found difficult with books and hand-written notes. But like any resource, CD-roms and websites are only part of the solution. So treat them as part of a package of revision and consolidation.  Nick Austin is an educational consultant and freelance journalist.

fields.headline: Faster, easier, closer
fields.standfirst: Broadband's high-speed networks could turn teaching on its head, says George Cole
fields.trailText: Broadband's high-speed networks could turn teaching on its head, says George Cole.
fields.body:
There are two distinct periods in ICT: before and after broadband. This new lightning-fast means of sending information across computer networks will transform teaching and learning at home and in school, change the way we use the internet, bring new and better online services, and alter the way educational broadcasters and software companies deliver content.

Broadband offers high-speed data connections on a network. Most UK schools use narrowband, which is rather like passing water through a straw; with broadband, think of high-power hosepipes. It is seen by many as the next big step for the National Grid for Learning.

For schools, broadband will enhance communication and collaboration. "Broadband will bring symmetry. Instead of people just pulling content from the internet, they will publish content and contribute," says Professor Stephen Heppell, director of the ICT research centre, Ultralab, at Anglia Polytechnic University.

Collaboration between schools will also include videoconferencing. The technology is not new, but until the arrival of broadband, videoconferencing has been a disappointing experience with small, jerky pictures on a PC screen.

Broadband technology also promises huge potential for broadcasters and software publishers. Some, like RM, Microsoft, Granada Learning, and the BBC are either developing special content for broadband networks or have introduced software licensing systems that allow them to deliver their educational materials over high-speed networks.

The BBC has been delivering a pilot digital curriculum to 50 primary schools across four local education authorities, and has developed materials for key stage three geography students.

"Broadband lets us deliver video as well as the usual web content such as audio, text and graphics, and that's exciting," says Hendrik Ball, the BBC's development executive, new media. "The challenge for us is to move from a system of one-way communication with viewers to a two-way system."

At present, most schools using broadband are part of major projects or initiatives. The cable and communications company - ntl - has developed the idea of a "community internet," which uses broadband to link homes, schools and the wider community. One idea is for a virtual classroom that brings parents and teachers together. The company says resources could be delivered to the home via a PC or TV. A trial community internet service will be used by 12 schools in Swindon, along with a library and 1,000 homes.

"If you can extend learning into the home, we can bring back people who have been excluded for a variety of reasons," says Richard Grazier, ntl's education sector business manager.

The Department for Education has provided £37m of match funding to create eight regional broadband consortia, including the East Midlands Broadband Consortium, whose £24m broadband network, developed by a consortium led by ICL, covers 2,000 primary and secondary schools, plus libraries and community centres. The Yorkshire and Humberside Community for Learning has 350 schools inside its network, created by a group including BT, Granada Learning and Espresso.

Some city councils and local authorities have also created their own broadband networks. Telford and Wrekin Council, with help from ICL, is developing a £12.5m network that will cover 85 primary and secondary schools.

Graham Foster, head of learning resources at Telford and Wrekin, says the aim of the network is to connect schools, libraries, community centres and eventually, health centres and GPs.

Rotherham Metropolitan Borough Council has created 17 City Learning Centres based at 17 secondary schools, each equipped with a 100-megabit connection. The network is being developed by RM and Telewest. Rachel Mullins, a centre manager, says the network may also be used to provide online mentoring for newly qualified teachers.

But there are problems. Adrian Carey, educational director at Edex-CWC is critical of the regional consortia set-up: "It's a patchwork quilt, and there is no strategy for connecting the consortia to create a national network. I'm sure some duplication is going on."

But for broadband schools, the benefits have been tremendous. Jenny Noel-Storr is headteacher of Redhill primary school, Telford, which has three computers with broadband connections. "It's no longer frustrating to use the internet," she says. "I wouldn't want to go back to the old type of connection."

The children use electronic whiteboards to display material from the web, and to create presentations which are published on the internet.

Brinsworth school in Rotherham has 20 PCs with broadband connections in its library, and the computers are booked 90% of the time each week, says assistant head Malcolm Clay. "We've had to put on two shifts for the lunchtime computer club, such has been the demand."

But funding is a big issue. Most schools in these projects are having costs heavily subsidised. "How are schools going to pay for broadband when the funding runs out?" asks Tim Clark, RM's internet business manager. "We estimate a broadband service could cost schools around £10,000 a year - excluding any digital content."

There is at least one potential solution. Steve Molyneaux, Microsoft Professor of learning technologies at Wolverhampton University, and a driving force behind the Telford network, believes that by using the network for e-local government, costs can be cut and used to subsidise education. The DfEE has appointed NH Rothschild to map out the next step for the national grid, including a broadband policy. The ball lies in its court.

What schools use

 Telephone modems: operate at speeds of up to 56,000 bits of data per second, slow and poor for receiving multimedia content.

 ISDN-2: a digital telephone system that offers data speeds of up to 128,000bps (not broadband). BT's Schools Internet Caller service, launched in 1998, offers schools an ISDN link for a flat fee of around £600 a year, with some restrictions. SIC is used by 23,000 schools.

 ADSL: a digital telephone system offering faster speeds (between 512,000 bps and 2Mbps downstream, and around 256,000 bits upstream). Being rolled out across the UK (BT says 70% of the country will be able to receive ADSL by the end of 2001), costs vary from £40 a month for home users to £500 a quarter for businesses. Not suitable for videoconferencing or school networks with more than 10 PCs.

 Low broadband: the DfEE says all broadband systems should offer a two-megabit connection (seen by many as the bare minimum). BT's Learning Stream, launched last May, offers a two-way 2Mb connection. Prices vary.

 High broadband: these networks typically offer around 100Mb links. (NB this speed does not refer to direct internet connections. Most of these networks have hosting systems that store web content on local servers for fast access.)

 Cable: companies such as ntl and Telewest offer high-speed internet connections over cable TV networks into the home or school at speeds of around 512,000 bits and half this speed out again. Home users pay a flat fee of around £30 a month.

 Satellite: Espresso offers a one-way high-speed service via an Astra satellite. Schools need a small dish and Espresso box (cost £1,500) and receive weekly updates of multimedia material linked to the national curriculum. The service costs £4.50 per pupil per year, and Espresso is launching a secondary school service this year.

 Wireless: a possible solution for schools in rural areas. Last November, the Department of Trade and Industry awarded licences for broadband fixed wireless access services to companies such as Energis and Norweb Telecom. They cover 60% of the population; more are expected to be awarded soon.

Fruits of broadband

 Faster access to web content: an end to the "world wide wait"

 More reliable connections that are always on

 Easier access to multimedia content such as streaming video and other media

 Higher quality video-conferencing, enabling teachers to teach students in other schools

 Online content: software and other materials can be delivered via a network

 Greater collaboration with other schools

 Better communication: email addresses for everyone become more feasible

 Educational TV programmes can be broadcast over the internet

 Easier access to a broadband network from homes and the community

How fast is fast?

Time taken to deliver a 1.5 megabyte file:

56k modem: 3.5 minutes

ISDN: 1.5 minutes

ADSL: 25 seconds

2-megabit connection: 6 seconds

100-megabit connection: 0.1 seconds

webTitle: Net safety at home: Out of harm's way

fields.headline: Out of harm's way
fields.standfirst: Keeping children safe from unsuitable content on the internet may be more difficult than we're led to believe. Irene Krechowiecka looks at a new report for parents
fields.trailText: Keeping children safe from unsuitable content on the internet may be more difficult than we're led to believe. Irene Krechowiecka looks at a new report for parents.
fields.body:
Children have access to an ever growing number of opportunities you'd rather they didn't, once they're out of your sight. So it's a relief to know that you can protect them from dangers on the internet simply by installing the right filtering software.

At least, that's what the makers of filtering software would have you believe. But according to the Parents Information Network (PIN), claims made by publishers about such products are not matched by reality. The results of PIN's evaluation of 14 internet filtering programs are not reassuring.

Volunteer families carried out rigorous tests on products which claim to prevent access to unacceptable content such as nudity, sex, violence, extremism, racism, illegal drugs and bomb-making. Some include a facility to stop children giving out personal details on chat sites or through emails; others prevent use of credit cards over the web or limit surfing time.

According to PIN, many of the claims made are not fulfilled. There are huge variations in how each works and no single product combines all the available features. Its report compiles information on each program's effectiveness, ease of use, flexibility, quality of support and compatibility with other software.

Jacquie Disney, director of PIN, admits she was surprised by the diversity and complexity of the software. "We never expected a complete solution, but in many cases the software didn't do what it claimed and even got in the way of researching quite legitimate topics. One program blocked access to nude artwork by Rubens, another that was supposed to stop nude images allowed access to Playboy.

"The word Middlesex was deemed unacceptable in some instances and, although most of the programs were reasonably effective at screening pornography, they were less good at denying access to sites with racist or offensive material. Some filtering programs block access to sites using Shockwave which rules out many good educational and children's games sites."

Blocking software works by preventing access to a database of banned sites or allowing access only to approved ones. The rationale for exclusion can be puzzling. One evaluator's son was dismayed to discover the Pokemon site a no go area.

Lists of acceptable and unacceptable sites may be predetermined by the publisher, but they can usually be customised. In some cases parents are expected to construct their own lists. With the number of internet sites growing daily, this takes a lot of research and doesn't offer foolproof protection.

Programs that filter by looking for unacceptable words or images work reasonably well for blocking pornography but are less reliable for screening out abusive material. Yet another type of software monitors the use made of the internet, a feature sometimes combined with blocking or filtering. But this involves explaining to your family that you've been snooping on them.

Products evaluated by PIN were geared to home-users and all cost money. Some internet service poviders, such as UK Online and AOL, provide free tools to their subscribers. These offer similar features with similar limitations. AOL advises users to "bear in mind that no system of automatic controls can completely take the place of good, old-fashioned parental supervision".

But children are safe at school, aren't they? Well, generally more so. Most schools have their content filtered by providers. Pupils normally sign an "acceptable use" policy which makes it clear they are being watched; it also spells out what is acceptable. The threat of having internet access removed is enough to make most cooperate.

According to Wendy Bowe, ICT coordinator at North Cumbria Technology College, it's not that youngsters want to put themselves in danger. "They're not always as streetwise as we assume and don't realise the potential consequences of giving personal details to strangers. People they meet on the internet can appear friendly and trustworthy, but once our pupils understand that electronic anonymity enables disguise, they start to take the risks seriously." Both Disney and Bowe see chatrooms as one of the most worrying areas of the web.

Disney stresses that educating parents and children about the dangers is the only way to ensure safe internet use: "It would be wrong to rely on filtering software. Even if you did find a program that met all your needs, you have to equip children for times when they will have unfiltered access.

"A lot is commonsense - never arranging to meet people you've only met virtually, and never giving out personal information. As for preventing access to all unsuitable material, you probably can't. Spend time with your children when they're on the web, talk to them about the sites they're visiting, help them become discriminating surfers. There are no easy shortcuts to providing a safe environment."

Just like real life then.

fields.headline: Fount of all knowledge
fields.standfirst: John Bald on the latest encyclopaedias - on and offline
fields.trailText: John Bald on the latest encyclopaedias - on and offline.
fields.body:
Encyclopaedias are the new annuals. Fresh editions, launched just before Christmas each year, have become a nice little earner. But there are snags. The first is that real innovations, such as Microsoft's atlas, do not always appear in time for Christmas. The second is that the full text of the former world leader, Britannica, is available free on the internet, with over 100,000 linked sites, including the New York Times and the Smithsonian Institute.

Some of these sites are the best in the world. The Vincent Van Gogh Information Gallery, for example, has 2,216 paintings, drawings and sketches plus all of his letters, a total of 3,451 pages. The full content of the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam is next on the list. Using the internet from Encarta's web centre gets you to exactly the same places. Why pay?

Microsoft's interactive world atlas, included with Encarta 2001 (De Luxe version, £99.99), is one good reason. This is a cross between a globe and a map. You move around the world with the mouse, home in on any location (down to most villages) and call up information on more or less anything.

The map of the world at night is beautiful and revealing, and there is an interactive map of the moon. Deciding on whether to upgrade from an earlier version will depend on how much you want new features, such as place names in local language and improved printing facilities. But this atlas does things the competition cannot match.

Encarta also has good dictionaries, 800 substantial articles from the Times, and glorious and informative panoramic views ranging from a Brittany village to an Everest expedition. It is over twice the price of the other encyclopaedias here, but it scores heavily on media features and entertainment value. The DVD version saves a lot of messing about changing discs.

Most encyclopaedias offer study guidance. Hutchinson 2001 (£29.99) has a national curriculum guide built into its menu, with links to short articles, typically of one or two paragraphs. On some topics, such as glacial erosion, these build up into a useful picture and would help with coursework.

Where an issue requires understanding rather than just description, though, Hutchinson's treatment is bitty and superficial. A few lines from Jane Austen, a snatch of John Bunyan, a couple of paragraphs on "juvenile offenders" - Hutchinson invites us to enquire about everything, but not to ask too much.

In fact, all of these encyclopaedia study guides suffer from a focus on information rather than understanding. In practice, they do not add much to the facility of copying text from one location and pasting it into another, where it can be edited.

This is the crunch. When we are not browsing through encyclopaedias, we use them to find out about what we don't know or understand, rather than to confirm what we do. With this in mind, I tried four encyclopaedias plus the internet to see what I could find out about differential calculus.

Encarta gave a historical introduction, followed by a table of 16 mathematical formulae, indecipherable to anyone who did not understand calculus. Its text began with a good, simple sentence - "Differential calculus is concerned with rates of change" - but then became so complex so quickly that I made no sense of it.

Britannica (De Luxe version £49.99) and Hutchinson were no better, despite a flash of lucidity from Hutchinson near the beginning. All three of these encyclopaedias save space and time by expressing ideas as compactly as possible, but this makes them useless to someone who needs technical language to be unpacked and explained.

The internet had a lot of potentially useful sites from American universities, but World Book (De Luxe edition, £39.99) explained the principles of calculus in simple English and did not jump into formulae too quickly.

The rest of this encyclopaedia has a similar style - it does not have the power of Britannica or the innovative qualities of the best parts of Encarta, but it has a reasonable range of information on things most non-specialist readers would like to know about, and takes time to explain as well as inform. Its grander competitors could learn from this.

Most encyclopaedias offer study guidance. Hutchinson 2001 (£29.99) has a national curriculum guide built into its menu, with links to short articles, typically of one or two paragraphs. On some topics, such as glacial erosion, these build up into a useful picture and would help with coursework. Where an issue requires understanding rather than just description, though, Hutchinson's treatment is bitty and superficial. A few lines from Jane Austen, a snatch of John Bunyan, a couple of paragraphs on "juvenile offenders" - Hutchinson invites us to enquire about everything, but not to ask too much. In fact, all of these encyclopaedia study guides suffer from a focus on information rather than understanding. In practice, they do not add much to the facility of copying text from one location and pasting it into another, where it can be edited. This is the crunch. When we are not browsing through encyclopaedias, we use them to find out about what we don't know or understand, rather than to confirm what we do. With this in mind, I tried four encyclopaedias plus the internet to see what I could find out about differential calculus. Encarta gave a historical introduction, followed by a table of 16 mathematical formulae, indecipherable to anyone who did not understand calculus. Its text began with a good, simple sentence - "Differential calculus is concerned with rates of change" - but then became so complex so quickly that I made no sense of it. Britannica (De Luxe version £49.99) and Hutchinson were no better, despite a flash of lucidity from Hutchinson near the beginning. All three of these encyclopaedias save space and time by expressing ideas as compactly as possible, but this makes them useless to someone who needs technical language to be unpacked and explained. The internet had a lot of potentially useful sites from American universities, but World Book (De Luxe edition, £39.99) explained the principles of calculus in simple English and did not jump into formulae too quickly. The rest of this encyclopaedia has a similar style - it does not have the power of Britannica or the innovative qualities of the best parts of Encarta, but it has a reasonable range of information on things most non-specialist readers would like to know about, and takes time to explain as well as inform. Its grander competitors could learn from this.

webTitle: School intranets: Ports in a storm

fields.headline: Ports in a storm
fields.standfirst: Intranets can offer relevant, safe and monitorable havens, as Roger Frost discovers
fields.trailText: Intranets can offer relevant, safe and monitorable havens, as Roger Frost discovers.
fields.body:
Schools looking for safe, reliable places to be online are finding hope in new breeds of "intranet" services expressly aimed at education. Rather than merely leaving teachers to surf the internet's choppy seas, the services direct them not just to the best content on the web, but to areas offering innovative activities, too.

In Croydon, for example, schools have taken the local education authority's lead in signing up to www.schoolmaster.net - a UK-based website that is a haven for staff, parents and children alike. Here in calmer waters, they can use email, surf the good and create web magazines. Come the end of the day at St Andrew's High, children stay back to use it. They've found themselves in a "community" where they can work on projects and meet with pals abroad.

Participating schools leave pupils to interact in the chatrooms and discussion groups, while the website monitors the pupils' dialogue centrally. It also keeps close control on who does what, based on what a teacher has programmed in earlier. This can even extend to deciding whether girls may chat with boys. A school will typically sign up through its ICT coordinator who then meters access to the system. It's that tight.

The move to Schoolmaster.net is also expedient: the staff and pupil lists can be used to create email addresses for all at a stroke. From here the community magic can start to work, helped by email, coursework and discussion all happening in the same space. For example, it's all the more easy to respond to today's request for staff to get your reports in, or for a project partner from a school in Iceland.

If off-site email brings time and money gains to system management and relentless software upgrades, there are broader gains to be made in the area of information sharing. For example, the software lets a school publish a calendar showing the term's meetings, while it will have separate calendars for booking the school hall, minibus and PC projector. And putting up class web pages? Well, you just make them.

The Schoolmaster.net software from BiblioTech feels unique: its online tools won a Bett 2000 award. A new pay-to-use feature, being launched this year, allows you to manage projects online - and there's no casual way in to the area for strangers. It's worth seeing at Bett 2001, the ICT in education show at Olympia this week.

With 300,000 members and 3,800 schools worldwide, Schoolmaster grows by 500 members each day because of its good level of safety, its fun approach and the fact that lots of its functions are free. Like other examples that follow, it is not just a sheltered port to make sense of a stormy online world but also a framework that schools can adapt.

Digitalbrain
Another sophisticated gateway to the internet, Digitalbrain is being used in 15 LEAs. On one level it's a practical way to store files, internet links and lesson materials so that you have everything in one place. You can quickly see this in practice as it only takes a minute or so to visit the site. On another level, children's and colleagues' work can be built into an intranet, which in a sense is a "digital brain". Already a heap of ready-made online learning material, reaching up to college level, is available here. At the wider level come even bigger benefits: Nottingham City LEA, for example, will use it in its Anytime, Anywhere Learning project. It aims to provide every child with a laptop and use Digitalbrain for sharing the material that such wholesale use of ICT is set to generate.

Schoolzone
If you're ever unsure what there is to find on the internet, www.schoolzone.co.uk is a good place to look. With entry points for teachers, parents and governors, Schoolzone is a gateway to revision sites, learning materials, exam boards, fundraising ideas, self-help and many in-and-around school needs. It's a great mine of links - the one-stop-shop idea but without the logins and passwords. There's even a place to post your CV and be headhunted.

Primary Zone
New for 2001, this is a rare find of primary material for ages four to 11. Primary Zone will fit the bill for homework, lunchtime clubs and lesson support. Software developer Granada Learning's penchant for clean graphics and on-target activity is put to use to support literacy, numeracy and science. To keep pupils on task you can pre-select the work each pupil can access. A 30-day free trial is available as this service for schools and parents launches this week (cost: £75 pa approx for schools, £10 pa for home).

Learnall
Learnall's enhanced online service offers access to a lot of commercial content for all school ages. You can search it in fine detail to find teaching materials and homework ideas from better-known names in ICT software, such as AVP, Storm Software and the award-winning Expresso Productions. And there's no need to carry it around on CD-roms and floppies - they're so 90s anyway - since you store the elements you need in your own area on the net. Learnall's wide range of material has been brought together and made easy to access by DIALnet, which has a pedigree in building LEA-wide networks for electronic information exchange. You can try it out on a one-month free trial.

Einsteinonline
The first "online primary school" arrives with tables, spellings, mental maths and more for ages four to 11. Like the "private tutor" you might suggest to a concerned parent, Einsteinonline offers a day-by-day learning programme where you can pop behind the work to check a child's progress. A one-week free trial shows a spread of graded, interactive, and unusually attractive exercises (cost: £5.99 a month to parents).

fields.headline: Movie moguls
fields.standfirst: John Davitt reports on the next generation of video-making and editing technology and visits a unique film-making project
fields.trailText: John Davitt reports on the next generation of video-making and editing technology and visits a unique film-making project.
fields.body:
The moving image has become the definitive medium, but it's still strangely elusive when we try to master our own versions via camcorder and screen. The end result is usually wobbly vision which takes too long to edit into something viewable so we give up and consign the school camera to the back of a cupboard.

Desktop publishing has long since given us all the power to be printers (albeit with occasional attacks of fontitis) but manageable video editing has been a lot longer coming - 2001 could be the year.

For schools the potential is enormous - the advent of fast broadband networks (see p18) means it's only a matter of time before schools run their own TV stations across the computer network - imagine tuning into the news coming live from room 12. Of course, there's nothing new in this: Sharnbrook Upper School in Bedford has been running TV around the school for 15 years. What is new is that digital video editing brings point'n'click ease to an area that was once complex and only for the cognoscenti. And now, once video is digitised it can be sent and shared via standard networks and the internet in just the same way as any other computer file.

The latest version of Microsoft's Windows Millennium Edition (ME) operating system comes with digital editing software built in, so that you can copy, paste and edit any digital video clip.

Apple has also invested heavily in this area and developed an interface called FireWire to allow computers to communicate with digital cameras and transfer video from camera to computer in real time. This has now become an industry standard, with most major camcorder manufacturers, including Canon and Sony, building a compatible port (which they call IEEE-1394) into their cameras.

Want to know what could be this year's best digital media advice? - don't buy a camcorder unless it has a FireWire compatible DV out port.

At an event last October Apple paired 16 students from four UK schools together with 16 Apple Masters. The masters were all media, entertainment and academic celebrities who have used Apple computers in their work. Their creative task was to film, edit and present a two-minute movie in two days using only a low-cost Canon MV30i digital camera and an iMac DV computer (it has the FireWire port fitted as standard).

The results were stunning as stars like Ken Russell and Hugh Laurie cajoled, encouraged and listened to their young charges. I stood behind Ken Russell as he worked with Emma Downey from Liswerry high school in Wales, and watched as they discussed the use of diagonal shadow and effect on the first clips. The computers running iMovie2 software, which comes as standard on the Mac, allowed simple edits, effects and transitions to be introduced with ease.

Watching the groups working I got a sense of what is possible now that neither camera nor computer get in the way of the creative process.

Video-making and editing is a natural communication activity which children can excel at. It also provokes talk and creative argument and, most importantly, it can give students a chance to represent their own view rather than be consumed by those of others.

"In the past, non-academic children couldn't shine on film because it was too expensive. Now if you believe in yourself and have access to equipment costing less than £2,000, you can produce something good enough to show a top producer," says Floella Benjamin, the TV producer and presenter.

I was seeing faces I remember from TV and voices from the airwaves and, yes, they were smaller in real life, but their creative commitment to passing on their skills was clear. Bob Geldof popped in to see the work nearing completion and John Hurt had a creative difference of opinion with Fergus Stuart, his young partner.

Elsewhere, Joseph Fiennes worked with Sarah Clarke from Bedford high school. She was more familiar than he with the editing tools - girls at the school regularly use digital video to make their own adverts for completed products made in Design and Technology lessons.

The creative experience of the 12-year-olds and mentors showed what is possible with support, equipment and a little creative constraint. Compact cameras, a low-cost computer and a tidal wave of creativity means that schools can now build their own digital video-editing suite for less than £2,000.

Further information

Visit Microsoft's stand (D30/34) and make you own movie on Apple's stand (E34) at the BETT show (London Olympia, January 10-13). See the movie work completed at www.apple.com.

webTitle: BETT show: Up, up and away

fields.headline: Up, up and away
fields.standfirst: John Davitt previews the gadgetry taking off at this week's biggest BETT show ever
fields.trailText: John Davitt previews the gadgetry taking off at this week's biggest BETT show ever.
fields.body:
All eyes are on Bett 2001 to benchmark past achievements and signpost future success in ICT in schools. The annual ICT in technology show kicks off tomorrow at London's Olympia, encouraging teachers to use any means to get there. Glasgow City Council has hired a 747 plane to fly 250 teachers to Bett for each of the show's four days. Whole trains have been chartered from Birmingham and hundreds of visitors from other continents are on standby to fly in.

To make the most of the Bett experience you'll need to decide priorities and then visit key knowledge and equipment brokers for your particular areas.

With 400 exhibitors represented and more than 100 seminars, many schools and local education authorities have designated the show an official Inset event. The show's website at www.bettshow.com or www.education-net.co.uk gives the latest information on Bett events, exhibitors and special features including specialist trails - suggested pathways through the show for primary, secondary and further education visitors.

Mark out your target sites on a floor map from the web or from the booklet when you arrive and try to take a small rucksack so you can gather material but keep your hands free to take notes.

At the British Educational Suppliers Association information stand (L35), you you can view the show on screen or get a computerised print-out of companies and stand numbers that interest you.

BettNet computers with similar facilities will be dotted throughout the show. As usual Bett is themed according to type, and this year a posse of New Opportunities Fund trainers will gather in the Teacher Training Centre, sponsored by the Guardian's new school resources website, learn.co.uk. You can ask them direct questions as to how training of teachers in ICT has gone so far and see testimonials from satisfied customers. Alongside the perennial and expanded Special Needs Village there is a Publishing Zone, a Software Centre and a Library Resource Centre.

The main themes emerging this year are strategies and software for successful whole school management of ICT. The show will also reflect the revolution in educational content publishing - making the best use of faster (broadband) internet connections.

And don't forget computer-aided design and control, for so long the poor relations in ICT, which are moving centre stage with events like designing a Formula One car from Denford (D64) with Jaguar Cars. In fact, Jaguar, which is sponsoring the challenge, is launching a national competition for pupils - just what's needed to raise the profile of ICT in the manufacturing industries.

At the Lego DACTA (E66) stand the new robotics system, Mindstorms for Schools, will have children building robots "that can see and make decisions" in less than two hours. Make sure you see it.

Microsoft (stand D34) will continue the roll-out of its Anytime Anywhere Learning programme. Several schools, including the laptop-packing Sawtry Community College, will be detailing their experiences of investment and curriculum planning with networks and wireless developments.

Acer (E22) and Compaq (W40) are two other key providers of portable computers robust enough to be used in schools. Both companies now have substantial case study experiences.

RM (E50) is expanding its Eduweb internet service for schools, setting a high benchmark for others to reach. RM Tutor software also provides important new tools for mediating group learning via a school network, be it hard-wired or wireless. Also on show will be its subscription-based Easiteach Maths, an interactive, whole-class teaching resource for schools launched last September.

Viglen (F60) will present a new version of ClassLink - software that allows teachers to observe and manage the work done on individual machines in a creative and dynamic way during lessons. A primary version will be launched at Bett.

Viglen is one of the three companies licensed by government to provide managed services for wireless, so examples will be on show. It will also launch @school, a way of allowing primary children to surf the web safely.

Management software for the curriculum is also starting to have real impact. On show will be Literacy and Numeracy Complete software from the Skills Factory (C162), which helps teachers to keep track of individual achievement and to sculpt individual action plans. Most importantly, it provides access to an online resources bank (ORB) where teachers can search and download thousands of lesson plans and teaching ideas. "Thanks for weekends back," says a numeracy coordinator in Manchester - the ultimate accolade for a piece of software.

PSE resources from Learning & Teaching Scotland (F54) (the old SCET) show the power of multimedia in its new series, Smart Moves, designed to help teachers deal with real life issues such as life choices, interviews and healthy eating. Extensive spoken sections and contemporary design mean that these materials may also be of particular use for students with special needs.

Transforming Learning (Z64) is a web-based professional development tool for teachers from HayMcBer. The service works by illuminating the impact each member of staff has on others, within a private space for reflection and planning. Early trials have led to considerable improvement in the learning environment.

Whole class teaching with ICT is also about to take off. Companies like AverMedia (G60) will be showing a range of low-cost solutions for sending computer displays through standard classroom televisions and small fixed cameras which allow 3D objects and books to be displayed on TV and overlaid with computer outputs .

To make the most dramatic leap in using ICT in the classroom, large screen projection is a major consideration. Just Projectors (G90) specialises in a wide range of units and aims to focus on low-cost projection technologies - some of which will be affordable even for primary schools.

The Mimio is a unique low-cost solution to creating interactive presentations on a standard, non-electronic whiteboard and saving them as web pages for students to revisit later (C166).

Beyond this the world of the interactive whiteboard beckons. Promethean will be demonstrating small infra-red tablets which let students contribute to points made by the teacher on the whiteboard at the front of the class.

The company will also launch a class voting system where students can enter choices on a keypad. Part game-show, part interactive lesson delight. By preserving anonymity, teachers may finally get an honest answer to the question "Has everybody got that?"

Online learning materials for primary schools and the home are also progressing. Spark Island (D94) is geared to the current speed of connection in schools and homes. This site features some delightful learning activities. And see TAG (F50) for the low-cost (sub £50) Jam cam digital camera and the latest version of the popular HyperStudio multimedia software.

Macromedia (M26) will be launching some excellent educational deals. In Flash it probably has the most powerful and challenging software fon the market to stretch children and foster their creativity. See work in progress in schools to develop higher thinking skills and creativity in the classroom and pick up a demo disc (stand SW63).

There are plenty of powerful ICT tools ready to take off at Bett 2001. Happy landings.

 John Davitt is a ICT trainer in education and a writer. His new book, New Tools for Teaching and Learning, will be launched tomorrow. The first chapter is available for download from www.newtools.org

The Guardian at BETT

At this year's BETT show, the Guardian is promoting the following on or near its stand (M90):

 Sponsorship of the teacher training centre on the first floor by learn.co.uk, the Guardian's new education resources website. Participation will be on a first come, first served basis for various types of ICT training offered free on each day of the four-day show.

 Free teacher support cards that take you straight to the half dozen best places on the web for specific curriculum topics. Cards are for history, geography, English, science and French. The first 50 people to register on the learn.co.uk site at the show get a free goodie bag including pen, pencil and padblock.

 Launch of new key stage three subjects from learn.co.uk

 www.educationunlimited.co.uk - the Guardian's education news site - is giving away free advice sheets on how to get to grips with ICT. The advice has appeared in past issues of Guardian Education in the "internet know-how" column

 Guardian Education is publicising its new teaching resource pages for key stages one to four, the first of which are in today's main education supplement. Every week there will be website and CD-rom reviews and reader offers, plus photocopiable lesson materials that are linked to interactive teaching resources on learn.co.uk.

In Flash it probably has the most powerful and challenging software fon the market to stretch children and foster their creativity. Cards are for history, geography, English, science and French. The first 50 people to register on the learn.co.uk site at the show get a free goodie bag including pen, pencil and padblock.  Launch of new key stage three subjects from learn.co.uk  www.educationunlimited.co.uk - the Guardian's education news site - is giving away free advice sheets on how to get to grips with ICT. The advice has appeared in past issues of Guardian Education in the "internet know-how" column  Guardian Education is publicising its new teaching resource pages for key stages one to four, the first of which are in today's main education supplement. Every week there will be website and CD-rom reviews and reader offers, plus photocopiable lesson materials that are linked to interactive teaching resources on learn.co.uk.

fields.headline: Finger-clicking good
fields.standfirst: Soon pupils and teachers will find it much easier to go straight to what they want on the internet. Emma Haughton says forget websites, think pages
fields.trailText: Soon pupils and teachers will find it much easier to go straight to what they want on the internet. Emma Haughton says forget websites, think pages.
fields.body:
January 2001 could be something of a watershed for the role of the internet in education. The end of the month will see the launch of National Curriculum Online, a much more sophisticated and powerful version of the print version currently available on the web, already one of the UK's most popular education-related websites.

Using a system of organising data called metatagging, National Curriculum Online aims to make life a lot easier for teachers. This involves using key words, otherwise known as metadata, to describe the content of the national curriculum on the site and on partner sites. Simply clicking on any statement in the curriculum programmes of study will take you to appropriate internet-based resources, often specific pages, not just whole websites.

"The national curriculum provides a great mechanism for tailoring a search," explains Roger Davies, head of publishing at the QCA, which has validated the new system. "Traditionally if you want to, say, find something suitable on the Romans, you would go into Yahoo! or another search engine and type in 'Romans' and up would come 10,000 sites.

"The national curriculum breaks down the curriculum into subjects and key stages, and into programmes of study and teaching requirements; metatagging allows us to underpin each of those with links to resources that support those."

Each of those internet resources will be carefully sifted by key stage and theme. These might be worksheets or other information directed at pupils, teaching guidance or background information about the skills, knowledge and understanding referred to in the requirement. They will include government and commercial resources, museums and galleries, and sites created by other teachers.

"The national curriculum will act as a filter that saves a lot of time in terms of research and evaluation," says Davies. "We want to get away from the sort of hot link that takes you to the home page, where you then have to find your way down to the information you actually want. We will reduce the number of clicks it takes to get you there."

Initially there will be at least 10 resources per key stage of each subject - around 440 for the whole curriculum - but in time the site will grow to include resources that touch on every statement, even including examples of pupils' work. And each external resource will be peer-reviewed by other teachers, making sure that the best rise to the top. "One purpose of the site is to become a place where teachers' knowledge is stored and shared," says Jonathan Hollow, senior education consultant at C21, the lead consultancy for the restructuring and design of National Curriculum Online. "Because any teacher can submit their own recommendations on useful websites, it will become a kind of archive of their knowledge and expertise."

National Curriculum Online will also form links with other educational content providers, known as "trusted partners". Publishers of any kind producing a lot of curriculum-related content will be invited to use the new metadata standard to index their own content. This will mean that every relevant page on their site will be linked automatically with all the applicable curriculum requirements, while teachers will be able to see at a glance what relevance any particular resource might have to the national curriculum standards.

Current trusted partners include learn.co.uk, the Guardian's education resources website, along with the BBC, Science Museum and the Tidy Britain group's Ecoschools project. "But there could be hundreds," says Hollow. "Basically we've written what we hope will become a British standard. Anyone can now adopt it and link their material to the national curriculum."

And good internet resources are not all that National Curriculum Online will offer. Within a few months of the launch it will link into the schemes of work, knitting together all the key government guidance on the curriculum. You will also be able to search the national curriculum text by keyword and collate the results, allowing you, for instance, to search for all the key skills for communication at key stage one.

You could also do similar searches to find all the ways to teach any area that cuts across the curriculum, such as thinking skills, citizenship and PSHE, or ICT.

It's a mammoth undertaking, but C21 is bullish about its reception. "We do see it as becoming the definitive access point for teachers to access resources for the curriculum," says Hollow. "Basically we think it will have a huge impact on teachers' lives."

 National Curriculum Online will be launched on January 22. See www.nc.uk.net for details. It will also be previewed at Bett.

webTitle: NGFL: Come on, join the club

fields.headline: Come on, join the club
fields.standfirst: Stephen Hoare on the pick of the latest developments on the Grid
fields.trailText: Stephen Hoare on the pick of the latest developments on the Grid.
fields.body:
The Gridclub

Learning on the web has just got a lot more fun with Gridclub, a new website for kids aged 7-11 due to be launched at this year's BETT show. In what looks certain to be one of the most exciting new online ventures in recent years, the Department for Education has provided funding for the key stage 2 project which brings together the creative brains of Ultralab (an ICT in education research organisation), Channel 4, Oracle and intuitivemedia. Intended for use mainly in after-school clubs and at home, Gridclub has been designed as a safe learning environment that will stretch children's imagination as well as their online communication skills. Children will learn through communicating with each other and by building up clubs on subjects that interest them such as animals or sport. Features of the Gridclub include password protected areas where teachers are not allowed and web clubs - virtual communities set up by children within their own school or across the country.

Every club or online community will provide content that is compatible with the national curriculum. Ultralab's Professor Stephen Heppell said: "This puts kids in control, at the centre of the learning experience. We have asked them what's useful, what they want to see. We've taken the opportunity to be really innovative!"

Another year for Tesco SchoolNet 2000

Tesco's highly acclaimed education website, SchoolNet 2000, will run for at least one more year to cope with the flood of web pages that pupils are submitting. To date 133,000 pupils have registered on the site which, at the last count, contained 52,850 pages of children's work with a further 32,000 pages waiting to be posted. Linked with SchoolNet2000, Tesco's Our School Awards were presented at the Millennium Dome on December 5. Voted for by fellow pupils, winners included a group of pupils who set up a youth club for a neighbouring special school, a 10-year-old special needs mentor, and a group of teenagers from Reading who taught local pensioners how to use the net.

Stella Stafford from Maiden Erlegh school, Reading, said: "The experience has given pupils patience and an understanding of teaching. It has also brought them closer to a generation that they will not have had much to do with."

Colette Cotton, head of St Mary's C of E primary school, Folkestone, said of her young prize-winners: "We're a religious school with a very high ethos. We've set up a suite of 36 computers which has enabled pupils to post 700 pieces of work on the SchoolNet site."

Ofsted on the web

Ofsted coming up? Worried your ICT will let you down? There is no need to get stressed since Becta has put the finishing touches to its school inspectors' website. Written by a registered government inspector as a series of checklists for inspectors to use when observing ICT in the classroom, the site has become hugely popular among teachers. "Over 50% of the hits are from teachers in pre-Ofsted mode," says Becta's Stephanie Harris.

Becta's grand prix

The virtual racing car driven by Sanquhar primary school, Dumfries, screamed past the chequered flag to win the Becta's Grand Prix Maths Challenge last month, narrowly beating Oval primary, Croydon and the Ysgol Bryn Coch team from Flintshire. The 10-minute race that took place in the Jaguar Centre, Birmingham, on December 5, saw 13 finalists from all over the UK revving calculators and fine-tuning PCs. Working in teams of four, pupils used their maths skills to calculate fuel requirements, pit-stop timings and safe speeds. The Dumfries pupils won a day's racing with Jaguar and Viglen computer equipment for their school.

Best practice at BETT

The quest for excellence in ICT takes a step forward when Becta announces the winners of its first ever ICT In Practice awards at the technology in education show, Bett, held in London from January 10-13. There are special categories for school management, special educational needs, subject teaching at primary and secondary, and for LEA advice and support. Helen Walker, head of practice at Becta, said: "We have received top quality entries from across the UK in all the categories and the judges have not had an easy time making their decisions."

Web Nose Day

It might involve shutting the head in a gunge tank or dancing the conga round the school playing field. March 16 is Red Nose Day and this year the fun-filled fundraising will also be going online. Comic Relief is organising Web Nose Day, a competition to find the best school websites dedicated to the event. Besides fundraising packs and lesson plans, Comic Relief will be putting design tools on its website: images, logos, video clips and animated banner ads which schools can download to create their own Web Nose website.

These can be entered in a new section of the annual Becta/Guardian school and college website awards (see page 26). "We'll be looking not just for technical skills but for real creativity," said Comic Relief's education manager Jonathan Smith. "We want schools to look at the big issues like poverty in the UK and Africa, as well as having fun."

In 1999 60% of schools took part in Red Nose Day. Comic Relief is hoping to see a lot of web noses!

fields.headline: Best laid plans
fields.standfirst: Terry Freedman outlines how to plan the ideal type of training for both teachers and school
fields.trailText: Terry Freedman outlines how to plan the ideal type of training for both teachers and school.
fields.body:
There is a bewildering array of training "solutions" available for schools and teachers. Choosing the right kind of inset training and training provider can be a nightmare. And yet it's a choice that sooner or later will have to be made by the 45-50% of schools still due to to sign up.

First of all, any training solution is there to address a problem. So the very first step must be to identify your own school's problem(s).

And that's not as simple as it sounds. A glib answer might be: to improve staff competence and confidence in using ICT. One teacher may be delighted to have learnt how to switch the computer on and produce a short document, but her colleague may not be happy until he has built a grand assessment tool from Excel and Access.

Other training needs will include learning how to assess pupils' work in ICT, finding out how to do simple trouble-shooting and making the best use of the computer in the corner of the room. Each of these is a legitimate training "problem", but the "solution" in each case is likely to be very different.

A good way to find out what staff perceive their weaknesses to be is to ask them to complete an ICT Skills Audit. There are several examples of these around now, including those provided by NOF training providers and others on the net. (See www.ictineducation.org; www.ngfl.ac.uk and www.ucrysj.ac.uk).

Few, if any, of these will exactly match your own needs, and so you may wish to construct your own. If you do, remember it should be short and simple - teachers do not have the time to fill in a four-page questionnaire: two sides is about right. Also, accept that an audit will only provide a broad view, not a highly detailed, individualised one.

After doing an audit and analysing the results, you face the next issue: priorities. There will always be some tension between the needs of the school and the (professional development) needs of individual teachers. So ask yourself: what training or set of training is most likely to help the school move closer to achieving its stated ICT aims? (These should be part of the school's ICT strategy or educational development plan.)

Of course, the fact that the school has to prioritise does not necessarily mean that individuals will lose out. Also, when planning inset, you will have to decide on the best form of delivery. For individual teachers, this could sometimes be a book or a CD-Rom rather than a formal course that could prove a lot dearer.

Finally, someone has to organise the inset. Ideally, your inset plan should work on a similar time scale to your ICT strategy, because it is one of the factors that will help to realise the ICT strategy, and will take into account the strengths and weaknesses of the staff revealed in the skills audit.

Of course, no one type of inset suits all circumstances. For example, a whole staff lecture-style inset best suits the idea of pumping out information rather than teaching of skills. Equally, focused work in small groups involving discussion of pedagogical issues or learning and applying software skills helped by a tutor is a better means of helping teachers gain specific skills or understanding.

This still leaves the issue of how to find the right training provider(s). It's important not to overlook the expertise you may have in-house, but if you want an external trainer there are several useful sources of information.

The first is the Learning Resource Index on the National Grid for Learning (NGfL). This covers a vast range of resources, including websites, CD-Roms and training providers. The advantage of searching this particular database is that all its entries have had to go through a rigorous process to become NGfL-approved.

Also look at the ICT Support Network listing provided by Becta. While the individuals and organisations listed are not necessarily "approved" as such, many are members of professional associations and have gone through an accreditation process.

Finally, for New Opportunities Fund training providers you will need to look in "ICT training for teachers and school librarians". Part two details a range of training providers and their specialisms. If you can't find the red folder in school, download the document in pdf format.

webTitle: Training: So you want to D-I-Y?

fields.headline: So you want to D-I-Y?
fields.standfirst: Terry Freedman trawls through the market to find the best resources for those who want to teach themselves about ICT
fields.trailText: Terry Freedman trawls through the market to find the best resources for those who want to teach themselves about ICT.
fields.body:
An inset training day in ICT isn't just about face-to-face training. There is a host of resources around to add to the live lessons.

Websites are an obvious choice, but don't forget the importance of CD-Roms and, of course, a collection of (loanable) books. Build up your own bank of resources that teachers will be able to access at their own convenience.

Books come in several categories, starting with technical vs pedagogical. In the former category, there are a range of options, from the highly technical to the self-proclaimed idiots' guides. In principle, the very technical titles should come out of the ICT budget rather than the training budget, since not many teachers will need or want to know about, for example, the intricacies of JavaScript.

Buy a range of books, several for each software application, since they tend to approach the subject matter in different ways. It's probably best to avoid books with the word "idiot" or "dummy" in their titles, because that's not a very good starting point for someone who is already feeling under-confident.

There are three main kinds of software-oriented book available. First, there is the "Teach yourself X in 24 hours" type. Although the timescale may be a bit of wishful thinking in the real world of teaching, the real strength of this type of book is that it tends to be very highly structured, with an introduction telling you what will be covered, the material itself, and then a summary and a few questions - just like a good lesson in fact!

For visual learners, Microsoft's "Easy" range is very appealing. Each topic is covered in one or two pages. However, the unique aspect of these books is that rather than containing text accompanied by illustrations, they consist of illustrations accompanied by text - a subtle but important distinction.

For very focused skills, such as how to set up tables in Word, consider the Essential Knowledge series from Dorling Kindersley. These are slim, highly illustrated and colourful, and inexpensive - less than a fiver.

A new series from Microsoft called Troubleshooting also looks promising, especially as each title will have its own dedicated website with monthly updates.

There are several important books about the pedagogy of ICT, which is an aspect of ICT training that all too often falls by the wayside.

An important new book on the market - intended for new teachers but relevant for practising ones - is Primary ICT by Sharp, Potter, Allen and Loveless (see www.learningmatters.co.uk). Two other books definitely worth a look are Teaching and Learning with ICT in the Primary School, by Leask and Meadows (Routledge Falmer) and Learning to Teach Using ICT in the Secondary School. Perhaps I may be permitted to add my own ebook, Using ICT, which consists of dozens of bullet points and is free.

CD-Roms vary in quality and usefulness. Many of the approved NOF training providers disseminate information and materials in this form. There are also a number of training CD-Roms available for the world of commerce, but these tend to be expensive.

CD-Roms generally come in two varieties: highly interactive, including sound and video clips, and those which are little more than a repository for hundreds of pages of materials.

A particularly useful one, which every school ought to have, is that provided by the Teacher Training Agency - ICT: Identification of Your Training Needs. There are two packages, one for primary and one for secondary (which consists of 3 CDs), each of which is available for both the PC and the Mac. Not only does the CD contain a wealth of material such as video clips, but also a tracking system that enables you to identify your own training needs and make notes as you progress. Being generic, this resource can be used with any other training materials you may be using.

No round-up of resources would be complete without a look at online training. Any training organisation worth its salt will have a supporting website, of course, but some forms of training are mainly delivered online. The advantages of online training are that you can work at your own pace any time of the day or night, and that often you can discuss things with colleagues from all over the country via an electronic bulletin board. (Indeed, many NOF training providers include online support and bulletin boards as part of their package.)

Look at www.knowledgepool.com which has a free sample online lesson to try out. It's also worth keeping an eye on companies which may not be in the training business as such, but who may offer free training for little or no cost. For example, last year Viglen offered a series of free seminars around the country. If you cannot get to the BETT show this year, at the very least look through the list of exhibitors at www.education-net.co.uk/bett/.

fields.headline: Training dos and don'ts
fields.trailText: What to avoid and what to include in your ICT development plan.
fields.body:
Do

 Exercise a choice, see what's on offer. Choose experts in particular areas rather than ICT in general

 Involve the specific heads of department

 Ask about schools where a training provider is working

 Use an internet search tool such as Copernic or Web Ferret, or a search engine such as Google to search for "ICT Training" to find other providers and products

 Look in online catalogues for organisations and products. Two good ones are the list of BETT show exhibitors and the British Educational Suppliers Association.

 Ask to see all trainers' CVs

 Ask other local schools and your LEA's ICT advisory service (if there is one) to recommend training providers and products. Check if your LEA or local college runs courses or provides in-house training

 Ask what online, telephone and face-to-face support isincluded in the package, how much it costs, and how long it lasts. Does the plug get pulled as soon as the course ends?

o Ask what kit the trainers have? Will they use your kit? Is their equipment compatible?

 Find out if the training offered, in whatever form, is a one-size-fits-all package or whether it can be tailored to your own circumstances

 Arrange for teachers to meet a trainer dedicated to the school, if that is what the provider is offering

 Ask about the level of support on offer. When does the support finish?

 Consider hidden costs of training, such as paying for supply cover for teachers on courses, and the opportunity costs in terms of what else the teachers on a course could be doing instead

Don't

 Be mesmerised by the technology: online training is often as good as that given by a live presenter

 Assume one session on one aspect of ICT will be adequate

 Assume everybody understands the basics... or that nobody does

 Forget to plan an exit strategy to follow when the present training budget runs out

 Plan different bits of training in isolation - it should all be part of an overall strategy

 Underestimate the importance of ensuring that everyone has their own network-user identities, and knows where to get help

fields.headline: Confidence building
fields.standfirst: David Brown is assistant head and ICT coordinator at Keswick school in Cumbria. He combines developing computer resources with being head of chemistry
fields.trailText: David Brown is assistant head and ICT coordinator at Keswick school in Cumbria. He combines developing computer resources with being head of chemistry.
fields.body:
It's taken us several years to get to the point where all staff use ICT confidently in their teaching. I spent a lot of time at the start just raising awareness about the benefits of ICT. Teachers need to see the point of it and believe it will, in the long run, save them time and add to the effectiveness of what they already do well.

Confidence takes more than just a few training sessions. It's built through regular use of a computer for a range of activities, which means having easy access to a machine whenever you need it - in classrooms, departmental rooms and staff work areas.

We decided at the beginning to have everything on one network so that teachers could use the same computer for admin, accessing the internet or working with curriculum software. It means they're always using the same front end and able to get to everything they need from any school computer. That helps confidence develop quickly.

Another good decision was to go for cross-curricular ICT rather than specialist teaching. That way every subject has equal access to the resources, and subject teachers rather than ICT specialists develop the provision.

We've offered after-school training for years, always on a voluntary basis. There's no point in pushing staff to do something they don't feel they have a use for. I'm doing less and less training all the time, as teachers are now more likely to help each other.

It's essential to have high-quality equipment, with every machine behaving in the same way and giving access to the same resources.

That takes management commitment and investment. Once that's there it's not difficult to motivate school staff to take advantage of it.

fields.headline: Soundbytes
fields.trailText: A round-up of the latest developments in ICT for schools.
fields.body:
Latin for tomorrow

Japanese, Latin and maths key stage three resources will be pumped out on the net to around 60 secondary schools and 15 independent learners for the next two terms in a government pilot scheme designed for the classroom of tomorrow.

A whole year's coursework for 11- year-olds will be provided mainly via the net, including printable materials for homework to avoid excluding children without net access. Some maths resources will be for specially supplied interactive whiteboards to test whole-class teaching techniques.

All three subjects have teacher shortages. The maths resources (from RM) are designed to reflect the national numeracy strategy and to help children switching over to secondary school. They tap into new ways of delivering the subject, with activities including against-the-clock and fun activities.

The Latin focus (with resources from Granada Media/Result) aims to revive dwindling interest in the classics. And using Japanese resources from the BBC, the government hopes to open up a subject with hitherto scarce learning opportunities and to assess how the net can encourage take-up of minority subjects.

Potential resources include video and audio items, interactive self-assessment programs, and online tests for monitoring.

"This is a first for education and points the way to the government's plans for the classroom of the future," says learning and technology minister Michael Wills, who will announce the scheme at the BETT show tomorrow. "It is essential we make this leap forward in thinking about educational content to keep pace with the hardware - the number of schools connected to the the internet has seen great progress over the past two years."

More free training

Computer chip manufacturer Intel is to quadruple the existing number of places for teachers on its free Teach to the Future ICT training courses. It plans to train a further 24,000 UK teachers this year and 100,000 by 2003, through its regional training centres. Three new centres are opening early this year to add to 17 operating across the UK. The courses are based on a curriculum developed with Oxford University's Department of Educational Studies. For more details, visit the Intel website.

3-in-1 primary site

Spark Island is an interactive online education channel aimed at 3-to 12-year-olds, their parents and teachers. For a £200 annual registration fee, schools will find a range of age-related and curriculum-based learning resources across English, maths and science, as well as lesson plans, articles, news and links to other sites. Spark Island also provides offline resources to print to complement its activities. Parents, who pay £49 a year, can access a series of articles covering everything from curriculum concerns and how to choose a school, to relationship and health matters, as well as a buying guide for books, tapes, software, toys and games. For details and a free trial, visit www.sparkisland.com.

Student communities

Andersen Consulting has designed and launched what it describes as the world's first global student online community destination. Aimed at all higher education students, anything!student offers access to worldwide educational and lifestyle services, covering entertainment, shopping, travel and recruitment. The ideas lab invites student business plans and promises feedback from industry leaders.

Young designers

Classroom D&T stars may want to enter the Young Designers competition, endorsed by the Design Council. The aim is to get 15-to 18-year-olds thinking about the design process, and using their creativity to come up with good design solutions. For more details and a registration form go to www.young-designers.com, email the organisers at young-designers@designevents.co.uk or call 020 7247 6116. Closing date for entries is June 29 2001.

Incredible but true

Sixteen young authors will see their stories transformed by Disney Channel into live dramas and animations as their prize for winning the channel's web-based Incredible Story Studio writing competition. Nine winners spent a day in London with artist Gerald Scarfe to help develop their character for animation, and all entries will be shown on Disney Channel or on its website. The Incredible Story Studio is a programme of work for key stages two and three. Information packs and further details of next year's writing competition are on: www.disneychannel.co.uk/incredible.

History online

History teachers can now subscribe, free of charge, to Teaching History Online, a monthly internet newletter including news, website reviews and articles on using ICT in the history classroom. The November issue features details of the Versailles Peace Treaty project, while the December issue offers extensive coverage of the US presidential elections. To sign up, go to the Spartacus Educational website. You'll also be encouraged to submit your own information for inclusion in future issues.

Websites for kids

Primary teacher and ICT trainer Jim Merrett has put together a list of over 2,000 websites suitable for all subjects and key stages, which includes an extensive professional support section. To get hold of a copy, send £6 to J Merrett, Tamar View, Blindwell Hill, Millbrook, Cornwall PL10 1BG.

notschool.net

Ultralab, part of Anglia Polytechnic University, is piloting notschool.net, a scheme to help 100 Essex and Glaswegian teenagers who can't continue in mainstream education because of exclusion, sickness, phobia and pregnancy. Using the internet, notschool.net provides PCs and a fast internet connection, as well as online tutors and materials targeted to each student's needs.

It also offers each student an undergraduate mentor to build their self-esteem and create opportunities for social interaction online. The pilot will run for 12 months, and a viable model should roll out to schools and LEAs the following year.

fields.headline: Access for all
fields.standfirst: Alan Craig is ICT coordinator at Penryn junior school, Penryn, Cornwall
fields.trailText: Alan Craig is ICT coordinator at Penryn junior school, Penryn, Cornwall.
fields.body:
We have formed a cluster with the eight local primary schools. Three of our own teachers plus one from the feeder college have become trainers for our local NOF training provider, Swift, and serve some 60 teachers.

We have gone from a school with two Pentiums last year to a network of 27 Pentiums, 12 of them in an ICT suite. Each class has a networked computer, and there are computers in the office and library.

If you want to boost teachers' confidence and competence in using ICT, you have to make sure they have proper access to the equipment! All our staff can get at student records and do all their admin and lesson preparation from anywhere in the school.

A "one size fits all" approach to training does not work. We provide a "menu" of courses from which teachers select the ones they'll find most useful. All the courses are voluntary twilight sessions and cover both software applications and hardware, such as how to use an interactive whiteboard (we own two). We also offer training in how to use ICT so as to embed it into the curriculum, not just as a bolt-on activity. We run "top-up" or surgery sessions for teachers who missed some training or need extra hand-holding.

Our approach works: a year ago, just two of our teachers were comfortable with computers; now it's all 13! We're even working with undergraduates from a local art and design college on our website.

fields.headline: The portfolio approach
fields.standfirst: David Fettes is ICT coordinator at Mandeville Primary School, Northolt, Middlesex, for pupils with severe learning difficulties
fields.trailText: David Fettes is ICT coordinator at Mandeville Primary School, Northolt, Middlesex, for pupils with severe learning difficulties.
fields.body:
We wanted some flexibility from our NOF training but also a definite goal to aim for. So we also picked mPowerNet as our provider, a company that uses the portfolio approach. With the need to complete a portfolio, teachers have been staying after school to complete tasks, booking me for in-class support and working on it at home.

The portfolio is manageable because it's broken down into individual tasks. It's also been helpful to have face-to-face training rather than on-line provision, at least for now.

We also decided to use directed time for the input as much as possible, which has meant planning at least a year ahead.

Our programme is not unduly complicated, although we find it important to keep detailed records on staff progress and chase people up from time to time.

When going in for NOF training, schools need to know that it isn't designed for teachers without basic skills. You have to decide that a topic has been covered only when there is a portfolio item to prove it. This all takes time - mostly after school. Managing the training is a huge job in addition to your normal workload.

But it's worth it - following our start last September we're doing many more things using Word, the internet, multimedia, and spreadsheet work.
