webTitle: Training first-hand: Take a little at a time

fields.headline: Take a little at a time
fields.standfirst: Francesca Crocker is the school librarian at Cardinal Vaughan Memorial school, London, a Catholic comprehensive with 900 boys
fields.trailText: Francesca Crocker is the school librarian at Cardinal Vaughan Memorial school, London, a Catholic comprehensive with 900 boys.
fields.body:
I decided to use Graham Small's Training For School Librarians as the NOF training provider for myself and my assistant. He set out targets clearly, and was always practical. Unlike other trainers I've met, he wasn't vague: I could see exactly where I was going! Personal experience or recommendation is very important when it comes to choosing a training provider.

After training I have lost my fear of computing, and have started to bring the library to the pupils - and even their parents - through the school's intranet.

I have also trained others to evaluate websites. I'm developing a library without walls, and making the library play a much more central role. For me, NOF training has been the best government initiative yet. And I only started it in April.

It's important to choose training providers who are experts in their area in order to inspire confidence. Also, the course should be in small stages: if you get too much information at one go, your self-confidence could be undermined. And it's important that schools plan and coordinate all their ICT training with heads of department and the school librarian.
fields.bodyText: I decided to use Graham Small's Training For School Librarians as the NOF training provider for myself and my assistant. He set out targets clearly, and was always practical. fields.headline: Face-to-face
fields.standfirst: Sue Patterson is head of Miers Court County Primary School, Rainham, Gillingham, which has just over 400 pupils
fields.trailText: Sue Patterson is head of Miers Court County Primary School, Rainham, Gillingham, which has just over 400 pupils.
fields.body:
We chose mPowerNet for training because of its face-to-face learning approach. We are following a tight timescale - within just a year we cover one main topic each term.

The first one has been basic training covering applications like PowerPoint and control technology.

Next term we'll be starting on primary English, and in the term after primary maths.

I've put all 15 teachers down for the programme, plus myself. I think it's important for the learning support assistants to be involved, and so we'll be cascading our new-found skills and knowledge down to them as well.

Although the main training consisted of two-hour twilight sessions (in our ICT suite), I also booked the trainer for half-days so that staff could be released from teaching for 30 minutes at a time to discuss problems with him.

We've found that there is not enough time in each session to think about what we've covered. Sometimes we've done two topics in an evening, but on reflection I should prefer just one topic per evening.

The school already had pockets of staff who were ICT-literate, but the training has made that more general. Since September we've made progress at a very fast pace. The staff are much more competent and confident, and that's reflected in the fact that they are doing classroom activities they wouldn't have dreamt of doing before. Also, staff now plan ICT together far more so than they ever used to.

In future, we're going to try to incorporate learning support assistants and administrative staff on a more formal basis, and we have some exciting projects planned, like ideas for parents on how to help their children with word processing.

fields.headline: Missed opportunity
fields.standfirst: Teachers' lack of time and equipment are just two of the problems besetting the government's ICT training scheme
fields.trailText: Teachers' lack of time and equipment are just two of the problems besetting the government's ICT training scheme.
fields.body:
Martin Reeves has parted with a lot of cash lately - and it's not only been on Christmas presents. Since September, as ICT manager at Testwood school in Hampshire, he has been helping to spend Testwood's share of the £230m of lottery funding allocated to support the training of teachers in ICT.

"It's very well received," he says. The Testwood staff are being trained by an Open University/RM consortium which is just one of the hundreds of ICT training providers recruited by the New Opportunities Fund (NOF) to deliver the training.

The project was announced in 1998 and is the biggest training exercise since the civilian population was taught how to use gas masks in 1939. It's almost certainly the most ambitious ICT training undertaken anywhere in the world, aiming to train Britain's 500,000 teachers and librarians in computer skills by 2003.

And this isn't basic skills training. There's no "This is a keyboard and this is a mouse". Right from the start the Teacher Training Agency specification demanded subject-based skills that teachers could use to enhance their teaching. And that led to the first brickbat.

"They came up with a perfectly valid specification for people who already had basic skills," one expert said at the time. But research by the Technology Colleges Trust showed that three out of four teachers did not have those skills. There were concerns about the scale of the project. Would there be enough trainers? Would enough companies come forward to bid for the contracts?

"There were genuine worries at the introduction," said Richard Hill at NOF. "But we've got a good set of providers who are doing good things." And at the Teacher Training Agency there is also a sense that the project has cleared those early hurdles.

"It was inevitable that we were going to learn," said the agency's Tim Tarrant. "None of us had ever run a programme like this before."

The agency has been undertaking a quality audit of the training providers and feels that they are doing a good job.

"Some training providers underestimated the scale of the task and some have taken time to get up to speed," said Tarrant. "But there's been a range of feedback with some unanimously positive."

"On the whole it's going well," said one experienced trainer in the north. But trainers have come across schools where lack of time and inadequate resources have devalued the quality of the training experience.

The NOF money is for training only; unlike other government initiatives, such as the literacy hour, no supply cover is attached. As a result teachers have to be trained outside the school day, either on a distance learning basis at home, or after school, in twilight sessions.

"Many schools insist on twilight sessions," said one trainer. "I've had a teacher who was supervising a detention while doing the training."

Many schools have started training with inadequate ICT resources, despite guidelines which say local education authorities should not release training money until schools have shown they are ready.

"Much of the New Opportunities Fund's training is built on the notion that teachers will have access to ICT," said David Hart at the National Association of Headteachers. "The government target that every school will be on the internet by 2002 simply means that, in the case of a primary school, they could just have one computer in the library and that will meet the government's criteria. It will not meet the needs of the teachers."

Even in secondary schools with ICT networks in place, the pressure on machines is such that teachers find it difficult to do their training in the manner envisaged by training consortia.

Capita's Learning Network has been well received in many schools. At its heart is a conferencing system, encouraging sharing of ideas and problems by email. Teachers get a set of CD-Roms to take them through a variety of tasks and are monitored by a mentoring team.

But participants' feelings about the effectiveness of the training are often mixed.

"The stuff is good," said Julie Bridges (not her real name), who teaches in the West Midlands. "I have used it at school lunchtimes with a small group - it was great, it's just the pressure to do it in your own time."

Ms Bridges is developing her training at lunchtimes because her secondary school has ICT rooms which are "block-booked" on the timetable for use by other departments.

The Capita programme expects teachers to devote two to three hours a week to the training over three five-week blocks. It's expected that the bulk of this will be in the classroom working with children, but for Bridges and thousands of other teachers it does not work out that way. She has been working on the materials at home and after school. "It's finding the two to three hours a week," she said.

Her concern about the lack of time is echoed by Andrew Moore, an advisory teacher for ICT in the East Riding of Yorkshire.

"Most teachers will argue that it's difficult to find the time for this," he said. "Twilight sessions simply mean that people defer all the other jobs that they have to get done between end of school and midnight."

Some schools have clearly started their NOF training before they were ready. Schools want to see the training completed and are worried that they need to be in on the act at the beginning.

Teachers are aware that ICT training is one of the criteria for passing through the performance threshold. It could be something that heads will expect to see on the CV of staff applying for promoted posts.

There's pressure from outside, too. Training providers need to see a revenue stream in place and the government has made this year's Standards Fund monies for ICT-related projects conditional on an ongoing or completed NOF training programme.

The result has been a rush to sign up. The Teacher Training Agency estimates that more than 200,000 teachers have signed up for the training, possibly before their schools are ready to benefit from it.

This is a point acknowledged by the agency. Yet schools do not even have to begin the process until 2002.

"Schools shouldn't feel pressurised to sign up," said NOF's Richard Hill. "There is no point doing the training until the school has adequate hardware and software - we've been trying quite hard to get that message across."

Back at Testwood school, Martin Reeves is happy with the training package chosen. The OU/RM training offers a mix of face-to-face and distance learning and his staff are using the opportunity to move their skills forward.

But Testwood has "some of the best facilities in Hampshire", with seven ICT suites and 150 machines. Reeves is quite clear on the basic issue: "To do good quality training you do need the equipment to do the job properly." To which Julie Bridges would no doubt add: " and the time".

webTitle: Teachers at understaffed school vote for 'no cover' policy

fields.headline: Teachers at understaffed school vote for 'no cover' policy
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The nationwide teacher shortage bit harder last night as staff voted to refuse to cover for vacancies and illness at a hard hit school.
fields.body:
The nationwide teacher shortage bit harder last night as staff voted to refuse to cover for vacancies and illness at a hard hit school.

As most pupils in England returned to school after the Christmas break, further indications emerged of what unions insist is a recruitment and retention crisis.

At Christ Church secondary school, Barnet, north London, members of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers balloted to take industrial action next week.

The school, which is in special measures, was eight teachers short of its required complement of 42 teachers last term.

Union members will refuse to take lessons left without a teacher because of illness or because the school has been unable to recruit. Out of 22 NASUWT members at the school, 14 voted in favour of the action and none against.

The NASUWT general secretary, Nigel de Gruchy, said: "While this might cause short-term inconvenience to pupils and parents, it is necessary to take such action to shake the government out of its complacent attitude towards the teacher supply crisis."

The National Union of Teachers has threatened similar action in schools with staff shortages.

Barnet council has drawn up contingency plans to bring in school inspectors to cover lessons at the school. A spokeswoman, Alison Moore, said: "We are in discussions with the union to resolve the situation. We are doing everything we can to avoid closing schools or reducing the school week to four days."

In Swindon, Wiltshire, Hreod school told parents last night it is to shorten the school day on Wednesdays to cope with shortages. From next Wednesday, classes will finish at 1.30pm, lessons will be cut from an hour to 50 minutes and the lunch break from an hour to 30 minutes.

Andrew Fleet, the headteacher, said the move would free teachers for one afternoon a week. He filled three vacancies over Christmas but is still short of full time teachers in science, English, religious education, and PE, and of a part time art teacher.

At Headlands school, a mile and a half away, pupils in years seven to nine are having an afternoon away from school this week because despite filling four vacancies over the holidays, it is still short of four full time staff.

The head, John Wells, who is interviewing candidates today, said last night he was hopeful he could get back to a full timetable next week.

webTitle: The educational gap grows between boys and girls

fields.headline: The greater divide
fields.standfirst: Top freshers are again female and the gender gap is still growing, says  Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: Top freshers are again female and the gender gap is still growing, says Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
The educational divide between the sexes continues to grow, with female students making up an ever larger share of the freshers entering university with the best A-level grades this year.

According to the latest official statistics for students enrolling last October, women accounted for 55% of degree entrants with As and Bs in their A-levels, and 56% of those with six or more Scottish Highers.

The figures confirm a steady trend over the last decade, reflecting the better performance of girls throughout the education system, from GCSE and A-level results to university graduation rates. A once male-dominated academic world has been transformed: women made up 54% of all degree applicants for the 2000 academic year.

It is particularly among the students with the highest A-level grades from state schools and further education colleges where girls outnumber boys. Nearly three out of five new degree students from the state sector with at least an A and two Bs in their A-levels were female this year.

This contrasts with the results at independent schools and grant maintained schools, which produce roughly equal numbers of girls and boys with top A-level grades.

Overall just under 26,000 female students enrolled with at least 26 A-level points, compared with just over 21,000 male students. Women accounted for 55% of top graded entrants in 2000, compared with 53.5% in 1999, and 51% in 1996, according to figures from the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service.

The gaping educational gender divide is likely to cause further concerns for education ministers, who have already unveiled plans to recruit more male teachers in schools to provide role models for boys.

Other official statistics for universities show that women are less likely to drop out of degree courses than men, all other things being equal. Women also now make up a larger proportion of graduates with upper seconds and firsts.

It may come as some comfort to ministers that the same educational trends are being experienced in the US and Ireland, however.

The gender split emerges as the clearest trend in an otherwise familiar set of enrolment figures. As with the previous year, under half of all university applicants came from the managerial and professional classes in 2000, with three quarters of the 389,000 applicants being white and state schools again producing a quarter of all university applicants.

The academic institutions with the highest female enrolments reflect a preference among women students for the arts and social sciences.

At Goldsmiths College, 70% of new degree entrants were female, while a cluster of institutions attracted three out of five applications from women including Ulster, Middlesex, Glasgow Caledonian, Keele, Manchester Metropolitan and Bangor universities.

Institutions attracting less than two out of five applications from women were mainly those recognised for their strengths in science and technology and sport: Imperial College, London, Umist, Heriot-Watt and Loughborough.

The University of Bristol emerges as the most popular university in the UK, receiving 35,000 applications - just over 12 for every place available. Other popular institutions included the London School of Economics (more than 11 applications for every place) and Warwick University (just under 10 applications for every place).

At the other end of the spectrum, the University of Central Lancashire and University of Wales, Lampeter, attracted fewer than three applications per place.

Cambridge is proving more popular - among men and women - than Oxford. Both universities had roughly 3,250 places available, but Cambridge received 12,000 applications, compared with only 9700 attracted by Oxford. (Students are not allowed to apply to both universities.)

Cambridge's intake for 2000 was 48% women students - up 3% on the previous year. At Oxford, meanwhile, 46% of the undergraduate enrolments were female.

webTitle: Teachers that won't be going back to school

fields.headline: I quit
fields.standfirst: As the teacher shortage brings talk of a four-day week for pupils,  Bob Hewitt  and  Carmel Fitzsimons explain why they are leaving the job they love
fields.trailText: As the teacher shortage brings talk of a four-day week for pupils, Bob Hewitt and Carmel Fitzsimons explain why they are leaving the job they love
fields.body:
Carmel Fitzsimons qualified last week, but there's no way she's going to be a teacher

This week, buried in the post with the last limping Christmas cards, came a thin brown envelope containing a certificate. It says, simply, that I am now a Newly Qualified Teacher.

Standing in the hall I felt quite young, being new at something again. Then came the deep swelling ocean of gratitude that it was over. After almost two years of two days a week in London schools, countless essays and assignments, and the almost unbearable tension of 10 weeks' teaching practice, I have this tissue-fine piece of paper in my hands saying I've made it.

If I had been going to start this term as a class teacher I would probably have gone whooping down to the kitchen to interrupt the kids' breakfast with my great news. As it was, I put the letter in the drawer where I fondly hide the letters from boyfriends who I'd rather liked but realised were not really good for me. It's a cul-de-sac place sort of place.

It's a way of saying that I have worked out that I cannot do it. I can do a morning of metaphor or help on a trip to the mosaics at St Albans but I can't do the day-in, no-nights-out stuff. Not for any snooty reason like I can't stand teachers or the pay is rubbish, but because it turned out to be too hard.

When I was clocking up 12-hour days in school I became a pharmacist's dream, with every stress-related ailment from 3am sleeplessness through killer cold sores to phantom marking at parties. I found myself congratulating my mother-in-law for sitting so nicely at the table. The job was so tough that waitressing 16-hour shifts at the Cats' Whiskers in Purley was transformed in my memory into the working equivalent of a day in a jacuzzi with Antonio Banderas.

It started out so well. I took on the training partly because my Irish emigrant parents had instilled in us that teaching was an honourable profession. My sister had done it without a murmur of complaint, but that might have been because I wasn't really listening. I was also idealistic - wanting to give something back, thinking I could help children from underprivileged families, like my own, to turn their lives around.

Perhaps I was naive when I took up the course. It was part-time, so I could still look after my four children and keep up a bit of journalism, which had been my career for 15 years. I had just won a poetry prize and was putting together an anthology for children and I needed to know more about what children were reading. I thought, what with the short school day and the holidays, maybe I could be the Playstation generation Renaissance woman and teach and inspire daily, write in the evening and perhaps fit in poetry in my spare time.

What I discovered is that the job itself is the root of the teacher shortage. You can train as many teachers as you like but once they have taken a good hard look at what it involves, few will go for it. There is hope for the young and single and also for those older people who never had families or whose children have long flown the nest. But for anyone who thinks teaching is a family-friendly profession - forget it.

A friend who trained as a mature teacher a couple of years ago but is not teaching, said: "The hours were a nightmare, and when I was not in school I was preparing. I could not get time off to go with my toddler to settle him into nursery and I could not make my older child's parent-teacher evening because we had one, too. Every other job I have ever had has been a thousand times more flexible."

Certainly the rigidity of school timetabling is a nightmare. You can only go to the toilet when it's break, only phone when it's break and lunch is usually a chance to fix the overhead projector. A teacher's regular diet is Tesco Bourbon biscuits. Although the school day is short, most teachers are in at 7.30am and do not leave until 12 hours later. Then they mark. They work in the holidays, their children go to and from school with child-minders, and worst of all, they worry.

As one trainee teacher who decided not to pursue it said to me, "I thought that I would meet loads of creative Dead Poets' Society people but I just met people who were really into tick-boxes. All the emphasis was on super-organisation."

I don't think teachers are uncreative - but creativity is being crushed out of them by the grinding cogs of bureaucracy and filing.

To give you a glimpse: for every lesson a teacher is supposed to prepare assessment sheets from the previous lesson; they must then reflect upon the issues the assessment throws up. Then they must prepare a lesson plan - based on long-term, medium-term and short-term objectives from the curriculum; and having delivered the lesson, they must write up an evaluation of how the lesson went and then individually assess the progression of each child's learning. This can mean five sheets of written paper per lesson for each of the five lessons a day. Add the individual record of each child, the reading records and the collection of money for the school trip and you start to wonder whether there is any time left for getting your coat on before legging it across the playground.

The final straw was the parents. Most of the children were so interesting that I could easily have taken out adoption papers. Even the ones who were sticking lead pencils in each other's legs and who made me cry when they would not listen. But the parents! They swore at teachers as if we were worse than traffic wardens. They thought nothing of taking kids out every Friday to "go down the caravan" and the only cultural experience they worshipped was shopping.

I look at the wonderful cards my classes have sent me, one with each child making a paper flower to create a bouquet, another a gallery with each child's self-portrait. It's a shame that while schools should be places where all of us can offer our talents, they have become arid academies where only the most totally efficient can survive.I have to say that while in so many ways I love teaching, it is so much easier just writing about it.

Bob Hewitt has taught for 30 years, but this will be his last

I'm a man of principle. And I'm so dim it hurts. Not long ago, we had our open evening for prospective pupils. The school was decked out with displays, the head gave the same speech twice, and the dance teacher and I shared a large classroom from which all furniture had been cleared except three rows of chairs. The place was packed. Thirty pupils put on dance displays while their teacher attended to the CD player. I did a couple of drama sessions.

A father sought me out afterwards. "Excellent," he said. "They were hanging on your every word. It's a pleasure to meet you." I lowered my eyes - I'm leaving at Easter. I also put off the dozen kids who were clamouring to know about the next school play - I don't know if there'll be one.

For 30 years, I've tried every way I know to stay in teaching because a) I need an income, and b) I've grown to be bloody brilliant at it. I mean, I'm a 56-year-old drama teacher, and the kids still tell me I'm cool.

But every year, it has got harder to stay on. I have left jobs in the past: once in the 1980s, when I refused to write a new syllabus I didn't believe in; and again in 1993, when, as an English teacher, I refused to follow the national curriculum (I'd rather be a motorbike courier). And once, in 1996, a contract was not renewed because, though the head said I was a brilliant teacher, he thought I'd get the place shut down when Ofsted came. But now, I am leaving for good.

Lesson plans are the problem. They were an excellent discipline when I was a student. I once spent two hours in 1970 getting the words right for the plan for the 40-minute lesson my tutor was going to see. I laid my plan on the desk the following day as the lesson began, and the next time I looked at it was after the bell had gone. I hadn't abandoned it as a policy decision. I'd forgotten it. There and then I resolved never to write one again (and I still got a double distinction for my PGCE).

Despite my lack of planning, I became head of drama at a local comprehensive in 1998. Drama is not a national curriculum subject, so I was delighted to take the job. I started in November. Ofsted came a week later.

I was teaching a year 11 GCSE class who'd had no teacher since June. My first priority was to give them some success, so we did lots of basic master-and-servant work. The inspector who watched the lesson failed it on both attainment and progress, but he hastened to calm me all the same. "Don't worry," he said. "You wrought a marvellous transformation in the first five minutes. You'll do wonders with them." But the school as a whole was placed in special measures. Out went the head. In came a new man. A straight-down-the-line, this-is-how-it-is, I-take-no-prisoners man.

When could he see me teach? Any lesson he wanted, just come in. I saw him a fortnight later at the back of the hall. He stood there for 10 minutes, then came forward to shake my hand. "Thank you, Bob, for the wonderful things you're doing for the children in this school," he said in front of all my year 8s. That was 11 months ago.

In March this year, however, he implemented a new Ofsted recommendation. All teachers were to write lesson plans broken down into five-minute segments. My heart sank.

How could I tell the head that I won't write lesson plans because I was right when I was 26? How can I tell him that I need my sleep, and that writing lesson plans would send me barmy inside a fortnight (hands up anyone who doesn't know of a teacher who's had a nervous breakdown). So I explain instead that much of my drama work is spontaneous. The only thing I know about any lesson is how I'm going to begin. Because the only way kids will perform spontaneously is if I set them the example.

But the head was unimpressed. Of course he was. We were in special measures. His instruction to all staff to write lesson plans in five-minute segments was a recommendation from our very own senior inspector. How could he have made an exception for me?

I refused to comply. A former pupil, Lee Simpson, came up from London for my disciplinary hearing. A Comedy Store player for 10 years, he explained that even when he taught at the National Theatre the only thing he knew in advance was the first thing he was going to do.

But Lee's evidence made no difference. The book of National Teaching Standards dictates that all lessons be planned. So I was up before the school governors. Twenty former pupils wrote to tell them what a great teacher I am, but they gave me a final written warning. I appealed. My appeal was turned down. The final ultimatum came: I must write lesson plans.

I love this job very much, but my instinct was just to let go. "Refusal to comply with a reasonable instruction is professional misconduct." Amen! Oh, amen! What a blessed release dismissal would be! But I have year 11s coming up to their GCSEs next spring, and if I continue to refuse to write the plans the head can't guarantee that I'll be allowed to stay that long. So although there's far less glory walking out the door than being thrown out, I will be writing lesson plans long enough to ensure that I can remain until Easter, and have resigned from that date.

Lesson plans are as good a peg as any upon which to hang up my coat. Although the £2,000 threshold would do just as well; or the health and safety rules that have banned my most challenging trust-exercise even though I've used it for 20 years without accident; or the new reward systems that are just cheap bribes; or the setting of targets that have nothing to do with educating children, and everything to do with performance-related pay; or the management's fear of Ofsted; or the new culture of improving all schools by encouraging pupils to inform on their mates.

To see schools these days as filled just with bureaucratic bullshit is to seriously miss the point, however. Education has traditionally been about freedom. But there is no freedom anymore. It's gone. Initiative and resourcefulness are banned. Every school has become a part of the gulag. How else could inspectors time the literacy hour with stopwatches, or a teacher be dismissed over a bit of missing paperwork?

It's all right for me to say so, mind. I've no more mortgage to pay. The head and the governors want me to stay, and my colleagues urge me to stick with it. "Just write the blooming lesson plans, Bob! The kids still need what you have to offer!" Well, maybe, but they'll get by.

I'm not happy about leaving. I was hoping to find out whether I could still be cool at 65. And I don't know how to tell my pupils I'm going. And if that father sends his kid to this school because he liked the look of the drama teacher, I won't be here to teach him. But I value my sanity too much to stay. And one thing's for sure: they cannot run gulags on their own.

webTitle: Competitions: Award-winners with the wow factor

fields.headline: Award-winners with the wow factor
fields.standfirst: Win cash prizes, software or hardware in three Guardian-supported competitions
fields.trailText: Win cash prizes, software or hardware in three Guardian-supported competitions.
fields.body:
Becta/Guardian Website Awards

Hurry, hurry, hurry, you only have one term left to enter the 2001 Becta/Guardian school and college website awards.

In this, the competition's third year, schools and colleges are again being asked to enter parts of a website or a whole site by April 13 and win substantial hardware and software prizes provided by the sponsors ntl, RM, ICL and Granada Learning.

This year's awards comprise four categories split up into primary, secondary and post-16 age groups: The awards categories:

School/College award
For whole websites that demonstrate a range of key factors, including: community involvement; an understanding of target audiences; and a promotion of inclusive approaches, ensuring accessibility for all.

Learners' award
Showcasing a range of pupils' or students' work that is part of a website, or of individual pages, and is either individual or collaborative in its approach.

Teaching Resources award
For teaching and learning materials that are part of a website, or individual pages, which can be used by other teachers, lecturers, students and pupils. Within each of the above awards there will be separate categories for primary, secondary and post-16.

Webnose Day award (Open to all aged under 18.)
Entries to this category need to show creativity, group work and community involvement. They should show both the serious and the fun side of Comic Relief and demonstrate fund-raising activities related to Red Nose Day (March 16 2001).

To enter the awards and find out about previous winning entries, look up www.becta.org.uk/websiteawards to register your interest. Email queries should be sent to webawards@becta.org.uk

BT's FutureTalk School Awards

Now into their second year, these awards, in association with the Guardian, offer schools the chance to win large cash prizes for innovative communication projects using low- or high-tech ICT to deliver part of the national curriculum.

Prizes of either £5,000 or £25,000 are on offer to groups of schools (two or more) that can come up with ideas (basic or advanced) combining imagination, flair and the "wow" factor. They need to be ideas that other schools can learn from and replicate.

Eighteen awards totalling around £300,000 were presented last year, benefiting some 5,000 pupils from 47 primary and secondary schools. A similar amount is waiting to be awarded in the current academic year. The awards are aimed at pupils at key stage two, three and four (P2-S4 in Scotland) in schools ranging from those starting to grapple with ICT to those technologically well advanced.

Take a look at the BT website which gives examples of the type of project ideas expected and full details of how to enter. It also includes a section on past winners, plus details of the BT FutureTalk roadshow which uses drama groups in schools to promote communications and the use of ICT as a teaching tool. These groups will be in the following areas until February 16 this year: Lincolnshire (Bury); Salford; Wiltshire (Swindon); Leicester; North Yorkshire; Devon (Plymouth).

Get a feel for what the BT/Guardian FutureTalk awards are all about by ringing 0870 3330373 to find out about drama group visits at a school near you.

Life Long Learning Awards

A sister awards scheme to the BT FutureTalk Awards, aimed this time at sixth formers, further education colleges, universities and libraries is BT's Life Long Learning Awards, also supported by the Guardian and launched at the beginning of last term.

Cash prizes of between £25,000 and £75,000 will go to institutions devising new learning opportunities for their local communities using ICT. Awards for the first tranche will be announced shortly and entries for the second phase may be submitted between February 19 and May 4 2001. The scheme is a revamped version of BT's earlier further and higher ICT awards.

For clues as to what makes a typical winner, visit the scheme's website through which schools need to enter the scheme. One example was an online care training scheme, based on a virtual hospital ward, designed for nurses, midwives and pre-hospital students.

fields.headline: Seeking the best
fields.standfirst: Bahram Bekhradnia is a very British - but very untypical - civil servant, as Huw Richards  discovers
fields.trailText: Bahram Bekhradnia is a very British - but very untypical - civil servant, as Huw Richards discovers
fields.body:
The publication deadline passed with the old year, the census date of March 31 looms. Soon the Research Assessment Exercise will pass out of the hands of universities and into those of the assessment panels.

The fifth assessment exercise is the third presided over by Bahram Bekhradnia, the Higher Education Funding Council for England's director of policy. Bekhradnia, 52, worked at the then Department of Education and Science for nearly 20 years, but is far from being the archetypal civil servant. He is disposed to talk to journalists rather than brandish a clove of garlic and shuffle them off towards the nearest press officer and has a longstanding taste for colourful bow-ties. In his early days at the department he was a DJ with a mobile disco purveying 60s sounds - a role he reprised recently for birthday parties.

Nor are many senior British public servants natives of Iran. Bekhradnia came here at 18 months after his father was blinded in a local war between Iran and the Soviet Union over influence in Azerbaijan. "He came first for medical treatment, then he and my mother decided life would be better for him here than in Iran," Bekhradnia explains.

Those origins supplied his name - he recalls without apparent rancour that Mark Carlisle, Secretary of State for Education and Science from 1979 to 1981, was incapable of remembering it and addressed him as "Bannerjee" - and a passion for Iranian food.

Otherwise there are few traces of his roots. He speaks only "pidgin Farsi", explaining: "My parents were very concerned that I should be immersed as far as possible in the English way of life, to the extent of sending me away to boarding school."

Their policy was spectacularly successful. He won a scholarship to Wellington College, read classics at University College, Oxford, and for the last decade has been one of the key figures in the formation of English higher education policy - influence now reinforced by having been at the funding council far longer than any other comparably senior figure. "I have become part of the corporate memory - the person who points out that we did something five years ago, or alternately that we didn't and why."

He predates the higher funding council having joined the Universities Funding Council from the department in 1991. His last Whitehall job was dealing with teacher shortages, an area of such sensitivity that it is little wonder he appears capable of coping with most higher education complexities in a genial, relaxed manner. It also helped crystallise some discomfort with Whitehall traditions. "What I found very difficult was the constraint on the way you think and talk. You had to stick very closely to the policy line."

He has enjoyed the funding council more. "I have found it very liberating. Hefce straddles the two worlds of the civil service and academia, but it is close to academics, has always been led by them and has been influenced by their attitude to open discussion."

Part of his job is to supply information on which those debates and decisions can be based. "The other directorates cover finance and corporate affairs, and relations with institutions. That leaves me with the sector-wide issues - examples are our recent research review, committees I chaired on East European studies and Chinese studies, the Joint Information Systems committee and the development of policies on access and participation. I should hate people to think that the Research Assessment Exercise is all that I do," he says.

Even so he does not flinch when described as "the architect of the RAE". He notes that the assessment exercise is not a policy in itself, but a device for the implementation of a policy - selective research funding. "We need a system which is transparent, based on academic judgments and gives us a basis for those judgments. I am aware of its weaknesses, but my challenge to critics is to suggest a better, equally rational way of identifying excellence and then funding it."

And the council has been responsive to concerns about the exercise, he says. "A good example was after the 1992 exercise where there were very strong representations that the publications count was encouraging premature and excessive publication and we decided to stop collecting that information."

While accepting that the salience of the assessment exercise may have led to the downgrading of non-RAE activity, he argues that it is up to the universities to ensure that those activities are recognised and rewarded.

An inhabitant of that well-known academic stronghold, north Oxford, Bekhradnia understands some professional grievances. webTitle: Charities call for internet training funds

fields.headline: Charities call for internet training funds
fields.trailText: Two leading children's charities are calling on the government to fund internet training for all social workers and criminal justice professionals to prevent paedophiles from using the technology to ensnare children. By David Batty
fields.body:
Two leading children's charities are calling on the government to fund internet training for all social workers and criminal justice professionals to prevent paedophiles from using the technology to ensnare children.

The joint proposal by the NCH, formerly the National Children's Homes, and the National Society also calls for new legislation to prosecute people who use electronic means, such as websites and internet chat rooms, to misrepresent their age with the view to meeting children.

The charities have formed a working party with the Association of Chief Police Officers (ACPO), the Association of Chief Officers of Probation (ACOP) and the Association of Directors of Social Services, which is meeting on February 19 to finalise the proposals.

John Carr, internet adviser at the NCH and co-ordinator of the campaign, said the proposals would extend existing internet training for teachers.

"We are dealing with a generation of social workers and probation officers for whom the internet is a foreign country," said Mr Carr.

He said the first step was to raise professionals' awareness of the technology, explaining what an internet service provider or a browser is. They would then need to know how to check whether the internet was being used to ensnare children.

"If there was an internet connection in a home where there was a child protection investigation, a social worker will need to be able to check whether it was being used to download hard core pornography to groom potential victims, for example," explained Mr Carr.

"Similarly a probation officer working with an offender would need to check whether their use of the internet was likely to lead to them re-offending."

"We want adults who misrepresent their age to a legal minor with a view to meeting them in the real world using electronic means to be prosecuted, as a deterrent," he added.

But Keith Akerman, chairman of the Association of Chief Police Officers' computer crime working group, said while he agreed with this idea in principle, it was difficult to legislate against paedophiles' grooming techniques.

He said: "We would have to look carefully at how this would be introduced into law."

Mr Akerman said current legislation was sufficient to tackle paedophiles using the internet but admitted there were limited police resources to tackle the problem.

He said:"The medium inhibits traditional police investigation. We need to establish where the risks lie - chat rooms and email. How on earth do you monitor that effectively? Internet training has to be the start."

webTitle: Why Swede into Turnip won't go

fields.headline: Why Swede into Turnip won't go
fields.standfirst: Sven-Goran Eriksson's resignation from Lazio was kind of inevitable, writes Sean Ingle, but it doesn't make him a bad coach
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson's resignation from Lazio was kind of inevitable, writes Sean Ingle, but it doesn't make him a bad coach
fields.body:
If their portly frames could manage it, one or two members of the England press pack would have no doubt broken into cartwheels of xenophobic joy on hearing of Sven-Goran Eriksson's resignation from Lazio this morning.

Several of them are deeply suspicious of a foreign manager. But now that he can be branded a failure they have suddenly chirped up. Take the Mirror this morning. "England bosses used to arrive as winners and then make a mess of itnot any more. We've got a loser from day one," chief football writer Harry Harris opined. "Eriksson will arrive not only perceived as a failure, but with a Lazio record to match."

Cue Rule Britannia, God Save the Queen and yet another inquisition into why England needs another foreign coach.

But Eriksson is hardly a loser. In his three and a half years at Lazio he won the Scudetto - the first time the club had won it for 26 years - two Italian cups and the Cup Winners' Cup. It's just that this season he's suffered from the curse that seems to inflict managers and players when they agree to move on at the end of the season, while staying put at their present club. Something bad just seems to happen.

Take a look at Marcello Lippi - the man once rated by Alex Ferguson as "the best coach in Europe." By the start of the 1998/1999 season he had taken Juventus to Champions League title and won three Scudetto's in four years (1995, 1997 and 1998). Then he announced he was off to Internazionale and his team stopped playing for him. Halfway through the season he was sacked.

In such cases the press expects failure, and failure almost inevitably results. So when Eriksson was unveiled as the new England coach back in October, you needn't have to be Nostradamus to predict stormy seas lay ahead.

And that's what happened. Despite a good run in early November, as soon as Lazio began to stumble - and that's all it was: they are fifth in Serie A and still in the Champions League - the ghost of Lippi's failure began to loom.

Eriksson has been unlucky too. He lost key players such as Claudio Lopez and Juan Veron to injury. And he also had to cope with having Sergio Conceicao and Matias Almeyda - respectively the width and the stability in his midfield - snatched from him in the summer, so that Lazio president Sergio Cragnotti could splash out on Hernan Crespo, his £35m plaything. As a result of Cragnotti's actions Lazio's double-winning side of last season has become completely unbalanced.

Perhaps even more importantly, Eriksson also lost his assistant Tord Grip - the man often described as "one half of Eriksson's brain", when he took up his post with the FA to prepare the ground for Eriksson's arrival.

That hasn't helped, and nor has the sight of city-rivals Roma, practically comatose for the last decade, charging away with the league. The first time there's been a clear favourite for the Serie A title in years.

So when you hear the Daily Mail's Jeff Powell ranting on tomorrow - he's the man who greeted Eriksson's appointment by claiming: "England's humiliation knows no end. We've sold our birthright down the river to a nation of seven millions skiiers and hammer throwers who spend half their lives in darkness" - remember the facts.

Eriksson isn't a failure. His record of four trophies in three years is better than any Premiership manager bar Alex Ferguson - and it towers above those of Kevin Keegan, Glenn Hoddle, Terry Venables and Graham Taylor when they took charge.

One bad month or two doesn't make a bad manager. England expects, and Eriksson will do his duty - by getting the team into the World Cup play-offs.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Call for legislative change to end child abuse on internet

fields.headline: Call for legislative change to end child abuse on internet
fields.trailText: Calls for new laws and internet training for social workers and probation officers to prevent paedophiles from ensnaring victims online follows several cases where children have been abused by men they first met on the net. David Batty reports
fields.body:
Calls for new laws and internet training for social workers and probation officers to prevent paedophiles from ensnaring victims online follows several cases where children have been abused by men they first met on the net.

Children's charities the NCH, formerly National Children's Homes, and the NSPCC believe the offences show that it should be illegal for adults to use electronic means to conceal their true identity from a legal minor in order to meet them.

Patrick Green, who abused a 13-year-old girl after posing as a 15-year-old boy to meet her, became the first person convicted for this type of offence last October. The 33-year-old exports clerk from Buckinghamshire was jailed for five years after luring the girl her to his home following a succession of online chats and emails.

But gaps in current legislation were exposed last April when a 47-year-old man who arranged to meet a 13-year-old girl after posing as a 15-year-old boy in an internet chat room was arrested but released without charge by Thames Valley Police, as they concluded no crime had been committed.

The girl's mother, from Milton Keynes, Buckinghamshire accompanied her daughter when she met the "boy" but contacted the police when she saw how old he was. After the man was released, she said: "I think the police should be given more powers and something like this should be a crime."

A Home Office spokesman said conspiracy, incitement or attempts to commit gross indecency with a child under 14, whether on or off line, were currently covered by the Indecency with Children Act (1960) and carried a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison.

However, he acknowledged that these offences might need to be re-examined, as legislators could not have envisaged the impact of the internet in 1960.

He said: "A report is due to be published shortly by the Internet Crime Forum, which will include recommendations about chatrooms."

Rob Hutchinson, chair of the Association of Directors of Social Services' children's and families' committee, which backs the NCH and NSPCC's proposals, explained how paedophiles were using the net to "groom" children for abuse.

"If they go into a chatroom they will find a common interest with a child. If a young person shows some vulnerability they will exploit that and express sympathy for them and seek to meet up," he said.

But Mr Hutchinson said social workers still knew little about how sex offenders use the net.

John Carr, internet advisor at the NCH, confirmed that growing numbers of social workers were seeking advice about such activity.

 Seven leading children's charities launched a campaign last month to increase child safety on the internet.

The NCH, NSPCC, Barnardo's, ChildLine, the National Children's Bureau and the NCVO called on the internet and computer industries to make children's safety their top priority.

Mary Marsh, director of the NSPCC, said: "The most hazardous place for children is their own bedrooms where they have unsupervised access to the net or in situations where they are supervised by adults unfamiliar with the technology."

webTitle: Blair splattered with fruit in Iraq protest

fields.headline: Blair splattered with fruit in Iraq protest
fields.standfirst:
Demonstration distracts from day's focus on economy
Larry Elliott: it's usually the economy, stupid
fields.trailText: Prime Minister Tony Blair was pelted with rotten fruit today on his first campaigning visit of the New Year.
fields.body:
Prime Minister Tony Blair was pelted with rotten fruit today on his first campaigning visit of the New Year.

Two women and one man were arrested after the incident in Bristol, which left Mr Blair with an over-ripe tomato splattered across the back of his left shoulder.

His Prime Ministerial convoy was ambushed by protesters outside the City of Bristol College which he had arrived to officially open. What had been a handful of peaceful demonstrators carrying banners protesting against sanctions on Iraq suddenly swelled to 20 or 30 as the Prime Minister's motorcade drew up.

Several tomatoes hurled from the crowd hit the roadway before one scored a direct hit on the Prime Minister who did not flinch.

Other demonstrators tried to lunge towards him but were held back by police, who were swiftly reinforced by mounted officers.

Small oranges were also thrown as the crowd screamed abuse. Inside the college campus one woman yelled at Mr Blair from only feet away: "How many Iraqi children have you killed?"

Meanwhile, the Conservative party has today reasserted its claim to be the guardians of low taxation and sound economic management, launching a poster campaign aimed at wooing voters disillusioned by the government's performance on the issue.

However the party's fightback has been undermined by the early unveiling of the posters - some of which were on public display at the end of last week - and by a fuss over a failed attempt by the party to project its low tax message on to the side of the Millennium Dome.

The posters, unveiled today by party leader William Hague and his shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, challenge New Labour's claim to have used increased tax revenues to improve key public services.

"You've paid the tax, so where are the teachers?" runs one of the three slogans. The others ask about police numbers and hospital operations.

This morning Conservative chairman Michael Ancram accused Labour of reneging on its promises on taxation.

"The point of the campaign is to remind people what has happened since the last election," he said. "Labour has broken nearly all the promises they made.

"They promised they wouldn't put taxes up, everybody knows that taxes have gone up, the average working family is now paying £670 more than they were at the last election," he told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme. In response the health secretary, Alan Milburn, insisted that the government had kept its promises on taxation.

"We have kept every promise that we made on tax," he said.

Meanwhile Labour has attacked an attempt by the Conservatives to project a slogan onto the side of the Dome early this morning. The projected message "You paid the tax - So where's all the money gone?" appeared blurry and shadowy on the canopy of the Dome.

A Dome spokesman added later: "Two white Transit vans came up to our property at around 6.20am and opened their back doors to momentarily project an image on to the Dome. The image was only up on the Dome for about two minutes.

"The vans were on our property without authority and we also have a policy that anyone wanting to project an image on to the Dome has to pay a fee," said the spokesman.

"People should realise that the funding arrangement for the Dome was established by the Conservative government in February 1997."

webTitle: News at Ten for Monday week

fields.headline: News at Ten for Monday week
fields.trailText: 4.30pm News At Ten bulletin is set to be restored to the schedules on January 22, senior sources at ITN have revealed.
fields.body:
News At Ten is set to be restored to the schedules on January 22, senior sources at ITN and ITV have revealed.

ITV bosses will confirm tomorrow that News at Ten is to be revived with Sir Trevor McDonald at the helm.

Journalists and programme editors at ITN have been put on standby for a 22 January launch. It is not clear whether Sir Trevor will be signed up for every news bulletin however.

This is because in the compromise deal thrashed out between ITV bosses at regulators at the Independent Television Commission, the network is only obliged to bring back the 32 year old institution on three nights a week.

It is believed that the Sir Trevor, 61, is unwilling to front bulletin on the nights that it goes out at 11pm, but that he is committed to presenting the programme on the three nights a week that it goes out at 10pm.

Sources say the name of the programme has yet to be confirmed, but bosses are said to favour "Nightly News at Ten", which allows the network to keep both its news brands intact.

The move would have the added advantages that it allows ITV to claim it has not caved in to pressure to reinstate News at Ten, and gives it scheduling flexibility.

The programme will not return to its former half-hour length, however.

Meanwhile, speculation continues that ITN is considering relaunching its 6.30 bulletin with two presenters.

A spokeswoman for ITV: "Nothing is yet confirmed."
fields.bodyText: News At Ten is set to be restored to the schedules on January 22, senior sources at ITN and ITV have revealed. ITV bosses will confirm tomorrow that News at Ten is to be revived with Sir Trevor McDonald at the helm. Journalists and programme editors at ITN have been put on standby for a 22 January launch. It is not clear whether Sir Trevor will be signed up for every news bulletin however. This is because in the compromise deal thrashed out between ITV bosses at regulators at the Independent Television Commission, the network is only obliged to bring back the 32 year old institution on three nights a week. It is believed that the Sir Trevor, 61, is unwilling to front bulletin on the nights that it goes out at 11pm, but that he is committed to presenting the programme on the three nights a week that it goes out at 10pm. Sources say the name of the programme has yet to be confirmed, but bosses are said to favour "Nightly News at Ten", which allows the network to keep both its news brands intact. The move would have the added advantages that it allows ITV to claim it has not caved in to pressure to reinstate News at Ten, and gives it scheduling flexibility. The programme will not return to its former half-hour length, however. Meanwhile, speculation continues that ITN is considering relaunching its 6.30 bulletin with two presenters. A spokeswoman for ITV: "Nothing is yet confirmed."

webTitle: Blair promises boost for public services

fields.headline: Blair promises boost for public services
fields.trailText: Prime minister Tony Blair today promised "the largest-ever sustained investment in public services Britain has seen" in a speech billed as setting out key themes for a general election campaign later this year.
fields.body:
Prime minister Tony Blair today promised "the largest-ever sustained investment in public services Britain has seen" in a speech billed as setting out key themes for a general election campaign later this year.

He defended his decision to stick to tight conservative public spending limits during his first two years of office - a policy blamed by many for the problems affecting public services - as a "tough choice" necessary to help rid the economy of its "boom and bust" tendency.

There would be no let up on reforms to ensure his spending plans delivered "world-class public services," he told an audience of party activists and business leaders in Bristol, although he warned it would take time to put right "20 years of Tory neglect".

But Mr Blair was given a taste of public dissatisfaction with the pace of change in the public sector by a student nurse who told him, in a question and answer session after his speech, that she could not afford to live on her "meagre salary".

Earlier, Conservative leader William Hague accused Labour of having failed to improve public services, despite having imposed hefty "stealth taxes". The NHS was in " a permanent state of crisis", he said.

Mr Blair said: "We will put in over the next few years, the largest ever sustained investment in public services Britain has seen. At every stage the money will be accompanied by reform to deliver steadily higher standards."

He added: "Of course it takes time. Twenty years of neglect - and let us be honest in the case of some services, more than 20 years - was never going to be put right in one term.

"But the direction is there. We can point to progress in every area. We have laid out plans for investment and reform. And if we carry on making the tough choices as a government and as a nation we will get the job done."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • Matthew Norman, the capacious-arsed occupant of this seat, and the perspicacious hound Steptoe have mysteriously disappeared. Police are investigating, but there are many suspects - including the entire parliamentary Labour party - and progress is likely to be slow, so you're stuck with me for a while. Should I do jokes, hot stories or simply parade my prejudices? A bit of each, I suppose.
fields.body:
 Matthew Norman, the capacious-arsed occupant of this seat, and the perspicacious hound Steptoe have mysteriously disappeared. Police are investigating, but there are many suspects - including the entire parliamentary Labour party - and progress is likely to be slow, so you're stuck with me for a while. Should I do jokes, hot stories or simply parade my prejudices? A bit of each, I suppose.

 When is an article not an article? When it appears in the Mail on Sunday of course. The main piece on its editorial page at the weekend was an assessment by George Alagiah of Greg Dyke's breast-beating over his whiter-than-white corporation. "Hideously white? I'd like to know where Greg Dyke gets his facts from," was the headline. A scoop for the paper to get the Beeb's star black newsreader to write about the DG (or, as the MoS put it, "the Sri Lankan newsman offers a brisk reply to his boss"). One problem - Alagiah didn't write it. He did, however, talk to a reporter from the paper on Saturday, and was surprised to see his off-the-cuff remarks given star billing. When he rang to complain, he was thanked for the article and told that a cheque for £1,000 was in the post. "But I didn't write it." "OK, so the cheque is for the interview." He wearily asked them to send the money to Christian Aid instead.

 The BBC's hideously white director of news, Tony Hall, is being seen as a shoo-in to head the Royal Opera House, but I have it on good (well, goodish) authority that that is far from the case. Hall wanted £250,000 a year to tame the monster; Covent Garden was offering £140,000. The board is now taking a fresh look at other candidates, notably Netherlands Opera's Pierre Audi and Richard Lyttelton of EMI, though this may be a negotiating tactic. Watch this space, as we diarists say.

 Liam Fox, the laugh-a-minute shadow health secretary, seems to have an odd idea of repentance. Having grudgingly issued an apology for his "joke" about the Spice Girls - you remember, the one that managed to be both racist and sexist - he has now told the local paper in his Woodspring constituency, south of Bristol, that he has had a very supportive postbag: 82 letters in favour and just one against. So that's all right then.

 Peter Mandelson attended the bash to mark the 150th anniversary of the AEEU at the Grosvenor House hotel at the weekend, though he skipped the dinner. It was in Geoffrey Robinson's flat in the hotel that the Mandygate deal was struck, so perhaps the memories were too much for the delicate minister to bear. Shame, because he missed Gordon Brown's excellent speech. "I know you thought of having this celebration at the dome," the chirpy chancellor said, "but of course it's not used to such large numbers." Not a reference to absent friends, surely.

 Beryl Bainbridge has left her long-time publishing home Duckworth, and moved to Little, Brown, august publishers of Fools Rush In, the memoirs of Anthea Turner. Which is merely an excuse to tell you that Dame Beryl was an actress before she turned to writing and, for a spell in the early 60s, appeared in Coronation Street as Ken Barlow's girlfriend. (Like so many of these items, there is no punchline so skip this sentence.)

 How small-minded of the Times to sack Stephen "what an amazing coincidence" Pollard for his parting message to Express boss Richard Desmond. After all, the magisterial Peter Jay once used the Thunderer's leader columns to send a billet-doux to a female friend with whom he had enjoyed a long and intimate lunch on the previous day.

 You will notice that the first letters of these paragraphs cleverly spell out MWTLPBHY, a village in Powys. Impressed? OK, I'll do better tomorrow.

fields.headline: Eriksson quits Lazio
fields.standfirst:
Graphic: Sven's career in full
Comment: Why Swede into turnip won't go
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson has resigned as coach of Italian champions Lazio, and according to FA chief executive Adam Crozier will take up his new post as England coach "within the next few days".
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson has resigned as coach of Italian champions Lazio, and according to FA chief executive Adam Crozier will take up his new post as England coach "within the next few days".

Eriksson announced his decision to the Lazio players at the club's Formello training ground this morning, and this afternoon spoke of his regret at leaving the club he guided to their first Serie A title since 1974.

"It was a decision taken in my car on the way to Formello this morning," he told a packed press conference. "The first people to know were the players.

"I have chosen to take this step and I hope it is better for the club and that results will come in the future," he added. "I don't like what I did but I think it is better for the club."

Eriksson's contract with the FA was to begin on July 1, but the Swede will now take charge of England in time for the friendly against Spain on February 28 at Villa Park.

Leicester manager Peter Taylor, who had been asked to take charge of affairs by the FA, must make do with a back-seat role alongside Manchester United's Steve McLaren.

"In the end what's happened over last 24 hours is good for everyone, for Sven, for England and for Lazio", Crozier said this afternoon. "Having spoken to him he will be here within the next few days ready to take up the post as England coach.

"What's happened has not taken the gloss off his appointment. We know what we're getting. He is one of the top three or four managers in the world, and he will be in charge for the game against Spain which is terrific because it gives him time to plan for the World Cup qualifiers."

Eriksson's decision comes after a woeful three-month period in which Lazio have fallen off the Championship pace in Serie A, tumbled to the bottom of their Champions League group and been knocked out of the Italian Cup. Lazio are currently 11 points behind city rivals Roma in the league.

It is believed that, following a 2-1 home defeat by struggling Napoli at the weekend, Eriksson was yesterday asked to stand down by club president Sergio Cragnotti. Today Cragnotti spoke of his sadness at Eriksson's departure.

"It is very bad news and a very difficult day for us," he said. "Lazio owes Eriksson a lot."

Former Italian national coach Dino Zoff, the club's vice-president, will step in as coach until the end of the season.

webTitle: Suicide of black worker 'caused by bullying'

fields.headline: Suicide of black worker 'caused by bullying'
fields.standfirst:
Family wins right to posthumous tribunal over son they claim was driven to hang himself

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Family wins right to posthumous tribunal over son they claim was driven to hang himself.
fields.body:
The family of a black postal worker who committed suicide because he suffered racial abuse at work has won the right to an employment tribunal hearing to take place posthumously.

Jermaine Lee, 26, was found hanged at his home in Hall Green, Birmingham, in November 1999. He had tied a martial arts belt to a roof rafter.

His family claim that Jermaine had been bullied and harassed at work over an eight month period. He had eventually been sacked from his job at the Aston sorting office in Birmingham. An internal investigation by the Royal Mail led to the suspension of six workers and the sorting office's manager was eventually dismissed.

Mr Lee left a suicide note addressed to his mother, Unnell, which said: "It's the only way out. Those guys at work hate me. Tell them it was nice playing with me and they won." An inquest held in the city in October last year found that he had committed suicide.

At a preliminary hearing in Birmingham yesterday, the employment tribunal chairman, John Van Gelder, allowed Mrs Lee to lodge the action on behalf of her son, despite the claim being made outside of the usual time limit.

Mr Van Gelder said he allowed the application of racial discrimination out of time. "The circumstances are that the deceased had been an employee of the Post Office who had committed suicide and, in a suicide note, had made reference to the fact that he had had difficulties in his place of work," he said.

He said there was evidence in the suicide note which suggested there might have been a basis for a claim of racial discrimination and that had extended over a period of time.

Mark Sahu, counsel for the family, explained the delay to the tribunal hearing. "There were a number of factors which led to the delay in bringing this action against Mr Lee's former employer," he said. "These include the shock, the horror and the trauma experienced by Mr Lee's family on finding their beloved son hanged.

"They also had problems finding information surrounding the case of Jermaine's death because of a wall of silence which was built up around the offices of the Post Office following the suicide."

He said it was not until much later that more information became available following an internal investigation at the Post Office. It was now clearly a serious case of race discrimination and a number of clear incidents had been noted.

After the hearing, Mr Lee's family said they were pleased with the decision.

A statement from Navneet Patwalia, the family's solicitor, said: "It has been over a year since Jermaine took his own life and the family have received comfort from learning of Royal Mail's confirmation that the actions of some of their employees did in fact contribute to Jermaine's decision to take his own life.

"The family are obviously relieved in securing justice. Although this will not bring Jermaine back, the family very much hope this will change the culture and prevent future atrocities."

The family had originally claimed constructive dismissal against their son's employers, alleging discrimination. But their claim has now changed to one of race discrimination and racial harassment.

Two other workers who claim they were bullied by colleagues are on long term sick leave from the Birmingham sorting office. A woman had a nervous breakdown after an assault at the office.

Steve Lee, Jermaine's father, wrote an open letter to 1,500 postal workers in Birmingham seeking more evidence about bullying. But instead of help, he received threats. In one menacing phone call, someone told him: "If your shitty little son hadn't done it, we would have done it for him."

Mr Lee said in an interview that Jermaine had always tried to right wrongs.

"It is only right that we should fight for justice for him now and uncover what happened," he said. "He had no other worries. The only thing he would ever complain about was work."

A spokesman for the Royal Mail in Birmingham said it accepted the tribunal's decision that it should go forward to a full employment tribunal, but it would be opposing the allegations.

"Given the nature of the allegations, we feel it is only right that all the evidence is heard in the proper manner and in a proper forum," the spokesman said.

"We take any allegation of harassment of our employees very seriously."

The tribunal was adjourned for 12 weeks.

webTitle: Sacchi named as Parma's new manager

fields.headline: Sacchi named as Parma's new manager
fields.trailText: Former Italy manager Arrigo Sacchi is the new coach of Parma, replacing Alberto Alberto Malesani who was sacked yesterday.
fields.body:
Former Italy manager Arrigo Sacchi is the new coach of Parma, replacing Alberto Alberto Malesani who was sacked yesterday.

Sacchi, who said he was retiring from coaching when he stepped down at Atletico Madrid in February 1999, took charge of training with his new club this afternoon.

The appointment marks Sacchi's second spell in charge of the Gialloblù. He coached Parma between 1985 and 1987, guiding them to promotion from the Third Division in his first year in charge.

Sacchi later took over at AC Milan in 1987 and built one of the most formidable sides in European football before coaching Italy to the 1994 World Cup final. He returned to Milan later that year and coached Atletico for nine months before returning to Italy to work as a television pundit.

Parma are 10th in Serie A and have taken just one point from their last 12. They lost 2-0 at home to relegation-threatened Reggina on Sunday.

fields.headline: The forgotten workers
fields.standfirst: Ancillary staff are the most underpaid and overlooked in the public sector, and further privatisation won't improve the situation, writes Sanjiv Sachdev
fields.trailText: Ancillary staff are the most underpaid and overlooked in the public sector, and further privatisation won't improve the situation, writes Sanjiv Sachdev
fields.body:
The author George Orwell remarked that "All people who work with their hands are partly invisible, and the more important the work they do, the less visible they are." This is true of the ancillary staff working in public services - the cleaners, laundry staff and caterers. Consisting mostly of working-class women, often black or Asian and mostly in their 40s and 50s, they are neglected and ignored. Yet without them public services would falter and fail.

For example, while the BBC's Casualty depicts a range of health professions, ancillaries are not represented. The library of the health think-tank, the King's Fund Institute, has shelf upon shelf of work devoted to nursing issues. In contrast, ancillary workers have a solitary box file concerning them, this contains just one book, published in 1968 and aptly titled The Forgotten Workforce.

Remember that the NHS employs tens of thousands of ancillary workers. In the late 1980s research on labour turnover in the NHS revealed an average rate of 45% a year among ancillary staff - in one health authority it was 111%. Yet when the audit commission examined labour turnover in the health service, the subsequent exhaustive study conspicuously did not examine turnover rates among ancillary workers

This invisibility is partly a product of their low status in employment hierarchies, partly an outcome of when they work - often early in the morning and late in the evening, and partly due to the widespread privatisation of their work. The pace of the latter is striking - eight years ago 98% of care provided by social services in England, such as meals on wheels and personal care, came from local authorities' in-house workforces - by 1999 just under half did so.

Privatisation through the introduction of compulsory competitive tendering (CCT) saw a dramatic reduction in the number of workers employed. Competition meant cutting labour costs, which were cut by lowering labour standards. Workloads increased, terms and conditions deteriorated, and a spate of scandals concerning dirty hospitals and schools followed. Some of the lowest paid workers in Britain saw their wages fall lower still. After privatisation, they often ceased to be regarded as part of the school or hospital team. A study in Rotherham found that "cleaners were no longer seen as integral to the school staff as a whole a member of staff commented that Christmas parties used to be for the whole school - cleaners and all - but after CCT it was hard to know who to invite".

Equal opportunity policies were of little value when CCT was involved. The equal opportunities commission (EOC) in Northern Ireland found a "minimal" consideration of equal opportunity issues in the competitive tendering process, despite the universal existence of such policies in the boards and trusts concerned. There was "no evidence that any steps were taken to ensure that the process was free of gender bias when services were chosen to be tendered, when tenders were assessed, or in the period after the award of contracts".

When ancillary services are privatised, be it by private finance initiative (PFI) schemes, best value or market testing it is likely to result in inferior terms and conditions for the staff; if not the existing ones, then for the new recruits. And this in turn damages society in ways not reflected in balance sheets.

Take the government's family-friendly policy proposals. The consequences of the absence of such policies are well known but difficult to quantify. The public sector, for all its failings, generally offers better family-friendly provisions than the private sector (one of the reasons why the latter is often cheaper) whether it is flexitime, job sharing, parental leave, working from home or child care subsidy.

A third of public sector workplaces offer job-sharing to their women workers; only 15% of private sector employers do so. The EOC study notes: "None of the companies provided contractual maternity benefits. Their employees were dependent on statutory provisions. In comparison, board/trust employees had access to paid maternity leave after one year's service."

With CCT, and arguably now with PFI, a narrow, accountant's view of efficiency prevails, but the meaningful is not always measurable. Playwright Dennis Potter, in his famous valedictory interview, makes the point well: " everything was given its price-tag, and the price-tag became the only gospel. And that gospel is very thin gruel indeed. If you start measuring human kind in those terms, everything else becomes less important, or laughable - all the things that bind us as a community".

 Sanjiv Sachdev is a senior lecturer in human resource management, Kingston University
