The library of the health think-tank, the King's Fund Institute, has shelf upon shelf of work devoted to nursing issues. In contrast, ancillary workers have a solitary box file concerning them, this contains just one book, published in 1968 and aptly titled The Forgotten Workforce. Remember that the NHS employs tens of thousands of ancillary workers. In the late 1980s research on labour turnover in the NHS revealed an average rate of 45% a year among ancillary staff - in one health authority it was 111%. Yet when the audit commission examined labour turnover in the health service, the subsequent exhaustive study conspicuously did not examine turnover rates among ancillary workers This invisibility is partly a product of their low status in employment hierarchies, partly an outcome of when they work - often early in the morning and late in the evening, and partly due to the widespread privatisation of their work. The pace of the latter is striking - eight years ago 98% of care provided by social services in England, such as meals on wheels and personal care, came from local authorities' in-house workforces - by 1999 just under half did so. Privatisation through the introduction of compulsory competitive tendering (CCT) saw a dramatic reduction in the number of workers employed. Competition meant cutting labour costs, which were cut by lowering labour standards. Workloads increased, terms and conditions deteriorated, and a spate of scandals concerning dirty hospitals and schools followed. Some of the lowest paid workers in Britain saw their wages fall lower still. After privatisation, they often ceased to be regarded as part of the school or hospital team. A study in Rotherham found that "cleaners were no longer seen as integral to the school staff as a whole a member of staff commented that Christmas parties used to be for the whole school - cleaners and all - but after CCT it was hard to know who to invite". Equal opportunity policies were of little value when CCT was involved. The equal opportunities commission (EOC) in Northern Ireland found a "minimal" consideration of equal opportunity issues in the competitive tendering process, despite the universal existence of such policies in the boards and trusts concerned. There was "no evidence that any steps were taken to ensure that the process was free of gender bias when services were chosen to be tendered, when tenders were assessed, or in the period after the award of contracts". When ancillary services are privatised, be it by private finance initiative (PFI) schemes, best value or market testing it is likely to result in inferior terms and conditions for the staff; if not the existing ones, then for the new recruits. And this in turn damages society in ways not reflected in balance sheets. Take the government's family-friendly policy proposals. The consequences of the absence of such policies are well known but difficult to quantify. The public sector, for all its failings, generally offers better family-friendly provisions than the private sector (one of the reasons why the latter is often cheaper) whether it is flexitime, job sharing, parental leave, working from home or child care subsidy. A third of public sector workplaces offer job-sharing to their women workers; only 15% of private sector employers do so. The EOC study notes: "None of the companies provided contractual maternity benefits. Their employees were dependent on statutory provisions. In comparison, board/trust employees had access to paid maternity leave after one year's service." With CCT, and arguably now with PFI, a narrow, accountant's view of efficiency prevails, but the meaningful is not always measurable. Playwright Dennis Potter, in his famous valedictory interview, makes the point well: " everything was given its price-tag, and the price-tag became the only gospel. And that gospel is very thin gruel indeed. If you start measuring human kind in those terms, everything else becomes less important, or laughable - all the things that bind us as a community".  Sanjiv Sachdev is a senior lecturer in human resource management, Kingston University

fields.trailText: ERIKSSON IS MOBILE
fields.body:
ERIKSSON IS MOBILE

Last night, the Fiver finally saw sense and abandoned its vigil at Luton airport. Actually, when we say abandoned, we mean "forcibly detained by police after urinating in a drinking fountain", but the bogs were locked, so what were we supposed to do? Anyway, it didn't seem to matter at the time, because Sergio Cragnotti had promised that Svennis wasn't set for the axe at Lazio, and if you can't trust the chairman who can you trus

"It was a decision taken in my car on the way to Formello [Lazio's training camp] this morning," Svennis said at a press conference to confirm his resignation as Lazio manager, and the appointment of former Italy coach Dino Zoff. It was a remark that won over all the cynics who had assumed he had been told to resign so the club could avoid paying any compensation. "I have chosen to take this step and I hope it is better for the club and that results will come in the future," he added. "I don't like what I did but I think it is better for the club."

Of course it is. And better for the British press who can look forward to tearing into Svennis as early as next month after the FA confirmed he would be in charge for next month's friendly against Spain (pushing Peter Taylor back into a supporting role). "The uncertainty of the past few months is at an end and the FA are delighted that one of the most successful coaches in the world will shortly be joining us." A job well done all round. Well, apart from the Lazio job, that is.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

HOW TO ARRANGE A TRANSFER, THE JOHN HARTSON WAY

1. Lumber around the Nationwide League, panting heavily. Score the odd goal with your arse. Tell everyone how unhappy you are with the way your life is heading.

2. Stop moaning about going bald. Demand a transfer instead.

3. Wait until a top manager, such as Coventry's Gordon Strachan, decides to make an offer to your club Wimbledon. (Just in case Cov know a doctor, like those time-wasters at Spurs and Rangers, it's probably best to go for a quick run at this point. Or at least do a couple of stretches.)

4. Panic a bit when Wimbledon say they will not comment on the transfer "until the fat lady sings". Ask the spokesperson if he's trying to be bloody funny or what.

5. Panic a lot when Jonathan Barnett, your agent, explains: "Negotiations are going on between Coventry and Wimbledon, but I'm not sure how close the two of them are to agreeing a deal. I'm not back until Thursday so I don't think anything will happen until then, if it happens at all."

6. If it happens at all?!? What if the teams can't agree on a payment plan (Coventry originally offered £2.5m plus defender Richard Shaw but Wimbledon want £3m up front with another £2m in instalments)?

7. Or what if the old knee gives way again ("I don't think this will be a problem", says Barnett)?

8. Need comfort food. Mmm, chips.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Tiger Beer has been our staunchest friend all these years" - John Koh, chief operating officer of the Singapore FA (backed by Tiger Beer), explains why Carlsberg-sponsored Liverpool won't be allowed to play a friendly in the country. A decision which is now being reconsidered, but only cos yer me besht mate.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

LET'S SELL IT

Bradford's business dealings during the summer were so pathetic, you'd be forgiven for mistaking the club for a dot-com start-up. Signing up Benito Carbone, Dan Petrescu and Stan Collymore - and making them the highest-paid players at Valley Parade - was an act of monumental folly, the like of which has not been seen since boo.com took their business plan to Barclays. Luckily, newly installed guru Jim Jefferies is sorting things out, and has understandably turned to the internet for inspiration.

Based on the nearly-collapsed letsbuyit.com - where canny users club together to get cheap goods - Jim's letssellhim.com hopes to offload overly expensive merchandise to gullible punters. And the venture has started well, with some "genuine interest" in Carbone from Italy. "Udinese have confirmed they are interested in Beni," explained chairman Geoffrey Richmond. "There are currently discussions going on at the club regarding a possible bid, but we are looking at £3m for him."

Of course, you can't expect everything to go smoothly at first, and letssellhim.com are prepared for a rough ride. As we reported yesterday, the sale of Collymore was scuppered by a problem with the phone connection, and it now looks as though flogging Petrescu might prove difficult too. "I want to end my career at Bradford," Petrescu told the Bradford Telegraph & Argus today. "I don't want to change clubs any more. I moved my family to this area and I am happily settled. Even if the club drop into the First Division that's not a problem to me." And when you're on £15,000 a week, that's got to be good business sense.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Aston Villa are interested in Paris St Germain's Moroccan defender Talal El-Karkouri.

Lille defender Pascal Cygan is a target for West Ham.

Portsmouth are interested in Bradford midfielder Lee Sharpe. "We are still trying to look for someone around the left-sided area, so Lee Sharpe might be an idea," admitted manager Steve Claridge.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Carlisle midfielder Richard Prokas has apologised for his two-footed lunge at Patrick Vieira during their FA Cup tie with Arsenal last Saturday. "Richard Prokas would like to publicly state that he regrets the incident last Saturday and certainly did not intend to injure Patrick Vieira," a statement read. "He regards Vieira as the best midfield player in the Premiership and particularly admires his competitive qualities in these circumstances."

Charlton striker Jonatan Johansson will be out for a month after injuring his knee during a training ground accident.

Marc Keller has joined Blackburn on loan from West Ham, with a view to a permanent move.

Laurent Blanc has ruled out the prospect of joining Manchester United. "I have two possibilities," he told France Football. "Either I continue to play in Italy, probably at Inter, or I return to France to end my career."

Egypt's Hossam Hassan will become the world's most capped footballer when he plays in a friendly against Zambia today. His 151st appearance will see him overtake Germany's Lothar Matthaus.

Former Italy manager Arrigo Sacchi has been named as the new coach of Parma after Alberto Malesani was sacked this morning.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Football Extra (3.15am) "I once saw Jimmy Greaves walking through Stevenage with what looked like parts of an Iraqi supergun during one sunny August Saturday afternoon circa 1994 (ie: post Saint and Greavsie)," writes Howard Blanchard.

Channel 4: Football Italia (1.50am) "He had two cardboard tubes, painted panzer grey which looked like they were causing old Greavsie a bit of trouble due to their weight and length making it tricky to hold them in independent hands."

Sky Sports 1: World Football Show (6.30pm, 11pm) "I watched him struggle for about two minutes - as did most the people in the precinct - hoping he would drop them so I could offer assistance to the old Spurs fave, or even ask for his opinion on the floundering lilywhites."

Brian Moore Interviews (7pm) "When he recomposed himself, I followed him as he went into Argos. Here he put the two disguised supergun segments on the counter."

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 2am) "I watched in amazement as the girl at the desk gave him a credit note and he left."

Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 with Ian Payne (7pm) Have you seen an ex-professional exchanging faulty / unwanted goods in a catalogue store? Or maybe you've spotted someone like Meridian football "anchor" Andy Steggall waiting at the collection point, getting all impatient. Whatever, mail us at the.boss@theguardian.com, even if it's dull.

webTitle: Prokas offers apology for Vieira horror tackle

fields.headline: Prokas offers apology for Vieira horror tackle
fields.trailText: Carlisle midfielder Richard Prokas has publicly apologised to Patrick Vieira for his dreadful two-footed lunge on the Arsenal player during an FA Cup third round tie last weekend.
fields.body:
Carlisle midfielder Richard Prokas has publicly apologised to Patrick Vieira for his dreadful two-footed lunge on the Arsenal player during an FA Cup third round tie last weekend.

He will also contact the French international to offer a personal apology.

"Richard Prokas would like to publicly state that he regrets the incident last Saturday and certainly did not intend to injure Patrick Vieira," a statement released this afternoon read.

"He regards Vieira as the best midfield player in the Premiership and particularly admires his competitive qualities in these circumstances.

"However, Richard accepts that his challenge for the ball was mistimed and would like to publicly apologise to Patrick.

"At the same time, he will be seeking to privately speak with Patrick to offer him his personal apologies and best wishes for the future."

The statement comes 24 hours after the FA admitted Prokas would not receive any retrospective punishment, for fear of undermining referees.

Steve Lodge, who refereed the game at Brunton Park, yesterday admitted he would have dismissed Prokas had he clearly seen the incident, which broke Vieira's shinguard and left the player and his manager Arsene Wenger incensed.

fields.headline: Feeling the squeeze
fields.standfirst: The property boom in the south of England has led to a shortage of key workers who are priced out of the market. Is the government's plan to build more houses enough to solve the problem? David Blackman investigates
fields.trailText: The property boom in the south of England has led to a shortage of key workers who are priced out of the market. Is the government's plan to build more houses enough to solve the problem? David Blackman investigates
fields.body:
That the booming south of England is facing a housing shortage is clear. The most graphic illustration of this was last week's dire warning by local education authorities that schools in many parts of the region are considering introducing four-day weeks because they cannot attract the staff.

A key factor underpinning this recruitment crisis is that workers in the relatively poorly paid public sector cannot afford a place to live. But any government that relaxes controls on new house building is immediately accused of environmental vandalism by the influential conservation lobby. Last month the government finally published its long-awaited regional planning guidance (RPG), outlining the south's proposed housing provision for the next 15 years. Ministers' proposed solution is to exploit the profits resulting from the region's booming property market to increase the amount of affordable housing on offer.

Out of the 39,000 new homes that housing minister Nick Raynsford said should be provided per annum in the south-east over the next five years, nearly half should be provided for those on low incomes. The south east regional assembly, which will take over responsibility for strategic planning, has been asked to monitor whether provision of affordable housing is meeting this benchmark, which has been set at 18-19,000 new social homes per annum. The same should be the case in the south-west, says the guidance for that part of the world. In this area, the indicator has been fixed at 6-10,000 new homes for low income earners, which is equivalent to between 30 and 50% of the region's planned housing provision.

Both documents echo the position put forward in London mayor Ken Livingstone's recent housing report which also said that half of all new housing in the capital should be aimed at those on low or middle incomes.

Town planning consultant Richard Bate, who represented the National Housing Federation's south-east branch at 1999's public examination of the planning proposals, says the inclusion of a guideline figure represents a significant departure on the part of the government.

Traditionally, councils have not been allowed to distinguish between housing tenures when making planning decisions apart from in the most tightly constrained rural sites. But how councils are meant to meet the goal outlined in the new guidance is less clear.

Professor Kelvin MacDonald, director of Room, which lobbies for affordable, well-planned housing, expresses disappointment that the new document contains no new mechanisms for local authorities. "This is a paper tiger and I don't think they (the government) have gone much further. We still need far more to deliver affordable housing."

The levels of affordable housing being asked for in the south-east and south-west have so far been achieved in few places. A rare example is the Imperial Wharf scheme in Hammersmith, where the local council gave permission for the development on the grounds that exactly half of the apartments would be set aside for social housing.

Nevertheless, John Adams, chairman of the Chartered Institute of Housing's south-east branch, is optimistic about the planning system's ability to deliver the affordable housing goods.

He argues that local authorities should insist more robustly that a share of all house building sites is earmarked for social housing. The lower profits that the house builder makes on his development, says Mr Adams, could be passed on to landowners who can better afford to take a cut because of high land prices. "Many of them have already had a windfall of £700,000 an acre," he says.

webTitle: Women describe their morning-after pill experience

fields.headline: How was it?
fields.standfirst:
Four women describe their morning-after pill experience

The morning after...
fields.trailText: Four women describe their morning-after pill experience
fields.body:
Ellen Davis, 29

Ellen had been on the pill for eight years when she decided to give her body a break. "We started using condoms, and one night one split. It was a Friday, the worst possible time. I knew about the morning-after pill, but I had no idea how to get hold of it outside surgery hours." She and her boyfriend got up at the crack of dawn on Saturday, phoned various friends, then headed for a clinic in Notting Hill, west London. "I was given a lot of literature about contraception, which did make me laugh. I mean, I'd been on the pill for so many years, I thought I knew what was what, and they were treating me like a teenager."

Lynne Robinson, 44

Lynne split up with husband when their daughter was four and since then she hasn't had a long term relationship. "Contraception was a totally dead issue as far as I was concerned." But in December she had a one-night-stand with a former colleague: they were drunk and had unprotected sex. The following morning, Lynne was in shock. She went to her doctor. Arriving at the surgery, she felt as if the practice nurse was treating her like a naughty schoolgirl. "Things got worse after I took the first pair of tablets. I threw up after an hour - well I was feeling a bit ropey with all the booze. I had to go back and get more pills."

Jane Summerton, 18

Jane had been seeing her boyfriend Mark for more than a year before they had sex. "We hadn't discussed contraception, I know that's probably a bit dim. On the night, we were so drunk that we didn't really know what we were doing. In the event, Mark produced a condom, but it came off. She went to her GP. "I felt covered with shame. I got a long lecture from the doctor about methods of contraception and safe sex. When I walked out of there clutching a fistful of condoms, I was in tears. Physically I felt dreadful too: the pills made me feel dizzy and drowsy, and I stayed in bed for two whole days afterwards."

Heather Ross, 37

"My husband wants children, but until recently I was unsure. We'd had a bit to drink - maybe that's why I began to be swayed by his point of view. That night I left my diaphragm in the bathroom cabinet." She went to work the next day as normal but by lunchtime she was seized with panic. "Suddenly I knew that I'd made a terrible mistake." She went to get the morning-after pill during her lunch hour. "The pills gave me a chronic headache, and my breasts felt sore and swollen. But when my period came, I felt it had all been worth it."

 Some names have been changed.

Lynne Robinson, 44 Lynne split up with husband when their daughter was four and since then she hasn't had a long term relationship. "Contraception was a totally dead issue as far as I was concerned." But in December she had a one-night-stand with a former colleague: they were drunk and had unprotected sex. The following morning, Lynne was in shock. She went to her doctor. Arriving at the surgery, she felt as if the practice nurse was treating her like a naughty schoolgirl. "Things got worse after I took the first pair of tablets. I threw up after an hour - well I was feeling a bit ropey with all the booze. I had to go back and get more pills." Jane Summerton, 18 Jane had been seeing her boyfriend Mark for more than a year before they had sex. "We hadn't discussed contraception, I know that's probably a bit dim. On the night, we were so drunk that we didn't really know what we were doing. In the event, Mark produced a condom, but it came off. She went to her GP. "I felt covered with shame. I got a long lecture from the doctor about methods of contraception and safe sex. When I walked out of there clutching a fistful of condoms, I was in tears. Physically I felt dreadful too: the pills made me feel dizzy and drowsy, and I stayed in bed for two whole days afterwards." Heather Ross, 37 "My husband wants children, but until recently I was unsure. We'd had a bit to drink - maybe that's why I began to be swayed by his point of view. That night I left my diaphragm in the bathroom cabinet." She went to work the next day as normal but by lunchtime she was seized with panic. "Suddenly I knew that I'd made a terrible mistake." She went to get the morning-after pill during her lunch hour. "The pills gave me a chronic headache, and my breasts felt sore and swollen. But when my period came, I felt it had all been worth it."  Some names have been changed.

fields.headline: Slim chance
fields.standfirst: Diary of a hypochondriac
fields.trailText: Tuesday: This year, along with the usual anticlimax/light deprivation New Year blues, there have arrived two specific causes for gloom: I am notably overweight, and I feel unusually slow-witted. To attack these twin depressants, I have developed a two-point plan: I will be spending most of each evening at my dartboard playing a game that permits me to indulge an ungodly talent for mental arithmetic; and tomorrow I begin a diet based on several of nature's finest anti-carcinogens - the prune, the carrot, Chinese green tea and limitless tandoori chicken.
fields.body:
Tuesday: This year, along with the usual anticlimax/light deprivation New Year blues, there have arrived two specific causes for gloom: I am notably overweight, and I feel unusually slow-witted. To attack these twin depressants, I have developed a two-point plan: I will be spending most of each evening at my dartboard playing a game that permits me to indulge an ungodly talent for mental arithmetic; and tomorrow I begin a diet based on several of nature's finest anti-carcinogens - the prune, the carrot, Chinese green tea and limitless tandoori chicken.

Wednesday: This afternoon, someone told me that I have lost weight. This is odd. I only started dieting this morning. And yet, unlikely as it may sound, looking in the mirror perhaps I do notice the hint of a certain gauntness around the cheekbones. I must be very ill.

Thursday: Further evidence of sickness arrives when I notice a vivid red hue to the loo paper. "It's cancer, isn't it?" I ask Rebecca. "That's why I'm suddenly so skinny." She snorts and asks what I had for dinner last night. "You know what I had. Six pieces of tandoori chicken." "Six pieces of bright red chicken? And what," continues the Socratic examination, "did you have on them?" "Mint sauce." "Would that be the curiously red mint sauce supplied by the restaurant?" "So?" The familiar sound of the front door closing sharply sends me scurrying to the dartboard for consolation.

Friday: Examining myself in the mirror after my bath, I can identify what may well be the outline of a ribcage. I begin to look almost wasted. Panicky, I ring my mother. "I wouldn't worry," she replies sardonically when I ask if she thinks it is cancer. "You're hardly Mahatma Gandhi, are you?" I return to the mirror. She's right. I am more enormous than ever, possibly even clinically obese.

Saturday: In a Telegraph article about how fat British women are, there is a formula to determine obesity: square your height in metres, divide it into your weight in kilos, and if it comes to more than 30 you're obese. After supper I will sit down and work it out. With my facility for figures, it won't take long.

Sunday: It is 4.29am, and I am about to retire for a brief but, I suspect, troubled night. The A4 paper ran out six hours ago, but after using the blackboard next to my dartboard until the chalk was exhausted, I have calculated my score at 27.41 - well on the right side of obesity. That's if I squared my height in metres. If, on the other hand, I used the square root - and I've now rubbed off the crucial lines - then I'm twice the size of Ann Widdecombe. At this moment, it's very hard to be sure.

Monday: A friend rings up complaining of mild flu, but when I give her the standard prescription - bed rest, paracetamol, liquids - it transpires she is calling not to request advice but to give it. She has bought a book called Eat Right 4 Your Type by a Dr Peter J D'Adamo, whose theory holds that each blood type demands a different diet. Apparently this is how Martine McCutcheon lost weight. Although sceptical, I check the website, and when Rebecca returns from work she finds me at the table in front of plates of pickled herring, a bowl of fresh cranberries, breast of smoked duck, walnuts, a marrow and a Cadbury's Chocolate Orange. "Oh," she says when I explain, "and what blood type would you be?" "As you can see," I reply, waving an expansive hand before me, "I would be, indeed I am . . . um . . ." God have mercy, I do not know my own blood type. I never have. "So what the hell's the point of that disgusting smorgasbord?" I have not the first idea. Rising from the table in despair, I head for the sanctuary of my dartboard, pausing only to pick up the pocket calculator on the way.

fields.headline: Just hanging on the telephone
fields.standfirst: On NHS Direct
fields.trailText: Sarah Boseley on NHS Direct
fields.body:
This is NHS Direct. Name please." "Oh, hello. I wondered if you could just tell me . . ."

"Postcode?"

". . . what I should do because my child is in real pain . . ."

"Phone number?"

". . . with her ears. I've given her the maximum amount of paracetamol it says on the bottle . . ."

"GP's name?"

". . . but it hasn't helped and all I want to know is . . ."

"Address?"

". . . can I give her any more?"

"A nurse will ring you back in half an hour to an hour's time."

"But she's crying and crying and it's the middle of the night and I want to know what to do RIGHT NOW."

"She'll ring you back."

The government tells us that 97% of patients have been at least satisfied with their experience of NHS Direct, the telephone helpline set up to give us rapid access to the advice of a nurse. That leaves me in a minority of 3%, and I don't believe that. It makes me wonder who they have asked and how they phrased the question.

The 97% figure has been trotted out ever since the first pilot schemes were assessed, and it was trotted out again recently as we were asked to celebrate the extension of NHS Direct to the whole of England. Call me a sceptic, but when does the British public ever give any institution a consistently sky-high confidence rating like that?

As it happens, I'm four-square behind the principle of NHS Direct. Busy people - and anyone with children is a busy person - like nothing better than to pick up a phone and get some help. Few of us want to bundle a sick child up and drive to accident and emergency. Most of us, although I hear the scornful laughs of doctors already, do not want to call out a GP except for something really serious.

This was not a casualty scenario. I am well familiar with the waiting rooms of ear, nose and throat clinics. We have been down the grommet road. I can talk glue ear with anybody. All I wanted to know was what I could do for the pain my hysterical child was suffering, but on the end of the line was what NHS Direct likes to term "a highly trained call handler" who has a script in front of her, just as she would have if she was taking calls to a mail-order catalogue. I told her half an hour to an hour was no good to me - it would be over one way or the other by then. I was right. The eardrum burst and the pain stopped. Thanks a million for the support, NHS Direct.

Maybe I was unlucky to get an automaton on the end of the phone that night who could have been asking me which size and colour jacket I wanted, for all the sympathy in her voice. I am sure that the nurse would eventually have rung me back and given me impeccable advice, albeit too late. But it seems to me that NHS Direct is failing to fulfil a real need if it cannot offer patients immediate and genuine comfort and support.

We are all increasingly healthy. Most of the problems we are taking to our doctors these days are not life-threatening, and many are not all that serious. Doctors complain about being besieged by the "worried well". These are the patients they and the government hope will be offloaded to NHS Direct. Much of the time they don't need medicine or surgery. They may need to be told to go to bed and get better by themselves. That is the role anticipated by government for NHS Direct.

But many may need reassurance. Christopher Bulstrode, director of education at the Royal College of Surgeons in Edinburgh, notes a 7% rise in the numbers turning up in accident and emergency departments in spite of our improving health. He blames it on a sort of hypochondria. The public loves to read about medical conditions in magazines and newspapers, he says. But the more people read, the more convinced they become that they have the diseases they learn about.

He does not think NHS Direct is the answer - diagnosis on the phone is too difficult, he says. And unless they get rid of the robots who protect the caring nurses from the potentially frantic public, I don't think it is either.

fields.headline: My secret life as a non-smoker
fields.standfirst: Gavan Naden on quitting quietly
fields.trailText: Gavan Naden on quitting quietly.
fields.body:
It's time to come out. I have been living a lie for more than a year now and feel I have to come clean. During the past 12 months not a single cigarette has made its way between my lips. And it's not that I want to sanctimoniously preach to all those who have tried and failed to quit. In fact, it's anything but. And here's the rub - shhhhh! - it's been a secret. I really didn't want any of my avid smoking friends to know. So I have remained isolated and furtive in an attempt to be . . . a secret non-smoker.

Only a paltry 50,000 out of an estimated two million quitters at the turn of the millennium are still on course. On this evidence, smokers have a one in 40 chance of giving up.

So it was a real piece of luck because on that night it was my 40th attempt. I was on a promise. As Big Ben struck for the year 2000, I exhaled, stubbed out, and said goodbye to a very old friend. "I love you," I mumbled, while sipping my millennium champagne. Who was I to rely on now?

I started smoking Dunhill while at college. I liked the colour of the pack, and thought it gave me an added level of sophistication. At that stage I thought it was just for fun. But when John Player Special released an all-black packet that was 20p cheaper, I immediately swapped allegiance. By then I was using my addiction in many positive ways. I made an entire coffee table from used packets. It didn't take long and I felt encouraged as I glued each new section in place. I took still-life photographs of backlit empty packs, next to a old shoe. It was supposed to mean something, but I can't remember what now.

By the time I'd left college, I knew it was impossible to stop without some effort, so I changed to a low-tar brand. And I knew I was in trouble when many a time I desperately searched for fag butts in the ash tray at the end of an evening.

But what was going to replace the void left if I did quit? What else can you light, inhale, flick, exhale? It occupies your hands, your mind and provides solace and security when all else fails. And all the while smokers have each other to bolster themselves.

Smokers notoriously want quitters to fall back into their old ways. And as many of my friends smoked I knew better than to admit to a campaign of denial. So I took a vow not to reveal my decision to stop. I claimed a bad cold or irritating cough was the reason I was having a "short break" from fags. (Which was not actually that untrue, as two weeks into the regime, I developed a hacking splutter that lasted a month.)

As time went on my secret became more difficult to deal with. So I became a master at non-smoking excuses. As the dinner party between -courses ciggies appeared, I would nip out of the room on some arbitrary excuse, or wave my hand to indicate I was still eating. A favourite was a short cough immediately followed by mumbling: "Not just now, thanks."

Why carry on with this ridiculous charade? Well smokers have a special camaraderie. It's like a club, a perfect relationship that can only be acquired between people who understand. Demand a smoker gives up and they will immediately take out a Silk Cut to blow smoke in your face. Smokers are only too happy to flaunt their habit, after all it's legal, rebellious and can be justified by providing the government with a huge income.

And more importantly how could I turn my back on the smokers' clan? The allure, fascination and desire to smoke is entwined with the need to be part of the fag fraternity. All those clandestine meetings, the conspiratorial whispers as the packet is slowly stripped of its cellophane cover; and the snort at non-smokers' efforts to make us stop. The smokers' clan is a powerful group, attack it and it redoubles its efforts to fight back. Kick the addicts and they bounce straight back up, cigarettes blazing. Ban us from the kitchen, and we move to the bathroom; ban us from the hall, we traipse into the garden; evict us from the office, and we happily pollute the street.

It was always us against the rest of the world - especially all those holier-than-thou do gooders. Go into a bar and what do you see - row upon row of smokers, laughing, joking and sharing. Watch the elegant French ladies on the beach and they come with a smoking stick in hand. But enter the pious world of west-coast anal America and they will shoot on sight if you so much as move a hand to your inside pocket. Get a life, we'd snigger.

And that is where a smokers' dilemma really does kick in, as we all know the real truth. It is a killer, and the life at risk is ours. Every year, around this time, we endure those appalling smoking statistics. The personal account of lung disease; the horrifying number of related premature deaths; the deep financial expense.

Yet all these shock-horror images and powerful words hold many back not a jot. Millions choose to carry on smoking despite the damning evidence. And the reasons for doing so are far more complex than addiction to nicotine.

But one year on, as I greeted 2001 it dawned on me: I am still surrounded by the same people as before, and that ever-present monkey on my back has gone. It's good not to live with the sub-conscious fear of some appalling illness. It's good not to have to slap my pockets to ensure the fags and matches are there, and it's good not to have to clear away the remains of a night's inhalation.

And I don't care who knows anymore.

webTitle: Should we be described as patients or clients?

fields.headline: Name and shame
fields.standfirst: Does it matter whether we are described as patients or clients? Theodore Dalrymple thinks it does
fields.trailText: Does it matter whether we are described as patients or clients? Theodore Dalrymple thinks it does.
fields.body:
Whenever I hear a patient called a client I shudder, just as I used to when my teacher caught her nail on the blackboard as she was writing on it with chalk. There is something about the term - it is simultaneously unctuous and euphemistic, as if some unpleasant reality were being concealed by its use. I can't help thinking we will soon hear prisoners referred to as "clients": even the term "con" would be preferable to that.

Patients in psychiatric services are now rarely referred to except as clients and the usage is now nearly universal. Indeed, if one still uses "patient", one can almost feel the disapproval. One is regarded as a reactionary and almost as an enemy of the people.

A paper in the latest Psychiatric Bulletin reports the first (admittedly small) survey of psychiatric patients and terminology: did they prefer to be called patients or clients? Overwhelmingly they preferred patients. Social class didn't matter nor did their diagnosis; in fact there was no identifiable subgroup that preferred to be called clients.

As the authors of the survey - psychiatrists at the Royal Free Hospital in London and at the Royal Park Hospital in Melbourne - point out, the two words have quite different connotations. A patient is a suffering person who either seeks or needs care. A client is a person who buys a service. Patients go to doctors, clients go to lawyers (or prostitutes).

The authors quote Ben Pimlott's introduction to the Penguin edition of Nineteen Eighty-Four: when Orwell noted the eagerness with which truth evaders shy away from well-known words and substitute their own he was observing it as something as relevant to petty bureaucrats as to dictators.

The demand that patients should become clients clearly did not originate with the patients themselves. I have never heard a single one ask to be called a client, though some, who wish to be left alone with their delusions and hallucinations, don't want to be called patients either.

Two questions emerge, one historical and one practical. Why did the change in terminology occur, and what happens next?

Ostensibly, the term client was introduced to equalise the relationship between the provider and recipient of help and attention. A client, after all, actively chooses his adviser and pays him: his payment stands guarantor of his dignity. In the NHS, no one pays his doctor or even chooses him. The patient gets whom he's given.

And a patient is much more passive, even when he does pay. He has things done to him. A patient, but not a client, is worthy of compassion because it is acknowledged that he is, by definition, a sufferer and therefore in need of succour and relief. An involuntary patient is not a contradiction in terms; but an involuntary client is.

The real reason for the change was a power struggle between various factions in the psychiatric services. It had nothing to do with the wishes of patients, or even with increasing professional respect for them.

Some people who worked in the psychiatric services just felt that doctors needed demoting, or putting in their place: and doctors above all see patients, therefore patients had to be turned into clients, whether they wanted it or not. As Humpty Dumpty so acutely remarked: "The question is, which is to be master - that's all."

It is not to be expected, therefore, that practices will change as a result of this survey. The march of the term client will continue, until it has been so widely used for so long that it becomes completely accepted, and no one will even be able to remember a time when it wasn't. A return to using the term patient would be a political defeat, its elimination a victory. In all this, patients (and clients for that matter) are mere pawns.

I suppose one might call the change from patient to client a little piece of linguistic engineering. I find it sinister: but perhaps I'm paranoid. In which case, of course, I need to become a client.
fields.bodyText: Whenever I hear a patient called a client I shudder, just as I used to when my teacher caught her nail on the blackboard as she was writing on it with chalk. There is something about the term - it is simultaneously unctuous and euphemistic, as if some unpleasant reality were being concealed by its use. I can't help thinking we will soon hear prisoners referred to as "clients": even the term "con" would be preferable to that. Patients in psychiatric services are now rarely referred to except as clients and the usage is now nearly universal. Indeed, if one still uses "patient", one can almost feel the disapproval. One is regarded as a reactionary and almost as an enemy of the people. A paper in the latest Psychiatric Bulletin reports the first (admittedly small) survey of psychiatric patients and terminology: did they prefer to be called patients or clients? Overwhelmingly they preferred patients. Social class didn't matter nor did their diagnosis; in fact there was no identifiable subgroup that preferred to be called clients. As the authors of the survey - psychiatrists at the Royal Free Hospital in London and at the Royal Park Hospital in Melbourne - point out, the two words have quite different connotations. A patient is a suffering person who either seeks or needs care. A client is a person who buys a service. Patients go to doctors, clients go to lawyers (or prostitutes). The authors quote Ben Pimlott's introduction to the Penguin edition of Nineteen Eighty-Four: when Orwell noted the eagerness with which truth evaders shy away from well-known words and substitute their own he was observing it as something as relevant to petty bureaucrats as to dictators. The demand that patients should become clients clearly did not originate with the patients themselves. I have never heard a single one ask to be called a client, though some, who wish to be left alone with their delusions and hallucinations, don't want to be called patients either. Two questions emerge, one historical and one practical. Why did the change in terminology occur, and what happens next? Ostensibly, the term client was introduced to equalise the relationship between the provider and recipient of help and attention. A client, after all, actively chooses his adviser and pays him: his payment stands guarantor of his dignity. In the NHS, no one pays his doctor or even chooses him. The patient gets whom he's given. And a patient is much more passive, even when he does pay. He has things done to him. A patient, but not a client, is worthy of compassion because it is acknowledged that he is, by definition, a sufferer and therefore in need of succour and relief. An involuntary patient is not a contradiction in terms; but an involuntary client is. The real reason for the change was a power struggle between various factions in the psychiatric services. It had nothing to do with the wishes of patients, or even with increasing professional respect for them. Some people who worked in the psychiatric services just felt that doctors needed demoting, or putting in their place: and doctors above all see patients, therefore patients had to be turned into clients, whether they wanted it or not. As Humpty Dumpty so acutely remarked: "The question is, which is to be master - that's all." It is not to be expected, therefore, that practices will change as a result of this survey. fields.headline: Marathon man
fields.trailText: Life was looking up really. My friends still liked me, the job was going reasonably well, I had narrowly avoided death at the tentacles of a rogue jellyfish off the coast of Australia, and my parents had bought me a food processor for Christmas.
fields.body:
Life was looking up really. My friends still liked me, the job was going reasonably well, I had narrowly avoided death at the tentacles of a rogue jellyfish off the coast of Australia, and my parents had bought me a food processor for Christmas. And then came the ludicrous urge to ruin my life by attempting to run 26 miles and 385 yards surrounded by a rhinoceros, builders dressed as nurses, policemen from Bangor and other hideousness.

Just a few unwise moments of thoughtlessness have led now to a grinding commitment: I am locked in to months of dread and a dreadful experience. Once committed to running a marathon, it's hard to get out of it without dying or at least losing a foot. The charity expects, your sponsors expect, your friends expect and desire pain.

In the next 12 weeks I am to run 390 miles, in a total of around 60 hours. That's the training plan laid down by the official London marathon web site. If you want to complete the 42.195 kms you should follow the plan, and stick to it - give up three nights a week to jogging plus your Saturday morning when all is required is a gentle two to three-hour trot. If I follow the plan by the morning of the race I will have run the equivalent of the distance from London to the Rowardennan Hotel on the banks of Loch Lomond, just north of Glasgow, at an average 6.5 miles an hour.

They say I'll get used to it and enjoy it. Bitterly cold evenings, ice underfoot, driving rain and no beer will become nothing short of one big party. Rather than arrive home to a cheery invite to the pub from my flat mate Fran, I am instead to enjoy running followed by carrot juice, raw vegetables and a handful of sand. The occasional cigarettes I smoke have now gone. The late nights will stop shortly.

Only the shopping bit has provided some relief. A new pair of trainers (see below), a thermal long sleeved top, some blue shorts and top socks: £113.50 on the road with a free official marathon stopwatch to measure my agony.

 Marathon man will run as a weekly column until the London marathon on April 22.

fields.headline: Online financial news provider raises £2.2m
fields.trailText: 4.15pm: Pan-European investment news aggregator EuropeanInvestor.com has raised £2.2m in second-round funding, reports Guy Middleton.
fields.body:
Pan-European investment news aggregator EuropeanInvestor.com has raised £2.2m in second-round funding. The move brings a small ray of hope to the beleaguered new media sector.

The online financial news sector has seen string of recent casualties as TheStreet.co.uk, The Motley Fool Germany and EO.net pulled the plug on their news sites.

EuropeanInvestor.com has raised the money from first-round investors Vertex Singapore and finance group Cairnwood, and is intended to bolster the company's technology infrastructure and staff development.

The Brussels-based stock market news and quotes site described the last year as being "enormously successful", however it was marked by significant shift in direction and the redundancy of a team of journalists and analysts.

Launched in October 1999, the site produced original news content from a team of journalists, but shifted towards content aggregation, buying in its content from a range of news agencies including Reuters and AFX, rather than producing its own.

This shift was matched by a move into providing business-orientated aggregation service to institutions and to other websites, a practise the company describes as a b2b2c model.

The company offers stock market data and news from 14 European exchanges, aiming to offer an overview of the European business scene.

The company lists Citibank, First-E, BT, KBN, Orange and Proximus among its customers.

Last year Reuters Greenhouse, the venture capital arm of the business information group, led a $21m investment in news aggregator Moreover.com. The company backed an aggregator while declining to invest in a content provider it had been in negotiation with - the pan-European new economy magazine and website Tornado-Insider.com.

webTitle: Tiananmen revelations raise new questions about massacre

fields.headline: Tiananmen revelations raise new questions about massacre
fields.standfirst: A US book claims to give new insights into the Beijing uprising and John Gittings says the claims have reached China on the web, prompting renewed interest in how the students' uprising was crushed
fields.trailText: Beijing's official reaction to the "Tiananmen Papers" emerged with unusual speed today - only three days after the contents of the dossier were revealed in the US.
fields.body:
Beijing's official reaction to the "Tiananmen Papers" emerged with unusual speed today - only three days after the contents of the dossier were revealed in the US.

Yet however much China insists that the collection consists of "fabricated materials and distorted facts", the new debate about responsibility for the Beijing massacre of June 1989 can hardly be stopped.

The papers raise obvious awkward questions about the role of several current leaders and the collective responsibility of the Communist party which still rules China. They may also revive some critical arguments over the tactics of the pro-democracy students in Tiananmen Square.

By reacting so swiftly, Beijing seems to acknowledge that it cannot prevent the contents of the documents circulating internally.

Indeed, China's web guerrillas leapt into action within a day of the news breaking. On the main People's Daily discussion group, one of them slipped in a tersely subversive message just before the site closed down for the night. "Web friends," it said simply, "our day has come!"

The message was promptly spiked by the unseen monitor, with a note that it was a "mistaken document".

Another anonymous writer posted a more subtle message, urging that a Chinese-language news website in the US should be blocked. Others chimed in complaining that the offending site carried "politically reactionary content" which would be banned on the mainland.

The site in question - whose address was posted helpfully by the alleged complainants - just happened to carry news reports of the Tiananmen Papers.

In the 21st century world of instant communications and proxy servers, young Chinese wishing to read the unexpurgated version of why and how their leaders smashed the aspirations of a previous generation of Chinese youth in 1989 will have little difficulty.

They will read how the former Communist party secretary-general Zhao Ziyang argued in vain for dialogue with the students, telling the council of elders headed by Deng Xiaoping that the party had lost credibility. Mr Zhao has been under virtual house arrest ever since, a forgotten hero - but these documents could revive his memory.

They will learn how Mr Zhao's arch-rival, the then premier, Li Peng, played on the fears of the ancient generals and revolutionary veterans by insinuating that the students in the square were manipulated by Taiwan and the CIA.

They will learn too that Jiang Zemin, now president of China, was set on his path to power by a secret decision of the Council of Elders to place him in Mr Zhao's position.

The decision - taken before the dreadful night of June 3-4, 1989 - does not actually implicate Mr Jiang in the slaughter which took place. But it brings him closer to it by association, as well as having been constitutionally incorrect.

Extracts from the Tiananmen Papers are published today in a book edited by two prominent US China scholars, Andrew Nathan and Perry Link. It would seem almost impossible to forge a collection of such length and detail, but in spite of the editors' reputation, the question of authenticity still has to be raised.

The documents are only a selection from what are said to amount to 15,000 pages in translated English text, smuggled out by a "disaffected civil servant" from China with the apparent backing of reformists in the leadership today.

Unfortunately, the editors have chosen not to release the original Chinese texts - which would provide a more reliable test - until later. Nor can we assume that every document in the collection is of equal reliability.

However, the material published so far is consistent with what we already know about the bitter leadership debate of those tense weeks.

And several documents circulating at the time in Tiananmen Square also gave (much more briefly) a similar account of the malign role of Li Peng and the elders' paranoia on which he played.

It must also be acknowledged that the new documents appear to provide justification for criticisms later made of the students' tactics.

Admittedly they had little incentive to engage in creative diplomacy while the government dithered and ignored their demands for "dialogue".

But by staying in the square even when President Gorbachev arrrived on a state visit, and by giving no hint that they would ever leave, the students seem to have tipped the balance in the secret debate in Mr Deng's residence. The loss of public face was too much for the octogenarian generals and party veterans to bear.

Significantly it was Deng Yingchao, widow of the late Premier Zhou Enlai (widely regarded as a moderate figure) who summed up the elders' beleaguered psychosis.

"Retreat means that we fall, that the People's Republic falls, that a capitalist restoration wins: it will be what that American (the 1950s US Secretary of state John Foster) Dulles hoped for, that our socialism would turn into capitalism after a few generations," she said.

In more bellicose mood, ex-General Wang Zhen raged: "The students are nuts if they think this handful of people can overthrow our people and government."

This "us or them" mentality chimes with the remarks of another ex-general, Yang Shangkun, in a speech summarising the elders' views which was reported unofficially at the time in a leaflet circulating in Tiananmen Square.

"(They) all agreed that there was no way to retreat", said Yang. "If we did we would fall from power. Capitalism would be restored. Just as the American Dulles had hoped, after several generations our socialism would turn into liberalism."

Yang quoted Chen Yun ( in his 80s like the other elders) as warning that this would mean "negating the Communist party".

Political discussion has been artificially held back ever since 1989: Chinese reformers are still unable to raise the sort of questions which were openly debated in the mid-1980s about the need for internal party democracy and accountability of the government to the people.

The release of these documents abroad may serve to re-open some of these arguments and loosen the inhibition of discussing the past.

China's leadership and people have moved on, and no one expects a repeat of the activism or the repression of 1989.

Yet the fundamental problem remains much the same - how to promote political as well as economic reform without panicking the power-holders.

fields.headline: Mark Thomas boosts Channel 4 share
fields.trailText: TV Overnights 3.30pm: Controversy about the provocative comedy show The Mark Thomas Product boosted audience share to 11%, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The advance publicity surrounding a Labour minister's alleged dirty tricks campaign against The Mark Thomas Product helped the comedian's show return to Channel 4 with a robust audience last night.

The Mark Thomas Product, which prides itself on asking awkward questions and getting up the noses of government ministers and civil servants, had 1.1m and an 11% share - good numbers for a Channel 4 late night show - from 11.10pm last night, according to unofficial overnights.

Another returning show, BBC2's Room 101, also opened strongly last night. The spectacle of Paul Merton quizzing magician Paul Daniels about his pet hates, which included motor show Top Gear, drew 3m - 13% of available viewers - to BBC2 from 10pm.

Earlier in the evening, BBC2 got good mileage out of repeated documentary Journeys to the Bottom of the Sea. The programme, about the search for a Royal Navy submarine that sank in 1925 with the loss of 69 lives, also attracted an audience of 3m, 9-9.50pm.

The documentary beat Channel 4 film premiere Paradise Road, which 2.4m and an 11% share from 9pm.

ITV's Caroline Quentin drama The Innocent concluded with 8.9m and a 36% share from 9pm.

It comfortably beat BBC1 opposition 2000 Acres of Sky, which had 6.4m, and a Vicar of Dibley repeat, which drew 6.3m.

webTitle: Heads roll at BMG as EMI merger nears

fields.headline: Heads roll at BMG as EMI merger nears
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: BMG, the music subsidiary of German media giant Bertelsmann, has shed two top executives as it continues a management reshuffle ahead of its merger with EMI.
fields.body:
BMG, the music subsidiary of German media giant Bertelsmann, has shed two top executives as it continues a management reshuffle ahead of its merger with EMI.

A successful link-up with UK music group EMI will create the world's largest music company, and BMG is keen to have its management structure in place by the time a deal is concluded.

Bertelsmann today confirmed that Kevin Conroy, head of worldwide marketing, and Tom McIntyre, chief financial officer, have quit BMG. The announcement follows the departure last year of chairman Michael Dornemann and chief executive Strauss Zelnick.

Bertelsmann insiders said Conroy and McIntyre were part of BMG's "old guard" and decided to leave following the departure of Dornemann and Zelnick.

The sudden death of chief executive-designate Rudi Gassner in December last year forced the appointment of Bertelsmann chief creative officer Rolf Schmidt-Holtz as the new boss of BMG. His extensive experience of mergers is expected to help the company push the EMI merger through by the end of the month, although it will face scrutiny by EU watchdogs.

webTitle: Dome marketing director moves to Reuters' new venture Kalends

fields.headline: Dome marketing director moves to Reuters' new venture Kalends
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: The Millennium Dome's marketing director, Sholto Douglas-Home, is to head up the marketing operation of Reuters' new venture Kalends, reports Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
The Millennium Dome's marketing director, Sholto Douglas-Home, is to head up the marketing operation of Reuters' new venture Kalends.

Douglas-Home, 38, will be relieved to be finally free from his controversy-soaked role at the ill-fated Dome project.

"I could not resist the infectious energy in the Kalends team and the entrepreneurial spirit that pervades Reuters," he said.

Douglas-Home's contract ended with the closure of the Dome on December 31. His job there has been described as "the toughest job in the business".

Kalends is a future events information service covering finance, sport and general news which users access over the internet, through mobile phones or via other digital devices.

It is the first venture to emerge from Reuterspace, the new division charged with extending Reuters business beyond its traditional financial markets.

Before taking on the high-profile job at the Dome, Douglas-Home was head of advertising and PR for BT's consumer division for two years, with an annual budget of over £75m.

webTitle: Johnny 'Mad Dog' Adair will stay in jail

fields.headline: Johnny 'Mad Dog' Adair will stay in jail
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The loyalist paramilitary leader, Johnny Adair, will stay in jail after the Northern Ireland sentence review commission today reversed an earlier decision to free him.
fields.body:
The loyalist paramilitary leader, Johnny Adair, will stay in jail after the Northern Ireland sentence review commission today reversed an earlier decision to free him.

Adair's supporters immediately said they will challenge the decision in the high court.

A preliminary ruling that would have allowed Adair to walk free from the Maghaberry prison near Lisburn, Co Antrim, was opposed by the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, and the Royal Ulster Constabulary chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan.

John White, chairman of the Ulster Democratic party, claimed his continued incarceration amounted to "another form of internment without trial".

He said: "We will be going for a judicial review. I feel the decision has been overturned on the basis of evidence given in camera, which is totally unfair.

"It's a fundamental right within the criminal justice system and the judiciary process if charges are lobbed at someone he should know the type of evidence presented and is able to defend himself."

Adair, 37, from Belfast's Shankill Road and linked to the Ulster Freedom Fighters terrorist group, was sent back to jail last August at the outbreak of a rival loyalist shooting war which left seven men dead.

Adair was originally jailed in the early 1990s for directing a series of sectarian killings. No fewer than 22 murders were linked with him. He was sentenced to 16 years, but was let out on licence in September 1999 under the early-release provisions of the Good Friday peace agreement.

Almost immediately he resumed courting controversy, making flamboyant appearances at loyalist rallies and giving provocative interviews. Mr Mandelson ordered his return to prison in August last year.

Although he claims to support the peace process, Adair remains closely associated with the banned Ulster Freedom Fighters, the ultra-militant wing of the Ulster Defence Association.

webTitle: New society formed for mental health experts

fields.headline: New society formed for mental health experts
fields.trailText: A new international academic society has been created to bring together researchers working on mental health problems.
fields.body:
A new international academic society has been created to bring together researchers working on mental health problems.

The International Society for Affective Disorders will enable academics from genetics, neuroscience, pharmacology, psychology, public health and the social sciences who are studying problems such as anxiety, panic attacks and depression.

The society is the brainchild of Prof Chris Thompson, head of the University of Southampton Department of Mental Health.

Society members will be able to work together daily on the Internet and through more conventional academic publications, conferences and seminars.

They will be able to post peer-reviewed publications and notices on the Society's website, find out about the latest research and talk to other professionals in an online chat room.

Depression is forecast to become the second biggest cause of disability in the world over the next decade.

The society hopes to attract more than 5,000 members world-wide over the next year.

fields.headline: The Mirror launches corrections column
fields.trailText: 2pm: The Mirror has launched a new column to correct factual errors very much like the Guardian's Clarifications and Corrections column, reports Matt Wells.
fields.body:
With G2, the Guide and Weekend magazine, the Guardian has always been a market leader. Today, another Guardian innovation has been taken up by a rival.

The Mirror has announced that it is to run its own version of the Guardian's corrections and clarifications column. Its feature, For the Record, starts tomorrow under the stewardship of David Seymour, group political editor.

"There are bound to be times when we slip up and a mistake creeps in. And we are not afraid to admit it," the paper said in its introduction to the column today.

For the Record appears to be modelled on the Guardian's Corrections and Clarifications, which began in November 1997.

It will appear on the letters page, be concerned with factual errors rather than differences of opinion, and be independent of the editor. The Mirror has even adopted the Readers' Editor title, invented by the Guardian's Ian Mayes.

Mayes welcomed the move. "I think it's very good news for readers of the Mirror. After doing the job here for just over three years I'm a more enthusiastic advocate of the idea than ever. Journalists like to pride themselves on their sense of fair play yet are happy to call for accountability in others without being truly accountable themselves. Our system is not perfect but I'm convinced we're going in the right direction, and it's entirely good that others are joining in."

Alan Rusbridger, the Guardian's editor, said: "This is a brave step by the Mirror. I've long thought that every broadsheet newspaper would end up having a Reader's Editor - it will be seen as a natural part of the bond of trust that has to exist between journalist and reader. It's very enlightened act by Piers Morgan to introduce the mechanism onto a tabloid."

The Mirror is only the second paper in Britain to take up the idea, although the concept of a readers ombudsman is common in the US. Politiken, a Copenhagen daily, started a column based on the Guardian model on January 1.

Some sources on the Mirror wondered whether the column would be a success: the relationship between Piers Morgan and Seymour has been strained in the past. But others said Morgan was excited about the move, and determined to make it work. It may even reduce the paper's legal bill: if the column is taken seriously, mistakes are likely to be corrected far more swiftly and with less likelihood of a recourse to legal action.

The Mirror said it would not include "trivial mistakes", declaring: "Only significant mistakes about facts will be covered." We can be sure, then, that For the Record will not include a regular "homophone corner".

webTitle: Government cash boost to personal safety centre

fields.headline: Government cash boost to personal safety centre
fields.standfirst: In recognition of fears over attack the government hands over crime reduction cash to help set up a  Suzy Lamplugh Trust centre.
fields.trailText: The government hands over crime reduction cash to help set up a Suzy Lamplugh Trust centre. Nicola Hill reports.
fields.body:
A 19-year-old woman waited on a pavement in London last Saturday night for a taxi she had booked. Within minutes, five men approached her pretending to be the taxi driver, before the genuine one appeared. Luckily she had the sense to ask them for her name and chosen destination and avoided a potentially dangerous situation.

In the latest British crime survey one in 10 people thought it likely that they would be mugged or attacked by a stranger.

The government has responded to the actual and perceived danger of attack by awarding a £500,000 cash boost to the Suzy Lamplugh Trust, to help set up an international personal safety centre. The money is part of the government's £250m crime reduction programme.

The trust was founded in 1986 after the abduction and presumed murder of estate agent Suzy Lamplugh. It promotes personal safety and aims to create a safer society. The charity provides a range of practical products and training for the personal safety of people in the workplace, schools and in everyday lives.

The centre aims to reduce fear of crime and victimisation as well as offering a specialist resource for advice, training and education on personal safety issues.

It will be composed of several buildings to be established on a semi-derelict site near Kings Cross, London. The centre could be fully functioning within two years but aspects of it will be opened as soon as possible. The money will fund the salary of a project manager and contribute towards architects, fundraising and marketing costs.

Diana Lamplugh, Suzy's mother and founder of the trust, said: "We aim to establish a centre of excellence, working with other voluntary sector partners and at least seven government departments. We want to create a society where people can live safely and without fear."

Home Office minister Charles Clarke said: "The Suzy Lamplugh Trust has proved its expertise in providing practical guidance, training and support on personal safety for everyone."

fields.headline: It's usually the economy, stupid
fields.standfirst: Unless there is disaster for Tony Blair in the next couple of months, the strong economy points to a Labour election victory, writes economics editor Larry Elliott
fields.trailText: 9 January, Comment: Unless there is disaster for Tony Blair in the next couple of months, the strong economy points to a Labour election victory, writes economics editor Larry Elliott.
fields.body:
Blame Bill Clinton. It was the soon-to-be-departed US president who gave us the over-used phrase "it's the economy, stupid", when he was campaigning for the White House in 1992.

But although hearing a politician utter those four little words for the umpteenth time is enough to make you scream, there is no getting away from the fact that when it comes to general elections, the economy is usually the deciding factor.

Crime, schools, the state of the railways, hospital waiting lists might all be factors in deciding how we vote, but all the parties agree that the difference between success and failure on election night is what is happening to living standards, inflation and unemployment.

The generally benign state of the economy is the reason Tony Blair hopes to be the first Labour leader to win two full terms as prime minister.

Unemployment, as measured by the number of people out of work and claiming benefit, is just over 1m, inflation is comfortably below the government's 2.5% target, earnings for those in work are rising by just over 4% a year, the treasury's coffers are awash with cash that is available for tax giveaways or higher public spending in the Budget.

But a word of caution is useful here. There are times, as in 1992, when governments can win elections even when the economy is in recession, and there are times, as in 1997, when they can lose them even though all the economic indicators are looking good.

In 1992, despite record bankruptcies, record home repossessions and unemployment close to 3m, John Major won a narrow victory because hard-pressed voters appeared to believe that life would become even tougher under Neil Kinnock.

But within months of that victory, the Conservative party's entire economic strategy was wrecked by the financial speculation that led to the pound's ejection from the exchange rate mechanism. Although the economy subsequently recovered, voters neither forgave nor forgot the events of September 1992.

So, a more accurate - if rather less snappy - soundbite would be that it's usually the economy, stupid.

Governments lose elections in the aftermath of big economic catastrophes - the devaluation of 1967 and the sterling crisis of 1976 were followed by Labour defeats - and oppositions find it hard to win when life is sweet, as in 1959 and 1987.

Unless something goes seriously wrong for Mr Blair in the next couple of months, the portents are good.

fields.headline: Newham failing on social services
fields.trailText: A damning independent report has said Newham's social services are seriously inadequate, with children's services in the east London borough being particularly bad. Linda Steele reports
fields.body:
Newham's social services are seriously inadequate, with children's services in the east London borough being particularly bad, according to a damning independent report.

A joint review by the social services inspectorate and the audit commission has found "confusion and weaknesses in the frontline response". Residents of Newham "are not consistently well served by their social services department and vulnerable people still find it difficult to access the help they need", despite an ambitious programme of change and some service improvements in recent years.

"Children's services are of particular concern," say the report's authors. Risks to young people were neither promptly identified nor reliably managed. When the joint review took place during June and July 2000, more than 500 children at risk or in care had not been allocated a social worker.

The joint review team says the authority must "focus more closely on basic quality and performance" and address "the issues of most immediate concern, including unacceptably long waiting times for services, protecting those at risk and uneven standards of social work practice".

The report cites low morale, a lack of training and high staff turnover and vacancies as key problems. A split exists between senior staff, who are enthusiastic for change, and staff on the ground, who are dissatisfied, under "considerable pressure" and suffering "change fatigue". The report also notes that personnel changes at a senior level had created "considerable difficulties".

At the time of the review, the post of assistant director (children and families) had been vacant for six months, with a temporary appointment being made last June. Also, social services director Deborah Cameron announced her early retirement around the time of the review and left last autumn. A new director, Kathryn Hudson, started in the new year.

The report points to a good record on strategic planning, partnership working, and commissioning and some innovative new schemes. However, these do not always translate into improvements in existing, mainstream services. "The prospects for continuous improvement are worrying," say the authors.

Newham chief executive Dave Burbage said the review team's judgment was "harsh", although the council accepted the report in full.

"The report itself points out that Newham has a track record in delivering service improvements," he said. "Considerable progress has been made since the initial findings were presented to us in August." The council had created an action plan with "a commitment to ensure greater attention is paid to effective performance management and the delivery of a quality service to users".

A spokesman for the council added that the number of children without a social worker was now down to 225. He said the council was trying to recruit more social workers and was about to advertise four care manager vacancies.

Newham is the second most deprived local authority area in the country. Almost half of its predominantly young population are from minority ethnic groups.

The department had a projected overspend of £800,000 for 2001-02. The report says the department must finalise its medium-term financial strategy and achieve a balanced budget.

webTitle: Jaeger hires marketeer to ditch frumpy image

fields.headline: Jaeger hires marketeer to ditch frumpy image
fields.trailText: 2.15pm: Jaeger has hired a former Mulberry marketeer Graham Sim to help it shake off its "twinset and pearls" image, reports Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Jaeger has hired a former Mulberry marketeer Graham Sim to help it shake off its "twinset and pearls" image and try to emulate the amazing transformation of rival brand Burberry.

Mr Sim has joined in the new position of marketing director. He left Mulberry in the middle of last year after launching a new collection in conjunction with up-and-coming designer Scott Henshall. He has been replaced by Philip Thomas

He was unavailable for comment but is thought to have joined in the past few weeks.

Jaeger, best known for its sensible tweeds and classic women's wear, is trying to shake off its dowdy image and grow as a fashionable brand.

The revolution is being masterminded by Pat Burnett, who took over of chief executive of the Jaeger and Viyella fashion retailer business last summer.

The company hired ad agency Bartle Bogle Hegarty last summer to advise of brand building.

It is expected to begin a new ad campaign in the spring, with a new collection designed by Bella Freud, dress designer to stars including Madonna and Courtney Love.

Over recent years rival clothing firm Burberry has undergone a remarkable transformation.

By drafting in new models including Kate Moss, it has shaken off a reputation for sensible raincoats and became a must-have street fashion brand.

In November its owner Great Universal Stores announced a stock market flotation for Burberry on the back of its success.
