fields.headline: Saturday night at the adverts
fields.standfirst: Film-goers are being urged to go to the cinema just to see a trailer for the Lord of the Rings. Andrew Pulver on marketable marketing
fields.trailText: Film-goers are being urged to go to the cinema just to see a trailer for the Lord of the Rings. Andrew Pulver on marketable marketing.
fields.body:
There's an advert currently going out on Virgin radio encouraging listeners to go to the cinema this Friday. Nothing strange about that, except that it's not a film that's being advertised. It does urge you go to a film - Lost Souls, with Winona Ryder - but only because this is the first opportunity to see the trailer for The Fellowship of the Ring, the first part of the Lord of the Rings trilogy being shot back-to-back in New Zealand. The film will be released next Christmas. Such is the anticipation that the film's distributor, Entertainment Films, is calling attention to its own marketing devices.

Of course, the principal motivation for any diehard Tolkien fan to make the effort to see the trailer is the chance - the first chance - to see scraps of actual footage on the big screen. The film's website (www.lordoftherings.net) has been carrying bits and pieces edited together as a "preview" for internet fans since last April, but Friday marks the first time that cinemas will see anything of a project that will be filling the seats for the next three years.

This isn't the first time that a trailer has had the power to hook film-goers on its own strengths. Back in 1998, George Lucas announced that a two-minute preview segment for Star Wars: The Phantom Menace was to screen in US cinemas. Fans bought tickets in droves to catch it, then walked out before the start of the main feature. The trailer - which represented millions of dollars in lab costs and advertising time - was consequently dubbed "the nine-dollar trailer".

Few movies, however, can command Star Wars' clout, and it may be presumptuous of Lord of the Rings to try. But if the commotion that has surrounded it ever since the announcement of production in August 1998 is anything to go by, there might be something in it.

First of all, the original book's constituency has evolved into one of the most slavishly consumerist of our time: the comic-book-reading, Dungeons-and-Dragon-playing, internet-surfing fanboy. For the last decade or so, film-makers have grown proficient at separating this segment of the audience from its cash - via films like X-Men, the seven Star Trek movies, Mortal Kombat and, indeed, the upcoming Dungeons and Dragons adaptation. Internet fan sites are a natural option for this breed, and two high profile efforts - www.tolkien-movies.com and www.theonering.net - have been avidly disseminating production-related minutiae ever since. This is on top of the official website, set up by backers New Line Cinema. It's no surprise, to be honest, that the Tolkien family are currently feeling besieged by Rings devotees, as they have recently complained.

Secondly, there's the matter of self-generating momentum. Teaser trailers, screened well before release, are a well-established tactic by cinema marketers as they attempt to build up anticipation before the opening weekend. And as cinema distribution gets more and more sophisticated, involving higher than ever outlay, the actual tools of the trade are accruing ever more attention.

The £70m spend on Lord of the Rings will be easily matched by the marketing budget, which will involve a globally coordinated campaign of different kinds of trailers. Committing, as New Line has, to making three feature films at once, is a desperately ambitious undertaking, even more so for the cinematically unknown quantity that Tolkien is. Turning a sprawling literary fantasy into an event movie three times over will require considerable commercial acuity, and what we're seeing now is the thin end of a wedge that will be with us until - if everything goes to plan - Christmas 2003.

For Lost Souls, the film which Entertainment is releasing on Friday, promoting the Ring preview is probably the best thing that could happen to it. It has already bombed in the US, and is likely to do the same here. With a bit of luck a few people might stick around after the real entertainment, and actually watch the movie.

fields.headline: Zoff is new Lazio coach
fields.trailText: Former Italy coach Dino Zoff has been appointed as Lazio's new coach following the resignation of Sven-Goran Eriksson.
fields.body:
Former Italy coach Dino Zoff has been appointed as Lazio's new coach following the resignation of Sven-Goran Eriksson.

Zoff, the former Italy goalkeeper and captain of the side that won the World Cup in 1982, had been working as club vice-president since he resigned as Italy coach after Euro 2000.

Zoff was coach of Lazio between 1990 and 1994 before becoming club president and he returned to the bench as caretaker manager midway through the 1996-97 season.

He led Italy to the final of Euro 2000 in July 2000, but surprisingly quit following criticism by Silvio Berlusconi of his performance in the "golden goal" defeat by France.

fields.headline: Eriksson resigns as Lazio coach
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson has resigned as Lazio coach, and could begin his involvement with England as early as next month's friendly against Spain.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson has resigned as Lazio coach, and could begin his involvement with England as early as next month's friendly against Spain.

Eriksson broke the news to the Lazio squad when they reported for training this morning after meeting with Lazio president Sergio Cragnotti last night, according to the Italian news agency ANSA.

ANSA claim that during the meeting Cragnotti asked Eriksson to resign, with the Swede refusing. However, after sleeping on it, it appears that Eriksson concluded he had no choice but to leave.

A spokeswoman for Lazio was unable to officially confirm the report but said the club would make a statement shortly.

The decision leaves Eriksson free to take charge as England coach. His contract officially starts on July 1, but he is now expected to play some role in next month's friendly against Spain, alongside caretaker coach Peter Taylor who is in charge for the game.

Eriksson's position at Lazio was thrown into doubt following the shock 2-1 home defeat to lowly Napoli on Sunday, which left the Italian champions 11 points behind leaders AS Roma.

ANSA said Cragnotti was expected shortly at Lazio's Formello training ground, where he is expected to hold talks with club vice-president Dino Zoff, the former Italy and Lazio coach, and the man widely tipped as Eriksson's successor.

webTitle: Bulger killers granted anonymity for life

fields.headline: Bulger killers granted anonymity for life
fields.trailText: The killers of two-year-old James Bulger won an unprecedented court order yesterday granting them anonymity for the rest of their lives when they leave custody with new identities.
fields.body:
The killers of two-year-old James Bulger won an unprecedented court order yesterday granting them anonymity for the rest of their lives when they leave custody with new identities.

Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, England's most senior family judge, granted the order - described by Desmond Browne, QC for the newspapers that opposed it, as "a historic first" - to protect Robert Thompson and Jon Venables from possible revenge attacks by James Bulger's relatives and the public.

The order, the first granted to protect the identity of an adult, bans the media from disclosing information about the new identities, addresses, appearance, and even the accents of the pair, who are expected to be freed within months.

In addition, no information may be published for 12 months about the eight years they have spent in local authority secure units in the north of England, including their rehabilitation and educational regimes.

The pair, now 18, were aged 10 in February 1993 when they battered the two-year-old to death and left him on a Liverpool railway line.

They are expected to be released soon after a ruling last October by Lord Woolf, the lord chief justice, that they had served the minimum term necessary for punishment and deterrence. They are likely to set up home somewhere in the north of England with new identities provided by the Home Office.

Their application for permanent injunctions protecting their new identities was opposed by News Group, Associated Newspapers and the Mirror Group.

Only Mary Bell, who killed two small boys in 1968 when she was 12, has had the benefit of such a wide-ranging injunction. But in her case, the order was granted to protect not her but her daughter, who was under 18 and a ward of court.

There was no power at the time to grant anonymity to an adult. But Dame Elizabeth, president of the high court's family division, ruled yesterday that the new Human Rights Act, with its duty on the state to protect the right to life, gave the court jurisdiction to make such an order for the first time.

She quoted a wide selection of inflammatory press reports, including a statement by James Bulger's father, Ralph, that he would "hunt down" his son's killers once they were released. These, together with Home Office evidence and other information, "convinced me that these young men are uniquely notorious and are at serious risk of attacks from members of the public as well as from relatives and friends of the murdered child," she said.

"In the exceptional circumstances of this case and applying English domestic law and the right to life enshrined in article 2 of the European convention, I have come to the conclusion that I am compelled to take steps in the almost unique circumstances of this case to protect their lives and physical well-being."

The injunction does not apply to newspapers in Scotland or abroad and does not prevent publication on non-media websites. But the media in England and Wales will not be able to publish just because the information is in the public domain through the internet or a foreign newspaper. Dame Elizabeth granted the newspapers leave to appeal, adding: "It seems to be entirely right if I've given a judgment which to say the least is unusual, the court of appeal should be entitled to review it and tell me whether I'm right or wrong."

Denise Fergus, James's mother, said in a statement: "They simply don't deserve it. What right have they got to be given special protection as adults?"

But the detective who investigated James's death backed the decision granting his killers anonymity. Former Det Supt Albert Kirby said: "I am relieved. I was concerned that had their identities and where they had been located not been protected there would have been a repetition of the behaviour that took place last year in the exposé over paedophiles. And also the very difficult and complex process of rehabilitation would be badly affected."

webTitle: Morning after pill enters the high street

fields.headline: Morning after pill enters the high street
fields.standfirst: So-called emergency contraception is now available without a prescription. So can you just walk into a chemist's and buy it, no questions asked? Victoria Moore gives the lowdown
fields.trailText: So-called emergency contraception is now available without a prescription. So can you just walk into a chemist's and buy it, no questions asked? Victoria Moore gives the lowdown.
fields.body:
We've all been there, and if you haven't your girlfriend has. The doctor's appointment shoehorned into a day that's already too busy. Minutes slipping past in the waiting room as you struggle to come up with a plausible explanation for why (and how, exactly) you've had unprotected sex.

Now, however, emergency hormonal contraceptives are to be available, not just on prescription from doctors' surgeries, family planning clinics and selected accident and emergency centres, but also over-the-counter at a chemist's.

Levonelle (the so-called morning-after pill) was removed from prescription-only control on January 1. Only then were Schering, its makers, free to start supplying the drug to the high street, with the result that while some pharmacies might receive stock as early as this week most of Britain's 15,000 chemists are not guaranteed delivery until January 30.

Those pharmacists who choose on moral or religious grounds not to sell it will be obliged to carry information about the nearest stockists. Boots say that all their pharmaceutical stores will carry supplies. Levonelle is not going to be difficult to find.

This has medical as well as convenience benefits. For while these pills can be taken up to 72 hours after unprotected intercourse, they are known to be more effective if taken sooner rather than later. (Levonelle is believed to prevent 95% of expected pregnancies if taken within 24 hours but only 58% if taken within 48-72 hours).

So no appointments, no waiting rooms, no uncomfortable questions? Almost. A slim little box containing two progestogen pills (to be taken 12 hours apart) is still not going to be as simple a purchase as suntan cream. There will be no slipping it quietly into your basket - you'll have to ask for it (tip: rather than make a foghorn decree of your nocturnal activities by demanding the "morning-after pill" try keeping icy composure and simply ask for Levonelle). And your boyfriend probably won't be able to buy it on your behalf either.

Before they sell the drug pharmacists are required by their professional body, the Royal Pharmaceutical Society (RPS), to obtain certain information from buyers. Expect a quick chat that ought to cover the following points.

First, pharmacists are supposed to satisfy themselves that their customer is 16 or over. Whether they go so far as to ask for proof of age is discretionary. They will also want to know that the pill is for you: RPS guidelines state that only in exceptional circumstances should Levonelle be sold to someone other than the patient.

The pharmacist will then seek to establish that you do need to take the pill; in other words, that you have had unprotected sex within the last 72 hours. Women ought to remember that they are not required to provide either details or excuses (although the pharmacist may make suggestions about suitable contraceptives); simply state the facts.

They will want to know if you could already be pregnant, in which case there would be no point selling this pill (though Levonelle does not appear to harm the baby if you do take it while already pregnant). So expect to be asked: Is your period late? If so, how late? Was the last one lighter or shorter than normal or unusual in any other way? Since the last one has there been unprotected sex at any time before this occasion?

The pharmacist ought also to check that you are not taking any medicine that might interfere with Levonelle and that you have no problems (such as vomiting or severe diarrhoea) that might affect its absorption. Finally, you will be asked if you are aware of having an allergy to levonorgestrel, the ingredient in Levonelle, or if you have a severe liver complaint, in which case this drug is not recommended.

Once you've got through that you'll have to pay £19.99 (significantly more than the standard prescription charge of £6.00 you'd pay after a visit to the doctor). With Levonelle, doctors say you don't have to worry about the side- effects - nausea and vomiting - notoriously associated with its predecessor "morning-after pill" the PC4.

A very small incidence of nausea and very occasional vomiting has been reported, says Professor Peter Bowen Simpkins, treasurer of the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists. "But the recommendation is that it is taken with food and the incidence then is much reduced."

Levonelle is a progestogen-only pill. (Progestogen is a synthetic form of the hormone progesterone; PC4 contains progestogen and oestrogen). It's fine to take it if you miss your ordinary contraceptive pill. But it's worth remembering that the most dangerous time to miss a pill is not around day 13 (the most fertile point in the cycle), when you are substantially protected by the 10 or so pills already taken, but at the beginning of the packet, by elongating the pill-free week.

It is not related to the so-called abortion-pill, an anti-progesterone that induces menstruation and is only licensed in this country as a medical form of termination of pregnancy. Instead, Levonelle works in three ways. First, it stops or delays the ovaries from releasing an egg. Second, it prevents the sperm from fertilising an egg that might have been released. And third, "and this is the bone of contention," says Professor Bowen-Simpkins, "it may interfere with implantation of the egg in the womb". This is why some say taking Levonelle is tantamount to having a very early abortion.

Is there a level of usage at which, from a health point of view, worry might set in?

Professor Bowen-Simpkins says not that he knows of, "except for more than once a cycle because then you may get chaotic menstruation. The point is that we would be failing a patient who needed to take it so often by not giving them reliable contraception. After all, Levonelle is not 100% successful. It should only be seen as a back-up."

One grey area remains: whether emergency contraceptives can be stashed away in advance without resorting to telling fibs to a pharmacist. The RPS advises its members that supply in advance of need is not currently recommended and instructs them only to offer clients advice on where such a service is provided locally.

In fact, the British Pregnancy Advisory Service (BPAS) has been providing women with advance supplies of emergency hormonal contraception - first PC4, now Levonelle - for about 18 months for about £15 (which includes a consultation with a doctor) a go.

So perhaps the morning-after pill bought at the chemist the night before is not so very far away.

Four women describe their morning-after pill experience Ellen Davis, 29

Ellen had been on the pill for eight years when she decided to give her body a break. "We started using condoms, and one night one split. It was a Friday, the worst possible time. I knew about the morning-after pill, but I had no idea how to get hold of it outside surgery hours." She and her boyfriend got up at the crack of dawn on Saturday, phoned various friends, then headed for a clinic in Notting Hill, west London. "I was given a lot of literature about contraception, which did make me laugh. I mean, I'd been on the pill for so many years, I thought I knew what was what, and they were treating me like a teenager."

Lynne Robinson, 44

Lynne split up with husband when their daughter was four and since then she hasn't had a long term relationship. "Contraception was a totally dead issue as far as I was concerned." But in December she had a one-night-stand with a former colleague: they were drunk and had unprotected sex. The following morning, Lynne was in shock. She went to her doctor. Arriving at the surgery, she felt as if the practice nurse was treating her like a naughty schoolgirl. "Things got worse after I took the first pair of tablets. I threw up after an hour - well I was feeling a bit ropey with all the booze. I had to go back and get more pills."

Jane Summerton, 18

Jane had been seeing her boyfriend Mark for more than a year before they had sex. "We hadn't discussed contraception, I know that's probably a bit dim. On the night, we were so drunk that we didn't really know what we were doing. In the event, Mark produced a condom, but it came off. She went to her GP. "I felt covered with shame. I got a long lecture from the doctor about methods of contraception and safe sex. When I walked out of there clutching a fistful of condoms, I was in tears. Physically I felt dreadful too: the pills made me feel dizzy and drowsy, and I stayed in bed for two whole days afterwards."

Heather Ross, 37

"My husband wants children, but until recently I was unsure. We'd had a bit to drink - maybe that's why I began to be swayed by his point of view. That night I left my diaphragm in the bathroom cabinet." She went to work the next day as normal but by lunchtime she was seized with panic. "Suddenly I knew that I'd made a terrible mistake." She went to get the morning-after pill during her lunch hour. "The pills gave me a chronic headache, and my breasts felt sore and swollen. But when my period came, I felt it had all been worth it."

 Some names have been changed.

webTitle: Amazon boasts a 40% jump in sales

fields.headline: Amazon boasts a 40% jump in sales over the last quarter
fields.trailText: 12.00pmOnline retail giant Amazon is boasting a 40% jump in sales over the last quarter, writes Guy Middleton.
fields.body:
Online retail giant Amazon is boasting a 40% jump in sales over the last quarter.

The unaudited figures claim net sales for the fourth quarter of 2000 are expected to exceed $960m (£644m) compared to $676m (£454m) in the fourth quarter of 1999.

The retailer attributed much of the growth to sales of electronics, however the market for such goods is fierce, leading to a slightly lower profit margin, down from 23% to 22%, compared with the same period last year.

Operating losses for the quarter were expected to be less than 7% of net sales, down from 26% in the previous year.

While sales increased in the fourth quarter they were still shy of the expectations of many analysts, something the company attributed to an overall drop off in consumer spending.

Dan Bieler, Internet analyst at investment bank Nomura, said he found the results encouraging.

"People sometimes forget when they talk about Amazon, that if they stuck to books and music they would make a profit," he said.

"They have committed to selling a lot of other products and some of those divisions are operating at a loss, if it comes to it they can always close them." he added.

"We're entering 2001 in a solid financial position with approximately $1.1bn (£738m) in cash and marketable securities," said Warren Jenson, Amazon.com's chief financial officer.

Once a star of the Nasdaq, Amazon has seen its stock tumble from $91(£61) to its current price of a little over $14 (£9), as some analysts speculated that the company might run out of cash.

fields.headline: Damilola Taylor murder: two held
fields.standfirst: More on the Damilola Taylor case
fields.trailText: Police in south London arrested two more teenagers this morning in connection with the murder of ten-year-old Damilola Taylor.
fields.body:
Police in south London arrested two more teenagers this morning in connection with the murder of ten-year-old Damilola Taylor.

The two black youths, aged 13 and 14, were arrested in Peckham, south-east London, and are being held at Southwark police station.

Neither of the boys had previously been arrested, and the move brings the total number of arrests in the case to 15. In December, police arrested 11 youths in an early morning sweep of London, then later arrested another teenager and a 39-year-old woman. Two of those arrested were released unconditionally. The rest have been released on bail.

Damilola, a Nigerian schoolboy, bled to death after being stabbed on his way home from a computer lesson in November.

fields.headline: 'Judge has slapped me in the face'
fields.standfirst: Denise Fergus condemned the decision. This is an edited version of her statement
fields.trailText: Denise Fergus condemned the decision. This is an edited version of her statement
fields.body:
"I am disgusted with the special treatment these two now get at every turn. The judge has slapped me in the face. She's not taken into account the full effects of this in the future for me as James's mother.

"It makes my blood run cold to think that they are being patted on the back and rewarded after the cruel, premeditated murder they carried out.

"The lawyers want us to forget about the evil way they took James and murdered him, but people will never forget what they did.

"If this privacy order stays in place the press and media in this country will be gagged.

"But the judges cannot control the world media. Thanks to the internet, anybody with a computer will be able to read all the details any foreign newspapers are printing.

It will be a complete nonsense and it means this privacy order cannot work.

"They [the killers] will be recognised and found out under any new name wherever they go.

"Every minute they will have to look over their shoulders... they will never be able to relax. That is some comfort to me - to know they will always be haunted and hunted.

"But it is the people they meet and succeed in deceiving that I am concerned about.

"What will happen when they meet girls and even have children? It is very dangerous and cannot be right for the government to conspire with them to hide the awful truth.

"It is terrible to think that anyone could have them living next door to them without knowing who they are.

"Now they can use these false identities as a cover and could even abduct and kill another child before anyone living close to them realises the danger.

"They should not get more privileges than any other prisoner. They should be left to fend for themselves, not have the Home Office mollycoddling them."

webTitle: Summary of the judgment by Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss

fields.headline: 'I am compelled to take steps to protect their lives'
fields.standfirst: Summary of the judgment by Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss
fields.trailText: The murder of James Bulger by Jon Venables and Robert Thompson on February 12, 1993 was a horrific crime and the circumstances unusually shocking and distressing.
fields.body:
The murder of James Bulger by Jon Venables and Robert Thompson on February 12, 1993 was a horrific crime and the circumstances unusually shocking and distressing.

It caused much public concern and a widespread feeling of moral outrage. There was massive national and international publicity both at the time of the murder and during and after the trial.

Press and media coverage continued throughout the period of the detention of the two boys and increased at the time of the decision of the lord chief justice on the tariff and the hearing of the present proceedings.

During the period of detention, injunctions have been in place which restricted the information the media was entitled to publish. Those injunctions came to an end on the 18th birthdays of the two boys. They made applications for injunctions to restrain publicity to run indefinitely. I granted interim injuctions on July 27, 2000 to continue until the full hearing of the applications.

I heard full arguments for Venables and Thompson seeking injunctions, from four groups of newspapers opposing injunctions and from the attorney general and the official solicitor supporting the grant of injunctions. I also received evidence from the home secretary. I reserved my decision and handed it down today.

I have decided that, taking into account the provisions of the European convention on human rights, the law of confidence may, in exceptional circumstances, be applied to protect individuals who are seriously at risk of injury or death if their identity or whereabouts became public knowledge and that the court has jurisdiction to grant injunctions to ensure their protection.

I have been provided with a wealth of information from Home Office evidence, press reports, judicial observations, and other information that has convinced me that these young men are uniquely notorious and are at serious risk of attacks from members of the public as well as from relatives and friends of the murdered child.

Threats to injure and to kill them have been set out in the evidence presented to me and have been reported in the press. I am satisfied that, although there has been balanced discussion in press articles in recent months, the sense of moral outrage has not diminished and there remains among some members of the public a serious desire for revenge if the two young men are living in the community.

The Home Office views these threats very seriously and is likely to give Venables and Thompson new identities on their release from detention. I am therefore convinced that their lives are genuinely at risk as well as their physical safety if their new identities and whereabouts became public knowledge.

I also read a number of press reports and editorials both from the time of the trial and later litigation and recently, and have come to the conclusion that certain sections of the press would not wish the two young men to remain anonymous and would wish to have them identified and if information about them became available, there was a real possibility it would be published.

In my judgment, if any section of the media decided to give information leading to the identification of either young man, such publication would put his life at risk. In the exceptional circumstances of this case and applying English domestic law and the right to life enshrined in article 2 of the European convention, I have come to the conclusion that I am compelled to take steps in the almost unique circumstances of this case to protect their lives and well-being.

I recognise the enormous importance of upholding freedom of expression and the right of the press to publish. I have, however, decided that, for the reasons I have given above, and set out at length in my judgment, it is necessary to grant injunctions to restrain the media from disclosing information about the new identity, appearance or addresses of Venables and Thompson when they are released from detention.

In my judgment it is also necessary to restrain any publication of information about their present appearance and whereabouts in order to protect them on release. After a period of 12months it will not be necessary to restrain the media from disclosing information about the past which is not already protected by the existing rules of confidentiality.

Since the information about their identity is so sensitive it will be necessary to continue to restrain information which might lead to finding them even if it has been placed in the public domain by publication for instance on the internet.

webTitle: Precedent warning as judgment promises new lives in secrecy for icons of hate

fields.headline: Precedent warning as judgment promises new lives in secrecy for icons of hate
fields.standfirst: Myra Hindley could use same argument to gain anonymity on release, court told.
fields.trailText: Myra Hindley could use same argument to gain anonymity on release, court told.
fields.body:
The ruling giving Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, the killers of James Bulger, blanket protection from media intrusion from the rest of their lives could set a precedent for other notorious criminals to seek similar gagging orders on their release.

Desmond Browne, QC for the three national newspaper groups which opposed a permanent injunction, told the judge, Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, that it could open the way for the Moors murderer Myra Hindley to ask for a ban on disclosure of her whereabouts and any new identity if she ever wins her freedom. Paedophiles too could invoke the ruling to ward off unwelcome press attention and vigilante attacks, Mr Browne warned.

The ruling was a "historic first", he pointed out. No adult had ever before won a court order guaranteeing anonymity. The so-called Mary Bell order, the prototype for the injunction granted yesterday, was in fact not granted to protect the child killer but to safeguard her daughter from press attention.

Had it not been for the existence of her daughter, the courts would have had no power to protect Mary Bell with a blanket ban on publishing or soliciting details of her new life. Yesterday's ruling could open the way for her to seek a new injunction to preserve her anonymity when her daughter reaches 18 and the current court order expires. She would have to show that her life was in danger from reprisals for her killing of two small boys in 1968 when she was aged 11.

She served 12 years before her release and managed to remain out of the public eye till two years ago, when a book by Gitta Sereny, Cries Unheard: Why Children Kill - the Story of Mary Bell, was published and the Sun tracked her down. Some details of her new life found their way into the newspapers and she was given police protection.

But Bell is no longer demonised - if she ever was - to anything like the same extent as Venables and Thompson, who abducted two-year-old James Bulger from a Merseyside shopping centre in February 1993, battered him to death and left his body on a railway line. She might not succeed in convincing a judge that publication of her whereabouts would put her life in danger.

Myra Hindley, however, still rivals the Bulger killers as an icon of hate. Although successive home secretaries have said that in her case "life means life", she is challenging the home secretary's role in setting the tariff for murderers. The lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, predicted two months ago that judges may well remove from the government the right to decide when murderers go free.

If that happens, Hindley could be released eventually, on licence, and provided with a new identity by the home office. Newspaper articles over the years painting her as a uniquely evil killer who should never be freed could prove, in her case, as convincing evidence of the danger of vigilante attacks as they did in the case of Thompson and Venables.

Dame Elizabeth ruled that the court now had jurisdiction to grant an order extending anonymity into adulthood because of the Human Rights Act 1998, which came into force last October, making the European convention on human rights part of UK law. Under article 2 of the convention, the state is obliged to protect an individual's right to life.

She had decided that the law may, in exceptional circumstances, be applied to protect individuals who are seriously at risk of injury or death if their identity or whereabouts became public knowledge.

Allan Levy QC, who has advised Mary Bell, said: "This is not a precedent in the sense that it opens the floodgates. But if another case comes along where there is evidence of serious risk to life, then it is likely it will be as persuasive in that case as it has been in this."

Dame Elizabeth ruled that past information on Thompson and Venables, including the names of the secure units where they spent their time in custody and the rehabilitation regimes they underwent, could be published by the media after a "cooling off" period of 12 months. Mr Levy predicted that once the 12 months elapsed, fellow inmates would demand large sums of money for anecdotes about the pair. "That's going to give rise to quite a little industry."

Resettled abroad

Stories that Thompson and Venables might be resettled abroad in Australia, New Zealand or Canada are wide of the mark. Apart from the question of those countries' entry restrictions on people guilty of serious crimes, settlement abroad would make it impossible for the British criminal justice system to give them the supervision required for murderers on licence.

Instead, they are expected to be resettled somewhere in the north of England, where their accents, and those of their families will be less conspicuous. New identities likely to be provided for them and their immediate family will include new names, birth certificates, national health service numbers and a new family history.

If the plan works, only a small circle of people will know their true identities. Workmates or fellow students will be kept in the dark. But there will be a police surveillance operation with a panic button for each in case a problem arises.

However, the information their lawyers have fought so hard to suppress could still surface on the internet. The injunction bans the media in England and Wales from picking it up and publishing it, but it could still travel swiftly over the web, aided by word of mouth. Nor does the injunction cover newspapers published in Scotland.

webTitle: In brief: Brosnan sweet-talks Kofi Annan for UN job

fields.headline: Brosnan sweet-talks Kofi Annan for UN job
fields.standfirst: Plus: Film companies smell success as bidding war for 20-year-old book hits $6m; Guy Ritchie has change of heart about Snatch
fields.trailText: Plus: Film companies smell success as bidding war for 20-year-old book hits $6m; Guy Ritchie has change of heart about Snatch
fields.body:
 Don't look now but it seems as though 007 has come over all peacenik on us. As if to make amends for years of extreme violence in defence of British interests, James Bond (or at least his present interpreter, actor Pierce Brosnan) yesterday discussed disarmament and peacekeeping with a series of United Nations specialists, including secretary general Kofi Annan. Brosnan, 47, has been interested in the UN's work for some years and is now apparently considering signing on as a roving ambassador for the organisation. "Celebrities can be very effective advocates, provided the issue is right," Kofi Annan told gathered reporters after the meeting. Brosnan, he said, "Could use his voice to help us in some of the work we do, just like Michael Douglas, who has been very active in disarmament." But when one reporter wondered if Kofi Annan was prepared to offer Brosnan a "license to kill" in the pursuit of peace, the secretary general was emphatic. "Definitely not," he snapped.

 A 20-year-old novel by German writer Patrick Suskind yesterday became the prize in a fierce bidding war as film companies scrambled for the rights to film it. Perfume: The Story of a Murder attracted open bids of around $6m (£4m) from various parties. The rights now look set to go to Constantin Film, which beat out close competition from a joint venture from Gangs of New York backers IEG, AMG and Miramax, who had hoped to tailor the film for Martin Scorsese and Leonardo DiCaprio. Ridley Scott is thought to have been another interested party. Written by Suskind in 1980 and published the following year, Perfume tells the tale of a shadowy, scent-obsessed serial killer in feudal France, who murders his victims (young damsels, by and large) in order to bottle their fragrant essence.

 Turns out that one of the biggest critics of Snatch - Guy Ritchie's slam-bang British gangster flick - is the film's creator. Ritchie recently confessed to reporters that he worried that the film was "disastrous" and admitted that he couldn't keep his eyes open while watching it. "Something happened in editing that was rather disappointing," said Ritchie. "I fell asleep after the first 30 minutes and that's a disappointing state of affairs when the director falls asleep on the first viewing of his film."

fields.headline: Sven-Goran Eriksson factfile
fields.body:
1975 - Knee injury brings an undistinguished playing career as a right back for Swedish second division side Karlskoga to an abrupt end.
1976 - Appointed coach of Swedish third division Degerfors and guides them to the top flight within three years.
1980-82 - Joins IFK Gothenburg. Coaches them to one Swedish championship, two domestic cup titles and the 1982 Uefa Cup.
1982-84 - Coaches Benfica to two championships and a cup title in just two seasons.
1984-85 - Arrives in Italy and joins AS Roma. Guides them to seventh place in his first season.
1985-86 - Coaches Roma to within sight of the league title but his side lose 3-2 at home to relegated Lecce on the penultimate day of the season and cede the crown to Juventus by two points. Eriksson has to settle for the 1986 Italian Cup title instead.
May 4, 1987 - Resigns from Roma.
1987-1989 - At Fiorentina. Coaches them to eighth and seventh place finishes in Serie A.
1989-1991 - Returns to Benfica and guides them to the 1990 European Cup final and the 1991 league title.
1991-1996 - Back in Italy with Sampdoria but brings them only the Italian Cup title in five years at the helm.
1997-1998 - Arrives at Lazio and coaches them to the Italian Cup in his first season in charge. Lazio briefly challenge for the league before fading in the run-in. They are beaten 3-0 by Inter Milan in the Uefa Cup final.
1998-1999 - Gives Lazio their first European trophy - the Cup Winners' Cup. They beat Mallorca in the final in Birmingham. But Lazio throw away a six-point lead at the top of Serie A in the spring and cede the title to AC Milan by a single point on the last day of the season.
1999-2000 - Coaches Lazio to the league and cup double, giving the Rome side only the second "scudetto" in their history and their first in 26 years. Lazio trail Juventus by nine points with seven matches to play but claw back the deficit and win the title on a dramatic final day of the season.
Oct 2000 - Linked with England job when Kevin Keegan resigns following 1-0 defeat by Germany at Wembley. Repeatedly pledges to fulfil his contract until July 2001.
Oct 31 - Eriksson confirmed as next England coach.
Jan 9 2001 - Resigns as coach of Lazio.

fields.headline: GUS pays £1.4m for Breathe.com
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Great Universal Stores yesterday rescued Breathe.com, the internet access group that collapsed last month with debts of £50m.
fields.body:
Great Universal Stores yesterday rescued Breathe.com, the internet access group that collapsed last month with debts of £50m.

The Argos stores to Reality outsourcing group said it was paying £1.4m for the assets and technology of Breathe.com but would not assume any of the company's liabilities. At its peak, Breathe was valued at around £100m.

News of GUS's move for Breathe.com came as another top UK retailer, Kingfisher, was pocketing £145m in cash and shares from the sale of its stake in French internet service provider Liberty Surf, which is being taken over by Italian group Tiscali.

GUS, which will take on 80 Breathe.com staff, said the company's skills and technology would be used to provide easier access to the GUS on-line shopping operations and to increase the services offered by its Reality arm, which provides website designs and logistical services.

GUS chief executive John Peace said: "We are very pleased to have the opportunity to use the information and technology we have acquired with Breathe.com. The company has been very advanced in developing multi-device access to the internet, with ease of use the top priority."

Breathe.com has over 300,00 registered users, and GUS said yesterday that it expected its acquisition to run up losses of between £4m and £7m in the next financial year.

Kingfisher's sale of its stake is part of a €650m (£412m) bid for Liberty Surf from Tiscali - a deal seen as part of the continuing consolidation among internet service providers in Europe around four leading players: Tiscali, France Telecom subsidiary Wanadoo, Deutsche Telekom's T-Online and Spain's Terra Lycos.

Under the terms of the deal Kingfisher and Groupe Arnault's Europ@web will each be given €2.13 and 0.365 Tiscali shares for every Liberty Surf share.

"It's been no secret that the shareholding in Liberty Surf was not be a core one in the long term. This is a good time to sell, and the price is right," said a Kingfisher spokesman.

Renato Soru, Tiscali's executive chairman, said: "Liberty Surf has been very successful in building up its market position in France and in developing its portal.

"France is a very important and fast growing market, and it is a key part of our European strategy.

Following this acquisition Tiscali will be the second largest operator in France and will further improve its position as Europe's second largest player - as well as the only one which is truly pan-European."

Liberty Surf had been reported to be considering the future of its non-French operations - including a British arm which employs more than 100 people.

webTitle: You bet your life: week nineteen, the expert's view

fields.headline: You bet your life: week nineteen, the expert's view
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. Betting expert Patrick Murray just can't stop shaking his head
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £169.89, Sean Ingle = £62.75, Football Unlimited punters collective = £44.53, Paul MacInnes = £37.45
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £169.89, Sean Ingle = £62.75, Football Unlimited punters collective = £44.53, Paul MacInnes = £37.45

Scott Murray: Liverpool v Rotherham - four goals or more £15 @ 6/5

I suppose I should have returned from the Christmas break refreshed and raring to go. But alas I feel as jaded, cynical and curmudgeonly as ever. The more things change the more they stay the same, as I believe the ever-philosophical French have been known to opine.

So no surprise then that our intrepid punters managed another clean sweep of losers this week. Even the normally profitable Scott let us down, eschewing his usual value outsider for a good old fashioned 'Liverpool are going to thump them' wager.

Haven't I always said avoid the obvious? No-one ever got rich backing Goliath to beat David. What's more, the good folk at Blue Square are well aware of the expectations of the average punter and skew their odds accordingly. Thus Joe Average expects lowly, unfashionable Rotherham to be on the wrong end of a good old-fashioned hammering at the hands of Liverpool, and so the bookies keep the prices artificially skinny as a result.

For me the value in this match, and in most similar mismatches, is the half-time/full-time market where draw/favourite is often available at 5/1 or even longer. With the underdogs likely to be playing for the draw there is a fair chance they may hold out for 45 minutes but little they will hold out for 90. 5/1 certainly looks value, to me anyway, with the bookies artificially shortening favourite/favourite knowing it will be backed.

Scott, doubtless, will protest that he nearly won, but there are no prizes for nearly. Not a good start to the year but there's plenty of time to put it right.

Sean Ingle: £7 win double: Huddersfield v Bristol City: Huddersfield to win @ 8/11 and Burnley v Scunthorpe: Burnley to win @ 4/9

Oh Mr Ingle. What can I say? Another losing double. New Year is a time for reflection and for resolution, for working out what you're doing wrong and deciding how to put it right. And then actually putting it right.

To quote Sean: "I see that in-form Wolves are way over-priced at 7/2 to beat Forest, but hang on a second, what's happening to my hand and before I know it I've picked Huddersfield and Burnley to win instead." A winning value single becomes a losing shorter priced double before you can say "Nottm Forest 0 Wolves 1".

Again the Inglemeister shows he has what it takes to pick winners. And again he turns winning selections into losing bets by his unnatural attachment to multiples. But there's still time to reform, Mr I, if not for me then for our children. Was that me?

Paul MacInnes: Birmingham to beat Man City at 10/3 - £5

Ah, the magic of the FA Cup, singles all round and a gin and tonic for the lady, isn't it? For all its alleged unpredictability the Cup is often quite a good money-making opportunity.

Indeed, as I'm sure the more astute of you have already anticipated in that smart-arse way you have, tis the very unpredictability that makes for the profit - especially as Joe Average's betting habits mean the bookmakers are likely to lay a bit of value on the outsiders as well as on the draw (see below).

In this case, Mr MacInnes may be right that Birmingham represented a bit of value - though ultimately, if the ever reliable Mr Raymond Stubbs is to be believed (which he most assuredly is by all right-thinking people or are the barbarians truly at the door), the might of the Premiership prevailed.

The MacInnes millions are looking ever more threadbare but its not over 'til its over. The show must go on. Never give up on a good thing. If only all towns were like Milton Keynes. As it were.

Neil Harnett of the Football Unlimited punter's collective: Walsall to beat West Ham, £5 at 7/2

I can't argue with this bet. Literally. Lord knows I've tried but the words just won't come out. I type what I think is a reasoned critique of this week's FUPC policy and all that appears on the screen is a list of cheeses. Very strange.

Mr Harnett argues his case well, and at 7/2 I'm inclined to agree with him, but I just have a sneaking suspicion that the draw was better value. I know I have said many times that I'm not a big fan of backing the draw but cup matches are an exception, particularly matches where a team is hosting a side from a division above them.

In this case neither side are likely to be too displeased with a draw - the home side have their pride intact and the prospect of some hard cash from the replay, the away side get to play at home in the return - and with the odds still the usual 9/4, a case can be made for backing the draw if you pick your matches carefully.

Walsall v West Ham looks a fair candidate for such a bet, though ideally I would pick a tie where there is only one division between the teams. Something to bear in mind anyway.

But enough, I grow weary, crushed beneath the weight of food consumed over the holiday period. And all this jogging (damn those new year's resolutions) isn't helping either. More nuggets of wisdom next week (it's irony, okay?).

fields.headline: BBC loses more talent
fields.trailText: 10.30am: They have already lost their on-screen star Des Lynam, now BBC Sports is losing its behind-the-scenes talent writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
It has already lost its on-screen star Des Lynam, now BBC Sports is losing its behind-the-scenes talent.

ITV has today raided BBC Sports' Match of the Day production team to hire rising star Tony Pastor to work on its own Premier League highlights coverage.

Mr Pastor will join former Match of the Day series producer Paul McNamara, who quit the BBC last month.

Both will work with ITV sports boss Brian Barwick to develop the station's Premiership coverage when it starts in the summer.

Mr Pastor is joining ITV as a programme editor, while Mr McNamara is taking a senior producer role.

An ITV spokesman said Mr Pastor and Mr McNamara would be "among the top half dozen ITV football producers".

Mr Pastor most recently edited Football Fever, the Sunday morning BBC1 show aimed at a youth audience, before returning to Match of the Day as a producer.

The poaching of the two Match of the Day staff by ITV has prompted BBC director of sport Peter Salmon and Niall Sloane, executive editor of football, to take urgent steps to arrest the talent decline.

fields.standfirst: All today's rumours have 'resigned'
fields.trailText: The Daily Express says that Coventry are close to agreeing a £5m deal for Wimbledon striker John Hartson. The paper says the Sky Blues will pay £2.5m up front and the rest on a pay-as-you-play basis. The medical, of course, is still to take place.
fields.body:
The Daily Express says that Coventry are close to agreeing a £5m deal for Wimbledon striker John Hartson. The paper says the Sky Blues will pay £2.5m up front and the rest on a pay-as-you-play basis. The medical, of course, is still to take place.

Fulham have made a £3m bid for Strasbourg defender Brahim Hemdane, according to the Daily Express. Hemdane can play as a defensive midfielder or an out-and-out defender and Jean Tigana sees the 24-year-old as an ideal replacement for car-crash victim Chris Coleman.

The Mirror, meanwhile, believes that Fulham will make a £2m bid for Liverpool defender Djimi Traore. The offer of regular first-team football could tempt the 20-year-old south, the paper claims

The Mirror reports that Edu's long-mooted move to Arsenal is set to be completed "within days". All the Brazilian has to do is fly from Brazil to Lisbon, pick up a Portuguese passport, then fly to England, cross his fingers as he goes through customs, and the move should be complete.

The Daily Star reports that Arsenal have had a £19m bid for Real Madrid's Ivan Helguera rejected, but that the Spanish international midfielder will not rule out a move to England. "After La Liga," the paper quotes Helguera as saying, "English football is the next best thing and London is a lovely place to live. Arsenal is a big club and there are lots of great players there."

All papers report that Liverpool and Arsenal are interested in signing Shay Given after the Newcastle goalkeeper handed in a transfer request.

fields.headline: Keanu: the drugs did work
fields.trailText: The star of The Matrix has admitted to taking Class-A drugs, but seems to have few regrets about his experiences
fields.body:
After much intense speculation within Hollywood, Keanu Reeves has finally admitted a lengthy association with Class-A narcotics and instead of the usual cautionary, sackcloth and ashes approach adopted by most celebrities, the Matrix star sounds positively upbeat about the experience. Drugs, says, Keanu, were "wonderful".

In the February issue of Vanity Fair, Reeves confesses that he has: "Had some wonderful experiences with drugs. I mean really wonderful." When asked to describe the nature of these experiences, the actor turns so tongue-tied that some observers would be forgiven for worrying that he's still under the influence. "In teaching," says Keanu. "Personal epiphanies. About life. About a different perspective."

Reeves, now 36, does admit that his reputation as a drug user hurt him in the industry and that he was forced to convince potential backers that he was hard-working and reliable. "To dispel that [reputation] I did some things that I wouldn't normally have done," he says. "Like a Japanese commercial to pay the rent or a video with Paula Abdul."

Reeves is currently on a productive streak, with a brace of films at various stages of completion. In March British viewers can see him playing a white-trash thug in Sam Raimi's thriller The Gift. He has recently finished work on the earthy thriller Hardball and will soon begin filming the Wachowski Brothers' two sequels to The Matrix. These days he has no vices, he tells Vanity Fair, although he appears to concede that one man's pleasure may be another man's poison: "I just don't relate to them as vices I don't consider smoking a vice."

fields.headline: Limits to free speech
fields.standfirst: Rehabilitation provides more protection
fields.trailText: Rehabilitation provides more protection.
fields.body:
Does the state have an obligation to protect people from serious assault, or even more important, death threats? To pose the question is to answer it. The reason the criminal justice system was set up was to put an end to private blood feuds and lynch law. That was the reason the Guardian declined to join the four newspaper groups that asked the high court to lift the injunction protecting the anonymity of the killers of James Bulger, the Merseyside toddler. Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the family division, rightly ruled yesterday that the protection should continue, even though the killers have now reached 18 and are expected to be released this year.

There is a clear clash in this case between two separate and vital democratic principles - the right to free speech versus the right to privacy. We yield to no one in emphasising the need - and indeed fighting in the courts - to make Britain a more open society. But it is equally important for campaigners to recognise the limits of free speech.

Jon Venables and Robert Thompson, the pair of deeply troubled 10-year-olds who killed James Bulger in 1993, will shortly have served the eight years which the lord chief justice declared last year should be the "tariff" for their crime. Their release, which will be decided by the parole board, will now depend purely on the risk that they pose to society. It is clear from the chief justice's judgment that, thanks to expert work by psychologists and support staff in the separate social service secure units in which the offenders were placed, the two young men no longer pose a risk.

The application from media groups talked of the public right to know - and the danger of a slippery slope. Free speech is important but so is the protection of life. The threat to the two young men could not have been more specific. Dame Elizabeth's long judgment contains a catalogue of stories in which overt threats - both to kill as well as injure - have been made against the young men by the public as well as relatives and friends of the murdered child. Home Office staff confirmed that they were taking these seriously. They were right to do so, following the fire-bombing of homes of suspected paedophiles by vigilante groups, spurred on by our tabloid press.

But is this a dangerous precedent? No. As the judge noted, the case has "almost unique circumstances". This is only the second time in the history of the Home Office that new identities have been planned for child murderers in anticipation of their release. The reason why this has been necessary is the tabloid's obsession with the offenders and their hysterical coverage of the case. Thankfully, the ban will prevent the tabloids from disclosing information about their new identities or their appearance or the addresses where they will be living.

Remember, if the boys had been just a few months younger, there would not have been a trial at all - they would have been below the age of criminal responsibility. In most other European countries, 10-year-olds would not have been prosecuted. The European court of human rights ruled the trial "unconstitutional", although it did not overturn the convictions.

The ban is unequivocal. It cannot apply beyond the English and Welsh borders or to the internet, but the judge made it clear that the English media would be clobbered if it tried to get round the ban by reporting facts appearing on the internet or in the Scottish media. The tabloids will protest, but brought the curbs on themselves. Rehabilitating the two remains the best public protection.

fields.headline: The disappeared are still missing
fields.standfirst:
Tito Tricot, who was tortured under the Pinochet regime, writes from Santiago

Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: Tito Tricot, who was tortured under the Pinochet regime, writes from Santiago.
fields.body:
Seagulls and pelicans shy away from the sun as they search the ocean for fish. There are no waves, no menacing storms, no tears like the ones that I struggle to hold back as I think of you, brother.

For we are so far away, yet so close in spirit. The last time I saw you, Juan, we shared a dark corner of a ship's haul, a floating concentration camp used by the Chilean navy to hold and torture thousands of political prisoners.

We were eventually released amongst the blows, laughter and sneers of our captors. I never saw you again, but I do know that three years later you were kidnapped by the secret police and murdered - becoming one of many of the 'disappeared'.

The disappearance of political opponents became one of the cruellest forms of repression implemented by the dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet, for it did not only affect those captured, but their families and friends too.

They became ghosts, dead without bodies, stars without skies. The military always denied any knowledge of their detention or whereabouts. Now, for the first time in almost three decades, the armed forces have provided some information about some of the disappeared in exchange for total immunity.

This is something president Ricardo Lagos did not refer to when he appeared on television to announce the result of an investigation conducted by the armed forces and different religious entities for the past six months. Instead, he "values the strength and courage of the armed institutions at a time like this".

What the hell is he talking about? Is he blind? Is he deaf? Is he so afraid of the military that he feels obliged to commend murderers?

All the armed forces have done is provide minimal information about some of their crimes. According to the information submitted by the military, and accepted by the government, they have clarified 200 disappearance cases.

This is out of an official estimate of over 1000 prisoners who vanished after being captured. So how can the authorities talk about clarification if 130 of these 200 were thrown in to the ocean and we still do not know their whereabouts? The military transformed our country, its rivers, sea, lakes, volcanoes and mineshafts into a gallery of horror and today, 27 years after repression began, they want our people to be content with the remains of 20 bodies that might be found somewhere in a mass grave.

But this is not about statistics. This is about human beings being brutally tortured and assassinated by the same military that president Lagos calls "courageous". The military have said nothing new, for we already know the names of those who disappeared. We know they are dead. What we want to know is the whereabouts of those responsible for these murders.

There is no doubt that there is institutional responsibility for all the most horrifying crimes committed against unharmed defenceless people. The military are fully aware of this, although they still insist that human rights violations do not respond to a systematic and planned repressive policy but simply to excesses committed by individual officers.

In fact, in their report about the disappeared, the military only included in the months that followed the military coup of September 1973. They hope to make us believe that the murders are somehow justified by the chaotic nature of that period. They fail to include in the report that the vast majority of kidnappings and disappearances were carried out by DINA, the Chilean secret police.

DINA was created in 1974 to systematise repression and became an instrument of state terrorism. Repression was so fierce that we cannot reduce the human rights issue to the disappeared. It's much more than that, because hundreds of thousands of Chilean men and women were affected - political prisoners, those tortured, raped, or forced into exile, amongst others.

Thus, when Ricardo Lagos asks us to move forward in the name of reconciliation, he is simply attempting to erase from our collective memory the most dramatic period in our history. When the armed forces state that "events that led to political violence should not be repeated in our country", they are evading their own responsibility and attempting to make all of us accomplices of their crimes.

Of course, the overwhelming majority of Chileans have never kidnapped, tortured or murdered anyone. The only criminals here are the military and their accomplices are those who believe their lies and applaud their supposed mea culpa, as the government does.

There is no justice in Chile - those who killed our brothers and sisters are still at large, those who incinerated bodies or cut their hands so as to make them unrecognisable, are still free.

But, I want you to know Juan that we will continue striving for justice. We know now that you were thrown into the sea you loved so much, and I'm sure that on the precise spot you kissed the cold water, the fish became brighter, the pink shells softer and a thousand sea horses came to see the timid and beautiful smile of a man who fought and died for freedom.

webTitle: Why Bristol is the most popular university

fields.headline: Why Bristol is the most popular university
fields.trailText: Academic, but not Oxbridge. Vibrant, but not dangerous. Big, but not London. Guy Newey explains why Bristol University is so popular among UK students.
fields.body:
Students known as Oxbridge rejects. Traditional degree courses. A public school haven. An ugly student union. No specific campus. Expensive rent. Halls located 40 minutes walk from college. Hardly the recipe for popularity. So why do the latest university admissions figures reveal that the University of Bristol gains the most applications per place in the UK?

Academically, Bristol is ranked highly, but manages to avoid the intimidating traditions of Oxbridge. Along with Nottingham and Sheffield, Bristol is seen as a good, attainable university for many potential students, as well as a refuge for rejected Oxbridge applicants. Set in the Georgian houses of Clifton, the university also has the architecture that so many Brideshead Revisited dreaming students aspire to.

But its reputation for Oxbridge rejects may be counter-productive. Bristol recently achieved the questionable distinction of the highest percentage of public school students, a balance that the university is keen to redress through its widening participation scheme.

Bristol's academic reputation is solid in both research and teaching, with only dentistry failing to achieve more than 20 out of 24 in its teaching inspection. Students are bright, with an average A-level score of 27.3 (just under two A grades and one B). A degree from Bristol is also highly marketable, with 46% entering permanent appointments after graduation and 21% continuing with postgraduate study.

But academia is very rarely the sole reason that students apply for a particular university. The city itself is diverse and cosmopolitan, far from its cider-swilling reputation. It is large enough to provide all the necessary attractions, without having the impersonal size of London. Most importantly, student life is based in the most attractive parts of the city.

Whilst in Manchester and Birmingham students are ghettoised in Fallowfield and Sellyoak, Bristolians are housed in the residential comfort of Clifton, Redland and Cotham. Rents are unsurprisingly high - up to about £75 a week - but there are none of the security worries that affect other big-city students. Bristol is also reachable. It is an hour-and-a-half train journey from London and directly linked to Birmingham, Manchester and Leeds.

The cultural and social vibe of the city is also impressive. With the addition of over 20,000 students from the University of the West of England, the city is forced to compete for the student pound and you are hard pressed to find a city centre pub or bar that is not vying for their custom. It also has one of the most exciting club scenes in the country, with each new week announcing the dawn of another 'Superclub' to complement the old pretender, Lakota. The twin phenomena of Trip-Hop and Drum and Bass are also Bristol inventions, home of Tricky, Massive Attack and Roni Size. Restaurants, theatres, cinema, gig venues and shopping are all handsomely represented and the notable achievement of having two Ikeas means student houses are often recreations of Scandinavian chic.

Bristol owes its application success to its middle-of-the-road status. Academic, but not Oxbridge. Vibrant, but not dangerous. Big, but not London.

Guy Newey is in his third year studying english literature at Bristol University and edits the Bristol student newspaper.

webTitle: Winslet decides to join thin set to bolster Hollywood prospects

fields.headline: Winslet decides to join thin set to bolster Hollywood prospects
fields.trailText: Kate Winslet, champion of the conceit that you do not have to starve yourself to be a successful actress, has announced she is going on a diet under pain of destroying her career.
fields.body:
Kate Winslet, champion of the conceit that you do not have to starve yourself to be a successful actress, has announced she is going on a diet under pain of destroying her career.

Ms Winslet, 25, who recently gave birth to her first child, Mia, has resolved to lose weight or run the risk of not working again in an industry that she said only values thin women.

"It's so insane and bloody boring," she said. "I despise myself for it and feel I'm letting a lot of people down. I constantly wave the flag of 'don't got on diets because they are rubbish'."

She conceded, however, the necessity of losing "a bit of the baby weight or I won't work".

Last year she criticised the pressure put on young women to fit the film industry's skinny ideal. webTitle: Martial arts movie takes UK by storm

fields.headline: Martial arts movie takes UK by storm
fields.standfirst: Chinese film of duty and suppressed desire a boon for independent cinemas with £686,386 ticket sales
fields.trailText: Until today it was safe to say that the market in Britain for Mandarin films about duty and suppressed desire in 18th-century China was a little on the limited side.
fields.body:
Until today it was safe to say that the market in Britain for Mandarin films about duty and suppressed desire in 18th-century China was a little on the limited side.

But after a weekend in which teenagers queued for the chance to hang on the words of lovelorn philosophising warrior mystics, Li Mu Bai and Yu Shu Lien, all that may be about to change.

The film that has persuaded thousands of cinema-goers to brush up on their history of the Han dynasties, is Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.

The spectacular martial arts film with enough emotional depth for art house credibility took 10 times more at the box office in London on its opening weekend than the best-performing new US film, the Kim Basinger vehicle Bless the Child.

With ticket sales of £686,386 from just 88 screens in three days, Crouching Tiger is now well on the way to eclipsing the Oscar-winning Life Is Beautiful as the most successful foreign language film ever shown here.

What is even more surprising is that some of this subtle, feminist film's most vocal supporters have been in the tabloids, whose critics have competed to shower superlatives on its Hong Kong stars, Chow Yun-Fat and Michelle Yeoh, whose doomed, unrealised love affair - think Brief Encounter with kick-boxing - is the movie's beating heart.

Crouching Tiger and its director Ang Lee are already the clever bets for the Oscars for best film and director.

Ang Lee has been unlucky to miss out before with his masterly adaptation of Jane Austen's Sense And Sensibility, The Ice Storm and The Wedding Banquet where he gave unusual depth to his female characters. He has in fact been credited with creating a whole new genre of intelligent karate film with Crouching Tiger.

With eye-popping fight sequences - most memorably a tree-top duel - Crouching Tiger is sure of a clutch of special effects awards. More im portantly iCrouching Tiger has become a boon for independent cinemas whose fight to keep foreign cinema alive here has at times been thankless.

The Duke of York in Brighton has seen nothing like it since it managed to get a print of the cult hit The Blair Witch Project a week before it went on general release.

Spokesman Dean Stewart said the film's great strength was that it had something for everyone. "It's a great martial arts film, it's got a love interest and it is beautiful to look at. I have not seen a film for a long time which had such a warm reaction from so many different people. It is great to see people who wouldn't normally go to a foreign language film having such a good time."

Next week the multiplexes will try to cash in, and Crouching Tiger is likely to be showing on up to five times as many screens across the country.

2 Cyrano de Bergerac (France) £2.45m

3 Il Postino (Italy) £1.27m

4 Delicatessen (France) £1.26m

5 All About My Mother (Spain) £1.1m

6 Farewell My Concubine (China) £1.03m

7 Cinema Paradiso (Italy) £1.02m

webTitle: Casting news: Jennifer Aniston no good girl in her latest film

fields.headline: Jennifer Aniston no good girl in her latest film
fields.standfirst: Plus: Child star gives voice to baby bear in Disney caper; Courtney Love sees a future in sleaze in her new comedy
fields.trailText: Plus: Child star gives voice to baby bear in Disney caper; Courtney Love sees a future in sleaze in her new comedy
fields.body:
 Friends star Jennifer Aniston (pictured) is in talks to play the eponymous heroine of The Good Girl, an indie production from the creative team behind last year's acclaimed Chuck and Buck. Aniston will play a dope-smoking small-town girl who begins an adulterous, sub-Bonnie and Clyde affair with the cashier in the shop where she earns a crust. The Good Girl, to be directed by Miguel Arteta and produced by Matthew Greenfield from a script by Mike White, rolls before the cameras in March.

 Disney has commissioned 12-year-old Haley Joel Osment to provide the bear necessities in their new production, The Country Bears. The star of The Sixth Sense will lend his voice to a live-action caper about an orphaned bear cub roaming Tennessee in search of his real family. Osment's character (imaginatively named "Beary") will be embodied by an actor in a radio-controlled "bear suit" that comes courtesy of Jim Henson's Creature Factory.

 Courtney Love is one of the late additions to the cast of Welcome to Collinwood, a grungey heist comedy which will be directed by Anthony and Joe Russo and executive produced by Steven Soderbergh and George Clooney. The Hole frontwoman will play the sidekick of a gang of down-on-their-luck blue-collar workers who decide to rob a porn shop.
