webTitle: Paul Foot: how Labour donors can buy their way into government

fields.headline: The proud purchaser
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: "As a proud supporter of the Labour party," says Lord Sainsbury of Turville, explaining his latest £2m donation to Labour, "I am happy to contribute." Proud he may be, but consistent he certainly isn't.
fields.body:
"As a proud supporter of the Labour party," says Lord Sainsbury of Turville, explaining his latest £2m donation to Labour, "I am happy to contribute." Proud he may be, but consistent he certainly isn't. He should attend to his entry in Who's Who, which proclaims his role as trustee of the Social Democratic party from 1982 to 1990. The founders of the SDP split the Labour party effectively enough to ensure at least another decade of Tory rule. The SDP benefited hugely from the patronage of the Sainsbury dynasty. The party is now wound up. Most of its founders are rotting in the House of Lords or among the Liberal Democrats. It took the ingenuity and self-interest of a handful of the richest SDP supporters, including Lord Sainsbury, to realise that although the SDP in name is dead as a dodo, its ideas still inspire New Labour.

Among those SDP ideas was the notion that the Labour party should no longer rely on money from the trade unions. These trade union contributions, though they were all openly declared and agreed by democratic vote, infuriated the rich. The very idea that a political party could be sustained by the pennies of trade unionists challenged the view that votes can be bought, like anything else, in proportion to the wealth of the buyer.

For a whole century the voices of the rich rang with indignation at this outrageous affront to the exclusive right of rich people to advertise political policies to their advantage. The answer to all this nonsense was simple: the funds to Labour from trade unions were collected from millions of workers to protect the interests of the many, while the funds to the Tory party from individuals were paid to protect the interests of the few.

Then came New Labour, the semi-literate rewriting of the Labour party constitution to remove the commitment to public ownership, the election of Blair's government and the appointment of ministers and advisers from the ranks of the rich. One of the aims of the Blair revolution was to replace union contributions with donations from the rich. Swift calculations proved to the new ministers that the entire block of union funds could be matched by a handful of hand-outs from people like Lord Sainsbury. It followed that a Labour government should stop supporting fuddy-duddy unions and switch to policies that would please dynamic and stylish millionaires.

This process is not yet complete. The trade unions will still be expected to cough up £8m or so for Labour's war chest. But the Blair government's devotion to Thatcher's anti-union laws and its readiness to concede to big business in almost every detail show that the next Labour government will be even more determined to shuffle off the "incubus" of organised labour. The result will be to reduce British electoral politics to what goes on in the United States, where the only count that matters is the count of the millions in contributions from the rich, while the poor and the workers, organised or not, are left to rot.

For the effect on this government there's no need to look much further than the Sainsbury family and their hoard of inherited wealth. No minister emerges with less credit from George Monbiot's devastating indictment of modern corporate power, The Captive State, than the science minister, Lord Sainsbury of Turville. He has put his vast shareholdings into "blind trusts", and therefore cannot say how his investments have benefited from the government's policies. He is blind, for instance, to the progress of Diatech, a biotechnology company that he backed with millions before he became a minister, and which helped to pay for the renovation of Milord Sainsbury's stately home in Buckinghamshire. Diatech's chief executive, indeed, has described the company as Lord Sainsbury's private office, but that investment, and all the others, is in a blind trust. Whenever any of these interests come up on any agenda in any meeting in which he is taking part, Lord Sainsbury leaves the room.

But every time Lord Sainsbury lobs £2m into the Labour party he is exposing himself to the most obvious charge of conflict of interest: namely that he is a leading and influential member of a government he lavishly subsidises. If Blair or any other minister ever gets irritated with Lord Sainsbury's legendary obsession, for instance, with genetically modified foods, is there a greater or lesser chance that the generous minister will be sacked? And is it likely to become more or less likely that in future this slavish adulation of the rich will lead to more and more rich Labour donors effectively buying their way into the government and then proclaiming on front pages how proud they are to do so?

webTitle: French hunt fugitive who killed four

fields.headline: French hunt fugitive who killed four
fields.trailText: A fugitive yesterday shot dead four people near Narbonne yesterday, including two prosecution witnesses at his trial for murder, provoking a major manhunt across south-west France.
fields.body:
A fugitive yesterday shot dead four people near Narbonne yesterday, including two prosecution witnesses at his trial for murder, provoking a major manhunt across south-west France.

The police deployed almost 300 officers and helicopters in the hunt for Albert Foulcher, who will be 50 next week.

Foulcher turned up near Narbonne early yesterday at the house of a couple who had testified against him at his trial last April for the murder of an insurance agent near Toulouse in 1993.

They called for help and Foulcher machine-gunned two policemen who responded to their call.

He then shot dead the husband, then drove to Valras and shot dead another prosecution witness.

Several other prosecution witnesses, and the two lawyers who represented Foulcher at his trial last April, have been put under police protection.

Foulcher was first arrested in June 1993, six months after the insurance agent was killed.

He was released on bail in October 1996 by an appeal court, which ruled that his long pre-trial incarceration violated the European convention of human rights.

He was put on bail, but soon ceased to report to the authorities, and was tried and convicted of the Toulouse murder in his absence last April.

fields.headline: Binyamin Kahane
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The death of the 34-year-old Rabbi Binyamin Kahane, head of Israel's most extreme settler movement, echoed the death of his father, Meir Kahane, assassinated a decade ago by an Egyptian in his native New York.
fields.body:
The death of the 34-year-old Rabbi Binyamin Kahane, head of Israel's most extreme settler movement, echoed the death of his father, Meir Kahane, assassinated a decade ago by an Egyptian in his native New York. Binyamin and his wife, Talia, were killed by Palestinian gunmen while en route with five of their six children to the West Bank settlement of Kfar Tapuach, where they lived.

Ironically, the rabbi told the Jerusalem Post two months ago that his followers were "waiting for a few more Jews to be killed" in the current intifada before they took decisive steps against their Palestinian enemies. Equally paradoxically, the movement he founded after his father's death was called Kahane Chai - Kahane Lives. Now the son, too, has become a martyr to a cause which only a hardcore minority of Israelis actively support. Its aims include the replacement of democracy by theological rule, the expulsion of Israel's Arab citizens and the annexation of the West Bank to "force the hand of God" and bring about the messianic age.

Kahane Chai has often acknowledged responsibility for attacks on, and murders of, Palestinians, and Binyamin and his ilk paraded throughout the occupied territories with apparent impunity, armed and unchallenged by the Israeli defence forces - while Arabs felt robbed and discriminated against on their native soil.

Kahane claimed his "true believers" possessed the "miracle" of knowing God's true intentions; it was a Kahane sympathiser, Yigal Amir, who murdered the Israeli prime minister Yitzhak Rabin in 1995 - an attack which heralded a renewed crackdown on Binyamin and his officially outlawed supporters. Israel's security services regularly raided his property for evidence of inflammatory literature or illegally held arms.

Binyamin's father founded the Jewish Defence League (JDL) in the United States in the 1960s. But what began as an agency to stop elderly Jewish ladies from being mugged in the street soon turned into a heady fusion of messianic zeal and militancy. More controversially, JDL thugs picked fights with African-American groups and bombed Soviet offices, in the days when the USSR restricted Jewish emigration.

In the late 1970s, Rabbi Meir set up the racist Kach (Take) movement in Israel, which fought Arabs and exemplified the extreme of Israel's right-wing religious trend. In 1989, the movement was banned from standing in elections, and, after the massacre of 29 Muslim worshippers in Hebron in 1994 by another American-born Kahanist, both Kach and Kahane Chai were outlawed - to the relief of many Jews, to whom Kahane's doctrine subverted the basic norms of Judaism.

Binyamin Kahane was investigated for sedition, banned from running for the Israeli parliament, the Knesset, in 1992, jailed for six months in 1998, and repeatedly accused of assault and instigating violent anti-peace demonstrations.

He was born in the United States, but moved to Israel with his family in 1971, at the age of four. He studied at the Merkaz Ha Rav Kook Yeshiva (or talmudic academy), and co-founded the Jerusalem-based Yeshivat Ha Ra'yon Ha Yehudi (the Yeshiva of the Jewish Idea) with his father in 1987.

Slightly built and introverted, Binyamin's faulty English initially proved a handicap with American-born devotees. However, like his famously articulate father, he soon developed a charismatic hold over his followers. After Rabbi Meir's death, Binyamin lost a succession struggle to become head of Kach, and founded Kahane Chai. In ideological terms, little separates the two sects.

All five of his daughters were injured in the attack in which he died. His son was not in the car.

 Binyamin Ze'ev Kahane, rabbi and zealot, born 1966; died December 31 2000
fields.bodyText: The death of the 34-year-old Rabbi Binyamin Kahane, head of Israel's most extreme settler movement, echoed the death of his father, Meir Kahane, assassinated a decade ago by an Egyptian in his native New York. Binyamin and his wife, Talia, were killed by Palestinian gunmen while en route with five of their six children to the West Bank settlement of Kfar Tapuach, where they lived. Ironically, the rabbi told the Jerusalem Post two months ago that his followers were "waiting for a few more Jews to be killed" in the current intifada before they took decisive steps against their Palestinian enemies. Equally paradoxically, the movement he founded after his father's death was called Kahane Chai - Kahane Lives. Now the son, too, has become a martyr to a cause which only a hardcore minority of Israelis actively support. Its aims include the replacement of democracy by theological rule, the expulsion of Israel's Arab citizens and the annexation of the West Bank to "force the hand of God" and bring about the messianic age. Kahane Chai has often acknowledged responsibility for attacks on, and murders of, Palestinians, and Binyamin and his ilk paraded throughout the occupied territories with apparent impunity, armed and unchallenged by the Israeli defence forces - while Arabs felt robbed and discriminated against on their native soil. Kahane claimed his "true believers" possessed the "miracle" of knowing God's true intentions; it was a Kahane sympathiser, Yigal Amir, who murdered the Israeli prime minister Yitzhak Rabin in 1995 - an attack which heralded a renewed crackdown on Binyamin and his officially outlawed supporters. Israel's security services regularly raided his property for evidence of inflammatory literature or illegally held arms. Binyamin's father founded the Jewish Defence League (JDL) in the United States in the 1960s. But what began as an agency to stop elderly Jewish ladies from being mugged in the street soon turned into a heady fusion of messianic zeal and militancy. More controversially, JDL thugs picked fights with African-American groups and bombed Soviet offices, in the days when the USSR restricted Jewish emigration. In the late 1970s, Rabbi Meir set up the racist Kach (Take) movement in Israel, which fought Arabs and exemplified the extreme of Israel's right-wing religious trend. In 1989, the movement was banned from standing in elections, and, after the massacre of 29 Muslim worshippers in Hebron in 1994 by another American-born Kahanist, both Kach and Kahane Chai were outlawed - to the relief of many Jews, to whom Kahane's doctrine subverted the basic norms of Judaism. Binyamin Kahane was investigated for sedition, banned from running for the Israeli parliament, the Knesset, in 1992, jailed for six months in 1998, and repeatedly accused of assault and instigating violent anti-peace demonstrations. He was born in the United States, but moved to Israel with his family in 1971, at the age of four. He studied at the Merkaz Ha Rav Kook Yeshiva (or talmudic academy), and co-founded the Jerusalem-based Yeshivat Ha Ra'yon Ha Yehudi (the Yeshiva of the Jewish Idea) with his father in 1987. Slightly built and introverted, Binyamin's faulty English initially proved a handicap with American-born devotees. However, like his famously articulate father, he soon developed a charismatic hold over his followers. fields.headline: 'Judge has slapped me in the face'
fields.standfirst:
Denise Fergus condemned the decision. This is an edited version of her statement:

Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: Denise Fergus condemned the decision. This is an edited version of her statement
fields.body:
"I am disgusted with the special treatment these two now get at every turn. The judge has slapped me in the face. She's not taken into account the full effects of this in the future for me as James's mother.

"It makes my blood run cold to think that they are being patted on the back and rewarded after the cruel, premeditated murder they carried out.

"The lawyers want us to forget about the evil way they took James and murdered him, but people will never forget what they did.

"If this privacy order stays in place the press and media in this country will be gagged.

"But the judges cannot control the world media. Thanks to the internet, anybody with a computer will be able to read all the details any foreign newspapers are printing.

It will be a complete nonsense and it means this privacy order cannot work.

"They [the killers] will be recognised and found out under any new name wherever they go.

"Every minute they will have to look over their shoulders... they will never be able to relax. That is some comfort to me - to know they will always be haunted and hunted.

"But it is the people they meet and succeed in deceiving that I am concerned about.

"What will happen when they meet girls and even have children? It is very dangerous and cannot be right for the government to conspire with them to hide the awful truth.

"It is terrible to think that anyone could have them living next door to them without knowing who they are.

"Now they can use these false identities as a cover and could even abduct and kill another child before anyone living close to them realises the danger.

"They should not get more privileges than any other prisoner. They should be left to fend for themselves, not have the Home Office mollycoddling them."

webTitle: Matthew Engel: Shunt this committee off the rails

fields.headline: Shunt this committee off the rails
fields.standfirst:
What's the point of a users' group that refuses to upset the railways?

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: What's the point of a users' group that refuses to upset the railways?
fields.body:
Concerned readers have been inquiring why this column has been silent on the subject of the railways - despite the crisis of the last few months, despite the author's known obsession with the subject and despite the fact that every other columnist in the land (specialist subject, as Basil Fawlty once said, "the bleedin' obvious") has used their space to demand renationalisation.

I have been a bit diffident for, um, personal reasons, dating back to late summer. That was when I saw a paragraph in the local paper requesting volunteers to join the Rail Passengers Council (West). This is the government sponsored consumer group enjoined to represent the interests of the poor saps who travel by train. You occasionally see it mentioned in news stories: "First Great Western yesterday announced a new plan to relieve overcrowding: passengers without seats will be herded off at Swindon and garrotted ... A spokesman for the Rail Passengers Council said: 'We feel this may be slightly excessive.'"

I do have a vague prejudice against journalists who leap over the footlights, as it were, and try to act on the political stage themselves. However, Simon Jenkins has been on every quango imaginable, including the old British Railways Board. He's a famous columnist. And remember who it was that made the trains run on time? Il Duce started as an editor. In comparison, joining the Rail Passengers Council (West) hardly seemed like a major grab for power.

There was no pay - just a bit of committee work. I saw it as a way of assisting fellow travellers and of sublimating my own rail rage, because of the danger that I might one day strangle a ticket collector ("Why isn't a supersaver valid? It's Sunday afternoon." "Yeah, but this is the delayed 08.39 from Friday. That'll be another £94"). So I applied and was asked to attend for interview before a panel in Bristol. I was told, unofficially, that they were desperate.

Not that desperate, it transpired. Now, I am, it so happens, the world's worst interviewee. At my first job interview at a newspaper, I shook so much that the tea spilt. I only got employed anywhere because I saw a nice old boy in Kettering who talked nonstop for half an hour, and so thought I was a really interesting young man. And these days I'm out of practice too.

I said nothing about strangling ticket collectors and tried hard to sound like a solid committee man. But they did know my profession. And about halfway through the interview, the panel chairman, a civil servant called Mrs Maysey, announced in a Lady Bracknell voice: "I don't think we want a journalist. The train companies wouldn't like it."

I dare say I was hopeless enough in that situation for them to reject me anyway. And they did: "Other applicants were better-qualified ... so sorry ... thank you for your interest ... you were the weakest link, g'bye." But if they were unimpressed, the feeling was at least mutual. I thought they were a bunch of complete twerps.

For form's sake, I protested. Hackism, prejudice against journalists, is obviously a serious problem in society, possibly requiring legislation. The Rail Passengers Council (West) comes under the aegis of the rail regulator, the thin-lipped Scotsman who's on the telly the whole time offering to fine Railtrack, a fatuous threat since the money will only be chiselled out of our pockets anyway. He panicked momentarily when he got my letter, presumably thinking I might write a column about it (which of course I never would), then recovered his composure and sent a snotty reply confirming the panel's rejection.

By that time, I had lost interest anyway. What use is the Rail Passengers Council (West) or (anywhere else)? Si monumentum requiris, circumspice. What could I have achieved? Nothing has been done to improve the lot of rail passengers for two decades, except the addition of baked beans to the £14.95 breakfast menu on the (notional) 07.25 from Cardiff. And I don't suppose Mrs Maysey was responsible for that.

If anyone wishes to form a Rail Passengers Direct Action and Guerrilla Warfare Council (West), I would be happy to attend for interview. This week, even amid the current outrageous shambles, fares have gone up. The train operators are promising "normality" in time for April, ie by an amazing coincidence, the election campaign. But do you remember how ghastly "normality" was?

The BBC obtained a report yesterday saying it will take five years for public confidence to return. Under the present regime, it will never return. It is an unworkable system run by people whose interests would be directly opposed to those of the travelling public even if they were half-competent. Which they ain't. Acting for us: Lady Bracknell. How long, Tony Blair, how long?

matthewengel@ndirect.co.uk

webTitle: Precedent warning as judgment promises new lives in secrecy for icons of hate

fields.headline: Precedent warning as judgment promises new lives in secrecy for icons of hate
fields.standfirst:
Myra Hindley could use same argument to gain anonymity on release, court told

Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: Myra Hindley could use same argument to gain anonymity on release, court told.
fields.body:
The ruling giving Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, the killers of James Bulger, blanket protection from media intrusion from the rest of their lives could set a precedent for other notorious criminals to seek similar gagging orders on their release.

Desmond Browne, QC for the three national newspaper groups which opposed a permanent injunction, told the judge, Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, that it could open the way for the Moors murderer Myra Hindley to ask for a ban on disclosure of her whereabouts and any new identity if she ever wins her freedom. Paedophiles too could invoke the ruling to ward off unwelcome press attention and vigilante attacks, Mr Browne warned.

The ruling was a "historic first", he pointed out. No adult had ever before won a court order guaranteeing anonymity. The so-called Mary Bell order, the prototype for the injunction granted yesterday, was in fact not granted to protect the child killer but to safeguard her daughter from press attention.

Had it not been for the existence of her daughter, the courts would have had no power to protect Mary Bell with a blanket ban on publishing or soliciting details of her new life. Yesterday's ruling could open the way for her to seek a new injunction to preserve her anonymity when her daughter reaches 18 and the current court order expires. She would have to show that her life was in danger from reprisals for her killing of two small boys in 1968 when she was aged 11.

She served 12 years before her release and managed to remain out of the public eye till two years ago, when a book by Gitta Sereny, Cries Unheard: Why Children Kill - the Story of Mary Bell, was published and the Sun tracked her down. Some details of her new life found their way into the newspapers and she was given police protection.

But Bell is no longer demonised - if she ever was - to anything like the same extent as Venables and Thompson, who abducted two-year-old James Bulger from a Merseyside shopping centre in February 1993, battered him to death and left his body on a railway line. She might not succeed in convincing a judge that publication of her whereabouts would put her life in danger.

Myra Hindley, however, still rivals the Bulger killers as an icon of hate. Although successive home secretaries have said that in her case "life means life", she is challenging the home secretary's role in setting the tariff for murderers. The lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, predicted two months ago that judges may well remove from the government the right to decide when murderers go free.

If that happens, Hindley could be released eventually, on licence, and provided with a new identity by the home office. Newspaper articles over the years painting her as a uniquely evil killer who should never be freed could prove, in her case, as convincing evidence of the danger of vigilante attacks as they did in the case of Thompson and Venables.

Dame Elizabeth ruled that the court now had jurisdiction to grant an order extending anonymity into adulthood because of the Human Rights Act 1998, which came into force last October, making the European convention on human rights part of UK law. Under article 2 of the convention, the state is obliged to protect an individual's right to life.

She had decided that the law may, in exceptional circumstances, be applied to protect individuals who are seriously at risk of injury or death if their identity or whereabouts became public knowledge.

Allan Levy QC, who has advised Mary Bell, said: "This is not a precedent in the sense that it opens the floodgates. But if another case comes along where there is evidence of serious risk to life, then it is likely it will be as persuasive in that case as it has been in this."

Dame Elizabeth ruled that past information on Thompson and Venables, including the names of the secure units where they spent their time in custody and the rehabilitation regimes they underwent, could be published by the media after a "cooling off" period of 12 months. Mr Levy predicted that once the 12 months elapsed, fellow inmates would demand large sums of money for anecdotes about the pair. "That's going to give rise to quite a little industry."

Resettled abroad

Stories that Thompson and Venables might be resettled abroad in Australia, New Zealand or Canada are wide of the mark. Apart from the question of those countries' entry restrictions on people guilty of serious crimes, settlement abroad would make it impossible for the British criminal justice system to give them the supervision required for murderers on licence.

Instead, they are expected to be resettled somewhere in the north of England, where their accents, and those of their families will be less conspicuous. New identities likely to be provided for them and their immediate family will include new names, birth certificates, national health service numbers and a new family history.

If the plan works, only a small circle of people will know their true identities. Workmates or fellow students will be kept in the dark. But there will be a police surveillance operation with a panic button for each in case a problem arises.

However, the information their lawyers have fought so hard to suppress could still surface on the internet. The injunction bans the media in England and Wales from picking it up and publishing it, but it could still travel swiftly over the web, aided by word of mouth. Nor does the injunction cover newspapers published in Scotland.

webTitle: Leader, the Bulger killers: Rehabilitation provides more protection

fields.headline: Limits to free speech
fields.standfirst:
Rehabilitation provides more protection

Related special report
The Bulger case
fields.trailText: Rehabilitation provides more protection.
fields.body:
Does the state have an obligation to protect people from serious assault, or even more important, death threats? To pose the question is to answer it. The reason the criminal justice system was set up was to put an end to private blood feuds and lynch law. That was the reason the Guardian declined to join the four newspaper groups that asked the high court to lift the injunction protecting the anonymity of the killers of James Bulger, the Merseyside toddler. Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the family division, rightly ruled yesterday that the protection should continue, even though the killers have now reached 18 and are expected to be released this year.

There is a clear clash in this case between two separate and vital democratic principles - the right to free speech versus the right to privacy. We yield to no one in emphasising the need - and indeed fighting in the courts - to make Britain a more open society. But it is equally important for campaigners to recognise the limits of free speech.

Jon Venables and Robert Thompson, the pair of deeply troubled 10-year-olds who killed James Bulger in 1993, will shortly have served the eight years which the lord chief justice declared last year should be the "tariff" for their crime. Their release, which will be decided by the parole board, will now depend purely on the risk that they pose to society. It is clear from the chief justice's judgment that, thanks to expert work by psychologists and support staff in the separate social service secure units in which the offenders were placed, the two young men no longer pose a risk.

The application from media groups talked of the public right to know - and the danger of a slippery slope. Free speech is important but so is the protection of life. The threat to the two young men could not have been more specific. Dame Elizabeth's long judgment contains a catalogue of stories in which overt threats - both to kill as well as injure - have been made against the young men by the public as well as relatives and friends of the murdered child. Home Office staff confirmed that they were taking these seriously. They were right to do so, following the fire-bombing of homes of suspected paedophiles by vigilante groups, spurred on by our tabloid press.

But is this a dangerous precedent? No. As the judge noted, the case has "almost unique circumstances". This is only the second time in the history of the Home Office that new identities have been planned for child murderers in anticipation of their release. The reason why this has been necessary is the tabloid's obsession with the offenders and their hysterical coverage of the case. Thankfully, the ban will prevent the tabloids from disclosing information about their new identities or their appearance or the addresses where they will be living.

Remember, if the boys had been just a few months younger, there would not have been a trial at all - they would have been below the age of criminal responsibility. In most other European countries, 10-year-olds would not have been prosecuted. The European court of human rights ruled the trial "unconstitutional", although it did not overturn the convictions.

The ban is unequivocal. It cannot apply beyond the English and Welsh borders or to the internet, but the judge made it clear that the English media would be clobbered if it tried to get round the ban by reporting facts appearing on the internet or in the Scottish media. The tabloids will protest, but brought the curbs on themselves. Rehabilitating the two remains the best public protection.

The reason why this has been necessary is the tabloid's obsession with the offenders and their hysterical coverage of the case. Thankfully, the ban will prevent the tabloids from disclosing information about their new identities or their appearance or the addresses where they will be living. Remember, if the boys had been just a few months younger, there would not have been a trial at all - they would have been below the age of criminal responsibility. In most other European countries, 10-year-olds would not have been prosecuted. The European court of human rights ruled the trial "unconstitutional", although it did not overturn the convictions. The ban is unequivocal. It cannot apply beyond the English and Welsh borders or to the internet, but the judge made it clear that the English media would be clobbered if it tried to get round the ban by reporting facts appearing on the internet or in the Scottish media. The tabloids will protest, but brought the curbs on themselves. Rehabilitating the two remains the best public protection. Talk about it What do you think? webTitle: Summary of the judgment by Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss

fields.headline: 'I am compelled to take steps to protect their lives'
fields.standfirst:
Summary of the judgment by Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss

Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: The murder of James Bulger by Jon Venables and Robert Thompson on February 12, 1993 was a horrific crime and the circumstances unusually shocking and distressing.
fields.body:
The murder of James Bulger by Jon Venables and Robert Thompson on February 12, 1993 was a horrific crime and the circumstances unusually shocking and distressing.

It caused much public concern and a widespread feeling of moral outrage. There was massive national and international publicity both at the time of the murder and during and after the trial.

Press and media coverage continued throughout the period of the detention of the two boys and increased at the time of the decision of the lord chief justice on the tariff and the hearing of the present proceedings.

During the period of detention, injunctions have been in place which restricted the information the media was entitled to publish. Those injunctions came to an end on the 18th birthdays of the two boys. They made applications for injunctions to restrain publicity to run indefinitely. I granted interim injuctions on July 27, 2000 to continue until the full hearing of the applications.

I heard full arguments for Venables and Thompson seeking injunctions, from four groups of newspapers opposing injunctions and from the attorney general and the official solicitor supporting the grant of injunctions. I also received evidence from the home secretary. I reserved my decision and handed it down today.

I have decided that, taking into account the provisions of the European convention on human rights, the law of confidence may, in exceptional circumstances, be applied to protect individuals who are seriously at risk of injury or death if their identity or whereabouts became public knowledge and that the court has jurisdiction to grant injunctions to ensure their protection.

I have been provided with a wealth of information from Home Office evidence, press reports, judicial observations, and other information that has convinced me that these young men are uniquely notorious and are at serious risk of attacks from members of the public as well as from relatives and friends of the murdered child.

Threats to injure and to kill them have been set out in the evidence presented to me and have been reported in the press. I am satisfied that, although there has been balanced discussion in press articles in recent months, the sense of moral outrage has not diminished and there remains among some members of the public a serious desire for revenge if the two young men are living in the community.

The Home Office views these threats very seriously and is likely to give Venables and Thompson new identities on their release from detention. I am therefore convinced that their lives are genuinely at risk as well as their physical safety if their new identities and whereabouts became public knowledge.

I also read a number of press reports and editorials both from the time of the trial and later litigation and recently, and have come to the conclusion that certain sections of the press would not wish the two young men to remain anonymous and would wish to have them identified and if information about them became available, there was a real possibility it would be published.

In my judgment, if any section of the media decided to give information leading to the identification of either young man, such publication would put his life at risk. In the exceptional circumstances of this case and applying English domestic law and the right to life enshrined in article 2 of the European convention, I have come to the conclusion that I am compelled to take steps in the almost unique circumstances of this case to protect their lives and well-being.

I recognise the enormous importance of upholding freedom of expression and the right of the press to publish. I have, however, decided that, for the reasons I have given above, and set out at length in my judgment, it is necessary to grant injunctions to restrain the media from disclosing information about the new identity, appearance or addresses of Venables and Thompson when they are released from detention.

In my judgment it is also necessary to restrain any publication of information about their present appearance and whereabouts in order to protect them on release. After a period of twelve months it will not be necessary to restrain the media from disclosing information about the past which is not already protected by the existing rules of confidentiality.

Since the information about their identity is so sensitive it will be necessary to continue to restrain information which might lead to finding them even if it has been placed in the public domain by publication for instance on the internet.

fields.headline: Republicans plan huge missile shield
fields.standfirst: Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: George W Bush is preparing to commit billions of extra dollars to develop a more elaborate system of national missile defence (NMD) which is certain to sour relations with Russia, China and Europe, and could bind future administrations to the policy.
fields.body:
George W Bush is preparing to commit billions of extra dollars to develop a more elaborate system of national missile defence (NMD) which is certain to sour relations with Russia, China and Europe, and could bind future administrations to the policy.

His plans, which are being driven by his vice-president, Dick Cheney, and his nominated defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, are likely to dwarf the 100-missile Alaska-based system which was under consideration by the Clinton administration before test failures last summer forced it to pass the issue to its successor's intray.

The scale of the Bush team's thinking began to emerge as the president-elect met congressional leaders in Austin, Texas, yesterday to begin mapping out the Republican legislative programme for defence.

His three principal campaign commitments on defence were raised at the meeting: a $1bn (£668m) pay rise for the armed forces, a $20bn boost for hi-tech weapons research, and the NMD system.

"Strengthening the military is one of my top priorities," Mr Bush said.

He was joined in the discussions by Mr Cheney, who is himself a former defence secretary, Mr Rumsfeld, and his national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice.

They were attended by eight senior Republicans and six senior Democrats, including the chairmen of key defence-related committees in the Senate and House of Representatives.

One notable absentee was General Colin Powell, Mr Bush's choice for secretary of will have the job of selling the NMD plans to America's allies, including Britain, which opposed the Clinton administration's scheme and object to Republican plans to abrogate the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty with Russia.

Diplomats in Washington believe that Mr Powell is advising his colleagues not to plunge into an immediate and detailed commitment to implement NMD, but to remit the whole issue to a commission which could consider all the military, political and spending issues involved in a long-term strategic commitment to missile shields.

Mr Powell is a supporter of missile defence, but he is understood not to favour developing a system in response to the dangers posed by North Korea, whose ability to launch missiles ostensibly triggered the current NMD development programme.

Rather, he wants NMD to be a long-term strategic cornerstone of US defence strategy, and is anxious not to antagonise world opinion by what might otherwise appear to be a premature and provocative development.

Mr Powell may get his way in having the implementation strategy remitted to a commission, but it will be given the job of defining how, not whether, NMD is introduced.

Mr Bush's team has not yet said in public how it will build missile defences, but several radical developments are under discussion.

All envisage a much bigger system than the Clinton administration's plan.

The most important of these are design changes which would shift the NMD strategy from its current land-based launching sites to sea-based and space-based interceptors.

"We need a system that is more robust than what the Clinton administration has designed," said Dave Smith, a Republican missile defence expert who served on the 1998 commission chaired by Mr Rumsfeld which persuaded Mr Clinton to go ahead.

"If you want to be more robust you have to go to sea or to space, or to both," Mr Smith said.

"The system needs to be global, it needs to be layered, and it needs to have an evolutionary approach."

The most likely expansion, at least as the first step which Ms Rice supported in remarks during the election campaign last year, would be for sea-based interceptors.

These would allow the US to attack enemy missiles at a much earlier stage in their trajectory, when interception would cause the debris, including any chemical or biological warheads, to fall over the launch country rather than the target country.

Interceptors based at sea would also enable the US provide missile defence protection for its allies and American troops stationed overseas.

Ms Rice believes this would be more attractive to Europe, as well as providing billions of dollars of extra contracts to the defence industries and their workforces.

Republican military strategy is based on the belief that the US must always develop further and faster than any other country, an approach which would lead next to the development of interceptors located in space.

"You serve notice to any potential challengers that there's always going to be something on the drawing boards," Mr Smith said. "You stay ahead of the threat."

fields.headline: Door closing on communal living
fields.standfirst:
Multi-family flats are one of Soviet socialism's failures, so capitalist Moscow is giving tower blocks a try

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Multi-family flats are one of Soviet socialism's failures, so capitalist Moscow is giving tower blocks a try.
fields.body:
The Moscow city council has started abolishing the despised beehive-like communal apartment of the Soviet era shared by numerous families. They are being replaced by cheaply built one-bedroom flats.

Housing officials are realistic about the speed with which the 270,000 families living in the city's 118,000 remaining kommunalkas can be rehoused, however, and their initial 10-year programme has already been replaced by a longer one.

"The time has come to move people into separate apartments," Mikhail Kulikov of the municipal housing department said yesterday.

"Life in a communal flat where people with different temperaments and lifestyles are thrown together to share one toilet and one kitchen is no longer considered a normal existence."

The kommunalka was conceived as a means of eradicating class divisions after the revolution.

Excessively big tsarist houses were subdivided for the proletariat, and a family housed in each room. The planners hoped that this would forge bonds between residents, and regarded the innovation as an exciting experiment in socialist living.

But the kommunalkas began to feature in dissident Soviet literature as one of the greatest evils of the regime.

President Vladimir Putin described the tensions of growing up in a St Petersburg communal flat in his recent memoirs, recalling the kitchen arguments between his parents and their neighbours and the joys of chasing rats on filthy stairways.

In Moscow property developers have bought out many of the families housed in handsome, pre-revolutionary buildings near the centre and most of the remaining communal flats are in less desirable buildings in less fashionable parts of town.

Anna Azimova's home in a Stalinist-era block in the north of the city is an extreme examples of the genre. There are 16 rooms and 14 families: a total of 43 people sharing one kitchen and one shower. Each family has a narrow box-like space about 12 square metres in total.

To avoid queuing for the shower, Mrs Azimova, who is the deputy head of the local school, gets up at 4.30am. She prepares breakfast, lunch and supper for her family while her neighbours are sleeping, to escape the crush in the kitchen.

To exist in such close confines the residents have developed a set of unwritten rules which dictate who must take responsibility for everything from washing the floor to changing the light bulbs.

Only the apartment's three confirmed alcoholics neglect these duties, preferring to torment their neighbours by stealing food from the kitchen and inviting stray acquaintances from the nearby railway station for all-night vodka parties.

To the eight children who bicycle up and down the central corridor, the lifestyle has a definite appeal. Their parents see its positive side only rarely.

At New Year and Christmas they try to put aside their differences and pull pieces of furniture into the hall to make a long banqueting table. But this year they decided not to, because the ceiling was leaking too badly to make sitting in the corridor feel festive.

"We're meant to live as a big family, but it doesn't work like that. The walls are so thin you can hear people talking quietly. When the alcoholics start drinking together the other 40 of us can't sleep," Natasha Zamarakhina, 25, said.

She moved in five years ago, shortly before the birth of her son. Her husband has lived here all his life.

"The gossiping is the most depressing thing," she said. No one can do anything here without it being discussed by the 13 other families."

Despite the programme to get rid of the communal flats, which was started in 1999 and is due to be accelerated this year, she has little hope that she will be rehoused soon. Faced with a long queue of people awaiting new homes, the council has established an order of priority, giving precedence to second world war veterans, Chernobyl victims, and invalids.

The housing department is also committed to obliterating Moscow's crumbling five-storey 1950s blocks and has contracted developers to build much taller blocks to allow for the gradual resettlement of communal flat inhabitants.

Since funds were limited, Mr Kulikov said, both programmes would take time.

"Every year more people move to Moscow, every year our waiting list grows. But we are working towards this goal."

webTitle: Lockerbie trial nears end after final twist

fields.headline: Lockerbie trial nears end after final twist
fields.standfirst: Special report: Lockerbie
fields.trailText: After defence lawyers unexpectedly announced yesterday that they would be presenting no more evidence, judges in the Lockerbie trial will decide within days whether the two Libyans in the dock are guilty of the biggest act of mass murder in British history.
fields.body:
After defence lawyers unexpectedly announced yesterday that they would be presenting no more evidence, judges in the Lockerbie trial will decide within days whether the two Libyans in the dock are guilty of the biggest act of mass murder in British history.

The defence made its dramatic announcement at the Scottish court in the Netherlands, after giving only two days of submissions during the 77-day trial.

This means the crown will give its closing speech at Camp Zeist today, followed immediately by closing speeches by counsel for Abdelbaset Al Megrahi, 48, and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, 44.

The submissions are expected to last for no more than a couple of days and it is anticipated that the three judges then will take no more than a week to deliver their verdict.

After months of evidence, the stop-start trial began its abrupt crescendo yesterday when William Taylor QC, counsel for Megrahi, told the court he intended to call no further witnesses.

Mr Taylor had called only a few minor witnesses and it had been expected that he would ask Megrahi to take the stand today to begin a defence which would lay blame for the atrocity at the hands of a conspiracy of Palestinian terrorist organisations.

After Mr Taylor sat down, Richard Keen QC, counsel for Fhimah, said he would not be presenting any evidence in defence of his client.

The trial reconvened yester day after a one month delay to allow Syria time to respond to a defence request to release a document which claims to reveal who was responsible for the Lockerbie bombing.

At the start of the trial last May, Mr Keen and Mr Taylor indicated that the defence would blame the Damascus-based Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, among others, for the attack on Pan Am flight 103.

It is understood the document held by the Syrian authorities backed this claim, but the Middle Eastern government has refused to release it.

After closing speeches, the trial judges will decide whether Megrahi and Fhimah are guilty of murder, conspiracy to murder and a breach of the 1982 Aviation Security Act.

The charges were brought after the exhaustive investigation which followed the destruction of the Pan Am jet over Lockerbie on December 21, 1988, killing all 259 passengers and crew on board and 11 locals on the ground.

Libya's refusal to hand over the suspects led to years of sanctions against a country which has always proclaimed it had nothing to do with the destruction of the jet.

The prosecution case against the Libyans has been plagued by problems, from witnesses not giving the testimony expected of them, to the star witness, Libyan "supergrass" Abdul Majid Giaka, appearing to crumble under cross-examination.

webTitle: Leader: At last, Britain shifts ground on Iraq

fields.headline: Flights of futility
fields.standfirst:
At last, Britain shifts ground on Iraq

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Indications that Britain wants to end joint air patrols over southern Iraq should be seen first and foremost by Washington as a warning from London that current US policy towards Saddam Hussein's regime cannot any longer be sensibly sustained or wholly supported.
fields.body:
Indications that Britain wants to end joint air patrols over southern Iraq should be seen first and foremost by Washington as a warning from London that current US policy towards Saddam Hussein's regime cannot any longer be sensibly sustained or wholly supported. Whitehall may also be sending a message that the tougher, "re-energised" line advocated by incoming Bushmen like Colin Powell, if translated into increased military and economic pressure on Iraq, could make a bad situation worse.

The Iraq "policy review", revealed in yesterday's Guardian and confirmed by Foreign Office officials, is but one move on the special relationship chessboard where the imminent arrival of George W Bush has given rise to a flurry of hasty recalculation. A unilateral US withdrawal from the Balkans, for example, could make it harder, mandarins might hint, to deliver national missile defence facilities in Yorkshire or to rein in the rapid reactionaries of Jacques Chirac's supposedly Nato-busting Euro-army. Labour may justly feel that this new, unabashedly rightwing US administration needs checks as well as balances. In pawn to the US on so many fronts, Britain has few courses to pursue. But given America's isolation on the issue, Iraq is one of them. British support, finally, is no longer unconditional. That is a step forward. Now the onus is on Washington to explain why it remains a useful idea to be blowing up Shia civilians (accidentally, of course) to protect Shia civilian insurgents who long since ceased to surge.

There are, in any case, plenty of other persuasive reasons why the RAF's Tornados should turn for home. Southern Watch serves no useful purpose. These flights of futility are symbolic of a failed war and a failed policy of sanctions and intimidation (as we have said many times). They merely obstruct the dialogue necessary for ending the Iraqi people's suffering and gaining re-entry for the UN's exiled weapons inspectors. As Saudi Arabia has reportedly made clear, Britain's solitary role as supporting actor to America's top-gun leading men in the skies over Iraq damages its standing in the Middle East, stokes anti-British hostility and stymies business. It undermines independent British and EU attempts to mediate the Arab-Israeli conflict and foster relations with key states like Iran and Syria. It actually helps Saddam who, careless of his people's lives, welcomes every foolish bomb.

fields.bodyText: Indications that Britain wants to end joint air patrols over southern Iraq should be seen first and foremost by Washington as a warning from London that current US policy towards Saddam Hussein's regime cannot any longer be sensibly sustained or wholly supported. Whitehall may also be sending a message that the tougher, "re-energised" line advocated by incoming Bushmen like Colin Powell, if translated into increased military and economic pressure on Iraq, could make a bad situation worse. The Iraq "policy review", revealed in yesterday's Guardian and confirmed by Foreign Office officials, is but one move on the special relationship chessboard where the imminent arrival of George W Bush has given rise to a flurry of hasty recalculation. A unilateral US withdrawal from the Balkans, for example, could make it harder, mandarins might hint, to deliver national missile defence facilities in Yorkshire or to rein in the rapid reactionaries of Jacques Chirac's supposedly Nato-busting Euro-army. Labour may justly feel that this new, unabashedly rightwing US administration needs checks as well as balances. In pawn to the US on so many fronts, Britain has few courses to pursue. But given America's isolation on the issue, Iraq is one of them. British support, finally, is no longer unconditional. That is a step forward. Now the onus is on Washington to explain why it remains a useful idea to be blowing up Shia civilians (accidentally, of course) to protect Shia civilian insurgents who long since ceased to surge. There are, in any case, plenty of other persuasive reasons why the RAF's Tornados should turn for home. Southern Watch serves no useful purpose. These flights of futility are symbolic of a failed war and a failed policy of sanctions and intimidation (as we have said many times). They merely obstruct the dialogue necessary for ending the Iraqi people's suffering and gaining re-entry for the UN's exiled weapons inspectors. As Saudi Arabia has reportedly made clear, Britain's solitary role as supporting actor to America's top-gun leading men in the skies over Iraq damages its standing in the Middle East, stokes anti-British hostility and stymies business. It undermines independent British and EU attempts to mediate the Arab-Israeli conflict and foster relations with key states like Iran and Syria. It actually helps Saddam who, careless of his people's lives, welcomes every foolish bomb. webTitle: Clinton's plan to get peace train rolling

fields.headline: Clinton's plan to get peace train rolling
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Promising to work for peace in the Middle East until his last moments in office, President Clinton has for the first time made public his plan to end the conflict
fields.body:
Promising to work for peace in the Middle East until his last moments in office, President Clinton has for the first time made public his plan to end the conflict

In a farewell address to the Israel Policy Forum in New York on Sunday night, he hinted that while both sides had accepted his proposals, their reservations made it all but impossible that he could bring about a deal while he was still in the White House.

"I am using my remaining time in office to narrow the differences between the two parties to the greatest degree possible," he said.

These are the main points of his proposals:

 A viable Palestinian state in the West Bank and Gaza. "Palestine to be viable must be a geographically contiguous state," Mr Clinton said. That means Israel will withdraw entirely from the Gaza Strip, dismantling the Jewish settlements that occupy 40% of the coastline

 Israel is to hand over "the vast majority" of the West Bank - perhaps as much as 95% - but the bigger settlement blocks will be incorporated into Israel

 Israel will swap land inside its borders for the blocks in the West Bank

 Refugees can return to the Palestinian state, but they will not have the right to return to the homes they were driven from in Israel. The US will lead the international community in raising money to compensate refugees for the losses, or to settle them in new homes

 An international force in Palestine will provide security along the Jordan river valley, and will monitor the implementation of the final agreement

 Jerusalem will be an open and undivided city, and the capital of both the Israeli and the Palestinian state, with freedom of access and worship to all. Israel will hand over the Palestinian quarters of Jerusalem, occupied in 1967. Mr Clinton gave no details of his proposals for the sacred ground at the core of the Middle East conflict: what Muslims call the Haram al-Sharif, the Noble Sanctuary, where the prophet Mohammed is believed to have ascended to heaven, and Jews call the Temple Mount, the site of their destroyed temple. The omission is a measure of the reluctance on either side to accept less than total control of the site

 Declaration of the end to the conflict, plus mechanisms to guarantee implementation of the agreements.

fields.headline: Film funds
fields.trailText: Your article on lottery-funded films (Honest truth, January 6) contains some well-reasoned comments about the problems facing the UK film industry. However, I would like to correct one misconception.
fields.body:
Your article on lottery-funded films (Honest truth, January 6) contains some well-reasoned comments about the problems facing the UK film industry. However, I would like to correct one misconception.

In talking about how public money is used to support filmmaking, Andrew Pulver writes, "no one appears confident about what to do with it" and adds that the Film Council ought to run training programmes - "massaging future talent into existence".

In fact, the Film Council has introduced a new cinema fund to nurture emerging talent, a development fund to create better scripts and a training fund. Creating a sustainable industry will take time, but these initiatives will bear fruit in the coming years.
John Woodward
Chief executive, Film Council

webTitle: Letter: BA Chief executive on the future of London's runways

fields.headline: London's next runway
fields.trailText: Following your report (BA chief backs third runway for Heathrow, January 5), I wish to make clear our position in the debate that surrounds the government's plans to relieve airport congestion in London and the south-east.
fields.body:
Following your report (BA chief backs third runway for Heathrow, January 5), I wish to make clear our position in the debate that surrounds the government's plans to relieve airport congestion in London and the south-east.

British Airways is not pushing for a third runway at Heathrow. The issue is far wider than that. The government has to look at all five London area airports to find the right way forward for the economy. I believe greater London needs additional runway capacity in the longer term. It is for the government to decide where and when.

We want Heathrow to grow so it can remain as one of the world's leading international airports. Though it is consistently rated in the top 10 of international airports by passengers, it is increasingly congested. Terminal one was originally designed for fewer than 10m passengers a year but is currently handling around 26m. This will get worse before it gets better.

Assuming it is built, the proposed terminal five will go a long way to enable British Airways, and other airlines using Heathrow, to improve the quality of service to passengers. The issue of improved runway capacity is a separate one that must be looked at in the context of the London and south-east region.

The politicians will have to take into consideration local communities and the environment in reaching a decision that will be vital for the future growth of London as a world-class trading centre. That is too big an issue to be focused on Heathrow alone.
Rod Eddington
Chief executive, British Airways

webTitle: Letters: How to measure risk factors for cancer

fields.headline: How to measure risk factors for a deadly disease
fields.trailText: There is little concrete evidence to support George Monbiot's assertion (Purporting to be beating cancer, January 4) that a rise in cancer incidence is due to the increased levels of synthetic organic chemicals in the environment.
fields.body:
There is little concrete evidence to support George Monbiot's assertion (Purporting to be beating cancer, January 4) that a rise in cancer incidence is due to the increased levels of synthetic organic chemicals in the environment.

It is important that the risk factors for cancer are accurately conveyed to the public. For example, tobacco is the cause of a third of all cancer-related deaths in the UK. However, it is important to be vigilant and George Monbiot's article underscores the need for full and accurate cancer registration - something that is threatened by the introduction of General Medical Council guidelines. We are concerned that GPs have been advised not to report cases of cancer as a matter of course to their regional cancer registry. This will undermine our ability to monitor changes in cancer incidence and understand the causes and effects of cancer. It will also impede our progress towards finding answers to the disease.

While the primary triggers of some cancers have proved elusive we believe that there will be significant progress in controlling cancer by focusing research efforts on the cancer process. However, we are monitoring evidence about environmental factors and if this warrants a closer look then it will become a priority.
Prof Gordon McVie
Director general, Cancer Research Campaign
Sir Paul Nurse
Director general, Imperial Cancer Research Fund

 In the UK, the probability of death from cancer before the age of 70 is decreasing, not increasing. Partly this is due to better treatment (particularly for breast cancer), but chiefly it is due to a large decrease in the number of premature deaths caused by tobacco (many smokers have managed to stop). These national mortality trends do not support George Monbiot's claim of rapidly increasing cancer rates due to industrial chemicals.

Admittedly the number of cancers being registered in Britain is increasing: we have more old people, cancer registration is becoming more thorough in some places and many cancers that might previously have been overlooked (some of which would never have threatened life) are now being detected by better screening and diagnostic techniques. But such artefactual increases are not evidence of any epidemic increase in the real causes of cancer.

There are also reductions in the causes, or improvements in the treatment, of many other diseases. In the UK, the overall probability of death before the age of 70 is only about half what it was 50 years ago.

Worldwide, the only two causes of death that are big and getting bigger fast are HIV and tobacco. But apart from these, people are living longer than ever before. Why not say so?
Richard Peto
Clinical trial service unit and Epidemiological studies unit, University of Oxford

webTitle: Police blame rail chaos for rise in drink-driving

fields.headline: Police blame rail chaos for rise in drink-driving
fields.standfirst: Special report: Transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The breakdown of the rail network after the Hatfield crash was partly to blame for an increase in the number of people caught drink-driving over Christmas and new year, a police officer said yesterday.
fields.body:
The breakdown of the rail network after the Hatfield crash was partly to blame for an increase in the number of people caught drink-driving over Christmas and new year, a police officer said yesterday.

Ken Williams, chief constable of Norfolk and chairman of the association of chief police officers road policing committee, said it was "common sense" to link the rise, the first in three years, to the chaos.

The percentage of motorists who tested positive after crashes rose to 7.18, compared with 6.5% in 1999-00 and 6% the year before.

Overall, 1,081 drivers involved in accidents in England and Wales between December 18 and January 2 were over the limit, the highest total for three years.

Gwent had the highest proportion of positive tests - 23%. Cambridgeshire had the lowest, 1.9%.

Though there has been no in-depth analysis of the figures, Mr Williams said it was highly possible the problems with the rail network, including the cancellation of trains and delays on some of the country's key routes, had forced more people to travel on the roads.

"The turmoil on the rail network may well have been a factor behind the increase in drink-driving."

He said it was disappointing a series of hard-hitting advertisements had not deterred more people from drinking and driving, and urged the government to consider stiffer sentences for offenders.

"It is clear considerable work remains to be done to target the hard core who continue to put the lives of other road users at risk. The carnage and destruction seen in these adverts appears not to affect these people."

Acpo said young drivers and those in their mid-40s seemed to be the worst offenders.

"Drivers aged between 17 and 24 can be more reckless, while those who are older tend to be of the 'let's have one for the road' generation," said an Acpo spokesman

"There is a solid core of people in their late 20s and 30s who have taken heed of the warnings not to drink and drive. They have grown up with the TV and poster campaigns and have taken notice. We have to focus on drivers either side of this group."

Acpo believes the fall in the number of drink-drivers last year may have been linked to the millennium celebrations.

"Thousands of people were at street parties or in city centres which were closed off to traffic. Things were back to normal this year so more people might have been out on the roads."

The RAC agreed the increase could have been due to rail passengers taking to their cars.

Edmund King, executive director of the organisation's campaigning arm, the RAC Foundation, said: "The Home Office proposals to increase sentences for the most serious, and repeat, offenders should send out a strong message not to drink and drive. We hope to see improvements in these figures in future."

After Gwent, Suffolk had the highest proportion of drink-drivers - 17.7% - followed by Thames Valley, West Mercia and the City of London.

Forces with low rates included the northern counties of Cheshire, Lancashire, Merseyside and Derbyshire.

webTitle: Letters: Lined up for the polls

fields.headline: Lined up for the polls
fields.trailText: You report (Tories signal Ulster retreat, January 5), a further step in the break-up of the UK. For 10 years the Conservatives have been the only national party to organise in the province. It was the only party that aspired to represent the whole of the UK.
fields.body:
You report (Tories signal Ulster retreat, January 5), a further step in the break-up of the UK. For 10 years the Conservatives have been the only national party to organise in the province. It was the only party that aspired to represent the whole of the UK.

We now understand that the Conservative party chairman, Michael Ancram, tells party activists in Northern Ireland that they should not field candidates who are likely to lose their deposits. Does he adopt the same approach to candidates in England, Wales and Scotland? How can the Conservatives claim to support the UK when it so clearly differentiates between the component nations of the country? The Tories in Northern Ireland have valiantly kept the union flag flying in the province with their nonsectarian approach to politics. It is an utter disgrace that they do not have the full support of the chairman.

I am sure that this change in approach does not have the support of "grassroots" members of the Conservative party. Perhaps if the chairman was selected by the members we would not have seen this. John E Strafford
Chairman, Campaign for Conservative Democracy

 Tony Blair claims he would "rather be right than popular" (Blair switches target, January 8). What makes him think the two are mutually exclusive?
Chris Willis
London

 Tony Blair's description of teachers (among other public service workers) as "saints and heroes" is probably just about right. The former frequently lived lives of grinding poverty; the latter were cannon fodder more often than not.
Terry Jones
Carlisle
TJones@staffserver.carlisle. ac.uk
