fields.headline: Why I oppose sanctions
fields.trailText: The Foreign Officer minister, Peter Hain (I fought apartheid, I'll fight Saddam, January 6), justifies the sanctions against Iraq by comparing them to those that contributed to the fall of apartheid in South Africa.
fields.body:
The Foreign Officer minister, Peter Hain (I fought apartheid, I'll fight Saddam, January 6), justifies the sanctions against Iraq by comparing them to those that contributed to the fall of apartheid in South Africa. He goes on to accuse those who oppose the sanctions of "propping up" the Iraqi regime.

I am an Iraqi in exile. My family left Iraq in 1979 after my mother was arrested and tortured by Saddam Hussein's agents. I do not believe there can be any peace in Iraq or the region as long as the current regime is in power. At the same time, along with the vast majority of Iraqis and people in the region, I am opposed both to the sanctions and the no-fly zones.

It is true, as Hain points out, that Saddam has not invaded any of Iraq's neighbours, sent rockets against Israel or poisoned the Kurds during the past 10 years. Nevertheless, after 10 years of sanctions, inspections and no-fly zones, his regime remains in power and with it the continued possibility of all these horrors and more. Life continues to be unbearable for ordinary Iraqis; sanctions and no-fly zones have not prevented the ethnic cleansing of Shiites and Marsh Arabs in the south nor the brutal raids against US-supported opposition groups in the north.

The fundamental problem with the international policy towards Iraq is that it has failed to address the source of the problem - the regime itself. On the contrary, the sanctions, along with other elements of international policy, have been the regime's main source of political legitimacy over the past 10 years. They provided Saddam with an alibi for the suffering brought upon the Iraqi people by his actions.

In this context the Iraq sanctions stand in stark contrast to those imposed against the South African regime, which were more targeted. Most importantly, while the sanctions against the apartheid regime were supported by and coordinated with the ANC, those against Iraq are opposed by most Iraqi opposition groups.

The no-fly zones share a similar flaw. Though well intended, they have failed to protect the Shiites or the Kurds from the regime's brutality. It is simply not possible, as the bombing of Yugoslavia showed, to rescue and protect the victims of human rights violations from the air alone. Moreover the cat-and-mouse games with the allied pilots, along with the mounting collateral casualties, are converted by the regime into political capital.

Contrary to what the minister says, those opposed to the sanctions and the no-fly zones are offering practical alternatives to tighten the political and military isolation of the regime and contribute to its demise. Such measures include the establishment of a war crimes tribunal to investigate crimes committed both inside the country and against its neighbours; the suspension of all negotiations with the Iraqi government as well as its membership of international organisations; a travel ban on Iraqi officials and other such measures which proved quite effective in the case of Yugoslavia. The no-fly zones should be replaced by manned safe havens like those established earlier in the Kurdish areas.
Yahia Said
London

 Peter Hain claims there is no alternative to the sanctions on Iraq. The Campaign Against Sanctions on Iraq is holding an international conference in Cambridge on March 10-11 entitled Policy Alternatives to Sanctions. Experts from around the world will debate policies designed to limit Saddam's oppressive capability without the crippling humanitarian cost of existing sanctions. Mr Hain is welcome to attend.
Tristan Jones
Cambridge
tmj24@hermes.cam.ac.uk
fields.bodyText: The Foreign Officer minister, Peter Hain (I fought apartheid, I'll fight Saddam, January 6), justifies the sanctions against Iraq by comparing them to those that contributed to the fall of apartheid in South Africa. He goes on to accuse those who oppose the sanctions of "propping up" the Iraqi regime. I am an Iraqi in exile. My family left Iraq in 1979 after my mother was arrested and tortured by Saddam Hussein's agents. I do not believe there can be any peace in Iraq or the region as long as the current regime is in power. At the same time, along with the vast majority of Iraqis and people in the region, I am opposed both to the sanctions and the no-fly zones. It is true, as Hain points out, that Saddam has not invaded any of Iraq's neighbours, sent rockets against Israel or poisoned the Kurds during the past 10 years. Nevertheless, after 10 years of sanctions, inspections and no-fly zones, his regime remains in power and with it the continued possibility of all these horrors and more. Life continues to be unbearable for ordinary Iraqis; sanctions and no-fly zones have not prevented the ethnic cleansing of Shiites and Marsh Arabs in the south nor the brutal raids against US-supported opposition groups in the north. The fundamental problem with the international policy towards Iraq is that it has failed to address the source of the problem - the regime itself. On the contrary, the sanctions, along with other elements of international policy, have been the regime's main source of political legitimacy over the past 10 years. They provided Saddam with an alibi for the suffering brought upon the Iraqi people by his actions. In this context the Iraq sanctions stand in stark contrast to those imposed against the South African regime, which were more targeted. Most importantly, while the sanctions against the apartheid regime were supported by and coordinated with the ANC, those against Iraq are opposed by most Iraqi opposition groups. The no-fly zones share a similar flaw. Though well intended, they have failed to protect the Shiites or the Kurds from the regime's brutality. It is simply not possible, as the bombing of Yugoslavia showed, to rescue and protect the victims of human rights violations from the air alone. Moreover the cat-and-mouse games with the allied pilots, along with the mounting collateral casualties, are converted by the regime into political capital. Contrary to what the minister says, those opposed to the sanctions and the no-fly zones are offering practical alternatives to tighten the political and military isolation of the regime and contribute to its demise. Such measures include the establishment of a war crimes tribunal to investigate crimes committed both inside the country and against its neighbours; the suspension of all negotiations with the Iraqi government as well as its membership of international organisations; a travel ban on Iraqi officials and other such measures which proved quite effective in the case of Yugoslavia. The no-fly zones should be replaced by manned safe havens like those established earlier in the Kurdish areas. Yahia Said London  Peter Hain claims there is no alternative to the sanctions on Iraq. The Campaign Against Sanctions on Iraq is holding an international conference in Cambridge on March 10-11 entitled Policy Alternatives to Sanctions. Experts from around the world will debate policies designed to limit Saddam's oppressive capability without the crippling humanitarian cost of existing sanctions. Mr Hain is welcome to attend. Tristan Jones Cambridge tmj24@hermes.cam.ac.uk

webTitle: Israeli rightwingers rally in huge show of strength

fields.headline: Israeli rightwingers rally in huge show of strength
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of rightwing Israeli protesters fanned out along the massive stone walls of the Old City of Jerusalem last night asserting Israel's eternal claim to the site.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of rightwing Israeli protesters fanned out along the massive stone walls of the Old City of Jerusalem last night asserting Israel's eternal claim to the site.

"It is the heart of the Jewish people. You cannot take the heart out, the patient will die," Rachel Himmelstein, a Briton now living in the central town of Beit Shemesh, said as loudspeakers blared patriotic hymns.

At the same time Palestinian officials were just as strenuously claiming Jerusalem as their capital of a future state, and criticising President Clinton's plans for sharing the city.

Mr Clinton unveiled the parameters of his peace proposals at a banquet in New York on Sunday night. In effect, his disclosure is an admission that he will not be able to broker a Middle East peace during his last 12 days as president.

However, he hinted that he hoped they would form the basis for future negotiations.

According to Mr Clinton, the proposals, which were at the heart of last week's highly guarded talks in Washington, have been broadly accepted by the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat

But as Jewish opponents of compromise were converging on the old city walls, Palestinian officials were lining up to shoot down the US president.

"Clinton did not take Arafat's reservations into account and these ideas don't offer our people their legitimate rights," said Ahmed Qureia - or Abu Ala as he is more commonly known - one of Mr Arafat's lieutenants.

Another negotiator, Yasser Abd Rabbo, said taking Mr Clinton's broad-brush proposals as a joint declaration of principles would leave the Palestinians marooned in another series of open-ended negotiations. "The most dangerous aspect when it comes to these proposals is the fact that they remain general principles that lack guarantees for their implementation."

He also said they stopped far short of Palestinian demands, in every sphere.

However, Israel reaffirmed Mr Barak's acceptance of the proposals. "We consider his ideas as a basis for the continuation of negotiations," said the deputy defence minister, Ephraim Sneh.

But for the thousands who converged outside Jaffa Gate, the entrance to the Old City favoured by visitors from Jewish west Jerusalem, the very thought is heresy.

Last night's rally was a show of force by the Israeli right - with generous funding from abroad, and participants flown in from the US and Europe. Speakers ruled out any transfer of territory to the Palestinians - even Arab East Jerusalem, which was occupied after 1967, and which few Israelis have ever seen.

It was meant to ram home Israel's claims to the Temple of the Mount, revered by Jews as the site of their destroyed biblical-era temple, and by Muslims as the Haram al-Sharif, marking the spot where the Prophet Mohammed ascended to heaven.

It also promises to give a boost to the election prospects of the hardline leader, Ariel Sharon, who opposes any compromise on Jerusalem.

Palestinian religious authorities condemned the rally as a provocation, and the chief cleric, or mufti, of Jerusalem issued a religious edict barring the transfer of any portion of the holy site to the control of non-Muslims.

But despite the protesters' insistence on Jerusalem as the "undivided and eternal capital" of Israel, the city was effectively partitioned last night on the 1967 lines. Fearing violence, police sealed off the city opposite Damascus Gate, barring Palestinians from crossing the old green line.

Also yesterday, the Israeli army commander in the West Bank city of Hebron confirmed that troops had shot a handcuffed Palestinian man in the leg, claiming that he had tried to escape from their custody.

fields.headline: Answer Me
fields.standfirst: Getting personal with... Jeff Green
fields.trailText: Getting personal with... Jeff Green
fields.body:
Full name: Jeff Green

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why?

Yes, on the internet. Always!

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why?

When I was 14, I lied to get into an X film called Let's Get Laid. A very misleading title. I don't think I've ever got over the disappointment.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad?

WEGSOH, WLTN, FS PMT, ASAP. No NSU.

What was the last illegal thing you did?

Speeding.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did?

I don't recall any kind-hearted thing I did in the last six months, to be honest!

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?

Jo Brand.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with?

FC.

Has a critic ever made you cry?

I don't read reviews because they always spoil them with little words like "not" and "far from" and "under no circumstances".

What would you advertise without a fee?

Greenpeace.

What would you never advertise?

Any of FC's gigs

What wakes you up screaming at 4 in the morning?

Falling asleep at the wheel.

What takes you to a "happy place"?

Being on stage (mostly).

Jeff Green is on tour throughout the UK from January 19th. Further information from 09068 501 251.

fields.headline: Of vice and men
fields.trailText: The Innocent | The Planets | EastEnders
fields.body:
On paper - or in the Radio Times, at least - The Innocent (ITV) hardly seemed like brave new drama. Focusing as it did on a schism between best friends, the subjectiveness of truth, and the compromises made and little lies told to live one's life, it appeared to be another off-the-peg contemporary drama.

And with the misogyny of the legal system, the choices women have to make, and the loveliness of everyone's house thrown in, you could have been forgiven for not even turning on.

But as soon as the story unfolded - and it was a story as clever and intricate as origami - it became clear that The Innocent was superior, intelligent and gripping.

Beth, David and Alison were best friends of 15 years standing. Beth and David were married, Alison divorced. Their children were all friends. Alison had not-so secretly fancied David while Beth gave up her career to have his children. David took a drunken Alison home after a ball one night. They kissed. We learnt of their history. He tried it on again, more ferociously this time. After an interruption, he told her to take her dress off. After the ad break, she said he had raped her. Who did you believe? Essentially, those were the bare bones of the plot, but the fine writing and excellent acting - from Clare Holman as Alison, Paul Rhys as David, and Caroline Quentin as Beth - put muscular meat on those bones. Here was certainly something to get your teeth into. The relationship between the three and, to a lesser extent, Alison's ex, was intriguing and convincing.

Fifteen years of history - and the terrible future - was elegantly set up in the first 30 minutes and the breakdown in that relationship was never melodramatic: methodical and impressive storytelling without reliance on flashbacks or cheap stunts.

Plot and character worked in harmony, one never overshadowing the other (and for a drama with such a fiery plot, such restraint is to be applauded). There was a truthfulness in the dialogue, in the way men talked to each other and the way women talk to each other - and the difference between the two.

As the legal process wore on and kitchen table confrontations were traded for the wood-lined interior of the court, the pace never slackened and the ambiguities of what had really happened remained as ambiguous.

In a neat scene between Alison and Mark, who agreed to testify for her, the tension between the "All men are rapists" line, which Alison advanced, and Mark's "All men are not rapists" rebuttal was wonderfully played out, adding further to the complexity of the drama, without coming over all "Introduction to Gender Studies". There may have been black and white in this case, but there were also shades of grey.

The Innocent trod a fine line between veracity - paying heed to the abysmally low conviction rate in rape cases - and an audience's desire for a suitable return on its investment. In the end, it was accurate without being bleak, sanguine without being whimsical or unrealistic.

While the cast was on the whole outstanding - even the child actors weren't annoying - Paul Rhys was particularly chilling. David's cold calculation and emotional manipulation were both shocking, and behaviour not entirely alien to your average man. "David Pastarov is Everyman," he said of himself at one point. That's the worry.

The Planets (BBC2) was a 10-minute trip to Jupiter, something Captain Kirk couldn't even manage. Once again, geezers - or maybe it was geysers - were causing trouble. On Triton, they were shooting 80 miles in the air (or the space equivalent of air which would be the absence of air, one supposes).

Whatever, the looks on the faces of the guys back at Nasa were almost as priceless as these galactic wonders. So excited were they, it was as though Pamela Anderson had just walked in, covered in marshmallow, offering to get off with anyone with glasses and a model replica of the Starship Enterprise on their iMac.

With Mr Popadopolous getting in extra help at the launderette, it was inevitable Pauline Fowler would find something else to do with her time in EastEnders (BBC1). Normally, she confines her misery-making activity to her family, but with them in America/turning homicidal/taking drugs ("Woo woo! I'm so high, Asif." As if indeed), it's Sonia's turn. If only Carol Jackson were around, that'd be Pauline well sorted. To coin a phrase.

fields.headline: Ex-mayor cleared of expenses fraud
fields.trailText: After more than a year of fraud prosecutions and 17 convictions of ex-councillors and officers in Doncaster, a former mayor of the Yorkshire town was cleared of all charges against him yesterday.
fields.body:
After more than a year of fraud prosecutions and 17 convictions of ex-councillors and officers in Doncaster, a former mayor of the Yorkshire town was cleared of all charges against him yesterday.

William Gillies, a Labour party figure in Doncaster for decades, was told by a crown court judge: "You can leave court without a stain on your character," after a jury threw out seven claims of fiddled expenses.

Mr Gillies said after the verdict: "I'm absolutely delighted." He left Hull crown court with fellow ex-councillor Brian Day, who highlighted claims during the five day trial that the "Donnygate affair" was wielding a sledgehammer to crack nuts.

Mr Day, who was fined £300 in October for a single false expenses claim, said: "The court has heard evidence of a witch hunt on Doncaster councillors who are in danger of becoming an endangered species."

Mr Gillies, a father of six, was accused of claiming for non-existent first class train journeys and conference hotel stays to give himself "a bit of spending money". Prosecutor Fiona Swain alleged that he had worked a fiddle for conferences at Bournemouth, Glasgow, Tynemouth and in Wales while chairman of Doncaster's public works committee between 1993 and 1996.

A former Labour council colleague, Mike Baron, told the court of a conversation with Mr Gillies at the town's Mansion House when the ex-mayor described the fiddle as a pocket money earner. But Mr Gillies countered that Mr Baron's memory was wrong and that he could not understand why he should make such a slur.

Told by his barrister, Rodney Jamieson, that "the crown says you went on a series of jollies", Mr Gillies replied: "I couldn't be jolly if I tried. I work very, very hard. Everyone will tell you that from the director down."

He told the court he had gone early to some conferences because of the amount of work to be done. It had also never crossed his mind, he said, that he was doing anything dishonest by claiming his expenses before he went, which sometimes meant that he invoiced for rail fares but ended up going by car.

He lifted his head out of his hands and gave an audible sigh of relief after the foreman of the jury delivered the not guilty verdicts, then punched the air, beamed at the public gallery and thanked each juror as they filed out of court. He then hugged his wife Mary, who gave evidence for him, and asked a friend: "Can I buy you a whisky?"

A former pit superintendent, Mr Gillies was a member of Doncaster's Labour council from 1959 until last year.

Charges as a result of South Yorkshire police's "Operation Danum" are pending against a further 27 ex-councillors or council staff.

fields.headline: No: 1796 Handy Andy
fields.trailText: Aha. Stripy jumpsuit. Looby Loo. No, that's Andy Pandy. We're talking about the butch man in Changing Rooms.
fields.body:
Aha. Stripy jumpsuit. Looby Loo. No, that's Andy Pandy. We're talking about the butch man in Changing Rooms.

Keep my private life out of this. No, I mean TV's Changing Rooms, the popular DIY series.

Oh, the drill-wielding odd-job man. Andy Kane, the fix-it fella's true moniker, "has many years' experience as a carpenter and joiner", according to the BBC, and "brings a huge amount of common sense" to the programme.

Does everyone agree? Funny you should ask. The Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents has nailed the handy hammerer, blaming him for a recent 27% rise in DIY accidents.

What's his crime? RoSPA spotted him drilling into brick without using safety goggles.

The scoundrel! Co-presenter Lawrence Llewelyn-Bowen was also censured, for using equipment without tying back his luxuriant locks. "These programmes make DIY look simpler than it is," rails the watchdog, "and have made people take on jobs that are beyond their capabilities."

Has the Beeb taken up chisels on Andy's behalf? "The issue of safety is taken very seriously," they have retorted, "in all of the BBC's leisure programmes."

So should we take RoSPA's advice seriously? Deadly seriously. Their annual home accident report focuses on the threat to human health posed by tin cans and underpants.

Never, ever wear them together. There were also, RoSPA points out, 130,000 people hospitalised in carpet-related accidents last year.

It's an epidemic. Burn your shagpile (while wearing protective goggles, of course)!

So how can Andy patch it up with the accident police? It's thought the handyman might offer to refit some shelves in RoSPA's offices, while his colleagues reimagine the lobby in a pulsating shade of pink.

Most likely to say: "Try this at home."

Most likely to need: Elastoplast.

Not to be confused with: Charles Handy, Carol Smillie, Driller Killer.

webTitle: Chilean army admits 120 thrown into sea

fields.headline: Chilean army admits 120 thrown into sea
fields.standfirst:
Disclosure adds to dossier against defiant Pinochet

Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: Disclosure adds to dossier against defiant Pinochet.
fields.body:
New evidence of crimes committed during the rule of Augusto Pinochet, including the dumping of 120 bodies from helicopters into the Pacific, lakes and rivers, has hardened the mood in Chile and made it unlikely that the former dictatorcan secure the amnesty he has been seeking for human rights violations by the armed forces.

At the same time he has lost another attempt to get today’s interrogation by the investigating magistrate Judge Juan Guzman delayed. The appeal court rejected it by two to one.

If General Pinochet fails to attend and answer Judge Guzman’s questions he can be declared “in rebellion” - similar to contempt of court - and thus liable to arrest.

Gen Pinochet, 85, was last seen on Sunday afternoon, hobbling with a cane from his beach home to prayers in his private chapel.

Police officers and security guards blocked public access to nearby roads to shield the former commander-in-chief and president from television cameras and passersby.

For months Gen Pinochet and his allies have saved dozens of officers from trial by arguing for the revival of the amnesty law his regime introduced in 1978.

Those efforts were effectively buried by the new evidence of the atrocities committed under the regime between 1973 and 1990.

Gory details of the fate of 180 missing detainees from that time were given by President Ricardo Lagos in a nationally televised speech on Sunday night.

He said they were among the 600 people still unaccounted for out of the 3,000 thought to have been the victims of political violence under Pinochet.

He said that, thanks to a government-backed forum in which the military, the church and other sections of society were cooperating, he had information about how they had met their end.

Of the 180, he said, 120 civilians kidnapped by security forces in the 1970s were tossed from helicopters into “the ocean, the lakes and the rivers of Chile”.

Mr Lagos, a socialist who began his political career by challenging the Pinochet regime in the 1980s, said he had asked the supreme court to review and investigate the new information quickly.

The material was ceremoniously placed in a leather satchel and passed to Hernan Alvarez, who heads the supreme court.

Mr Lagos made no direct reference to Gen Pinochet in his speech, but the testimony and documents are a blow to the general attempt to revive and shelter behind his regime’s amnesty law.

More than 100 officers are under indictment for crimes committed during that period.

Further macabre details of summary executions, including the use of dynamite to dismember prisoners, are expected to be released within days.

The revelations will set off many further judicial investigations which are likely to involve teams of forensic anthropologists wielding their shovels under the country’s gaze.

In his speech, Mr Lagos sur prised commentators by referring to those who disappeared under the dictatorship as “our fellow countrymen” and “children of the nation”.

It was a remarkable break from the language of past civilian administrations, which buried the dead under the cloak of euphemism or classified them as the unfortunate victims of a fictitious civil war.

President Lagos left no doubt about his sentiments, referring to the events as “this tragic, dark episode of our national history”.

Without being specific, he revealed that a “mass grave” containing 20 bodies had been discovered in the capital, Santiago.

Further details, he said, would be released after the families of the dead were notified.

The president also chastised military and civilian officials who are still withholding information about the death of hundreds of people.

“I have not resigned my hopes that their conscience speaks and will help alleviate the pain of many [Chilean families],” he said.

But he praised “the recognition by the armed forces high command, who have accepted that Chile can’t look forward without clearing the debts of the past”.

The president of the Family Members of the Detained and Disappeared, Vivianna Diaz, said at the organisation’s office that Mr Lagos had told her privately that her father had been tossed into the sea in the mid-1970s, along with other prominent members of the banned Communist Party of Chile.

“After fighting for so long to find him, I know tonight that I will not ... To discover that he is in the depths of the ocean is terrible and distressing,” Ms Diaz said with tears rolling down her face.

She then told the group that “together with him were all his companions who were taken prisoner in May of 1976”.

The new evidence of what happened to 180 people came from six-months roundtable discussion in which human rights lawyers, religious leaders and military commanders discussed the systematic violations which began within hours of the 1973 coup that overthrew the elected left-wing government of Salvador Allende and installed Gen Pinochet.

For the first time in more than a quarter of a century opposing political forces have been confronting each other in a civilised and orderly way.

The army commander, Ricardo Izurieta, has played a crucial role in balancing the army’s present needs - fewer personnel, modern equipment, and a coordinated central command structure - with respect for the old guard, which is loathe to break away from nearly 30 years of lies about the armed forces’ role in mass murder.

Ultimately the military chose to divulge the truth, though critics maintain that President Lagos’s government had to toss in a£480m bone, the purchase last week of a batch of F-16 jets fighters.

fields.body:
There was room for a little confusion in our television review of Rebel Heart, page 22, G2, yesterday, in our reference to the Scottish accent of Bill Paterson who, we said, was "doing a Connery". He was, in fact, doing a Connolly - playing James Connolly, who was born and raised in Scotland of Co Monaghan ancestry. Not to have had him sounding Scottish would have been an inaccuracy.

Tim Luckhurst has asked us to point out that, contrary to what we said in the lead article in Media (page 2), yesterday, he was acting editor of the Scotsman for more than three weeks. He says he held the position, in fact, from February 6, last year, until the middle of June.

In our obituary of the glass engraver Laurence Whistler, page 22, January 6, we referred to his exhibition at the Coming Museum, New York. That should have been the Corning Glass Museum.

The new tests for benefits claimants advocated by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, page 1, January 6, are designed to find out what people lack in terms of basic literacy and numeracy, rather than "literary and numeracy".

The drumlins which "skittered in and out of the sea like paddling children" near Lindisfarne, page 10, Travel, January 6, were probably dunlins.

Apologies to readers of the Guide, January 6, who found some of Wednesday's (tomorrow's) terrestrial television programmes reprinted in Thursday's agenda.

fields.headline: Judge punched in court
fields.standfirst: Prisoner punches judge in court
fields.trailText: An inquiry was under way yesterday into how a man facing a murder charge managed to vault from an Old Bailey dock, hurl a water carafe at a judge and repeatedly punch her in the face.
fields.body:
An inquiry was under way yesterday into how a man facing a murder charge managed to vault from an Old Bailey dock, hurl a water carafe at a judge and repeatedly punch her in the face.

The man carried out the attack, which left Judge Ann Goddard QC needing hospital treatment, even though he was flanked by three security guards from Securicor. He was finally overpowered by a police officer and court staff.

The company and the Home Office were looking into why the man was not handcuffed although he has been involved in previous incidents in court.

The dramatic incident began when the 64-year-old judge adjourned the man's case yesterday morning so he could consult his lawyers.

Without warning, the man, who is 6ft tall and in his early 30s, jumped from the dock. A police officer who was in court said: "Everyone thought he was trying to escape and blocked off the exits but instead, he ran down the side of the court and on to the platform where the judge sits.

"He grabbed a jug of water from the jury bench. He threw it 10ft towards the judge, but luckily it missed her and it smashed against the wall. He punched her five or six times."

Detective Constable John Nicholson was first to react. He jumped on to the judge's bench and then leapt down onto the man. He and other court staff wrestled him from the judge.

The judge, who is resident at the Old Bailey and has been a barrister for more than 40 years, suffered a gash to her left temple. Her wig slipped and she lay in a pool of glass.

She was given first aid where she lay and then helped from the court by the Old Bailey matron and attended to in her chambers. Later she received treatment at University College hospital in Bloomsbury, central London, and was in good spirits.

The inquiry will focus on why the man, who has been on remand at the top-security Belmarsh prison, Woolwich, was not in handcuffs. On a previous appearance before the judge he made a sit-down protest in the dock for 15 minutes. He swore and shouted: "I'm being murdered in Belmarsh by an illegal machine. I want it turned off, I demand it." He has also hurled papers towards a judge.

Both the jail that is holding a prisoner and an agency in charge of escorting a prisoner to court can make an application that he or she be handcuffed while in the dock, although courts allow this relatively rarely. There is a fear that seeing a defendant in handcuffs can prejudice a jury.

Concerns about an inmate are recorded by prison officials on his or her prison escort record and security information record. The Home Office said both documents in this case were passed to Securicor. It is understood that some concerns about the man's mental health were highlighted.

Securicor Custodial Services, which is in charge of escorting prisoners to and from 63 courts in the Metropolitan police's area, said it had launched its own inquiry. It said it was only in extreme circumstances that it applied for a prisoner to be handcuffed.

Some lawyers who work frequently at the Old Bailey have privately expressed concern over security for some time, as numbers of court officials and attendants have been reduced. One senior lawyer said: "This attack was waiting to happen."

fields.headline: Market whispers hit Geo
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Market forces.
fields.body:
It was late in the session but the word was out - avoid Geo Interactive Media. By the close, the stock was trading at 585p, off 52.5p.

The bearish call came as traders heard whispers that Geo's main rival in the video compression market will reveal today details of a tie up with mobile phone maker Motorola.

PacketVideo in America is expected to reveal at the Consumer Electronics show in Las Vegas details of a collaboration that will make its products compatible with Motorola phones. Motorola is also expected to announce that it has taken a stake in PacketVideo.

Industry watchers say the news will hurt Geo's stock price. For months now, Geo has being telling anyone who would listen that its technology is 12-18 months ahead of the competition. A recent deal with Swedish group Ericsson seemed to have proved that but now the market is not so sure.

Perhaps it was the agreed £3.2bn takeover of cement group Blue Circle, up 29p to 487p, that started it, but a wave of speculation swept over the London market yesterday, as trading got into full swing for the first time since the Christmas break.

Abbey National was among the stocks on the punters' menu as a tale first heard by a select few late on Friday was reheated for wider consumption. Somehow the speculative end of the market has got hold of the idea HSBC, down 18p to £10.08p, is weighing the merits of making an offer for Abbey.

Although, HSBC has hitherto appeared uninterested in the domestic banking market, the gossips claim a chance to beef up its exposure to long term savings and mortgage markets, while at the same time blowing a big hole in the expansion strategy of Lloyds TSB (off 8p to 743p), is an opportunity too good to miss.

Whatever the truth, Abbey closed 19p lower at £12.55, hurt by its removal from Deutsche Bank's influential European buy list. Deutsche reckons there is little upside in the shares at current levels even if Lloyds makes an offer.

Grocer Safeway, 10.5p stronger at 311p, had a late surge with buyers literally queueing up for the stock after details of what was said to be its Christmas trading statement leaked out. If true, Safeway appears to have had a very good Christmas.

Predictions about Christmas trading were also behind the 10p to 210.5p gain in the Marks & Spencer share price. Traders traced the majority of the buying to Brandes Investment Partners, the US fund which owns 4.32% of the high street retailer.

According to dealers, Brandes seems to have taken the view that M&S's trading statement - due January 23 - could be better than the pundits predict.

At the index level, the session was all about the market's biggest stock - Vodafone - and the market's biggest influence, Wall Street. Vodafone tumbled 14.5p to 227.75p, wiping 40 points off the FTSE 100, after Hutchison Whampoa said it would sell 1.1% of its stake in the mobile phone operator via a convertible bond issue.

As a rough rule of thumb, a penny move in Vodafone shifts the blue chip index three points.

On the other side of the Atlantic, Wall Street was having another sticky session as the downgrades and profit alerts continued to roll in and investment bank Morgan Stanley shifted its outlook for the US economy to that of an outright recession.

This cocktail of bad news saw the FTSE 100 close the day 48.5 points weaker at 6,149.6. The FTSE Techmark 100, however, fared rather better, easing just 10.34 to 2,438.29, helped by buying of the stocks such as Sage, 12.25p higher at 292p and ARM Holdings.

Lower down, internet security group Baltimore shed 13.5p to 284.5p, unsettled by a very negative research note from Deutsche Bank, which said there was a strong risk the company would miss its numbers in the one of the coming quarters.

fields.headline: Warning wipes 45% off IDS price
fields.trailText: IDS, a firm specialising in applications that calculate hire purchase agreement terms, yesterday underlined the fragility of the software sector by issuing a profits warning that wiped 45% off its share price.
fields.body:
IDS, a firm specialising in applications that calculate hire purchase agreement terms, yesterday underlined the fragility of the software sector by issuing a profits warning that wiped 45% off its share price.

The news left several big institutional investors furious. Three months ago they agreed to provide the company with a further £55m for expansion but now find the shares they received in return worth less than half the value at which they were issued.

IDS said it had failed to sign licence agreements it hoped for and, combined with a disappointing performance at one of its main businesses, that would mean "substantial" losses for the year to the end of December 31, 2000.

Three senior directors, including the firm's founder, Alfred Stein, have quit immediately, with non-executive director John Hubert taking over as chairman.

Shares in IDS fell 71.5p to 87p, and stand at less than a third of their value last month when signs of the licence difficulties first arose.

IDS had been expected to make a pre-tax profit of around £4.5m.

A company spokesman was unable to say how big the losses might be. However, IDS still expected to secure the licences it was negotiating for and those revenues could mean a positive outcome for 2001.

fields.headline: R-word avoided
fields.trailText: The world's leading central bankers sought to calm jittery financial markets yesterday when they ruled out the prospects of recession in both the United States and the global economy as a whole.
fields.body:
The world's leading central bankers sought to calm jittery financial markets yesterday when they ruled out the prospects of recession in both the United States and the global economy as a whole.

Sir Eddie George said that the American economy was slowing from its recent rapid growth but that a soft landing was more likely than a period of contraction.

"Nobody around the table was projecting a recession either in the US or the global economy," said Sir Eddie after chairing the regular meeting of central bankers at the Bank for International Settlements in Basle.

Most central bankers at the meeting, which included Fed vice-chairman Roger Ferguson, believed the US economy would grow at 2-3% in 2001, about half the rate in the first half of 2000.

webTitle: American hots up air war with TWA purchase

fields.headline: American hots up air war with TWA purchase
fields.trailText: American Airlines is expected to buy the troubled Trans World Airlines as part of a multibillion-dollar transaction that could transform the US airline industry.
fields.body:
American Airlines is expected to buy the troubled Trans World Airlines as part of a multibillion-dollar transaction that could transform the US airline industry.

The proposed acquisition of the loss-making TWA, the eighth-largest US carrier, could happen as soon as tomorrow. It would enable American to keep pace with its biggest rival, United, which announced the acquisition of US Airways last year. That deal, still to be approved by regulators, sparked a new round of consolidations.

Texas-based American and Chicago-based United rank as the world's two largest airlines. If the deals are approved, they would control more than half of all US air travel.

American is also in talks to buy about 20% of US Airways' assets for around $1.5bn, according to local reports yesterday. This move would help United win regulatory approval for its acquisition.

As part of the proposed acquisition of TWA by American, TWA would have to file this week for bankruptcy protection for the third time in less than a decade. TWA has not made a profit for 12 years. Its shares fell slightly yesterday to $1.32, valuing it at just $95m. American is understood to be prepared to take on TWA's debt, bringing the value of the deal to about $2bn.

Neither company would comment on the talks yesterday. Tim Doke, an American Airlines spokesman, said: "We are talking to lots of folk about lots of different things all the time and whenever they result in specific deals, we announce them promptly."

TWA said in a statement it was "always receptive to legitimate business overtures and is open to consideration of business combinations that will be beneficial".

Shares in AMR, American's parent, fell 4% to $41.9 yesterday morning while those of other, smaller US airlines rose as traders speculated on further consolidation.

Wall Street analysts warned that American's plans could face opposition from both the regulators and the airline's workforce. United was hit by crippling industrial action last year following its proposed acquisition of US Airways.

In a note to investors, Michael Linenberg of Merrill Lynch said: "It is likely any proposed transaction would have to be 'blessed' by American Airline's unions."

The proposed acquisition of the loss-making TWA, the eighth-largest US carrier, could happen as soon as tomorrow. It would enable American to keep pace with its biggest rival, United, which announced the acquisition of US Airways last year. That deal, still to be approved by regulators, sparked a new round of consolidations. Texas-based American and Chicago-based United rank as the world's two largest airlines. If the deals are approved, they would control more than half of all US air travel. American is also in talks to buy about 20% of US Airways' assets for around $1.5bn, according to local reports yesterday. This move would help United win regulatory approval for its acquisition. As part of the proposed acquisition of TWA by American, TWA would have to file this week for bankruptcy protection for the third time in less than a decade. TWA has not made a profit for 12 years. Its shares fell slightly yesterday to $1.32, valuing it at just $95m. American is understood to be prepared to take on TWA's debt, bringing the value of the deal to about $2bn. Neither company would comment on the talks yesterday. Tim Doke, an American Airlines spokesman, said: "We are talking to lots of folk about lots of different things all the time and whenever they result in specific deals, we announce them promptly." TWA said in a statement it was "always receptive to legitimate business overtures and is open to consideration of business combinations that will be beneficial". Shares in AMR, American's parent, fell 4% to $41.9 yesterday morning while those of other, smaller US airlines rose as traders speculated on further consolidation. Wall Street analysts warned that American's plans could face opposition from both the regulators and the airline's workforce. United was hit by crippling industrial action last year following its proposed acquisition of US Airways. In a note to investors, Michael Linenberg of Merrill Lynch said: "It is likely any proposed transaction would have to be 'blessed' by American Airline's unions."

fields.headline: Teddy bears' picnic
fields.standfirst: Seasonal sales set record
fields.trailText: Seasonal sales set record.
fields.body:
Retailers recorded their best December sales figures in three years as shoppers went a Christmas spending spree, new research shows today.

Although London stores fared less well than others because of the unreliability of the rail system, the British Retail Consortium said the Christmas period had been better than hoped for by the sector.

The BRC's lastest sales index rose by 3.4% in December, the best result for that month since 1997, when households were spending building society windfalls.

Today's figures will disappoint the Bank of England, which is relying on consumers starting to tighten their belts before it cuts interest rates. But the BRC said the sales figures were still at a fairly low level.

"Despite a better than expected December figure, the underlying trend in retail sales growth remains low," said Bill Moyes, director general of the BRC. "In these circumstances, the monetary policy committee must reduce interest rates to stimulate demand." The Bank's rate-setting committee begins its monthly meeting tomorrow.

As evidence of the happy Christmas for retailers, Hamleys yesterday announced a 10% rise in like for like sales, helped by an in-store teddy bear factory (above) and a refurbishment programme at its once chaotic flagship store in Regent Street, London.

The revitalised 240-year-old store led the group's sales figures for the five weeks to the end of December with an increase of 13% on the previous year, while the Hamleys-owned Toystack chain posted a smaller rise of 3%.

Chairman Simon Burke said the sales rise was primarily due to extensive refurbishment in the Regent Street store.

Mr Burke has introduced a number of reforms since he was recruited in August 1999 to turn around the fortunes of the then ailing toy retailer.

Shares in Hamleys rose 1.5p to 142.5p yesterday, while Electronic Boutique's share price rose 4.75p to end the day at 60.75p.

fields.headline: At this price? Pace Micro
fields.trailText: Toward the end of last year Telewest, the cable operator, had good reason to curse Pace Micro Technology under its breath. A components shortage meant that Pace, Europe's biggest maker of set-top boxes was unable to supply the equipment needed for Telewest's digital TV service
fields.body:
Toward the end of last year Telewest, the cable operator, had good reason to curse Pace Micro Technology under its breath. A components shortage meant that Pace, Europe's biggest maker of set-top boxes was unable to supply the equipment needed for Telewest's digital TV service. Marketing was suspended for a number of weeks and an unforgiving market punished the cable company.

Pace did not get off scot-free but yesterday demonstrated that it was able to shake off the investors' discontent more effectively than could Telewest. Shares in Pace ended almost 15% higher at 517p after it reported better than expected results for the first half.

Pre-tax profits were 41% better than the previous year at £17.9m while turnover increased 31% to £205.8m.

Pace chief executive Malcom Miller said the problem of components shortages meant £20m of lost revenues and about £1.6m lost profit.

The experience of Pace demonstrates the new myopia of the markets. In March, when the shares were worth £12.45, eyes were fixed firmly in the distance at long-term prospects of the business. By the end of last year a short-term problem with an obvious fix, such as a temporary shortage of com ponents, was able to damage the business. The proper view and share price lie somewhere in between.

Pace still has powerful prospects. BSkyB may have converted much of its 5m strong subscriber base to digital but the cable firms have a long way to go. Then there are the 15m or so households which have not subscribed to multi-channel TV at all.

With the switch-off of analogue due as early as 2006, those 15m will need either to buy specially adapted sets or use set-top boxes. Digital TV is not going away.

Pace is starting to break out of Britain, which is the most advanced digital TV country in the world. It has just signed supply contracts with two of the largest cable companies in the US. The contracts are relatively small but the door is at least ajar.

webTitle: 'Hedge fund UK' faces biggest risk in slowdown

fields.headline: 'Hedge fund UK' faces biggest risk in slowdown
fields.trailText: The economy's growing reliance on the City has turned Britain into the world's biggest hedge fund and made the country uniquely vulnerable to a global bear market, according to a report yesterday.
fields.body:
The economy's growing reliance on the City has turned Britain into the world's biggest hedge fund and made the country uniquely vulnerable to a global bear market, according to a report yesterday.

Investment adviser Smithers & Co said Britain had enjoyed a disproportionate share of the fruits of the 20-year global boom in bond and equity prices and was now "exceptionally exposed" to a reversal of that trend.

The warning came as Stephen Roach, chief economist of US investment bank Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, predicted a full-blown recession in the US that would reduce global growth in 2001 to 2.9% from 3.5%.

"The risks remain very much on the downside, and I would now attach a 45% probability to a full-blown global recession," said Mr Roach. Smithers & Co said that, with official figures showing that Britain's foreign liabilities exceed its assets, the country had only remained profitable in recent years by making skilful but risky bets in booming financial markets.

Like a hedge fund, it had made exceptional profits by, for instance, buying better performing shares abroad than foreigners were buying here, borrowing in low yielding currencies to invest in high yielding ones and trading derivatives.

If these profits were wiped out by a bear market in financial assets, the current account deficit could sink deeply into the red.

Moreover, the business and financial services sector had been a very important source of overall output growth in the second half of the 90s, and if it got into trouble the whole economy would suffer.

Smithers & Co said that in 1996, 1997 and 1999, financial and business services had accounted for about one third of overall growth. In 1999, the sector had been responsible for half the growth in output.

"As financial markets weaken, the UK is exceptionally exposed to economic shocks," said Smithers & Co. "The most likely are: slower than anticipated growth in GDP; worse than expected current account deficit; very poor budget forecasting."

Yesterday the Confederation of British Industry confirmed the strength of Britain's financial sector last year. It said the final quarter of 2000 had seen a strong rise in business volumes in financial services, although it added that firms expected the pace of growth to slow in the new year.

While 15% of firms said business was down on the same period a year ago, 45% said it was up - producing a positive balance of 30%, compared to 13% in September. Banks and general insurers reported the sharpest rises, while securities traders, fund managers and finance houses saw declines.

fields.headline: Two jailed for racehorse scam
fields.trailText: A controversial racing tipster and his former accountant were jailed yesterday for conspiring to defraud thousands of shareholders in a horse buying company.
fields.body:
A controversial racing tipster and his former accountant were jailed yesterday for conspiring to defraud thousands of shareholders in a horse buying company.

Basildon crown court was told Ronald Dawson and accountant Andrew Irish dishonestly concealed the true costs of promoting Classic Bloodstock II from investors.

The pair persuaded thousands of people to invest in the firm, which aimed to buy, train and race horses, without disclosing it had millions of pounds of liabilities.

But those shareholders found themselves out of pocket in 1997 when the company went into liquidation with losses of more than £2.5m.

A Department of Trade and Industry investigation found a £155,000 debt - from another Mr Dawson-owned firm - had been introduced into the company's accounts.

During the eight-week trial, estimated by lawyers to have cost £500,000, evidence was given by Bob Champion, a non-executive director of Classic Bloodstock II, who battled back from cancer to win the 1981 Grand National.

Mr Champion, who was not accused of any wrongdoing, told the court he thought the firm was "a good idea" and presumed all was in order.

A jury found the two defendants guilty, by a 10-2 verdict, of two counts of conspiring to defraud shareholders.

Mr Dawson, 62, was given two 12-month concurrent sentences, while 48-year-old Irish, a senior partner at Newmarket-based accountants Stephenson Davies, received one 12-month and a 15-month concurrent term. Both men will serve half their sentences, with the rest suspended, and are understood to be considering appeals.

Judge Zoe Smith told them: "A custodial sentence is appropriate. This behaviour has to be punished to protect the public and warn others who might be tempted to behave in the same way."

fields.headline: Lafarge's £3.2bn wins Blue Circle
fields.trailText: Rick Haythornthwaite, outgoing chief executive of Blue Circle, Britain's leading cement maker, is to make a paper profit of at least £1m on share options and win a substantial pay-off under the terms of yesterday's agreed £3.2bn takeover by Lafarge.
fields.body:
Rick Haythornthwaite, outgoing chief executive of Blue Circle, Britain's leading cement maker, is to make a paper profit of at least £1m on share options and win a substantial pay-off under the terms of yesterday's agreed £3.2bn takeover by Lafarge.

Blue Circle shareholders, who received a £800m special dividend last year, will pocket £75m on top of the French group's offer of 495p a share for a British company that can trace its origins back to 1824.

They will receive a special interim dividend of 11.65p a share on March 31, making the full deal worth 506.65p a share, around £450m more than last May's Lafarge hostile bid of 450p rejected by Mr Haythornthwaite, his board and advisers.

Mr Haythornthwaite, who earned £389,000 in 1999 after becoming chief executive in July, said he had rejected Lafarge's offer for him to stay on as an executive director. He will become a non-executive.

Determined to stay on until the summer, when completion is expected, Mr Haythornthwaite said he would exercise his options - some 980,000 granted at an average price of around 400p. He also owns a small personal stake.

Bertrand Collomb, chairman of Lafarge, which will be the world's largest cement and aggregates producer after the takeover, said: "We were never in disagreement over the logic of a deal, only on the price."

With the recent strengthening of the euro against the pound, it will cost the French group, which already holds a 22.6% stake, around €7.4bn (£4.7bn), the same as it offered last May.

Lafarge, which is taking on Blue Circle's £1.7bn in debt, said it would finance the deal with a €1bn rights issue but also planned to sell assets worth €1.5bn over the next 18 months.

Mr Haythornthwaite, a former oilman, said Lafarge had agreed to keep Blue Circle's corporate identity and brand in Britain at least.

webTitle: Curry plant may counter bowel cancer

fields.headline: Curry plant may counter bowel cancer
fields.trailText: A version of an ancient tonic for digestive ailments made from curry plants by the people of Irian Jaya could be marketed this year by the drugs firm Phytopharm as a food supplement to help prevent bowel cancer.
fields.body:
A version of an ancient tonic for digestive ailments made from curry plants by the people of Irian Jaya could be marketed this year by the drugs firm Phytopharm as a food supplement to help prevent bowel cancer.

The Oxford-based company yesterday published clinical trial results which showed that in five out of 15 cases the spread of bowel cancer stopped when patients took P54, a tonic based on oils from the shrub curcuma. Curcuma is best known for producing the curry ingredient turmeric.

Phytopharm's chief executive Richard Dixey believes it could be a breakthrough for sufferers of irritable bowel diseases such as Crohn's Disease, who have a vastly increased risk of developing cancer.

Mr Dixey said: "We're looking to develop something which stops pre-cancerous signs from developing any further."

The company has obtained patent protection for a method of mixing these oils with liquids from another plant. The substance works by inhibiting the production of COX-2, an inflammatory enzyme in the colon which is associated with the spread of cancer.

Phytopharm is in talks with several food companies about marketing P54 as a nutritional supplement. Mr Dixey said: "A launch this year is not definite, but certainly a possibility."

The supplement would cost about $1 (67p) a day, aimed at the 300,000 people in Britain alone who have colonic polyps - the first sign of possible cancer.

Drugs companies have been criticised by some environmental groups for profiting from traditional, indigenous medicines, although Mr Dixey insisted that Phytopharm's formulation is unique.

webTitle: Everyone deserves a slice of Orange

fields.headline: Everyone deserves a slice of Orange
fields.standfirst: Flotation must pass liquidity test
fields.trailText: One of the big questions about France Telecom's plans to float Orange is just how many shares will be offered to investors. The company has said that it will offer up to 15% of the equity. Additional shares on offer through an exchangeable bond issue could bring the total to 20%.
fields.body:
One of the big questions about France Telecom's plans to float Orange is just how many shares will be offered to investors. The company has said that it will offer up to 15% of the equity. Additional shares on offer through an exchangeable bond issue could bring the total to 20%.

Although Orange shares will be heavily and widely marketed, with the campaign targeting retail as well as institutional investors, the figure could be smaller than that, however. In theory it could be as low as 10%, although that would increase by a third through the bond element.

Either way, France Telecom and Orange are likely to be happy enough. On current estimates, Orange is likely to be valued in the €75bn-80bn range. So even if the percentage of Orange equity offered barely staggers into double figures, it will still raise a significant amount of money. That will help refinance the original purchase of Orange. The flotation will also give Orange an acquisition currency of its own and provide an identifiable value for Orange which should help support the France Telecom share price.

It is worth remembering, however, that in London the benchmark for the free float - the percentage of shares available to be traded - has traditionally been around 25%, although big issues have come in below that level. If 15% of the shares were offered, Orange would come within hailing distance of that level, close enough to satisfy even the purists.

If it were to take a more restrictive approach - something closer, say, to Deutsche Telekom's flotation of T-Online where a bare 10% of the shares was offered - that would be less cause for cheer. Liquidity is important, especially in these volatile times.

Investors should make it clear they expect the Orange free float to be at the top end of the range.

Micra scope

Some time this month Nissan is expected to announce whether its Sunderland plant will get the nod to build the new Micra. Although the plant has a fine reputation for productivity, the auguries are not entirely hopeful. Take the most recent figures from another Japanese car maker, Honda. Losses at its British plant hit almost £60m at the operating level in the year to last March. The European operation, which includes the British contribution, has already run up considerably bigger losses in the first half of 2000/01 than for the whole of the previous 12-month period. The strength of sterling, tighter competition and overcapacity are all to blame.

The British plant at Swindon is running at 50% capacity, one of the reasons Honda recently put on ice plans to build a new super-mini in this country.

However, despite the bleak outlook - Honda is not expecting the European operations to break even until 2003 - retrenchment is not on the cards. Honda is still committed to spending a further £450m between 1999 and 2001 on a second assembly plant and is recruiting 500 staff for this purpose.

It is also aiming to boost plant utilisation by building its new Civic and CR-V models at Swindon. A special three-door Civic will be exported back to Japan while CR-Vs will be shipped to the US where the exchange rate is more favourable to British manufacturers. Toyota, too, is stepping up British output. The recovery in the value of the euro against sterling might help the Wearside plant's case, too.

Sunderland's problem is not simply whether Britain is a good place for Japanese car makers to continue to invest. It has to compete with a French rival, too. Fingers crossed.

Euro rescue

The mood music from the central bankers meeting in Basle yesterday was reassuring. Yes, the US economy was slowing, a degree of turbulence was to be expected but the course was still set for a soft landing. Last week's Fed interest rate cut was a timely touch on the controls. But then central bankers have to sound confident. Any hint that they are worried and the financial markets would take flight.

Not everyone is convinced. Analysts at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter have just announced the largest ever cut in their forecasts for the global economy, posited on bad news from the US.

By contrast they reckon Europe could weather the storm reasonably well with growth of 2.2% this year - double MSDW's prediction for the US. That in turn is expected to boost the euro's value against the dollar.

If MSDW rather than the central bankers have got the call right we could see a situation where it is euroland rather than the US which is dragging the global economy back from the brink of recession. That would certainly encourage supporters of Britain joining the single currency. Just a thought.

Euro rescue The mood music from the central bankers meeting in Basle yesterday was reassuring. Yes, the US economy was slowing, a degree of turbulence was to be expected but the course was still set for a soft landing. Last week's Fed interest rate cut was a timely touch on the controls. But then central bankers have to sound confident. Any hint that they are worried and the financial markets would take flight. Not everyone is convinced. Analysts at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter have just announced the largest ever cut in their forecasts for the global economy, posited on bad news from the US. By contrast they reckon Europe could weather the storm reasonably well with growth of 2.2% this year - double MSDW's prediction for the US. That in turn is expected to boost the euro's value against the dollar. If MSDW rather than the central bankers have got the call right we could see a situation where it is euroland rather than the US which is dragging the global economy back from the brink of recession. That would certainly encourage supporters of Britain joining the single currency. Just a thought.

fields.headline: Britain is upwardly mobile
fields.trailText: Two-thirds of the British population now own a mobile phone after nearly 6m were bought in the weeks running up to Christmas.
fields.body:
Two-thirds of the British population now own a mobile phone after nearly 6m were bought in the weeks running up to Christmas.

Yesterday BT Cellnet claimed that it had managed to fend off Orange to maintain its position as the second largest network in Britain when it reported sales of 1.5m handsets in the final quarter of 2000.

The record-breaking sales figure increased BT Cellnet's customer base to 10.2m, keeping the company narrowly ahead of Orange, which has 9.8m.

One2One also published its fourth quarter numbers yesterday, showing it had added 1.2m customers.

When added to Vodafone and Orange sales reported last week, these figures bring total sales for the final three months of last year to 5.68m, outstripping even the most optimistic forecasts.

About 40.1m mobile phones have been sold in Britain.

A note of caution came, however, from One2One's managing director, Harris Jones, who said that the industry was guilty of sacrificing good business sense for the sake of building up the number of phone users.

"Customer numbers are not the appropriate measure for the wealth and health of this industry," he said. "We are not trying to acquire those customers looking for the £19 handset offers of some of our rivals. That's an area we choose not to play in - our cheapest price was £39. The industry needs to act more financially responsibly, and handsets need to move more in line with the actual value of the product."

The One2One customer figures included 262,000 acquired by Virgin Mobile, the joint venture with Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Group which now has 675,000 customers.

fields.headline: Orange flotation gears up
fields.standfirst: Up to 15% of mobile phone group will go on market
fields.trailText: France Telecom yesterday remained steady in the face of volatile stock market conditions as it primed investors for a flotation up to 15% of the Orange mobile phone business.
fields.body:
France Telecom yesterday remained steady in the face of volatile stock market conditions as it primed investors for a flotation up to 15% of the Orange mobile phone business.

The flotation in Paris and London is likely to go ahead next month and will be a significant test of the market's sentiment toward telecom and hi-tech stocks. It will also be a test for the backlog of companies considering flotations.

The enlarged Orange, which includes the mobile phone assets of France Telecom, is expected to be valued at €75bn-80bn (£47bn-51bn), around half the original estimates of €150bn when markets were at their peak last year.

Michel Bon, France Telecom chairman, said: "Clearly the market is not what it what it was and sure prices are different but that is not really the point. We have built something that will be one of the greatest players in the mobile market in the world.

"If the price today is not the highest possible, it may be tomorrow and we will still own between 85% and 90%,".

Details of pricing and the exact number of shares on offer will be published later this month, the provisional date being January 22.

In addition, France Telecom is planning to issue a bond which will be exchangeable for Orange shares at an unspecified premium to the share offer price. The bond issue will increase the offer size by up to a third and was viewed as a safeguard for investors nervous about the equity markets.

Orange said the market would determine how much it could raise from the flotation.

The marketing campaign for retail and institutional investors began in Britain and Germany yesterday.

There will also be a media campaign in France and Italy beginning later this month, coinciding with publication of the pathfinder prospectus. Information on the share offer will be available from any Orange shop, HSBC branches and through an Orange hotline.

The combined business, which also includes Itineris in France, has a customer base of 30m across 19 countries. The intention is to roll the Orange brand out across the group. It will use its shares as currency for further acquisitions and hopes to expand across Asia and into north America.

Hans Snook, who is giving up the role of Orange chief executive to become a part-time consultant to the business, said: "This is the second time in our history that we have been on the runway to flotation but this time it is a very different business.

"At the end of 1995 we had 385,000 subscribers. We now have more than 10m and the UK is only a part of the business. Orange is a far bigger group with a far bigger opportunity."

It has been an extraordinary 18 months for Orange. The company was first bought by Mannesmann, the German engineering and telecoms group. That sparked a successful hostile bid for Mannesmann by Vodafone, leading to the £26bn sale of Orange to France Telecom in May last year.

France Telecom is expected to use proceeds from the sale to buy back shares issued to Vodafone during the transaction.

fields.headline: Donna Karan snub for LVMH
fields.trailText: US designer clothing manufacturer Donna Karan International yesterday snubbed the French luxury group LVMH saying it was considering a number of options including a merger with another company and remaining independent.
fields.body:
US designer clothing manufacturer Donna Karan International yesterday snubbed the French luxury group LVMH saying it was considering a number of options including a merger with another company and remaining independent.

Donna Karan, of New York, which was founded in 1984 by the designer who gave her name to the company, received a takeover bid last year from the Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton group.

In December LVMH said it would pay designer Donna Karan and her husband Stephan Weiss $450m for Gabrielle Studio, the organisation administering the Donna Karan International trademarks, and offered another $195m to buy the New York fashion house itself. The couple agreed to exchange shares in Donna Karan Inter national for shares in the combined company.

LVMH then offered to pay $8.50 in cash per share for the fashion house's outstanding shares. Since then the stock has traded above $8.50 per share in the hope that the company would eventually be sold at a higher price.

The company, which last month retained Merrill Lynch as its financial adviser, said that its board would evaluate LVMH's proposal as well as any viable proposal for a merger with another company or remaining independent.

fields.headline: Steel strike moves closer
fields.trailText: Britain's main steel union, the ISTC, is to press ahead with ballots for strike action over compulsory redundancies at two of the country's biggest plants, Scunthorpe and Tees-side, despite making "real progress" in talks with Corus executives yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's main steel union, the ISTC, is to press ahead with ballots for strike action over compulsory redundancies at two of the country's biggest plants, Scunthorpe and Tees-side, despite making "real progress" in talks with Corus executives yesterday.

Corus, formed from the merger of British Steel and Dutch group Hoogovens, insisted that 95% of the 4,700 planned redundancies announced last year had already been agreed on a voluntary basis and said it would reconsider compulsory job losses.

But the group, which might have lost up to £500m on its British carbon steel operations last year, is due to announce by the end of this month a further round of restructuring, including possible closure of its Llanwern plant in south Wales and thousands more job losses.

The UK Steel Association highlighted the group's problems by reporting that British steel output reached a 14-year low last year, with mainland European producers taking advantage of the weak euro to boost their British market share to 41%.

Britain, which produced just 15m tonnes of steel, down 7% - implying a 1m tonne fall in Corus' British output to 13.5m tonnes - is now Europe's fifth largest producer. It was overtaken by Spain in 2000 for the first time.

Mick Leahy, ISTC leader, said his union would hold a ballot on strike action at Scunthorpe on January 13 while plans for the mass meeting and ballot would be held on Tees-side later today.

ISTC officials said that, while Corus insisted no compulsory redundancies were intended, the group was pushing through enforced redeployment of staff, which amounted to the same thing.

Allan Johnston, Corus executive director, said he was confident the issue could be resolved soon.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Man Utd halves brand staff
fields.body:
Man Utd halves brand staff

Manchester United is to halve the number of people working in its merchandising operation. A total of 48 jobs will be lost over the next 12 months, leaving 50 people employed by the operation based at Old Trafford.

The division plans, designs, produces and promotes Manchester United branded goods for the club. It will switch to partnerships with firms around the world to develop and promote its merchandising rather than running a one-stop shop operation.

Revived hopes for EMI merger

The new chief executive of Bertelsmann's music arm, Rolf Schmidt-Holtz, lifted hopes for a merger with rival EMI Group yesterday, saying it should be possible to agree a deal by the end of January.

After taking the helm of Bertelsmann Music Group on Friday, Schmidt-Holtz told German daily Süddeutsche Zeitung in an interview yesterday that it made no sense to prolong talks with London-based music group EMI.

"It should be possible to reach the goal by the end of January and then to inform the competition authorities without delay," he told the newspaper.

Interbrew takes time out

Belgian beer group Interbrew said yesterday that it would be "a few weeks" before it makes a decision on Britain's refusal to approve its acquisition of Bass's brewing business.

In an unexpected ruling last week, the government said Interbrew's £2.3bn buy of Bass' beer division was against the public interest. Interbrew has not yet said whether it will appeal.

Rivals to pay BT for customers

Rival phone companies will have to pay BT more than £20,000 for the right to lure its customers, it was announced yesterday.

Communications watchdog Oftel also ruled that they would have to pay the telecom firm an additional £4.46 for every client that they successfully tempt away.

The ruling follows measures set up last month to allow rival phone firms to tap into BT's network of lines through new "carrier pre-selection" services.

Airbus delivers £220m saving

Airbus is set to deliver annual savings worth at least €350m (£222m) after yesterday's decision to turn the consortium into a stand-alone public company known as AIC by the end of next month.

BAE Systems, which holds a 20% stake in the company, expects an even greater return from earnings on sales of the wide-bodied A340-500/600 airliners under the deal with the 80%-shareholder, European Aeronautic Defence and Space Company.

The British group said it would retain a veto on the firm's budget, business plan and borrowings. It has already vetoed initial plans for a partial AIC float.

Goodyear to cut 560 jobs

Hundreds of jobs at a leading tyre firm are to be cut after workers rejected a package aimed at reducing redundancies.

Around 560 workers at the Goodyear factory in Wolverhampton will lose their jobs next week under a cost-cutting and productivity plan.

webTitle: Resources:  Key stage 3, the future of shopping

fields.headline: Will the internet kill the high street?
fields.trailText: Resources: Key stage 3, the future of shopping
fields.body:
We find out if Christmas 2000 was a successful one for shops. Figures are due out showing how much people spent during December, which is the busiest time of the year for shopping. The signs were not good. Sales in November were weak - bad weather and the chaos on the trains were blamed for putting people off travelling into city and town centres to buy their presents.

Times are hard for the shops on Britain's 1,200 high streets. Over the last 15 years they have lost a large amount of their business to out-of-town supermarkets and shopping centres. They also face the growing threat posed by the internet.

Three in 10 households are now linked to the web and before Christmas some people were predicting that internet shopping would hit high street retailers very hard. However, not as many people shopped on the internet as expected, and some online retailers suffered. Only last week, the online toy store, eToys Inc closed down its British business in an effort to stay afloat in the US.

So, the internet has a long way to go if it is to become the main way for people to buy things. For most of us, it is still important to be able to go to a shop to see, feel, and bounce on the things we want. But this is not so true of goods such as books or CDs and online sales of these are threatening smaller book and music shops.

We are also starting to order more of our "necessity goods" (such as food) through our computers, as the big supermarkets go online. Certain services, such as banks and travel agents, are easily available online, so these businesses are starting to vanish from our high streets.

This is not the first time in our history that shopping patterns have changed dramatically. Until quite recently, most people lived in small villages, and grew and cooked the things they needed for themselves. Visits to shops were rare. Then came rapid industrialisation in the late 18th century. People flocked to towns and cities for jobs in the new factories. Local shops were now a necessity. How else could people work long hours and still get the food they needed? As there was more money around and more to buy, bigger stores started to appear.

Then came cars. Suddenly, it was possible to travel further to shop. This and the fact that many people wanted to leave dirty, crowded city centres to live in suburbs meant we were ready for American shopping styles - supermarkets first, and then out-of-town shopping centres. These places may seem common today, but they are both recent arrivals. The first supermarkets actually had to employ actors to teach customers how to use them. However, these new trends were not so good for the city centres or for their shops, which became increasingly run-down.

But towns and cities are still the places where 80% of us live, so it is important that our high streets remain lively. Their focus will have to change. Banks may vanish to be replaced by cafes - places that are as lively at night as they are in the daytime. More shops will offer "retailainment" - becoming places to buy things and hang out with friends. Local high streets will also benefit if people start to work more from home.

But there will be losers, too. For the 8,750,000 people in the UK living on low incomes, internet shopping will remain out of reach. Also, there will be business casualties. Middle-of-the-road stores, including M&S, are already suffering. Last year, C&A pulled out of Britain, with the loss of 5,000 jobs. And if Christmas 2000 sales are down, other high street names will be in trouble. Chemists may be praying for a flu epidemic - sales of over-the-counter medicines always boost their profits at this time of year.

Did you know?

Christmas 2000 ... of the £40 billion spent in December, only 1% - that's £400 million - was spent on the internet.

Geography: Shopping - past, present and future is a year 8 scheme of work; (5a and b) Environmental change and sustainable development.

History: Britain 1750-1900.

Citizenship: topical/social issues.
