webTitle: On the web:  World War One

fields.headline: On the web:  World War One
fields.trailText: Sites for key stages 3 and 4
fields.body:
WWI Document Archive

Suitable for teachers/KS4 pupils

Most of the existing documents from the first world war are here - official papers, personal reminiscences etc. There are biographical sketches and nearly 2,000 photos, though many aren't printer-friendly.

Life in the trenches (1)

Suitable for KS3 / KS4 pupils

Topics are grouped under three main headings: life in the trenches, trench warfare and the trench system. Also has lesson plans, but would need differentiation at KS3. Useful for GCSE study, Medicine through time.

Life in the trenches (pt 2)

Suitable for KS4 pupils and teachers

A comprehensive, easy to use site. Loads of pictures, a user-friendly time line and a useful search engine.

Treaty of Versailles

Suitable for able KS3/4 pupils

Articles from the Manchester Guardian from 1919. Hosts an online event, in which students play the role of one of the Versailles negotiation teams. Click on each contemporary thinker to read their views. More useful as background to the second world war.

What the papers said

Suitable for KS3

A concise history, with useful links to contemporary Daily Mail reports.

WWI Slang

Suitable for teachers

Could be useful for teachers to enliven a writing task, eg a letter from the front.

WWI Poetry

Suitable for GCSE English students

A host of material relating to the poet Wilfred Owen, plus audio interviews with veterans and video clips.

Imperial War Museum

Suitable for KS3/4

This site contains useful worksheets for groups visiting the museum; not really suitable to stand alone.

What the papers said Suitable for KS3 A concise history, with useful links to contemporary Daily Mail reports. webTitle: Resource: Key stage 4,  Eminem - should he be censored?

fields.headline: Eminem - should he be censored?
fields.trailText: Resources: Key stage 4, free speech and music
fields.body:
Few Christmas hit singles can have lacked festive spirit more than Eminem's Stan - a song featuring a crazed fan, suicide and murder. But the song leapt straight to the top of the UK charts in December and, last week, the 26-year-old Detroit rapper was nominated for four prestigious Grammy awards, including one for album of the year. But Eminem is as controversial as he is successful, as critics argue that his songs, with their violent lyrics, should be banned.

In real life, too, there has been controversy, including insults to his mother in his songs - she is now suing him for $10m - and frequent fights with his wife, Kim. Then there are the arrests, including a recent charge of pistol-whipping someone - a crime carrying a possible nine-year jail sentence.

With a few exceptions, rap, which has its origins in dance music, rhyming and the ghettos of New York, has been the preserve of black performers. But Eminem's "trailer trash" roots have enabled him to become the voice both of America's white "have-nots" and of middle-class teenagers attracted to his songs by their disreputable attitudes and dark, dark humour.

Not everyone is laughing. Eminem's songs have attracted strong criticism from people appalled at their violent content directed at women and gay people. They point to the repeated references to women as "bitches and hos", especially in the extremely violent song Kim (about his wife). And critics remain unimpressed by the idea that songs such as Role Model are meant to be ironic:

"Follow me and do exactly what the song says:

"Smoke weed, take pills, drop outta school, kill people and drink."

This is not the first time that popular culture has sparked a moral panic. Everything from novels to horror comics has been accused of undermining values. In the 1950s Frank Sinatra was condemning "the most brutal, ugly, desperate, vicious form of expression it has been my misfortune to hear". His target? Elvis Presley. It was Presley's dancing that upset the authorities; TV appearances were filmed from the waist up so his pelvic thrusts could not be seen.

Often the upset caused in one era seems silly to the next. But does this mean that mass media products do not exert powerful influences? Once a song is out there, there is no knowing how people are going to understand it. In interviews, Eminem acknowledges the power he has "to push his fans' buttons", but he assumes that they will not take the songs too seriously. Stan suggests Eminem wants to put his more deluded fans straight about the importance they should place on his lyrics.

But does the possibility that a song could encourage violence prove the need for censorship? No, say defenders of free speech. If the authorities ban Eminem today, what's to stop them banning anything else they don't like tomorrow?

Those who bought Stan on CD can hear the screams of the girlfriend as the deranged Stan drives off the bridge. On the radio, these are censored - but should they be? After all, Romeo and Juliet starts with young men joking about "thrusting maids to the wall. Should Shakespeare's play be performed, let alone be taught in the classroom?

Did you know?

The following songs have been banned by the BBC or given restricted play:

Rolling Stones, Let's Spend The Night Together (1967)

Jane Birkin and Serge Gainsbourg, Je T'aime ... Moi non plus (1969)

Eminem's Stan is broadcast with swearing removed (2000)

Curriculum links

Citizenship: (Skills) Justify a view.

English: En1 (1a-g, 2a-f, 3a-b) A group discussion on Eminem, media influence or censorship. Should lyrics be "bleeped out" on Radio 1? Why is his swearing shocking?; En2 (1a-k) Students could analyse Stan as a piece of narrative and poetry. For a copy of the lyrics, see www.strictlyrap.co.uk/

Link to Robert Browning's My Last Mistress (Ferrera) or The Laboratory; (5a/5d) How meaning is conveyed in media texts, how audiences respond to media.

Media Studies: A unit of work on Eminem could cover many keys concepts - genre, audience, industry, narrative and media languages.

PSHE (3a) Effects of stereotyping and discrimination.

fields.headline: School report on...
fields.standfirst: Logiblocks, Key stages 1,2 and 3
fields.trailText: Logiblocks, Key stages 1,2 and 3
fields.body:
Logiblocks Education Kit

 www.logiblocks.com - £159.90 + VAT

Age 4-14

The manufacturers say: An electronic system that helps children understand the world of technology as they create their own inventions.

Jess Anderson, year 4 teacher from Christchurch School, London SW3, says: "The children were very keen to use it. The kit wasn't big enough to use with the whole class, so I used it with a mixed-ability group of seven eight-year-olds. The children did project 1 (making a flashing thing!) from the kids' booklet and managed to make the working model independently. They concentrated for the whole lesson (one hour) and stayed fully motivated until the end. In many respects the kit is excellent. Children would soon be able to design and make their own models - just the kind of thing that would appeal to them. However, nowhere was there a visual explanation of what each component was, and the circuits themselves are hidden inside the blocks.This didn't bother the kids, but undermines its usefulness as a teaching tool to some extent.

Curriculum links

ICTYear 1 Unit 1f: Understanding instructions and making things happen.
Year 3 Unit 3d: Exploring simulations and consequences.
Year 5 Unit 5e: Controlling devices.
DT Year 3 Unit 3c: Make a working model of a monster.
Year 5 Unit 5c: Moving toys.

webTitle: Recommended book: 1940s House and The Wolf Sisters

fields.headline: Recommended books
fields.standfirst: Key stage 2: 1940s House, by John Malam
fields.trailText: 1940s House, by John Malam and The Wolf Sisters, by Susan Price
fields.body:
1940s House, by John Malam

Channel 4 books, £4.99

Age 7-11 yrs

This activity book, partnering the Channel 4 series, is an informative resource for KS2 history study unit, Britain since 1930, covering the impact on people of the second world war. It records the experiences of Ben Hymer, 11, and younger brother Tom who, with their mother and grandparents, spend two months living in a 1940s house. Stories from Ben and Tom - who are the same age as the target audience - help to make the factual detail more relevant, and good use is made of cross-curricular activities. This is an excellent resource book, blending factual information with accessible learning, although differentiation would be needed for some tasks.

Amanda Roper

The Wolf Sisters, by Susan Price

Hodder Silver, £12.99 Age

13 yrs-plus

Price is a fine writer, winner of the Carnegie Medal for Ghost Drum and Guardian Children's Fiction Award for The Sterkarm Handshake. Despite these and other accolades, her books tend not to attract widespread attention and are therefore unfamiliar to most young people.

The Wolf Sisters occupies classic Price territory - set in quasi Saxon times in which settlements are constantly under threat, and communities, ruled by thanes, live, eat and drink together. The eponymous wolf sisters are fabulous creations, their seduction of the central protagonist, Kenelm, powerful and utterly convincing. The plot is dark and gutsy, definitely not for the faint-hearted.

Lindsey Fraser

webTitle: Key stage 1, the history of the Great Fire of London

fields.headline: Did these cakes set fire to London?
fields.trailText: Resources: Key stage 1, the history of the Great Fire of London
fields.body:
Did you know?

In 1666 a baker's shop in Pudding Lane in London caught fire. People think the fire started when the baker burned some small cakes he was making. The fire burned for several days. It is called the Great Fire because it destroyed 13,000 houses and 89 churches. It spread across most of London but only 20 people were killed. Afterwards London was rebuilt with safer materials.

 This is a recipe for making small cakes like the cakes which people think caused the Great Fire of London. The recipe comes from a book written more than 300 years ago by Sir Kenelme Digby. It was printed in 1669, three years after the Great Fire. Sir Kenelme's father was killed for his part in the Gunpowder Plot. Sir Kenelme was the first cook to say that bacon and eggs would be nice for breakfast.

What is in it?

1 pound of self-raising flour

Half a pound of caster sugar

1 pound of currants

Half a pound of butter

3 tablespoons of milk

3 egg yolks

A pinch of nutmeg

3 tablespoons of Sack

Icing sugar to sprinkle on top

1 kilogram = 2 pounds (approx)

How they made the cakes in 1666

This is what Sir Kenelme wrote in his book, which is called "The Closet of Sir Kenelme Digby Opened".

"Take one pound of very fine flower, and put to it half a pound of sugar. Add one pound of currants well washed. When your flower is well mixed with the sugar and currants, you must put in it a half a pound of melted butter, three spoonfuls of milk, with the yolks of three new-laid eggs beat with it, some nutmeg; and if you please, three spoonfuls of Sack.

"When you have mixed your paste well, you must put it in a dish by the fire, till it be warm.

"Then make them up in little cakes, and prick them full of holes. Bake them in a quick oven unclosed. Afterwards sprinkle them with sugar.

"The Cakes should be about the bigness of a hand-breadth and thin; of the cise of the Sugar Cakes sold at Barnet."

Could we make the cakes today?

We made them and it was great to find out what cakes tasted like 300 years ago. But first, you have to work out what some of the old words mean.

Here is a dictionary to help you understand the recipe.

Flower is an old way to spell flour, dryed means dried, and cise means size. Bigness is an old word for size. Sack is an old word for dry Spanish wine (you can just leave this out). Quick is an old word for hot.

Sir Kenelme made the cakes in a hot oven, "unclosed". If you wanted to cook the cakes today it would be safer to put them in the oven for 15 minutes at 200C - with the door shut!

Prick the cakes with a fork, and spread them out on the baking tray because they rise when they cook.

You may want to find out more about the fire from The Diary of Samuel Pepys, who was there when London was burning.

Curriculum links

Primary History Unit 5, Year 2: How do we know about the Great Fire of London?

Objectives met by this resource

 It links an event beyond living memory with a person (Sir Kenelme).

 It develops a sense of chronology with references to the earlier Gunpowder Plot, the Great Fire, and the publication of the book.

 Children consider why the Great Fire happened.

Lesson ideas

For discussion: did the cakes cause the fire; does baking in 1666 sound riskier than today? Write a baker's diary (less confident writers could describe making the cakes). Create a portrait of Sir Kenelme to hang on a time line. For numeracy, convert the recipe into kilograms and halve the amounts to make it manageable. Brave teachers could make the cakes!

webTitle: Key stage 2, the study of geology

fields.headline: Travelling the sand to dig rocks for oil
fields.trailText: Resources: Key stage 2, the study of geology
fields.body:
Geology is the study of how the world was formed. Just as there are many different types of rock, there are many different types of geologist. Some study sedimentary rocks. These are rocks laid down by water, wind, snow and ice. Inside these rocks, geologists find coal, gas, oil, gold, even diamonds. Sedimentology is the study of sedimentary rocks. It is used a lot in the oil business. We followed the geologist Dougal Crockett, aged 27, as he flew to the desert to find oil.

Crockett's diary

9am Monday Oil Town The plane touches down on a single-track airstrip, somewhere in Algeria. We have arrived at the oil town. It is full of workmen, but really it is the middle of nowhere. All around are sand dunes. I have a meal of curried goat. It tastes like chicken!

10am Off to the rig I board a plane that seats only six people, and we take off over the desert. We are cruising at 300 metres and all below us is desert. I see some Bedouin with their camels. We touch down on a bumpy airstrip near the rig, and the plane is tied to the ground so that it won't blow away!

1pm Home Sweet Home I drop my bags off in a Portakabin - my home for the next three months. The heat of the desert hits me. In the summer the temperature can rise to 56C.

6pm Off to work Everyone on the rig works a 12-hour shift (all day or all night) so that the rig can drill 24 hours a day. I put on my overalls, hard hat and boots, and head off to the rig.

To look for oil you drill down through the Earth to where it lies. I test rock samples and tell the engineers what kind of rock they are drilling into. I have to draw a geological "map" of the hole so that we know where to find the oil.

Mud is poured down the inside of the drill to keep it cool. This brings broken fragments of rock up to the surface. These rocks have been lying there for over 100 million years. I am the first person to handle them.

Sifting through the samples is like being Sherlock Holmes, because any sample may contain different parts of stone, rock, shale, or even fossils. Each rock type has its own characteristics that can be described by studying them under the microscope - a geologist's most useful tool.

8pm Time Travel I have worked for 12 hours, but I feel like I have travelled back in time over millions of years. The rocks I am studying are a history of the world laid down over time. A layer of rock that took hundreds of thousands of years to form is drilled through in minutes.

Three months later Eureka! We arrive at the depth where we should find oil. The tension on the rig starts to mount. All eyes are on me as I look for evidence of cap rock, the type of rock under which oil is trapped. At the first sign of cap rock the drill slows down, so that we can stop before we break into the reservoir of oil. I shine ultra-violet light on the last bit of rock that we cut through - any oil will glow white or yellow. The better the grade of oil the brighter it glows. It glows brightly! We've found oil. I can go to bed.

Did you know?

Oil comes from the soft fatty parts of dead marine plankton and sea creatures. 90% of all organic stuff gets regenerated back into the food chain. A tiny percentage becomes oil.

Curriculum links

Primary Science Unit 3d, Year 3: rocks and soils.

Objectives met by this resource

 Children learn that rocks are used for a variety of purposes.

 They learn that rocks can be grouped according to observable characteristics, and that rocks are chosen for particular purposes because of their characteristics.

 They also learn that beneath all surfaces there is rock.

Lesson ideas

Discuss the diary: why does the geologist say he is "like Sherlock Holmes"? Children could find Algeria on a map and work on a definition of "geologist". Those confident with research methods could investigate the Bedouin. In a link to literacy they could write their own diary: what happens when the geologist does not find oil?

Each rock type has its own characteristics that can be described by studying them under the microscope - a geologist's most useful tool. 8pm Time Travel I have worked for 12 hours, but I feel like I have travelled back in time over millions of years. The rocks I am studying are a history of the world laid down over time. A layer of rock that took hundreds of thousands of years to form is drilled through in minutes. Three months later Eureka! We arrive at the depth where we should find oil. The tension on the rig starts to mount. All eyes are on me as I look for evidence of cap rock, the type of rock under which oil is trapped. At the first sign of cap rock the drill slows down, so that we can stop before we break into the reservoir of oil. I shine ultra-violet light on the last bit of rock that we cut through - any oil will glow white or yellow. The better the grade of oil the brighter it glows. It glows brightly! We've found oil. I can go to bed. Did you know? Oil comes from the soft fatty parts of dead marine plankton and sea creatures. 90% of all organic stuff gets regenerated back into the food chain. A tiny percentage becomes oil. Curriculum links Primary Science Unit 3d, Year 3: rocks and soils. Objectives met by this resource  Children learn that rocks are used for a variety of purposes.  They learn that rocks can be grouped according to observable characteristics, and that rocks are chosen for particular purposes because of their characteristics.  They also learn that beneath all surfaces there is rock. Lesson ideas Discuss the diary: why does the geologist say he is "like Sherlock Holmes"? Children could find Algeria on a map and work on a definition of "geologist". Those confident with research methods could investigate the Bedouin. In a link to literacy they could write their own diary: what happens when the geologist does not find oil?

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Ex-mayor cleared
fields.body:
Ex-mayor cleared

A former Labour mayor of Doncaster, William Gillies, was cleared at Hull crown court yesterday of seven claims of fiddled expenses by claiming for non-existent first class train journeys and conference hotel stays.

Women top college entries

Fifty-five per cent of university students enrolling last October were women, according to this year's admission figures. They are outperforming males throughout the education system.

£500,000 for safety centre

The Suzy Lamplugh Trust received £500,000 from the government yesterday to set up an international personal safety centre at King's Cross, central London.

Imagine boosts C4 figures

The four-hour Channel 4 show The 100 Greatest Number One Singles overtook BBC1 and ITV during its last 45 minutes on Saturday night. Viewing figures peaked with 5.9m watching the number one, Imagine by John Lennon.

'Disgrace' of cold deaths

Help the Aged yesterday called for urgent action to halt the "national disgrace" of tens of thousands of old people dying in winter because they cannot afford to keep their homes warm.

£1m books theft case

A man accused of stealing antique books and pamphlets worth an estimated £1m appeared in court yesterday. William Jacques, 31, of Kensington, west London, pleaded not guilty at Middlesex Guildhall crown court to 23 counts of theft from academic institutions.

Mistake in Kosovo

Four British soldiers in Kosovo were accidentally dropped into the no man's land separating Serb forces from peacekeepers, Nato said yesterday.

Air traveller breaks leg

Aer Lingus is investigating an incident in which a woman passenger sustained a broken leg during turbulence caused by another aircraft.

Petrol tanker stolen

Police were yesterday hunting thieves who stole a fuel tanker carrying 36,000 litres of petrol from a terminal in Grays, Essex, at the weekend.

Clear skies for eclipse

Forecasters say skies over most of the UK could be crystal clear for today's lunar eclipse.

webTitle: Scientists seek traces of marriage made in heavens

fields.headline: Scientists seek traces of marriage made in heavens
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Researchers believe they have found evidence of consumption on an astronomical scale - the "fossil" remnants of a galaxy that was gobbled up by the one which contains our solar system.
fields.body:
Researchers believe they have found evidence of consumption on an astronomical scale - the "fossil" remnants of a galaxy that was gobbled up by the one which contains our solar system.

The earth orbits one of the 100bn stars in the Milky Way galaxy, which is itself only one of 100bn galaxies in the visible universe. The mystery is how galaxies form in the first place.

"The Milky Way is a fairly large galaxy. We believe it was formed by the merger of several smaller galaxies," Rosemary Wyse of Johns Hopkins University told the American Astronomical Society in San Francisco yesterday. "What is not clear is what merged when. This is very significant in trying to constrain theories about the origins of the galaxy."

Prof Wyse and colleagues from Britain's Institute of As tronomy in Cambridge, and from the Siding Spring observatory in Australia, are studying 10,000 stars like the sun in the outer regions of the galaxy.

So far they have looked at 1,500 stars and believe they can detect the remains of our galaxy's last "meal".

The Milky Way is a disc of gas and stars moving together in more or less circular orbits around a galactic centre. There is also a component called the "thick disc", which is is puffed up to a greater depth than the rest of the galaxy.

This puffed-up effect was most likely caused by the entry of a massive satellite galaxy into the Milky Way. This colossal merger could have occurred 10bn years ago, when the universe was only a third of its present age.

Prof Wyse and her colleagues believe this marriage made in the heavens must have left behind tell-tale evidence of marital strife.

"Just as tidal interactions between the moon and the earth cause distortions, there are going to be tidal interactions as a satellite galaxy comes into the Milky Way. Those can be severe enough to tear mass off the outer parts of the satellite galaxy," Prof Wyse said. "Those stars should be left on an orbit similar to the orbit of the satellite galaxy at that time."

 Astronomers have found evidence of massive starbursts which have blown huge holes in distant galaxies. These "Swiss cheese" galaxies contain spherical regions 10 million billion miles across, where exploding stars have blown a hole in the gaseous cloud between the stars.

"The energy released by the dying stars in those moments is equivalent to the output of 10,000 suns over their entire 10bn year lifetimes," Jane Charlton of Pennsylvania State University told the San Francisco meeting yesterday.

webTitle: Police investigate claims that ex-SS men are living in Britain

fields.headline: Police investigate claims that ex-SS men are living in Britain
fields.trailText: The Metropolitan police yesterday confirmed it was investigating allegations that members of a Ukrainian SS division responsible for a string of atrocities during the second world war are living in Britain.
fields.body:
The Metropolitan police yesterday confirmed it was investigating allegations that members of a Ukrainian SS division responsible for a string of atrocities during the second world war are living in Britain.

According to an ITV documentary as many as 8,000 members of the notorious Galizien Waffen SS division were allowed into Britain in 1947 without having their wartime activities properly investigated.

Many of the men subsequently emigrated to Canada and Australia, but the programme makers estimate that as many as 1,500 are alive and well in Britain today.

Yesterday a spokesman for the Met confirmed the force was looking into the matter, but refused to specify if it was investigating any particular individuals.

"We can confirm that the Metropolitan police has received a number of allegations which were recently passed to us by the Home Office," the spokesman said.

The spokesman said the matter had been passed to the anti-terrorist squad, which has taken over the role of the now disbanded war crimes unit.

Lord Janner, of the all-party parliamentary war crimes group, said the Home Office should set up an immediate inquiry into how members of the unit were allowed into Britain in the first place.

"If there is sufficient evidence against individuals, it should be put before a jury so that these men can receive the justice that they denied to their victims."

The programme, broadcast on Sunday, revealed how members of the Nightingale battalion, a Ukrainian police unit which later joined the SS Galizien division, took part in the mass murder of thousands of Jews in Lvov in June 1941.

Galizien troops also murdered more than 800 Polish civilians in the village of Huta Pieniacka in February 1944, and killed 44 unarmed civilians, including children, in the village of Chlaniov in August of the same year.

Members of the Ukrainian Self Defence Legion, another unit which later merged with the division, suppressed the Warsaw uprising in autumn 1944. Some of the men now living in the UK helped capture downed British and American airmen, who were then handed over to the Gestapo, the programme, made by Yorkshire Television, claimed.

webTitle: Mandelson warns SDLP over Ulster police deal

fields.headline: Mandelson warns SDLP over Ulster police deal
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, piled pressure on the SDLP yesterday, warning that the entire peace process could be torpedoed if the party refused to back government plans for police reform.
fields.body:
The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, piled pressure on the SDLP yesterday, warning that the entire peace process could be torpedoed if the party refused to back government plans for police reform.

But the row over one of the most contentious issues currently causing political deadlock in the province looked set to continue, as the largest nationalist party said it still did not have enough confidence in the legislation to nominate representatives to the new police board, scheduled to be set up at the end of January.

Mr Mandelson denied he was issuing an ultimatum but said it was his duty to advise parties when they were endangering the process by taking an absolutist position.

Sinn Fein is also dissatisfied with the new policing arrangements, but the SDLP denied a hint by Mr Mandelson that its stance might be influenced by the looming general election.

"It would be terrible at this stage for the sake of some relatively small issues, or for the sake of politics and the shadow of a coming election if we were to let this enormous prize (on policing) slip from our grasp," he said. "It would be a torpedo through the peace process and I don't think anyone would want to bear responsibility for that."

However, the SDLP policing spokesman, Alex Attwood, said there were still substantive matters on which his party wanted guarantees before it could take its seats on the board or recommend Roman Catholics join the service.

These include the neutrality of the new police emblem, the closure of Gough barracks in Armagh and the phasing out of the full time reserve.

"Much progress has been made but more progress is re quired," said Mr Attwood, who is to meet the RUC chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, and the security minister, Adam Ingram, this week.

He warned that trying to impose a deadline was unhelpful and refused to accept Mr Mandelson's analysis that further delays could sabotage the whole political process.

The government is due to restart separate negotiations with Sinn Fein and the Ulster Unionists in the next few days in an attempt to avert the growing crisis over paramilitary decommissioning and demilitarisation. Talks with Sinn Fein broke off acrimoniously before Christmas with republicans blaming Tony Blair for the impasse.

Mr Mandelson must now tread a fine line, as any further compromise to make policing arrangements more palatable to nationalists could increase pressure from hardliners on the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, to pull out of the Stormont government.

Belfast high court is expected to rule soon on the Sinn Fein challenge to Mr Trimble's ban on its ministers, Martin McGuinness and Bairbre de Bruin, attending cross-border meetings due to the IRA's failure to engage seriously with General John de Chastelain's disarmament body.

Ulster Unionist party officers will meet in Belfast on Friday to discuss the situation and a meeting of the 100-strong policy-making executive or the full 860-strong ruling council will almost certainly be convened in the next few weeks and asked to vote on withdrawal from Stormont.

Mr Trimble's problems are multiplied by the coming election, which is set to further expose the split within his party between Good Friday agreement supporters and opponents, which Ian Paisley's anti-agreement Democratic Unionists intend to exploit to the full.

fields.headline: Schröder backs his 'violent' foreign minister
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gerhard Schröder went to the aid of his hard-pressed foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, yesterday as he encountered increasing difficulties about his violent and radical past.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gerhard Schröder went to the aid of his hard-pressed foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, yesterday as he encountered increasing difficulties about his violent and radical past.

The woman who has made a string of accusations against Mr Fischer, Bettina Röhl, announced that she was pressing for him to be investigated on suspicion of attempted murder.

Ms Röhl, the daughter of the late Ulrike Meinhof, co-leader of the terrorist Baader-Meinhof gang, claimed that Mr Fischer was the key figure behind the use of molotov cocktails in a 1976 demonstration in which a policeman almost died.

Speaking in Hanover, Mr Schröder said his most popular minister had never concealed what he had done in his youth. And he had shown in government that he was a "really good representative" of Germany.

The chancellor offered his backing just over a week before Mr Fischer is due to testify in Frankfurt at the trial of a friend from his days on the far left. Hans-Joachim Klein is charged with taking part in the 1975 raid on an Opec oil ministers' conference in which three people were killed.

He has denied having any sympathy for terrorism and he said he was shocked to discover his friend had played a part in the raid. This is why the latest allegation against him is potentially explosive.

Ms Röhl claims that, a year after the Opec raid, Mr Fischer was still a central figure in organising potentially lethal activities.

A police officer nearly died of his injuries after being set alight by a molotov cocktail during the 1976 demonstration which was called to protest at the death of Ms Röhl's mother.

In an open letter to President Johannes Rau, Ms Röhl said she had written to the public prosecutor in Frankfurt urging him to bring attempted murder charges against Mr Fischer.

"On the basis of all the known facts, I have drawn the conclusion that Josef Martin Fischer was par excellence the leading figure in the violent group [at the centre of the demonstration] and also effectively helped to set up violent groups acting in parallel," she said.

Mr Fischer, who was arrested but released after the clash, has denied throwing fire bombs or proposing their use.

Ms Röhl, who is soon to publish a book on the radical left in the 1970s, claims that he argued for the use of molotov cocktails at a meeting the day before the demonstration.

Horst Breunig, one of the three policemen on the receiving end of the fire attack, said: "As far as I am concerned it was a deadly attack on our lives, and for that there is no statute of limitations."

Mr Fischer's past was brought vividly to life last week with the publication of photographs, discovered by Ms Röhl, showing him beating a fallen policeman during a 1973 protest. Mr Fischer was once a leader of the Spontis, a radical group which clashed repeatedly with the police.

The Greens are the junior coalition partners of Mr Schröder's Social Democrats and Mr Fischer has played an important role in government.

webTitle: Ivory Coast rounds up coup suspects

fields.headline: Ivory Coast rounds up coup suspects
fields.trailText: Ivory Coast's new government accuses supporters of the former prime minister Alassane Ouattara, who was barred from standing in last year's presidential election, of attempting the failed military coup on Sunday night.
fields.body:
Ivory Coast's new government accuses supporters of the former prime minister Alassane Ouattara, who was barred from standing in last year's presidential election, of attempting the failed military coup on Sunday night.

Dissident soldiers seized the state television and radio stations in the main city, Abidjan, and broadcast a message saying: "Dear compatriots, dear Ivorians. The country has undergone another change."

At least six people were killed in the fighting as they were driven from the broadcasting stations by loyal forces. The government said two policemen also died.

Explosions and shots were heard in other parts of Abidjan, some near the residence of President Laurent Gbagbo, who was away visiting his home village.

Yesterday ministers went to the same radio station to say the situation was "totally under control".

The defence minister, Moise Lida Kouassi, implicitly blamed supporters of Mr Ouattara, who was favoured to win last October's election until he was barred from standing on the disputed grounds that he was born outside Ivory Coast.

Loyal troops arrested at least 40 people and marched them to jail.

The defence minister said they had "already begun to confess".

webTitle: Defector hopes Labour will find him a seat

fields.headline: Defector hopes Labour will find him a seat
fields.standfirst: Former Tory Shaun Woodward will not contest his Witney constituency at the next election. But he wants to stay in the Commons
fields.trailText: Former Tory Shaun Woodward will not contest his Witney constituency at the next election. But he wants to stay in the Commons.
fields.body:
Tory-turned-Labour MP Shaun Woodward is searching for a new Westminster constituency after party officials agreed to exempt him from Labour's "chicken run" ban.

The former Conservative frontbench spokesman, successfully wooed by Tony Blair in December 1999, disclosed in an interview with the Guardian that he hopes to stand again at the election despite announcing he will step down in Witney, Oxfordshire.

Mr Woodward, earmarked for a prominent role in the party's campaign to persuade middle Britain and Tory converts in 1997 to stick with Mr Blair, said he wants to "play a role" in the government's expected second term. "Although I would dearly love to play that role in Westminster, that realistically might not happen. But my ambition for the Labour party is greater than my ambition for myself," said Mr Woodward.

His comments will fuel speculation that Downing Street is planning to parachute the 42-year-old recruit into a safe Labour seat at the start of a short election campaign, creating a vacancy by sending a sitting MP to the House of Lords. Millbank is believed to have identified as many as 25 constituencies where reselected stalwarts could be tempted to retire.

Another option for Mr Blair would be to send Mr Woodward to the Lords and make him a minister while the MP, who will make a final decision next month, is considering his own options, including the possibility of a post with an international body such as the United Nations or charity like the Red Cross.

But Mr Woodward, who gave up a Tory seat-for-life and party post as well as political friendships to join Labour, made it clear he would prefer to stay in the Commons. "I received no promises when I joined the Labour party," he said. "Clearly it will depend on a constituency wanting me. These things are as much in the hands of the gods as they have ever been in my life."

The MP announced shortly before Christmas he would not run again in Witney, a seat where his 7,028 majority for the Tories in 1997 puts it out of Labour's reach.

Labour has banned MPs in marginal seats following what the party four years ago dubbed the "chicken run" when Tories abandoned marginal constituencies for safer berths but Mr Woodward is considered a special case after he switched parties.

Downing Street officials have also argued that Labour has a "debt of hounour" to fulfil and a seat must be found to have any chance of persuading other Tories to defect if William Hague loses heavily and the Conservatives lurch further to the right.

Mr Woodward's defection 13 months ago was a spectacular coup for Labour and a bitter blow for William Hague, with Tories launching a personal smear campaign, including the "outing" of Lesley, born his brother and now his sister after a sex change who suffered the full tabloid treatment.

He is now one of Labour's most active backbenchers, visiting constituencies as far apart as Falmouth and Dover, Preston and Newcastle to offer his inside knowledge to highlight the dangers posed by the Conservatives.

Mr Woodward, who joined the Tories in 1989, crossed the floor after being attracted by Mr Blair's centrist brand of New Labour and repelled by Mr Hague's shift to the right, finally jumping over the Tory leader's backing of the anti-gay section 28.

The Tories will make sure every Labour constituency party is aware that he married into the incredibly wealthy Sainsbury family and lives on a huge estate.

At meetings, Mr Woodward, a trustee of the Childline charity after working for founder Esther Rantzen on That's Life, points out his father worked in a department store and his mother was a barmaid before adding, in a Kinnockite touch: "If you run the tapes back, I'm the first kid in my family to go to university." Insisting if he was as ambitious as Tories make out he would never have given up a safe seat, he acknowledges that some colleagues question his commitment to the people's party. The suspicions were illustrated soon after his defection when, with wife Camilla, he went into Westminster's clubby Strangers' Bar and asked a group of Labour MPs: "Would you chaps like a drink?" One present recalled: "It was as if he'd popped downstairs to see the staff", yet another MP insisted: "It wasn't like that at all. He was genuinely trying to be friendly."

But Peter Kilfoyle, a Labour MP in Liverpool who quit as a minister over the government's direction, said: "In my view we, as members of the Labour party, are duty bound to make Shaun Woodward welcome."

A Tory defector in the last parliament, Alan Howarth, is a minister in the government after winning Newport East for Labour. Peter Temple-Morris, who has also swapped the Tories for Labour since 1997, is to stand down in Leominster.

Mr Woodward said: "The response of the Labour party has been infinitely kind, more generous than I could have hoped for. Conversely, the response from the Tories was far worse than I could have imagined.

Laugh of the day
Refusal of the day
Policy of the day
Today
fields.body:
Laugh of the day

Labour MP for Pendle Gordon Prentice expressed astonishment that Lancashire police was paying £450,000 on private security for its headquarters. To laughter he asked: "Where is this contracting out culture leading us? Are we going to get Group 4, for example, guarding the soldiers at Preston barracks?"

Refusal of the day

Home secretary Jack Straw gave a categoric no to calls for a judicial review into the conduct of the Metropolitan police's complaints investigation service. He was responding to Labour's Andrew Mackinlay (Thurrock) who said he had "very considerable" evidence of alleged corruption in the force's directorate of professional standards, formerly the complaints investigation branch.

Policy of the day

The Tories pledged to overhaul civil legal aid if they won the election. Shadow attorney general Edward Garnier promised a Conservative government would scrap means testing for legal aid in civil cases.

Today

Commons: Health questions. Armed forces bill, second reading. Debate on flooding at Selby. Westminster Hall: Backbench debates include government youth policy, British Indian Ocean territories, and student funding. Lords: Not sitting.

fields.headline: Man denies sex killings
fields.trailText: A father of four yesterday denied being the accomplice of a sex killer responsible for a series of rapes and three murders over four years.
fields.body:
A father of four yesterday denied being the accomplice of a sex killer responsible for a series of rapes and three murders over four years.

David Mulcahy, who is accused of forging a "unique and wicked bond" with John Duffy, insisted he had never been present when Duffy struck.

Duffy was jailed for life in 1988 after being convicted of a string of rapes and murders. He has said he expected to spend the rest of his life in jail and, wanting to clear his conscience, named Mulcahy as his partner.

George Carter-Stephenson QC, defending Mulcahy, told the Old Bailey yesterday that Duffy was a "manipulator and a liar". He also claimed the length of time it had taken to bring Mulcahy to trial had put the defence at a disadvantage. "It's often said that justice delayed is justice denied. The longer it takes for a matter to be dealt with, the more evidence is lost.

"In this case, exhibits have been destroyed which would have been of forensic or scientific significance."

Mulcahy, 41, told the court Duffy became a "good friend" after they met on their first day at Haverstock secondary school, north London. But they drifted apart later after Mulcahy met his wife, Sandra, and following a pub fracas.

The prosecution alleges Mulcahy and Duffy would go on "hunting" expeditions looking for women to attack while psyching themselves up by listening to Michael Jackson's Thriller album.

It is alleged they fed off each other's excitement, becoming more aggressive with each attack. The prosecution claims Mulcahy's "hunger for excitement" needed to be fed with ever increasing acts of cruelty.

But Mr Carter-Stephenson said there was no evidence that two men were present during the murders. He claimed there was no credible evidence to confirm Mulcahy was there at the time of the rapes.

Mulcahy, from Chalk Farm, north London, denies three murders in 1985 and 1986, seven rapes, and five offences of conspiracy to rape with Duffy.

The trial continues today.

webTitle: Bush confronts a bonfire of economic vanities

fields.headline: Bush confronts a bonfire of economic vanities
fields.standfirst: Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: The removal trucks queued up outside the Governor's House in Austin, Texas, yesterday to collect the Bush family possessions and transport them to the White House in Washington in time for the presidential handover next week.
fields.body:
The removal trucks queued up outside the Governor's House in Austin, Texas, yesterday to collect the Bush family possessions and transport them to the White House in Washington in time for the presidential handover next week.

But George W Bush's prized baseball collection and his wardrobe of snakeskin boots are not the only things that will now be seen in a different setting. The new president's most cherished fiscal and budgetary policies are also being reinvented too, in the wake of a transformation in America's economic mood.

Five months ago Mr Bush told the Republican national convention in Philadelphia that "the promise of prosperity" had never been so vivid for average Americans. "America has a strong economy and a surplus," he announced, and it was time for the federal government to share it with the voters in the form of a massive tax cut.

Mr Bush is still pressing for tax cuts, but his reasoning has changed sharply. With the American economy in slowdown, and with some economists even predicting recession, he has rediscovered Keynesianism and is pressing for the same tax cuts in order to reinvigorate demand and help stimulate growth.

The change in America's economic mood has been astonishingly rapid. Only a few short months ago economic activity was booming. Profits were high. The stock market was soaring. Inflation was low. New jobs were everywhere. The rich got unbelievably richer.

But now, as the economy begins to slow, "it's beginning to look like Paradise Lost", as yesterday's front page story in the Christian Science Monitor newspaper put it.

The macroeconomic warning signs include the falling stock market, but they go beyond it. GDP growth is down to 2.2% in the last quarter compared with almost 6% a year previously. Layoffs are beginning to dwarf new jobs. And these changes take place against a background of a high trade deficit, of Americans' traditionally low rate of savings and of the sharpest rise in income inequality since the 1920s.

But they also have to be seen against the background of the continuing strength of the US economy. Unemployment remains exceptionally low, as does inflation. Disposable income has risen steadily for more than eight years. Home sales have boomed and half of all Americans now hold shares in a stock market whose long-term upward trend far exceeds its recent short-term losses.

The headlines, though, tell of an increasingly sick economy. In the hi-tech "new economy" sector, companies are learning the hard lessons for the first time. A succession of dot.com businesses have closed and even the technology giants are lowering their forecasts.

In the so-called "old economy", car companies like Ford and Daimler-Chrysler are putting their plants into idling mode, hoping for an upturn in demand. The manufacturing sector as a whole lost 54,000 jobs in December and companies have already exceeded that figure in January. Retailers did badly over Christmas, and last week the Montgomery Ward department stores went into liquidation after 120 years as a high street business.

Economists are still struggling to interpret all the signs. All are agreed there is a slow down. But opinions differ as to whether recession is on the way, while only a handful of observers predict anything approaching a market crash.

"An honest but unhelpful answer is that nobody knows. A more detailed but equally unhelpful answer is that it's possible to make a case either way. But on the whole I'd vote for panic," says the Massachusetts Institute of Technology economics professor Paul Krugman in his weekly New York Times column.

webTitle: Met wants special courts for violence in home

fields.headline: Met wants special courts for violence in home
fields.trailText: Special courts to tackle domestic violence should be set up to encourage more victims to come forward, the Metropolitan police said last night.
fields.body:
Special courts to tackle domestic violence should be set up to encourage more victims to come forward, the Metropolitan police said last night.

Launching a drive against domestic violence, senior officers proposed a similar scheme to that in Cyprus, where dedicated courts deal with cases from assault to child custody and divorce. They believe this would encourage more women to come forward - those who would otherwise be deterred by multiple hearings in different courts.

Sheryl Gascoigne, the former wife of footballer Paul Gascoigne, and stars including actor Lynda Bellingham and journalist Kate Adie attended the launch at the Globe theatre in London. The scheme aims to make violent partners face up to their crimes by encouraging victims to come forward.

As well as a London-wide television and radio campaign, posters will be distributed around the capital's doctors' surgeries, libraries and hospitals encouraging victims to contact their local community safety unit for help.

The units, set up in every London borough in June 1999, provide services for victims of "hate crimes" such as racist, domestic and homophobic attacks.

Ms Gascoigne, who had a violent eight-year relationship with her former husband Paul, has been a long-standing campaigner with Refuge against violence in the home. Her suffering became public when the footballer broke two of her fingers and gave her a black eye.

Lynda Bellingham, who starred in the Oxo television commercials, and helped publicise the force's Enough is Enough domestic violence conference last year, said in October that she had been mentally and physically abused by her ex-husband Nunzio Peluso for years.

The deputy assistant commissioner, John Grieve, head of the Met's racial and violent crime task force, said: "One in four of all crimes dealt with by Metropolitan police officers is a domestic violence incident. This is proof of the scale of the problem." Police in Britain receive 1,300 calls relating to domestic violence every day.

A Scotland Yard survey in September revealed women accounted for 81% of calls relating to domestic violence, while 8% were said to be men attacked by a female partner.

Last night Detective Constable Kevin Shapland, a community safety unit coordinator, said police teams had been provided with 300 cameras to photograph evidence of abuse in the home, such as physical scars or damage to property.

The Met was also collaborating with the crown prosecution service and judiciary to see how it can be made easier for victims to give evidence in court. It is scrutinising legislation in Cyprus, which has one special court for domestic violence. Under Cypriot law, if an assault takes place in the presence of a child, the abuser can be charged with psychological assault on that child.

"The Cypriot method could be a good tool in this country to take the issue forward," said DC Shapland. Ms Gascoigne said she had never called the police about her husband's assaults because women were told not to speak out.

She said Gascoigne would attack her for inexplicable reasons such as laughing at another man's joke or leaves blowing through the front door. "I didn't know there was anyone out there suffering like me. I would like any woman out there who is suffering to have the confidence to pick up the telephone."

webTitle: Guard tried to sabotage nuclear reactor

fields.headline: Guard tried to sabotage nuclear reactor
fields.standfirst:
Security checks tightened after high-level alert
Special report: British nuclear industry
fields.trailText: Tough new security checks are to be imposed at nuclear power stations after a guard employed to protect a complex attempted to sabotage the site's computers.
fields.body:
Tough new security checks are to be imposed at nuclear power stations after a guard employed to protect a complex attempted to sabotage the site's computers.

The patrolman triggered a high-level security alert that led to a shutdown of the station's automatic access control system, locking doors electronically to effectively close it, as colleagues started searching for an intruder.

Leaked documents obtained by the Guardian show that the guard had never been vetted and had two undisclosed criminal convictions.

Internal Department of Trade and Industry memos marked "restricted" reveal that as a result all security staff, including existing employees, will from March be required to undergo security tests.

Written by Peter Hatton, head of security in the government's office for civil nuclear security, the documents refer to a security breach at an unnamed station which was the "deliberate action of a member of the site security force".

No details are divulged but the station is understood to be the Bradwell magnox reactor in Essex, run by state-owned BNFL and the nearest nuclear power generator to London.

The guard is believed to have hacked into Bradwell's computer system to alter sensitive information. "He got into one of the systems and wiped the records. The security people are still very touchy when we try to find out exactly what happened," said an industry employee.

BNFL said last night it was unable to provide further information but the incident, in June 1999, which was never disclosed nationally, was considered so serious that a working party was formed to review security.

Mr Hatton says in his memo: "The incident did highlight the danger of not conducting retrospective vetting particularly of those individuals such as members of the security police force who enjoy a freedom of movement over the whole of a site and have a high degree of trust placed in their integrity."

From March this year more than 500 guards, including hundreds of existing personnel, will be subjected to 10-yearly tests including security service, court and credit clearance, and taking up references.

New recruits have since April 1998 been required to undergo less stringent checks but employees in post before that date, including the Bradwell guard, were not covered. The guard's two criminal convictions would not necessarily have led to clearance being denied, records the DTI note.

Jack Dromey, who represents security staff as national secretary of the Transport & General Workers Union, said: "Employers have a duty not to put the public and fellow employees at risk by penny-pinching or through sloppy procedures."

Another union official said: "Lunatics, industrial spies or terrorists could have walked through the gates with a badge that almost anyone could get."

The new security tests will apply to British Energy civilian security staff at Dungeness B, Hartlepool, Hinkley B, Sizewell B, Hunterston, Torness and two Heysham power stations, plus BNFL magnox employees at Oldbury, Wylfa, Dungeness A, Sizewell A, Hinckley Point A, Berkeley and Bradwell.

A spokesman for British Energy said: "We understand the need for such arrangements and are happy to comply."

The department of trade and industry confirmed the new checks but played down the Bradwell incident, saying security was constantly under review.

"There has been an incident in 1999 which, although it did not cause a breach of security, caused a review of security and in the light of that review revised procedures are to be introduced," a spokesman said.

The bigger security companies, MPs and trade unionists have campaigned against "cowboy" guards for years.

The government has published a bill requiring the 250,000 guards, bouncers, wheelclampers and private investigators working in the security industry to be vetted after a significant minority were found to have criminal convictions.

Mr Hatton says in his memo: "The incident did highlight the danger of not conducting retrospective vetting particularly of those individuals such as members of the security police force who enjoy a freedom of movement over the whole of a site and have a high degree of trust placed in their integrity." From March this year more than 500 guards, including hundreds of existing personnel, will be subjected to 10-yearly tests including security service, court and credit clearance, and taking up references. New recruits have since April 1998 been required to undergo less stringent checks but employees in post before that date, including the Bradwell guard, were not covered. The guard's two criminal convictions would not necessarily have led to clearance being denied, records the DTI note. Jack Dromey, who represents security staff as national secretary of the Transport & General Workers Union, said: "Employers have a duty not to put the public and fellow employees at risk by penny-pinching or through sloppy procedures." Another union official said: "Lunatics, industrial spies or terrorists could have walked through the gates with a badge that almost anyone could get." The new security tests will apply to British Energy civilian security staff at Dungeness B, Hartlepool, Hinkley B, Sizewell B, Hunterston, Torness and two Heysham power stations, plus BNFL magnox employees at Oldbury, Wylfa, Dungeness A, Sizewell A, Hinckley Point A, Berkeley and Bradwell. A spokesman for British Energy said: "We understand the need for such arrangements and are happy to comply." The department of trade and industry confirmed the new checks but played down the Bradwell incident, saying security was constantly under review. "There has been an incident in 1999 which, although it did not cause a breach of security, caused a review of security and in the light of that review revised procedures are to be introduced," a spokesman said. The bigger security companies, MPs and trade unionists have campaigned against "cowboy" guards for years. The government has published a bill requiring the 250,000 guards, bouncers, wheelclampers and private investigators working in the security industry to be vetted after a significant minority were found to have criminal convictions.

webTitle: Simon Hoggart: Tories prepare for election (of new leader)

fields.headline: Tories prepare for the election (of their new leader)
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Parliament
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Parliament has returned for the run-up to the election. The government wants to get back with a large majority; the Tories, meanwhile, have more or less given up, and are worrying about a battle which, to them, is far more important: the one for their party leadership.
fields.body:
Parliament has returned for the run-up to the election. The government wants to get back with a large majority; the Tories, meanwhile, have more or less given up, and are worrying about a battle which, to them, is far more important: the one for their party leadership.

The effect is disjointed, like watching a dispute between two people arguing about different topics.

"He was mad, putting Phil Neville at the back like that."

"Huh, I suppose you think that redefining the headline rate will allow Tony Blair to claim he's met another pre-condition for joining the euro."

"Good point, I grant you. But what about Rio Ferdinand?"

So yesterday Jack Straw said that the government was half way to meeting its manifesto pledge to reduce anti-social behaviour. This is nonsense, and Ann Widdecombe sat in her place rolling from side to side, growling, raising her eyes heavenward, and emitting short squeaks of "No!"

This is because she is looking forward to summer and the possible leadership election. The choice will be made by the 300,000 members of the party in the country. But they can only pick from a shortlist of two drawn up by the MPs. Miss Widdecombe would stand an excellent chance - as the Tories' answer to Britney Spears she is very popular - but she has to be on that list.

To this end she has decided to calm down a little. In the past a Widdecombe outburst was like Mount St Helens exploding. It was fun to watch from a safe distance, but not very statespersonlike.

Now she wants to appear, not as an extinct volcano, but as a dormant one - safe for the moment, but with the potential to erupt at any time with devastating results.

For ages she didn't even stand up. Instead she smiled a terrifying smile, or gave her hair - cut in the pageboy bob now favoured by Martine McCutcheon, once of EastEnders - a mighty, contemptuous flick. A Home Office statistic would create a rumbling noise, and peasants on her lower slopes, tending their olive trees, would feel the first light sprinkling of hot ash.

She didn't speak on police numbers, though a mighty "hyah, hyah!" rent the air when one of her underlings claimed that recruitment was down. Once, with a huge harrumph, she lifted herself up then hurled herself back onto the bench, so that the peasants must have wondered if it was time to head for shelter.

Only when we had almost reached the end, and the subject of asylum seekers came up, did she drag herself up to the dispatch box. She was calm, measured, and - dare one say it? - almost boring. She certainly went on for a very long time, to the extent that the Speaker reproved her in Scottish. ("Ah mus' tell the hon'ble la' she has had a ver' lengthy question, mmmm, hurrr, mmmm, wurrr, se'll don, se'ell don!") MPs can't understand what Michael Martin is saying, but they can usually work it out from the general tone and body language.

So Miss Widdecombe has decided to reinvent herself as someone sane. It's a bold move; we shall know in a few months if it has succeeded.

The best question of the day came from Labour's Gordon Prentice, who thought it was "astonishing" that Lancashire police were spending £450,000 over three years to have Group 4 and Securicor guard their HQs. "Where are the criminals who are going to break into a police HQ, staffed 24 hours a day, 365 days a year, by police officers?"

He thought this proved that the contracting-out culture had gone too far. The poor minister was left mouthing an empty, meaningless reply.

fields.headline: The hardest sell of all
fields.standfirst: Simon Midgley introduces the new training brokers
fields.trailText: Simon Midgley introduces the new training brokers
fields.body:
It could be harder than flogging brushes or encyclopaedias. But for anyone whose skin tingles at the challenge of the cold-call, the latest import from the US looks worth a go.

It's selling training to bosses and it's simple in theory. "Brokers" with business experience knock on firms' doors and try to talk employers into the wisdom of forking out to boost the literacy, numeracy and other basic skills of their workforces. For every new lead they generate, the brokers are paid £200-300.

Alan Wells, director of the Basic Skills Agency, saw the scheme working in Virginia and thought it was worth bringing back to try over here. He and his colleagues feel it might bridge the crucial gap between employers sensing that they ought to get their employees some training and actually taking action.

This could be one of the bold, innovatory solutions called for in the Moser Report, A Fresh Start, which reckoned that a fifth of adults in England have poor basic skills and can't, for instance, find a plumber in the Yellow Pages.

A key barrier to expanding basic skills education in the workplace is the absence of a suitable programme. Employers may identify the need for training but have no idea how to set about providing it.

The Virginian programme is managed and co-ordinated by James Madison University and funded by the Virginia state government. The Basic Skills Agency has set up its own pilot scheme in West London in partnership with the CBI, TUC and Ufi.

Dawn Walker, the agency field officer who has been setting up the pilot projects, says that in the past it has often been difficult to persuade employers to recognise that working routines might be improved if employees' basic skills were improved.

The west London pilot involved finding potential brokers "with a business background and then training them. On successfully completing four assignments to demonstrate their skills and knowledge, the trainees achieved approved broker status and their names were registered centrally with the agency.

Basic Skills Agency-approved post-16 training providers, such as further education colleges, were also given training to adapt their training provision to the needs of the workplace. And the agency secured funding from the Department for Education and Employment to finance programmes of customised training in the workplace.

In west London 13 brokers were trained and some 15 workplace projects have been established in organisations as diverse as Lufthansa and the French Croissant Company.

"There have been tremendous benefits," Ms Walker says. "The change in the workforces of those organisations who participated has been incredible.

"There is a bakery, La Fornaia, near Southall which wanted to work towards Investors in People status. They knew their communications had to be improved. The training provider put on an essential business skills course which included report writing and improving verbal skills. This had knock-on effects in terms of improving employees sense of self worth and confidence and improving team working skills."

A second pilot programme is now being run in the north-east of England. Tomorrow there will be a day of workshops and presentations in Washington, Tyne and Wear to examine how the work can be developed further. Some 25 brokers have been accredited and providers are now being trained. It is hoped to establish a network of workplace training programmes throughout the north-east.

A third pilot project is in Berkshire aims to improve skills in very small firms which find it especially hard to provide training for employees. This project will use brokers to encourage small businesses to invest in basic skills and make use of ICT technologies for teaching and learning.

The Basic Skills Agency is now talking to the Trades Union Conference about adapting the brokerage model in such a way that union learning representatives could use it to "broker" basic skill training to their members.

fields.headline: Dogged popularity
fields.standfirst: Who is the best-loved bitch in education? Ask  Janet Jones
fields.trailText: Who is the best-loved bitch in education? Ask Janet Jones
fields.body:
This is the Tuesday to name-drop. You don't get a lot of name-dropping in further education. You get status dropping instead. So further on I'm going to break the mould and drop the name of perhaps the most popular individual in British education for generations.

In the meantime, further education's fondness for status dropping is like those purple rhododendrons that are strangling the Welsh mountains: pervasive and de-individualizing.

Look at it:

"Equal Opportunities is taking an interest."

"Has Security got your package?"

"Ask the General Office."

"She's having a word with Health and Safety."

"Switchboard is at lunch."

"I told The Funding Council."

"Has Management noticed?"

"It's been sent to Personnel."

"IT Services can fix it."

"Give it to the Union."

"The Student Body"

"Academic Board"

There you have it: a mishmash of statuses and functions working as a substitute for names.

(Royalty and government have taken this one step further so that Buckingham Palace talks to Downing Street and London talks to China: the craziness of buildings, streets, cities and countries chatting to each other spreads itself with such successful insidiousness that nobody notices.)

Back here in education, the great thing about hiding an individual underneath what they do is that it doesn't matter if you don't have a clue who they are. The downside is the facelessness of it all.

The individual whose name I am going to drop has managed to rise above this. She is a triumph both as an individual and as a function. You should see her working a school playground - surrounded by delighted children. And when she was sick in the House of Commons, not only was it front page news, but also many people in this country smiled; everybody is pleased to see her ... the accolades go on and on.

We are very proud of her in our park. Dodger, our park's James Bond of a Jack Russell, risks life and limb to chase her when he sees her working her way through the traffic outside the park. And when she was sick in the House of Commons we were all much concerned that it was the bread put out for our park's pigeons that was the cause. We follow her well-being closely.

Some of you, I suspect, know that her name is Lucy and she is the secretary of state for education's dog. Lucy's popularity in our park is such, that more of us know her name than know her master's.

It could be that the same is true in circles beyond our park.

webTitle: So you want to learn about... archivists

fields.headline: So you want to learn about...
fields.standfirst: Archivists
fields.trailText: Archivists
fields.body:
Good morning. Hello.

This'll fascinate you. Right.

You're interested in historical records? That's right.

Well, I bet you've seen nothing like this. What are they?

1,200 theatre tickets. Quite a collection.

They were my dad's. All for Starlight Express?

Yes, alas he had to be certified. I'm sorry.

Don't be. Anyway, these tickets. Yes?

Do you want them? They're fascinating but ... no.

But aren't they the sorts of things you archivists like? Sort of. We are responsible for the preservation and management of historical records, making them more accessible and ensuring they are preserved for use by future generations, but we don't have limitless space.

What sort of historical records do you want? They come in many media - paper, photographic evidence, film and tape. Demand to use them ranges from historical researchers to individual members of the public.

What about collections? An important part of our work is recognising potential collections. Many archives belong to private organisations or to families, which means the archivist must negotiate with them to ensure the collection is preserved and handed over for public use.

Doesn't it get a bit monotonous? The working environment can vary considerably. Some archivists spend most of their time working with the general public and organising the exhibiting of work. Others find themselves working alone or in offices with only a few other people.

It sounds rather sedentary. Not at all. At times the work can be physically demanding. The archivist will often have to go out to view collections and will sometimes have to work in cramped and dirty conditions, particularly when retrieving an archive.

How do you get into the business? The majority of archivists enter the profession through the postgraduate route. There are postgraduate courses in archive studies at University College London, University of Wales at Aberystwyth and Bangor, University of Liverpool and University College in Dublin.

What about the first degree? Any good honours degree is acceptable but it is important to demonstrate a keen interest in history. Languages may also be of value, particularly Latin, and these days you need a working knowledge of computers. Computers are playing an increasing role in archive restoration. Records are often transferred to microfiche to ensure the original is preserved and more and more collections are making their way on to the internet.

Is it a popular career? Competition for postgraduate courses can be strong and it is advisable, before applying, to gain some relevant experience, possibly unpaid and preferably for a year.

Any other ways in? The Society of Archivists offer both a Certificate in Archive Conservation and a Diploma in Archive Administration but to do either course you have to be a member of the society.

 Society of Archivists, 40 Northumberland Road, London EC1R 0HB
Telephone: 020-7278 8630
Website: www.archives.org.uk

 Records Management Society of Great Britain, Woodside, Coleheath Bottom, Prince's Risborough, Buckinghamshire, HP27 0SZ
Telephone: 01494 488599

 Business Archives Council, 101 Whitechapel High Street, London E1 7RE

 Business Archives Council of Scotland, Archives and Business Records Centre, University of Glasgow, 77-87 Dumbarton Road, Glasgow G11 6PW

Telephone: 0141 330 4159

fields.headline: Fighting shy
fields.standfirst: John Crace bravely samples a course that treats a self-effacing problem
fields.trailText: John Crace bravely samples a course that treats a self-effacing problem
fields.body:
Competition time. What would you consider to be the most embarrassing personal problem? Alcoholism? Drug addiction? Impotence? Think again. If you want to write about any of these subjects you can generally find a number of recovering alcoholics and drug addicts and impotence sufferers willing to talk about their experiences, particularly if you are prepared to guarantee their confidentiality.

But try finding people who have suffered from chronic shyness and you soon draw a blank. Walter Friedman, an American psychotherapist working in the Harley St area, has been running Britain's only shyness clinic for nearly three years and yet, despite having helped hundreds of people in that time, he is unwilling to put me in contact with any of his patients.

"You have to understand, John," he says, "that the very nature of the condition makes people extremely reluctant to come forward."

"Even if they can remain anonymous?" "Even then."

The idea that people who have been successfully treated for shyness might still be unable to face talking over the phone has an intrinsic comedic quality, but it also masks a more serious edge. Friedman believes that shyness, or social anxiety is one of this country's most undiagnosed or misdiagnosed psychological problems, as well as being one of the least discussed, which makes it particularly difficult and embarrassing for chronic sufferers to talk about.

We all suffer from varying degrees of shyness in certain situations, but for those with severe shyness the condition can infect all areas of their life. Those who make contact with Friedman tend to do so at around 30.

"Most people hope that shyness is something they will grow out of," says Friedman. "And for some people it is. But others find they are becoming increasingly isolated; their circle of friends is decreasing and they experience difficulties with dating. A significant number also feel their shyness is impeding their professional development; many of those who come to me find they become highly anxious at departmental meetings and are too nervous to contribute to the discussion."

What causes someone to become chronically shy is not wholly clear; some believe that shy people may be born with a more sensitive nervous system and be more prone to social anxiety as a result. However, it is also widely accepted that life circumstances play their part; those who are brought up in a nurturing environment may find their shyness mitigated and Friedman also reports that some of his patients have said that shyness was never a problem until they were bullied or shamed at secondary school. Shyness is certainly no respecter of the sexes, though Friedman's clinic tends to attract slightly more men than women.

Friedman himself suffered from shyness in his teens and 20s, which he only came to terms with after several years of therapy. After training as a therapist himself he was keen to work within this neglected area and to offer help that could be measured in months rather than years. His clinics consist of 20 two-hour sessions held on a weekly basis in groups of eight to 10 people. All those who contact him receive a one-to-one consultation. "Not everyone is suitable for the groups," he says. "Some may have more primary problems, such as depression, while others may be so socially anxious that they cannot function within the group. In both instances, I recommend the appropriate treatment, either with me or another professional."

Once accepted on the course, patients are taught cognitive therapy techniques where they learn appropriate behavioural responses. "We teach breathing, visualisation, body language and assertiveness," he continues, "as well as providing a safe environment to hold conversations and improve their communication skills." As important as the work within the group, is the homework. Which may take place in the pub; Friedman's clinic is one of the few psychotherapeutic groups where members are actively encouraged to fraternise with each other.

At £40 a session, Friedman does not come cheap. But there again £800 to cure a condition that has dogged you for 20 years could well seem like a bargain at twice the price.

 Walter Friedman can be contacted on 07979 856188 or at www.shyclinic.com
