But others find they are becoming increasingly isolated; their circle of friends is decreasing and they experience difficulties with dating. A significant number also feel their shyness is impeding their professional development; many of those who come to me find they become highly anxious at departmental meetings and are too nervous to contribute to the discussion." What causes someone to become chronically shy is not wholly clear; some believe that shy people may be born with a more sensitive nervous system and be more prone to social anxiety as a result. However, it is also widely accepted that life circumstances play their part; those who are brought up in a nurturing environment may find their shyness mitigated and Friedman also reports that some of his patients have said that shyness was never a problem until they were bullied or shamed at secondary school. Shyness is certainly no respecter of the sexes, though Friedman's clinic tends to attract slightly more men than women. Friedman himself suffered from shyness in his teens and 20s, which he only came to terms with after several years of therapy. After training as a therapist himself he was keen to work within this neglected area and to offer help that could be measured in months rather than years. His clinics consist of 20 two-hour sessions held on a weekly basis in groups of eight to 10 people. All those who contact him receive a one-to-one consultation. "Not everyone is suitable for the groups," he says. "Some may have more primary problems, such as depression, while others may be so socially anxious that they cannot function within the group. In both instances, I recommend the appropriate treatment, either with me or another professional." Once accepted on the course, patients are taught cognitive therapy techniques where they learn appropriate behavioural responses. "We teach breathing, visualisation, body language and assertiveness," he continues, "as well as providing a safe environment to hold conversations and improve their communication skills." As important as the work within the group, is the homework. Which may take place in the pub; Friedman's clinic is one of the few psychotherapeutic groups where members are actively encouraged to fraternise with each other. At £40 a session, Friedman does not come cheap. But there again £800 to cure a condition that has dogged you for 20 years could well seem like a bargain at twice the price.  Walter Friedman can be contacted on 07979 856188 or at www.shyclinic.com

fields.headline: Higher than you think
fields.standfirst: Look at the facts: most college lecturers have had the national pay rise, says  Sue Dutton
fields.trailText: Look at the facts: most college lecturers have had the national pay rise, says Sue Dutton
fields.body:
Even-handedness has rarely been a component of the rules governing the traditional festive pastime of berating scrooge bosses, as the article in Guardian Further on December 19 (Prime Suspects - Thousands of lecturers have not had the national pay rise) well illustrated. But let's look at the facts.

Each year, the Association of Colleges surveys colleges in December and February on the extent to which the nationally-negotiated pay recommendation for lecturers has been implemented. Some colleges can pay promptly, or with only a short delay - hence the December survey. Others wait until February, when they are able to set a budget with accurate funding council sums for recruitment, retention and claw-back before them - hence our February re-survey. Our December survey shows conclusively that some 70% of colleges have already paid or are committed to paying the recommended award of 3.3% or thereabouts. Given that there are 350 general further education colleges (excluding sixth-form colleges), the fact that so many have settled is encouraging.

David Melville, the Funding Council Chief Executive, told the Public Accounts Committee on November 22, 2000 that 72 colleges were at that time in Category C, that is, in a vulnerable financial position. What we see here, therefore, is colleges acting with due and proper regard for their students' provision and staff's security. Many colleges are waiting until the full financial facts are before them.

Each year, the Association of Colleges also carries out a comprehensive survey of the pay of senior managers in colleges of further education and sixth-form colleges in England, Wales and Northern Ireland. It is the only accurate survey of its kind. Preliminary results of the survey for the year 2000-01 show that top management pay is relatively settled, with the median for a college principal now around £65,000, a median increase of 4.06%. Not all principals have received a pay increase, while some have been awarded a higher increase and some a lower one. In general, the smaller general colleges have given lower pay increases to their principals than the larger ones with large budgets and tens of thousands of students.

As for other top managers, for vice-principals and heads of departments, the survey results show that awards are lower, where they have taken place. As with principal posts, there are variations across the sector and across regions. For vice-principals, the median pay increase is 2.13% and for heads of department, it is 1.89%.

Colleges, of course, warmly welcome the extra monies which are coming to them from this government, in part to address the significant issues of staff turnover now affecting the sector. New Association of Colleges research shows that staff turnover is currently running on average at 8.9% for teaching staff and, interestingly, at the higher rates of 9.9% and 13.6% for management and support staff respectively. Over 70% of colleges cite higher salaries on offer in schools and the private sector as negatively affecting their ability to recruit staff at all levels.

So in 2001, let's concentrate on resolving these real disparities rather than those which we would traditionally rather believe. February this year will see the roll-out of several new pieces of work to address the difficulties.

First, there will be new monies for pay for those "directly involved in teaching and learning". Second, there will be a new national job-evaluation scheme which will help to combat inequalities of pay within the current pay systems. Third, and not before time, there will be a comprehensive research study of pay arrangements in colleges, targeted at identifying blockages and disparities in the system.

If colleges are to continue to meet the government's challenge to provide high and improving standards of education, play a leading role in growing the skills the economy needs and widen participation, all staff in colleges will need to be rewarded within a modernised and competitive pay system.

 Sue Dutton is Deputy Chief Executive of the Association of Colleges.

webTitle: Should colleges cast off their old, social safety-net image?

fields.headline: Gosh, Cinderella!
fields.standfirst: Should colleges cast off their old, social safety-net image?
fields.trailText: Should colleges cast off their old, social safety-net image?
fields.body:
It was Malcolm Wicks on this page who recently described education as a "battering ram". A tricky image perhaps for the post-corporal punishment era. But the lifelong learning minister, who is an authority on the welfare state, was expressing a conviction about education as a potent social policy tool, not as a weapon for coaxing recalcitrant students. To complete the Wicks quotation, education was "potentially the most effective battering ram against social inequality".

Any college head would be proud to have coined the metaphor. Who knows? It might already have crept into one or two messages-from-the-principal in next year's college prospectuses.

But any principal tempted to pinch the minister's phrase should think twice. According to new advice soon to be offered to further education managers it's time to stop talking about the sector's mission to rescue the poor and disadvantaged.

"Can we not find something else?" asks James Murphy. "We are a hi-tech industry. It's not just social work. It's not just people living in bad urban estates for whom colleges are the only exit."

Who is this Murphy to be uttering such apparent sacrilege?

Hailed in various blurbs as "one of the UK's leading socio-economic forecasters", he's an affable and engaging Scot who directs Model Reasoning, described as a "forecasting consultancy", and he trails an impressive credit list for helping major corporations and public sector organisations rethink how they brand themselves.

The Association of Colleges called him in, firstly to cast a furrowed brow over how it projects its image and then to do the same for the sector.

Having cast a considered look over further education, visited its institutions and talked to principals, he is impressed by much that he has seen. But he thinks that the face presented to the outside world, if discernible at all, is the wrong one.

"The whole sector is suffused with the best public sector ethic," he says.

"There are principals who devote themselves to helping young people in bad areas to get skills. That's their vocation in life and it's great.

"But we've got to get our face out of that ethic for promotional purposes."

The sector appears better placed now than at any time over the past decade to blow its trumpet. Some of the more prominent problems of the recent past are being addressed if not solved. Things are looking more hopeful on the industrial relations front, Murphy says. The inspection regime has shown that while problems do remain, the sector "has turned an important corner".

But he reckons that these improvements are not yielding the appropriate benefits, and many in the sector would agree.

"I have to ask myself why is it the case that the image of the industry is weak, that it is vulnerable to images of mismanagement or sleaze. That it doesn't capture the public imagination.

"That it never, or very rarely, gets mentioned in the prime minister's speeches."

It remains the Cinderella sector. While schools and universities hog the limelight "further education becomes a kind of forgotten area of marginalised activities".

And yet, there are colleges across the sector that are "seriously overachieving", to use Murphy's phrase.

"My private view is that the only thing that matters now is the successful evolution of the identity and image of colleges because that will make it easier to lay claim to resources.

"Investment, staff pay - any aspect of the sector's needs stands to be seriously enhanced if an image transformation can be brought about.

"Why should people think that a university is great but a college is second best for a young person?"

It is Murphy's belief that the sector has got to ram home the message that it is a vital part of the economy, that it is at the heart of any strategy for future British prosperity.

"You are part of the government's ambitions for the skills economy, you are not just there as a kind of social work safety net," he will advise colleges.

And what would be his tip to the AoC's chief executive David Gibson about his speeches from now on?

"I would suggest he says that the college sector exists to enhance British competitiveness in global markets."

Barely three years since its birth might seem a tad soon for the Association of Colleges to be having a facelift.

Not so, says its chief executive, David Gibson. "Like all membership organisations, we need to make sure that our brand mark and identity are as sharp and fresh and clean as possible."

He is understandably anxious to distinguish the AoC's image review from the whole sector's need for the same. "We would consider that our reputation with our membership is quite clear, well defined and high."

But as colleges' leading collective voice it makes sense for the AoC to submit to scrutiny first.

Design House, a London design company, won the tender for the task. The first and most obvious results are a new "brand mark" - the term logo has now become cliched and trivialised.

Out goes the three-italics blue and green design. In comes a bolder combination in ...

"I'd call it deep red," says James Dicken, its creator. For obvious reasons, nobody wants to talk about "claret" or "burgundy".

Nonetheless he agrees that the colour is deliberately racier than what went before.

"Blue is a very over-used colour in the sector and in business generally because it looks safe and trustworthy. We wanted to go for red because it looks interesting.

"Bright red would look a bit cheap and tacky and perhaps like the Labour Party's rose."

Similarly the Palatino typeface is intended to look more dynamic.

"We didn't want anything too symetrical and static."

Colleges can feel reassured. The sizes of the letters indicate the relative importance of the words they begin.

webTitle: British adults must lose their fear of languages

fields.headline: You too can parlez-vous
fields.standfirst: British adults must lose their fear of languages, says  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: British adults must lose their fear of languages, says Peter Kingston
fields.body:
The British are not as dismal at speaking other languages as they assume, a new survey reveals. Britain's black and ethnic minorities are particularly successful language learners, putting the rest of the country to shame. At least 45% of adults in these communities speak more than two languages, compared to 11% of white British adults.

However far too many adults are still put off learning languages by poor teaching methods and memories of school. And many are discouraged rather than inspired when they hear other nationalities on radio or television speaking English perfectly.

Only one in 20 adults is learning a foreign language, according to the report by Niace, the National Organisation for Adult Learning.

This contrasts starkly with the 44% of adults questioned who said they would like to learn one.

Social class remains a key factor in language learning. Adults in social group AB (8%) are twice as likely to be studying a language as everyone else.

Niace has published its report - Divided by Language - to mark the beginning of what has been designated the European Year of Languages.

The research, in which 4,000 adults across the county were questioned, challenges the view that little language learning is happening, according to Sue Cara, Niace's associate director.

We still compare woefully with many of our European partners, says Alwena Lamping, of the Nuffield Languages Inquiry, which recently published its report on what languages capability will be neeeded in the UK in the next generation.

"In many European countries they think nothing of teaching their children two or three languages," she says.

"In this country nine out of 10 youngsters in the 16 to 19 age group drop languages."

There should be particular concern for young people pursuing vocational courses in the further education sector.

"We found it very odd that there are courses like tourism, business and hospitality where taking a language is often just an option. Languages should be an integral part of these courses.

"Our young people are coming out of colleges and competing for jobs in these occupations with youngsters from the rest of Europe who speak several languages, and they won't stand a chance."

Furthermore they won't have the understanding of other cultures which is crucial in many sectors.

English's status as a lingua franca gives an advantage to the British but in no way should that deter them from learning other languages, says Pauline Swanton, adult education adviser to CILT (the Centre for Information on Language Teaching and Research).

But when so many other nationalities speak English well it has an intimidating effect on adults who might otherwise try to learn another language.

"If you talk to English native speakers about what learning a language means they have a model before them of complete fluency because they've heard, for instance, so many Dutch people speaking perfect English."

Swanton believes that adults should not necessarily be thinking in terms of becoming fluent.

"We should reassure people that an appropriate outcome doesn't have to be fluency or an A-level. It might be simply being able to say: I'd like two beers and a croissant."

webTitle: Warwick University develops crucial new mobile technology

fields.headline: Ahead of the game
fields.standfirst: A new antenna that could cut radiation by 97% and double battery life has mobile phone companies queuing up at Warwick University, says  Chris Arnot
fields.trailText: A new antenna that could cut radiation by 97% and double battery life has mobile phone companies queuing up at Warwick University, says Chris Arnot
fields.body:
Few universities are more adept than Warwick at squeezing juicy profits from the fruits of research. With its adjoining business and science parks on the edge of Coventry, much of the campus is never far from the interface between academia and industry. And right now the mobile phone industry is sitting up and taking notice of a new development from the School of Engineering.

Professor Roger Green has devised an antenna which, it is claimed, can cut the radiation passing through a user's head by up to 97%.

At the same time, it can double the life of the battery - or produce the same output from half the size - thereby opening up the prospect of phones even smaller than the compact handsets which slid to the bottom of so many Christmas stockings last month.

Warwick Ventures, set up to exploit commercially the ideas generated by the university's academics, has already patented the invention with the London company Marks and Clerk.

Professor Green is also expecting Motorola executive to fly in from Florida for talks. Meanwhile, Nokia invited him to address a conference in Copenhagen.

"It's quite frightening because these industry scientists know what they're talking about," he muses.

"All companies have people working behind the scenes to produce new antennae."

Mobile communications company Vodafone hit the headlines recently after being threatened with billions of dollars' worth of lawsuits from users who claim their brain tumours were caused by radiation from mobile phones.

"No company will say that they're trying to improve safety when, by implication, that would be to admit that their products are not safe already," Prof Green points out.

"Whether I make any money out of this or not, at least the issue will be out in the open," he says.

The professor has an open mind about the alleged link between mobiles and potentially damaging levels of radiation. He is aware that government scientists have found no apparent link. But he also knows that the exchequer benefited by £22bn in 1999 by selling frequencies to four companies.

"The waters are clouded a bit. But when all's said and done, there are likely to be more hazards from overhead power lines. The power from mobile phones is very small and people ought to get these things in perspective," Professor Green says.

All the same, he has taken to using his own mobile in short bursts and alternating the receiver between one ear and the other.

"Irrespective of any real or imagined health hazards," he continues, "there is a lot of waste at the moment. The basic idea of an antenna is to radiate energy from a resonant structure. But there's too little control over where that energy is going. There's no point in it going into the head. If you can direct it away from the head, you can double the amount of power sent out."

Professor Green's system is dependent on dielectrics - in this case a ceramic material which concentrates the electro-magnetic field.

"It allows you to produce miniature versions of an antenna which have particular properties with regard to the way you can direct or con tour radio waves. You have to arrange the electrical structures, in combination with the dielectrics, to divert radiation away from the head."

This harnessing of energy leads to efficiency savings which could, in theory, double the signal power. Instead it can be used to halve the overall radiation output of the phone while generating the same signal strength. And the unit costs? "Because the amount of material is small, they shouldn't be very high," Professor Green says.

The industry should like the sound of that.

fields.headline: Pacific hates
fields.standfirst: Post-coup crime and tension is still hurting Fiji's seat of learning.  David Cohen  reports
fields.trailText: Post-coup crime and tension is still hurting Fiji's seat of learning. David Cohen reports
fields.body:
Seven months after an ethnically inspired coup plunged Fiji into civil chaos, the country's only university continues to mirror the political tensions that have bitterly divided the 850,000 inhabitants of this one time British colony.

While the stories of many institutions of higher learning in the Asia-Pacific region are taking buoyant new turns, the same old pessimistic themes keep recurring at the University of the South Pacific.

"I do not believe we've reached the bottom yet," says one faculty member who asked not to be identified. "Things are definitely going to get worse before they get better."

The coup, which was led by indigenous Fijians, was directed against the multiracial government of Prime Minister Mahendra Chaudhry, who along with 45 others was taken hostage at Fiji's Parliament House.

In the wake of the seizure, the country witnessed unprecedented scenes of rioting in the streets of the capital Suva, with supporters of the ultra-national ist Taukei Movement - from whose ranks the insurgents were drawn - destroying scores of buildings in the city centre. The university campus managed to escape physical damage.

The drama came after months of growing tensions between the majority population of indigenous Fijians and the 43% of the population who trace their roots to Indian migrants. The latter were brought to Fiji as indentured labourers by the nation's erstwhile colonial overlords in the late 1800s.

Until last year, Indian Fijians, or Indo-Fijians, played a commanding role in the country's commerce and academic life, resulting in widespread resentment against their perceived good fortune, not least at the University of the South Pacific.

Established in 1968, two years ahead of Fiji's independence from Britain, the institution serves 12 member countries and territories sprinkled across 20 million square miles of ocean and including the Cook Islands, Kiribati, Marshall Islands, Nauru, Niue, Samoa, Tonga, Solomon Islands, Tokelau, Tuvalu and Vanuatu.

It currently enrols some 4,700 full-time students and has about 300 fac ulty members, roughly half of them Indo-Fijian.

But while the campus may have escaped physical damage during the May riots, academics say the coup has left its lingering mark on many other aspects of its operation.

Following the coup, the institution shut its doors for two months, during which more than 50 staff members resigned their positions, many to seek new opportunities abroad.

For those who remained, any work deemed to be politically sensitive has been conducted in conditions of "extreme anxiety and many [academics] have engaged in various forms of self-censorship in terms of what they could have written and said about the illegal overthrow of the democratically-elected government," according to Biman C Prasad, an economist at the university and a prominent member of the Fiji Trade Union Congress.

"I am sure you can imagine the kind of academic environment we had when people carrying M16s and AK47s were roaming around the place and when the police and the military were unable to do much to restore peace and stability. In this kind of environment, you can't be expected to do serious academic work."

In recent weeks the university has been robbed twice. In the first incident, on December 11, two staff members were held up at gunpoint and relieved of more than £10,000 worth of course fees. A day later, another £7,000 was stolen from one of the offices.

On current indicators, such crimes against property are only likely to increase. With international investments hitting their lowest point in years and a surging exodus of Indo-Fijians bound for Australia, Britain, New Zealand and the United States, it has been estimated that it could be a quarter-century before the nation can enjoy its pre-2000 levels of economic activity.

By far the most divisive issue to have yet faced the university, however, has been the selection of a prominent ethnic Fijian economist over an Indo-Fijian scholar to become its next vice-chancellor. The decision, which was made in October, reversed an earlier one to appoint the popular Indo-Fijian scholar as the next head of the University of the South Pacific.

Savenaca Siwatibau, an economist and former head of Fiji's Reserve Bank, won the position over Rajesh Chandra, a professor of geography and long-standing administrator at the university. The term of the current vice chancellor, Isikia Solofa, ends next month.

Initially, the university's governing council had recommended Dr Chandra be chosen, not Dr Siwatibau. The politically sensitive decision was made at the behest of an Australian-led team of academics that went to the university to help in the selection process.

"There's been a great deal of dissatisfaction over the way in which this process has become politicised and made into an ethnic issue, and as such has brought our institution into some disrepute," says Dr Prasad.

Nevertheless, he added, with a note of optimism: "The general attitude among most of the staff here is now to take a let's-wait-and-see approach to the appointment."

Others, however, are less sanguine. "This is another nail in the coffin of what until recently was one of the region's premier centres of excellence," says one, who sees little end in sight to the current tales of South Pacific woe.

fields.headline: Higher browsing
fields.trailText: Research news, plus all the top stories and gossip
fields.body:
The third degree

 More answering fire from Oxford at John Kay, erstwhile head of the Said Business School, who wrote at length about the university declining into bureaucratic mediocrity. The business school was a "daft idea in the first place", sniffs Alan Ryan, Warden of New College, in this month's Prospect magazine. "Riding into town on a white elephant is no kindness to hard-up universities." Being offered £20m by benefactor Wafic Said is not everyone's idea of an imposition, and it's not quite the line his colleague Anthony Hopwood, present head of SBS, took in Guardian Education when he responded to Kay's venom.

 Kay's attack on endless committees and the university's inability to take decisions completed a miserable media year for Oxford, dominated by the public relations battering the university took after refusing a place to Laura Spence. So much so that the dons' Oxford Magazine has called for a Rapid Reaction Force to rebut criticism "in crisp and where necessary combative English". Isn't that what a press office is for?

 Maths teachers are nerds, say their pupils, but what about science teachers? Sheffield Hallam lecturer Mick Nott wants people to dredge up memories of science lessons and their teachers. "Were they mad scientists or sensitive souls who got the best out of you?" Mick, who is putting together an exhibition for the centenary of the Association for Science Education, can be contacted at the university (tel 0114 253 2463) or via www.ase.org.uk

 Stories? Gossip? Contact us:
donald.macleod@theguardian.com
lee.elliotmajor@theguardian.com

News: Empty coffers

The new money for academics heralded in last year's government spending review is already plagued by delays.

Officials last month announced that plans to consult institutions last week over the allocation of the new £1bn Science Research Investment Fund had been abandoned until a later date. The sudden change of plan has led to rumours that the distribution of grants, for university laboratories and buildings, may be even more skewed towards the research heavyweight universities than originally proposed.

Meanwhile plans for the successor scheme to the Higher Education Reach-Out to Business and the Community (HEROBC) programme - the "third leg" of university funding to improve academic-business links - have also been delayed. A battle is raging between the two bodies - the Office of Science and Technology and the Higher Education Funding Council for England - contributing to the £100m programme. Both want to lead the initiative. Will the science minister Lord Sainsbury's £2m donation to the Labour Party sway the issue for the OST?

Officials are already blaming the forthcoming general election for the delays.

Research news

 An electronic test will be employed to verify the publication claims of academics in the forthcoming Research Assessment Exercise. The test will use research publication databases to check the validity of academic papers listed by researchers in departmental submissions to the exercise.

 Cambridge University's proposals for a new animal testing laboratory have been rejected by local planners after concerns that the lab would attract animal rights protesters. South Cambridgeshire District Council last week said the centre would damage the green belt. The university is considering an appeal.

Universe

Could the US vice-president Al Gore gain a presidency after all? There is speculation among US academic circles that Harvard could end its long search for a new president by offering the post to Gore.

He looks like a strong runner. He was a Harvard undergraduate, and a university trustee from 1987 to 1993. And the Harvard presidency is these days mostly about public relations and fundraising.

One problem could be academic credentials. The university's search committee has said that candidates must have "academic background". It needs to look no further than Harvard's own records for Gore's undergraduate grades: all Cs and Ds.

fields.headline: Fair deal?
fields.standfirst: In 2001-2 Edinburgh will spend nearly £1,400 more on each student than Westminster - and £1,600 more than Cardiff.  Stephen Court reports on the disturbing fallout of devolution
fields.trailText: In 2001-2 Edinburgh will spend nearly £1,400 more on each student than Westminster - and £1,600 more than Cardiff. Stephen Court reports on the disturbing fallout of devolution
fields.body:
Consider yourself lucky if you were born in Scotland and plan to study at a Scottish university. The Scottish Executive will spend about a quarter more on your education than will be spent on students in England and Wales. You won't have to pay up-front tuition fees. Some of you will be eligible for a non-repayable grant to help with living costs. And, for students on standard full-time first degree courses, you will have four years at university, compared with three years in other parts of the UK.

Other attractions could include having the television chef Clarissa Dickson Wright as the rector of your university, if you go to Aberdeen, or sharing a lecture theatre at St Andrews with Prince William.

The sharpest funding differences in the UK are shown in the unit of funding resource for each full-time equivalent student. Next year, the unit of resource for all expenditure (recurrent and non-recurrent) in cash terms will be £5,360 for each student in England, £5,138 in Wales, and £6,744 in Scotland. Information for Northern Ireland was not available at the time of writing.

The unit will rise by slightly over 5% in England and Scotland, but only 3.5% in Wales. Once you have taken inflation at 2.5% into account for next year, the Welsh increase is only a lit tle bit above the rate of inflation.

In terms of the unit of recurrent funding alone, which gives a clearer picture of what is actually being spent on the education of each student, spending next year in Scotland will be around 2% above inflation, spending in England will be 0.4% above inflation, and spending in Wales will be around 0.4% below inflation - a real-terms cut, in other words.

This in itself is a remarkable improvement on the past decade and more, which has seen consistent real-terms cuts in spending for each student in the UK. But why is spending per student more than a quarter higher in Scotland than in England or Wales? Why are the recurrent increases higher for Scotland than for England and Wales?

It is not that Scotland has a proportionately lower number of students. In fact, 46% of young people in Scotland participated in higher education in 1997-98, compared with 32% in England and Wales, and 44% in Northern Ireland.

The answer lies in post-devolution funding decisions, and in the historical differences in spending baselines in each country, which may have been accentuated by the application of the so-called Barnett formula. This formula was introduced in 1978 as a means of linking levels of change in funding in England to funding in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. It is based on population levels. The accuracy of the formula, and the extent to which its application may have benefited non-English parts of the UK - particularly Scotland - is a matter of controversy. But whatever the reason, spending per student in Scotland is way ahead of England and Wales.

What must be galling to students in England and Wales is the fact that, while the amount spent on them lags behind Scottish students, they - like students in Northern Ireland - are having to pay up-front tuition fees for full-time undergraduate courses.

Recent student support measures from David Blunkett's Department for Education and Employment mean that in 2001-2 only half the undergraduates in England and Wales will be liable to pay fees. But that's still 50% more than in Scotland, where fees were abolished from autumn 2000.

The fissures in the UK caused by Scottish students in England, Wales or Northern Ireland having to pay fees, and English, Welsh and North ern Ireland students in Scotland also having to pay fees - unlike EU students - underline the impact of devolution.

Students north of Hadrian's Wall aren't getting away scot-free: they will have to pay a graduate endowment of £2,000 once they are income-earners. But this is about a third less than tuition fees elsewhere in the UK over the three years of a typical first degree. Since it is contingent on income, the Scottish endowment will be easier to pay than the up-front lump-sum tuition fee. And the burden on Scottish families while they are supporting students through higher education will be smaller.

And what is more, from 2001-2 non-repayable cost of living bursaries, to a maximum of £2,000 a year, will be available to young students from poor families in Scotland. And about 30,000 mature students entering higher education for the first time will benefit from discretionary bursaries.

It's a matter of attitude, as much as anything. The Scottish Executive, in last year's report Scotland: The Learning Nation, said: "The fear of debt is a possible disincentive to students from lower income families entering higher education. A key objective of our new scheme is therefore to reduce the amount of loan students need to take out over the period of their study."

Because of this, the executive is prepared to find resources from elsewhere to compensate institutions for the loss of tuition fees and fund a limited reintroduction of maintenance grants.

Some vice-chancellors in England have questioned whether the position in Scotland is sustainable. The Scottish Executive estimates that the cost of these changes for HE and FE will be about £50m a year, 2% of the total budget for the Department of Enterprise and Lifelong Learning in 2001-2.

It should be manageable - particularly since the additional cash funding for higher education in Scotland from grant and fees in 2001-2 will be £53m (and £24m in 2002-3 and £27m in 2003-4). In the long run, the cost of the abolition of fees will be offset by the full projected income of £16m a year from the graduate endowment scheme. Since the Scottish participation rate is near the government's 50% target, less extra funding will be needed than in England and Wales.

With devolution, it is likely that levels of public spending will increasingly diverge. A Treasury report notes: "Responsibility for United Kingdom fiscal policy, macroeconomic policy and public expenditure allocation across the United Kingdom will remain with the Treasury. As a result, the devolved administrations' budgets will continue to be determined within the framework of public expenditure control in the United Kingdom. However once overall public expenditure budgets have been determined, the devolved administrations will have freedom to make their own spending decisions on devolved programmes within the overall totals."

While education and employment secretary David Blunkett adopts a policy in England of ameliorating the impact of the introduction of tuition fees and the end of the maintenance grant, views in other parts of the UK are changing. The Welsh Assembly's education and lifelong learning committee is conducting a review of higher education in Wales. The review asks: "How can we ensure that no student is deterred from taking up or completing his/her studies due to financial hardship?" This includes assessing whether students should contribute financially towards tuition. The results of the review will be available in the spring.

Meanwhile the minister for education and lifelong learning in Wales, Jane Davidson, is setting up an independent enquiry into student hardship and funding in Wales, to tackle problems in the current system of student maintenance and support.

The Northern Ireland Assembly's committee for higher and further education, training and employment has proposed a system similar to Scotland's, with the abolition of up-front tuition fees, graduate contributions to tuition, and means-tested non-repayable cost of living bursaries. Although higher education minister Sean Farren has not gone along with abolishing tuition fees, it may be that the example of Scotland and developments in Wales will create sufficient pressure to make him change his mind. That could just leave England as a bastion of the Blunkett-inspired system of tuition fees and no maintenance grant. But with a general election in the offing, who knows what will happen?

 Stephen Court is senior research officer at the Association of University Teachers

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Algerian rebels kill Russians
Beckers 'close to custody deal'
Ex-governor faces jail in US
Blizzards kill 20 in China
fields.body:
Algerian rebels kill Russians

Islamic militants slit the throats of four Russian engineers who were picking mushrooms on Sunday in Edough Forest, 250 miles east of Algiers, sources close to the security forces said yesterday.

It was the first time in almost two years that rebels have attacked foreigners.
Reuters, Algiers.

Beckers 'close to custody deal'

The German tennis star Boris Becker and his wife Barbara are trying to reach an out-of-court settlement of their divorce and child custody dispute, their lawyers said yesterday.

A Florida judge agreed to postpone yesterday's hearing to give them time to work out a deal. Barbara Becker, 33, moved into the family's home in Miami in December with the couple's two sons.
Reuters, Miami.

Ex-governor faces jail in US

After years of apparent political and legal invincibility, the Democrat ex-governor of Louisiana Edwin Edwards, 73, was facing prison yesterday after being found guilty on 17 counts of racketeering, extortion, fraud and conspiracy.

The Baton Rouge court was expected pass sentence yesterday. Edwards is to appeal against his conviction. AP, Baton Rouge.

Blizzards kill 20 in China

A blizzard in the Inner Mongolia region of northern China a week ago killed 20 people and cut off thousands from food supplies, a local government official said yesterday.
AP, Beijing.

fields.headline: Vote rigging 'cost Labour local poll'
fields.trailText: A substantial vote rigging conspiracy in a local council's elections two years ago may have deprived Labour of overall power, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A substantial vote rigging conspiracy in a local council's elections two years ago may have deprived Labour of overall power, a court heard yesterday.

In a two-pronged fraud, three Liberal Democrat candidates, a Conservative and a college caretaker allegedly teamed up to either "take away peoples' right to vote", or invent "imaginary electors".

As a result the east London borough of Hackney's final political landscape may not have reflected the real will of the electorate, it was claimed.

"We suggest the scale of the fraud shows there was a real possibility that the fraud in this election was substantial enough to have altered the results, not only regarding at least two councillors, but also could have altered the result of the election itself," John Bevan QC, prosecuting, told Wood Green crown court in north London.

"Labour, therefore, had good reason to complain about the apparent voting figures.

"This is not just about the odd bit of cheating here and there. The effect may have been to deprive Hackney of the council that the electorate truly voted for."

In the dock are the three Liberal Democrats who were eventually voted in - Zev Lieberman, 29, Ian Sharer, 55, and Shahid Achhala, 29, all of Stoke Newington, north London.

With them are the Conservative councillor, Isaac Leibowitz, 36, and 22-year-old Chananya Gross, both from Clapton, east London.

Lieberman, Sharer, Achhala and Leibowitz all deny conspiracy to defraud Hackney's deputy returning officer, between May 6, 1994 and May 7, 1998, by inducing him to accept dishonest proxy vote applications for the Northwold ward as genuine.

Leibowitz, Lieberman, Sharer and Gross separately plead not guilty to a similar count, covering the same period, but concerning the alleged registration of non-existent electors and those not entitled to vote.

In addition, Achhala, Sharer, Leibowitz and Lieberman deny 18 counts of forgery.

Mr Bevan warned the jury that while the case involved politics "it is absolutely not a political trial."

He told the court that Hackney was divided into 23 wards. One of them was Northwold, which returned three Liberal Democrats - Lieberman, Sharer and Achhala - out of a total of 10 candidates, ousting the incumbents in the process.

"The crown say the Lib Dem councillors together with Leibowitz, who is currently, oddly, a Conservative councillor for the Springfield ward, conspired together to abuse the proxy voting system in order to increase the number of votes cast for them - that is, for the three Lib Dems."

He maintained they used various "dishonest devices" to obtain votes.

The hearing continues.
Press Association

fields.headline: Ban on Italian track supplies
fields.standfirst: Special report: Transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack placed a ban on rail supplies from Italy after the discovery of scarring on a "rogue batch" of rail which was being laid in two separate 600ft sections in south London, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Railtrack placed a ban on rail supplies from Italy after the discovery of scarring on a "rogue batch" of rail which was being laid in two separate 600ft sections in south London, it emerged yesterday.

The batch, which was removed, formed part of a consignment of 10 miles of track manufactured by the Italian company Lucchini. Railtrack said last night that it had imposed an immediate embargo on further supplies.

Railtrack said that the fault was discovered before the Hatfield rail crash last October. It added the defect would not have been a threat to safety but would have affected the quality of the ride.

It said that it hoped the embargo would soon be lifted but that it would not take any chances over rail quality. A senior Railtrack engineer is due to visit Lucchini this month to check on progress.

Railtrack said that the fault was not connected with gauge corner cracking, the incident largely responsible for the Hatfield crash.

The scarring occurred be cause the finishing at Lucchini was not up to standard.

This is not the first time Railtrack has been forced to send back a shipment to its suppliers, although it is the first incident with Lucchini, which signed a contract with Railtrack last May.

Research commissioned by Railtrack said that it might take up to five years for the industry to recover from the consequences of the Hatfield crash.

The report, compiled by Mori for Railtrack, said that "lasting and irreparable harm" might have been caused by the crash.

The rail passengers' council said that the report was "very, very worrying" and showed that train companies still had a big hill to climb.

The findings came on the day when some unregulated fares rose above the level of inflation, a move condemned as "barmy" by Gwyneth Dunwoody, chairwoman of the House of Commons transport select committee.

webTitle: Leader: MoT certificates for homes are a good idea

fields.headline: Buyers' bonus
fields.standfirst: MoT certificates for homes are a good idea
fields.trailText: MoT certificates for homes are a good idea.
fields.body:
Even extreme devotees of the market do not pretend that buying and selling a home is like other transactions: yet for too long the law (in England at least) has pretended house purchase is a simple matter of come, negotiate and transact. For many buyers and not a few sellers reality is a thicket of vendors' promises made and broken, nerve-wracking waits and futile spending on surveys and legal fees. The Tories promised to streamline the business but never got round to it - too many estate agents among them, perhaps. Labour has taken its time and the reforms set out in its homes bill, which won its second reading in the Commons yesterday, are limited. But they do start to re-equilibrate costs and duties between home buyers and sellers. That the Law Society, bastion of restrictive practices, should resist is as strong a testimony as the bill could have.

Just as the buyer of a second-hand car expects to see logbook and MoT, house purchasers will have a right to see their equivalents before they talk turkey. This "seller's pack" will include title deeds, planning search and some proof of a dwelling's condition, probably a report by a chartered surveyor. Nothing here lifts the onus from the buyer to beware, but the pack could save buyers profitless spending on surveys and searches. None of the required documents are new; all would have to be produced at some stage. What changes is who pays. Any extra expense for sellers will probably be registered in the asking price.

There is a long way to go to make house sales convenient. Electronic conveyancing is well behind the curve - this is not unrelated to the fact that so few solicitors have invested in information technology. Sellers' packs do not address growing disrepair in property owned by people who cannot afford its upkeep - nor will they expand a vital link in the chain, council trading standards officers. It is none the less a welcome start.

fields.headline: Lord Spens
fields.standfirst: Buccaneering banker who fought to salvage his reputation after Guinness scandal
fields.trailText: The ebullient Lord Spens, who has died aged 58, went through more than his "11 years of hell" centered around his appearance at the second Guinness trial of 1991-92.
fields.body:
The ebullient Lord Spens, who has died aged 58, went through more than his "11 years of hell" centered around his appearance at the second Guinness trial of 1991-92. In June 1999, his right to legal aid - to help him sue the Bank of England for what he said was the destruction of his lucrative career - was abruptly withdrawn. He had said the case had been about "10, 12 years of my life, whatever that costs".

Spens had lost his job, as the £100,000-a-year managing director of the Henry Ansbacher merchant bank, in January 1987, and his life savings and reputation had followed. The Bank of England forced Ansbacher to sack him. Within months, came his arrest on charges of concocting - with another banker, Morgan Grenfell's Roger Seelig - an illegal share support scheme, creating a false market in Guinness shares.

The story had begun when inspectors from the Department of Trade and Industry raided the Guinness drinks group in December 1986. This followed share-rigging allegations stemming from the 1985-86 takeover battle for the Distillers drinks giant between Guinness and the food group Argyll.

In 1990, the former Guinness chief executive, Ernest Saunders, tycoon Gerald Ronson and stockbroker Antony Parnes were convicted for their roles in an illegal shares support operation. Spens had spent 170 days observing that first Guinness trial and had become fearful. Just before his own and Seelig's trial began in October 1991, he had a heart attack requiring a double bypass operation. Five months later, Seelig's ill health led to the trial being abandoned. In July 1993, Spens was formally acquitted, as was Seelig.

Spens was the City of London's most predatory peer, a cigar-chomping extrovert, and he had been accused of actions of dubious legality. It is illegal for firms to buy their own shares to maintain their price in a takeover war. So City buccaneers like Spens had used substitute tactics to maintain share prices.

In the final stages of the takeover battle between Guinness and Argyll, Spens had agreed with Seelig to buy 2.15m Guinness shares, nominally for clients of Ansbacher. In exchange, Seelig, acting for Saunders of Guinness, would indemnify Spens's bank. After Guinness won the takeover battle, Spens agreed not to sell the shares, provided £7.6m was deposited to cover the shares plus holding costs. But the money came from Guinness, making the action potentially illegal.

Spens attacked the trial judge for his "limited experience of criminal trials of this nature". The judge refused to award him the £400,000 he had expended before receiving legal aid, saying he had "brought the prosecution on himself".

He was left with debts of £500,000 and requiring another heart bypass operation. Yet, as he continued his battle by suing the Bank of England for "abuse of power" and losing him lucrative employment, he was able to maintain the sense of humour he had often displayed in debates in the House of Lords. Right up to the time of his death, he was fighting before the ombudsman to restore legal aid to continue his battle against the Bank.

Patrick Spens was the grandson of Sir Patrick Spens, the first Barons Spens, who had been Britain's last chief justice of India (between 1943 and 1947) and later a Conservative MP. His own father, the second Lord Spens, was director of the Federation of British Carpet Manufacturers and a compulsive gambler. He was jailed for two years for stealing from the federation.

Patrick himself was educated at Rugby and Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, where he read law. He took articles in accountancy, then joined Morgan Grenfell, becoming a director in 1972. In 1983, he became managing director of Henry Ansbacher, the small merchant bank of which he became the buccaneering spearhead in 300 takeover bids. When the Bank of England urged him to moderate his behaviour, he famously replied: "That is what Ansbacher and I do well, and I intend to carry on doing it."

In 1966, he married the daughter of Rear Admiral Ralph Fisher, Barbara Fisher, who found it much more difficult than her husband to cope with the problems of impoverishment after the City's most dramatic battle, but stood by him nevertheless. They had a daughter and a son, 32-year-old Patrick, who inherits his father's title.

Andrew Roth

 Patrick Michael Rex Spens, 3rd Baron Spens of Blairsanquhar
 Merchant banker
 Born July 22 1942; died January 5 2001

fields.headline: Walter Hayes
fields.standfirst: Ex-editor whose business skill saved Aston Martin
fields.trailText: One day in 1987, the sometime Fleet Street editor and senior Ford executive Walter Hayes, who has died aged 76, dropped in on his close friend, Henry Ford II.
fields.body:
One day in 1987, the sometime Fleet Street editor and senior Ford executive Walter Hayes, who has died aged 76, dropped in on his close friend, Henry Ford II. "Well, Walter," said the multinational's supremo, "what are we going to do today?" "Well," Hayes replied, "we could always buy Aston Martin."

Ford thought this a great idea. Aston Martin was one of Britain's most hallowed companies, but, although it had for years been making wonderful cars, it never made any money. The tractor tycoon David Brown, who built the famous DB range - the preferred transport of the Prince of Wales and James Bond - had sold the company in 1972 after 25 years, after which it fell on hard times until taken over by Pace Petroleum's charismatic Victor Gauntlett, backed by the Greek Livanos shipping dynasty.

But even Gauntlett had to seek assistance elsewhere, and Hayes played a significant part in this. He had met Gauntlett socially, and learnt that Aston Martin was seeking additional capital to develop a new car. The deal was agreed that July, shortly before Ford's death, and his company acquired a 75% shareholding. Two years later, Hayes retired from Ford, but was appointed a director of Aston Martin; in 1991, he became executive chairman.

A great enthusiast, he was a natural choice to run Aston Martin and, with his knowledge of the Ford organisation - which, from 1989, also included Jaguar - he pulled the strings which got the new DB7 introduced in 1993. This car made good use of selected Jaguar components, and was built at Tom Walkinshaw's Jaguar Sport factory at Bloxham.

With guidance and encouragement from Hayes, the new car was styled by Ian Callum, who later became Jaguar's director of design. As a small and slightly more affordable Aston Martin, it broke new ground, but could also be seen as the modern successor to the classic DB2 and DB4 models. Hayes astutely linked it to Aston's heritage by giving it the DB tag, after Sir David Brown, whom Hayes persuaded to accept the position of honorary life president until his death in 1993. The title passed to Hayes himself on his retirement in 1994.

Born in Harrow, Middlesex, Hayes went to Hampton grammar school before joining the RAF as a cadet pilot in 1943. After the war he turned to journalism, and, in 1956, became the youngest-ever editor-in-chief of a national newspaper, the Daily Mail's then sister, the Sunday Dispatch. During his tenure, he formed a friendship with Colin Chapman, of Lotus, who wrote a motoring column for him.

Later, Hayes was associate editor of the Daily Mail, but became head of Ford's public affairs department in 1962, the year the Cortina was launched. He had the inspiration of creating sporting versions of this family car, and first thought up a GT version; the name was chosen because Halfords had a nice-looking GT badge in stock.

Next, he got in touch with Chapman, and the two men came up with the Lotus Cortina, using the Ford-based, Lotus twin-cam engine. As a race and rally car, it was the start of a motoring legend; a Lotus Cortina won the 1966 RAC rally. By 1965, Hayes had become a board director of Ford, and, while his main responsibility remained public affairs, he was also involved with Ford Advanced Vehicles, the subsidiary set up to build the GT40 racing car, which, after a hesitant start, went on to win the Le Mans 24-hour race four years in a row from 1966.

In 1965, Hayes persuaded Ford to spend £100,000 backing the development of the Cosworth three-litre V8 engine for the new grand prix formula. The engine, first supplied to Chapman of Lotus, eventually powered most grand prix cars and became the most successful in the history of the race, with 175 wins over 30 years.

That the Ford Escort, introduced as the first European Ford car in 1968, became so successful in rallying was also, in no small measure, due to Hayes. Conspiring with competitions manager Henry Taylor, he got approval for a last-minute addition to the range, the Escort twin-cam. The car won the World Rally Championship in 1968 and 1969 - effectively taking over where the Mini Cooper had left off - and firmly established Ford's reputation as a manufacturer of sporting cars.

Ford in Britain had now become part of Ford of Europe, and, in 1976, Hayes's responsibilities were extended when he became a vice-chairman. From 1980 to 1984, he was vice-president for world public affairs in Detroit, where his friendship with Henry Ford II developed. Three years after Ford's death, Hayes published Henry: A Memoir Of Henry Ford II.

Shrewd, independent-minded and pragmatic, Hayes was never completely the corporate man, and perhaps it was this slightly maverick approach that made him successful at Ford. He was a cultured man of wide interests. A trustee of the National Motor Museum and the Aston Martin Heritage Trust, he also chaired the Stowe Garden Appeal for the National Trust, and the Churches Conservation Trust. His publications included poems and a children's story.

He was made a CBE in 1980. His wife Elizabeth (née Holland) survives him, together with their two sons and daughter.

Anders Ditlev Clausager

 Walter Leopold Arthur Hayes, editor and motor industry executive, born April 12 1924; died December 26 2000

fields.headline: Hit-run driver carried victim's body on roof
fields.trailText: A persistent speeder may face jail after hitting an elderly pedestrian and driving for two miles with the man's body wedged in his sun roof.
fields.body:
A persistent speeder may face jail after hitting an elderly pedestrian and driving for two miles with the man's body wedged in his sun roof.

Unemployed Craig Gant told police he was too scared even to look round when he felt his victim's lifeless arm brush his shoulder as he accelerated on to a pub, where he had arranged to have a drink.

Hazel Darnton, prosecuting, told Wakefield magistrates the case was the worse example of failing to stop after an accident she had encountered. The victim's injuries were "more consistent with a motorway accident than a crash on an urban road."

Retired hospital porter Tadeusz Rogala, 74, was flung on to the windscreen and then rolled on to the roof as Gant's uninsured Honda Accord careered through a 30mph zone in Wakefield, West Yorkshire.

Mr Rogala was crossing the road, said Ms Darnton. "Mr Rogala's left leg was severed below the knee. Mr Gant returned to the scene of the accident but it appears he then did a u-turn to continue his journey to the pub."

Police received calls reporting a car with a body on the roof. They went to the pub at Horbury, near Wakefield, and found Gant drinking inside with his father. The car was parked outside with Mr Rogala's body still jammed in place.

Gant, of Crofton near Wakefield, admitted careless driving, failing to stop and driving without insurance as well as breaking the speed limit for the third time in four years. The court heard that he had been disqualified from driving in November 1996 and had received two fixed penalties since getting his licence back.

Julie Allott, defending, said Gant had panicked after the accident and had been traumatised after the tragedy. He told police he had slowed down and tried to avoid Mr Rogala, who was on his way to a Jehovah's Witness meeting, but hit him when the pensioner started to run across the road.

"I was crying out for my dad. I did not know what to do. I carried on driving." He had felt something on his shoulder but dared not look until he reached the pub, more than two miles away, where he "totally freaked out".

The magistrates adjourned the case for three weeks for pre-sentence reports.

fields.headline: 'Complacent' employers accused over pay inequality
fields.trailText: Employers were yesterday accused by the equal opportunities commission of being "shockingly complacent" over continuing large scale pay inequality, after it released evidence of widespread discrimination against women across the workforce.
fields.body:
Employers were yesterday accused by the equal opportunities commission of being "shockingly complacent" over continuing large scale pay inequality, after it released evidence of widespread discrimination against women across the workforce.

An EOC survey of 300-plus large employers found that women were commonly denied access to bonuses and performance-related pay, while more than 10% reported that part time employees, mainly women, were illegally excluded from pension schemes. The hourly earnings of women were, on average, 18% lower than those of men, but the weekly and annual gap was around 26% because of the effect of discrimination over pensions, bonuses and performance-related pay.

The EOC report found that manufacturing industry had a worse record than the public sector or private services of failing to take action over gender pay inequality, while at the same time manufacturing employers were by far the most confident that their pay systems were fair.

"Many employers are simply burying their heads in the sand," the EOC chairwoman, Julie Mellor, said yesterday. "Employers have a major role in eliminating pay discrimination and manufacturing organisations in particular are not doing enough to ensure they are paying women fairly."

The CBI, the main employers' organisation, last night hit back at the criticism, insisting there was little evidence to suggest most firms were operating unfair pay structures.

"There is a pay gap, but the reasons for it are much more complex than simple direct discrimination," Susan Anderson, the director of CBI human resources policy, said. "Research shows the key cause of the pay gap is occupational segregation - women are more likely to work in lower paying sectors."

But Ms Mellor countered that studies at the London School of Economics and for the Economic and Social Research Council had found that up to a half of the earnings gap between women and men could be attributed to pay discrimination at work, rather than job segregation.

She added that employers needed to reassess why jobs carried out mainly by women were often worse paid than those done by men. The report found that many human resources managers in manufacturing industry regarded male-dominated professional, technical and skilled manual jobs as having "greater intrinsic value" than female-dominated support and administrative jobs.

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Hunstanton, Norfolk
fields.trailText: Hunstanton, Norfolk.
fields.body:
It is a measure of the rate of collapse that there are now three lines of fencing around the top of the town's crumbly chalk cliffs, and some sections of the outermost fence are now suspended in mid-air. Not that these erosion problems trouble the fulmars that nest on the cliff ledges.

Although there are still five months before the birds begin to breed, they are already back at their nesting site. They planed back and forth across the chalky face as if in readiness for the long-awaited event, only the falling snow a perfect match for the purged white of their undersides. Otherwise this was an intensely drab scene.

The sea sloshed below us the colour of molten lead, and receded imperceptibly into the bruised blue-grey of the sky. The dense snowfall reduced our vision to a fuzzy monochrome, like the broken reception on an old black-and-white television.

In these conditions we could just make out a loose flock of birds floating steadily beyond the tide edge. They were red-breasted mergansers, the males of one of our most attractive winter duck, whose outstanding feature is a shaggy crest which looks like one of those hair spikes that just won't lie flat. Momentarily, as each bird surfaced from the murky shallows, the icy water slicked down those glossy green heads. Then back sprang the unkempt tufts. Each time a bird rose to the surface it also sent out a brief ripple across the gel-like slush that formed temporarily on the water's surface. Little by little all twenty birds drifted away until they were swallowed finally by the dark blur of sea and snow.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Edward Scissorhands | Peggy Sue Got Married | Black Rain | Bram Stoker's Dracula
fields.body:
Edward Scissorhands

(Tim Burton, 1990)

4pm, 10.20pm, Sky Premier

Funny-peculiar fantasy from the fertile mind of Tim Burton. This is in the modern fairy-tale style of Beetlejuice, with Johnny Depp (pictured) as the strange, black-clad Edward, created by barmy Vincent Price and left with large scissors where his hands should be. For a time he's sheer delight for suburban woman Dianne Wiest and daughter Winona Ryder - until he's finally obliged to cut up rough.

Peggy Sue Got Married

(Francis Coppola, 1986)

9pm, Living

Kathleen Turner is captivating in this testing dual role: first as a fortyish wife unhappy with her lot in general, and dud spouse Nicolas Cage in particular; then, having fainted at a high-school reunion, returning to the fresh-faced picture of near innocence she was, circa 1960. Given the opportunity of a second time around, she makes out with the lad she admired from afar, helps Dad out of financial trouble and addresses the problem of the slick-haired teenage rebel who will become her husband: a charming, wistful comedy.

Black Rain

(Ridley Scott, 1989)

11pm, 3am, Bravo

Stylish culture-clash thriller with maverick American cops rampant in Japan. Michael Douglas gets vengeful when buddy Andy Garcia loses his head, and joins forces with by-the-book local detective Ken Takakura - who, naturally, learns to play the all-American way. All very stereotypical, and with a misfiring mud-and-blood finale at odds with the clean-cut, gleaming mayhem that precedes it.

Bram Stoker's Dracula

(Francis Ford Coppola, 1992)

2.10am, FilmFour

Coppola reads the great gothic tale as a grand amour: in the blood-weltered Middle Ages, Gary Oldman's grieving Dracula condemns himself to the undead when his woman dies. He exists in torment for centuries until, in London, he discovers her living image in Winona Ryder's beautiful Elisabeta. Visually ravishing, it is powered by Oldman's amazing performance as a love-mad, merciless beast. Anthony Hopkins plays vampire slayer Van Helsing, Keanu Reeves as Jonathan Harker.

webTitle: Self-help books are worse than useless

fields.headline: Hearts and minds
fields.standfirst: Self-help books have become hugely popular in recent years. And now television is getting in on the act. But, says Ben Marshall , Channel 4's Living By The Book proves what he's always suspected: that the whole genre is worse than useless
fields.trailText: Self-help books have become hugely popular in recent years. And now television is getting in on the act. But, says Ben Marshall , Channel 4's Living By The Book proves what he's always suspected: that the whole genre is worse than useless.
fields.body:
In Britain the constituency for self-help is mercifully small, mostly made up of wildly insecure pop stars and Bridget Jones-style divorcees. In America, however, if you really want to help yourself, you write a book nominally designed to help others. Self-help manuals are a multi-million dollar industry in the US. Thus Channel 4's decision to get a few amiable British guinea pigs to road-test some of the best-selling American titles is a good one.

I should point out at this stage that the only book I have ever put to a practical test is Luke Rhinehart's novel, The Dice Man, in which the protagonist makes major life decisions based on the outcome of the roll of a dice. For me, it resulted in a brief bout of heroin abuse and the loss of my job. The series Living By The Book, though, opens by trying out an ostensibly more constructive book, The Rules, the dating manual for women. But if the programme is anything to go by, The Rules' influence is just as pernicious as Rhinehart's fiction.

Basically, it consists of 35 instructions that, its authors emphasise, cannot be cherry-picked and must be followed to the letter. Here are a few choice examples: "Never accept a Saturday-night date after Wednesday", "Never let a phone call last longer than 10 minutes", "Always end the phone call yourself", and "Be a creature unlike any other." This last one, elusive to say the least, involves moving around the room "like a movie star" until men "flock to your side". Like all the other rules in The Rules it obviously works best if you look like a movie star, or better still are one.

Playing hard to get is all very well, but its success does largely depend upon the fact that people want you in the first place. However, the book's authors, Ellen Fein and Sherrie Schneider, like to pretend that their book will work as well for an Ann Widdecombe as it might do for a Julia Roberts.

As the two writers watch the Brits putting their book into practice they provide a weird, cruelly critical running commentary on everything the girls are getting wrong. These sentiments, expressed by Ellen and Sherrie with a mixture of half-baked, homespun whimsy and barely contained fury, lead you to suspect that if the Doris Day Fan Club has a paramilitary wing they are it.

Pretty much everything that is wrong with self-help is writ large in the appalled scowls of these two appalling people.

The Rules, like almost every other book of its kind, relies on high hopes and false promises. The first ever self-help book was How To Win Friends And Influence People. The book promised to change its readers' lives. These words have since become the rallying call for the whole self-help industry. It was basically a get-rich-quick guide and it certainly worked for its author, Dale Carnegie, who became a millionaire overnight at the height of the American Great Depression teaching people how to make new buddies and exploit them.

Since then the self-help industry has mushroomed. It was the 80s, though, that determined the present tone of the self-help manual.

Now they deal in everything from finding the ideal man/woman, through putting on the perfect party, to curing yourself of cancer. All of them adopt the same crypto-Thatcherite approach by taking credit for their readers' successes and blaming them for their failures.

Sex and cigarettes (how to get the former and dump the latter) are the main and most profitable areas in this seemingly limitless self-help racket, to the extent that advertisements for books on how to kick nicotine addiction are commonplace on pornographic internet sites and newsgroups.

American market research suggests that any house with a reasonably sized book collection will either bulge at the seams with self-help manuals or contain none at all. Surely it is only a matter of time before the same market research identifies self-help books as a dangerous addiction. We may then look forward to the global best seller, How To Kick Self-Help Manuals And Stand On Your Own Two Feet. Naturally the advocates of self-help argue that it is preferable to other forms of help, say government assistance, because it ends up costing the rest of us nothing. This, of course ignores the baleful influence these luridly worded tomes have on their readers and their readers have on the rest of us.

Karen, who begins the documentary as a nice and generous woman, ends it as a confused monomaniac. The target of her affections, Dave, takes to her sudden Jekyll and Hyde impersonation like a goat takes to water. Ellen and Sherrie just carry on scowling. Eventually I was reminded of Paul Hogan in Crocodile Dundee, who when told that an acquaintance was seeing a therapist remarked, "Hasn't he got any mates?" In Britain we still have mates. Come to think of it, didn't we invent the word?

 Living By The Book, Wednesday, 9pm, C4

fields.headline: True confessions
fields.trailText: I hate Sex And The City. Or that's what I told myself during its last series as I sat transfixed throughout the entire thing.
fields.body:
I hate Sex And The City. Or that's what I told myself during its last series as I sat transfixed throughout the entire thing. Desperately, I tried to convince myself that I most certainly did not savour the witty banter of gorgeous Manhattanites in stunning frocks, all the while looking over my shoulder to make sure no one found me indulging my dirty little secret. Because Sex And The City is vapid, shallow, post-feminist nonsense. Except, of course, it's not. It's clever, entertaining, post-feminist nonsense.

Which is how it became my downfall. Thanks to some cunning, post-ER Wednesday night scheduling on the part of Channel 4, I suddenly found the show I happily dismissed first time round was not what I imagined it to be at all. Yes, sex-columnist Carrie, gallery-owner Charlotte, lawyer Miranda and PR queen Samantha all totter about in fabulous outfits, have exquisite apartments and seemingly perfect lives. But it's not all blowjobs and Prada shoes (although, admittedly, both feature prominently).

At first I justified my watching S&TC by classifying it as an anthropological study; a wildlife documentary with more expensive fur. Then I graduated to seeing it as a soap opera. Then, as the weeks went by, and I found myself wondering whether Carrie and Mr Big would ever work it out, and why the others couldn't find happiness despite their swanky duds and sexual empowerment, I found the real reason for my passion. Sex And The City has female protagonists who, rather than being role-models, are honest-to-goodness characters . They have good points and bad, and any number of flaws, hang-ups and idiosyncracies (as well as killer bodies and great hair). And Sex And The City, like all great drama, manages to make the specific problems of its heroines into something that strikes a universal chord. So, yes, I'll admit it. I don't hate Sex And The City. Not at all. But, please, somebody shoot me if I start taking an interest in Ally McBeal.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Taking A Stand | Performance On 3
fields.body:
Last year's international gathering to discuss the world Aids crisis was startled by a fierce attack on the host for his refusal to acknowledge the realities of the disease. The denunciation of President Thabo Mbeki came from one of his own judges, Justice Edward Cameron of the South African supreme court. In Taking A Stand (9.0am, Radio 4) the judge explains to Fergal Keane why, with 20 per cent of his countrymen now affected, he felt obliged to take such a dramatic stand.

At the turn of the last century, Bechstein, the piano makers, commissioned a new London concert hall from Thomas Collcutt, who designed a mock-Renais sance number costing £100,000. In 1915 anti-German feeling saw the Bechstein Hall sold for a knockdown price and re-opened as the Wigmore Hall. Performance On 3 (7.30pm, Radio 3) offers the first of several centenary concerts, this one concentrating on works receiving their first performance at the hall.

fields.headline: The night stuff
fields.standfirst: When she has insomnia, Louise Bourgeois doesn't count sheep - she draws them. Jonathan Jones visits her new installation at Tate Modern
fields.trailText: When she has insomnia, Louise Bourgeois doesn't count sheep - she draws them. Jonathan Jones visits her new installation at Tate Modern.
fields.body:
'Look, that one's called Footprint," says Dad to Son. He's pointing at a footprint on the floor. Oh yes, you can hear all the old jokes at Tate Modern on a Sunday afternoon. So the decision to exhibit Louise Bourgeois's provocatively artless Insomnia drawings seems bloody-minded. "A effing kid could have done that," a teenager pronounces.

Tate Modern has shuffled its displays, getting rid of some of the less successful juxtapositions to make way for new surprises. By far the most fascinating is a room hung with the drawings Bourgeois makes when she can't sleep.

Insomnia is a terrible affliction: the hypersensitivity to sounds in remote parts of the home, the gloomy but precise outlines of objects, the clock saying 3am. Bourgeois, the great US-based artist, born in France in 1911, puts the light on and doodles. This series of drawings was produced during endless nights between November 1994 and June 1995.

Where is the signature of genius? Drawing is the most personal art and great artists supposedly have a distinctive drawing style. Picasso was Picasso even in his doodles. But Bourgeois does not draw in a style. She makes no attempt in these nocturnal meanderings to distinguish herself as an artist, to make art. Eventually you do notice the subtlety with which she wields a Biro. But these sketches look like what they are - spontaneous, automatic productions of a mind delirious from lack of sleep, done in felt pen, pencil, on lined foolscap, music manuscript paper, whatever comes to hand.

Here's a woman with her legs apart, above a sketch of a sheep. "Santé mouton," Bourgeois has written underneath. In another, women's faces and breasts overlap so that one woman has eyes for nipples, a mouth in her tummy.

A cat appears, holding a high-heeled shoe in its mouth. Houses are swirled up in a tornado. The sphere keeps coming into her mind in drawings of trees, dandelion clocks and interlocking geometric circles. She makes her circles by frantically going round and round with a ball-point pen.

There are tunnels that appear to be made of hair. The number six is repeated. In two very sinister pictures, a guillotine stands next to a double bed, and men operate what looks like a medieval torture instrument by turning a crank to move a giant saw-blade.

These drawings resemble the compulsive sketching of mental patients celebrated in the 20th century as art brut. Not that Bourgeois is mad, but she has managed to strip away the protecting veils of fine art so that she seems to draw as directly as a child or someone with no awareness of art and its rules. She does not put up any defences of irony or erudition. This is her waking dream life spilling out, the agony of insomnia crystallising into images, the terrible thoughts that won't go away.

Elsewhere Bourgeois has exhibited photographs of her father working in the French countryside in the early 20th century. "I had gone back with my children to see the house where I had grown up and where the river Bièvre flowed through the back yard," she says. "But the river was gone. Only the trees that my father had planted along its edge remained as a witness."

These are the trees that recur in her drawings, in one sketch reflected in the river that no longer exists. Then in one of the photographs you see a lock gate whose mechanism incorporates a frightening, vertical saw-like gear, its teeth black and sharp in the wintry light: the one in her drawing. This device
