webTitle: The rise of the female sports commentator

fields.headline: Girls with balls
fields.standfirst: A rugby player fronting a sports show may not sound like news - but this one's a woman. Julie Welch reports on the rise and rise of the female commentator
fields.trailText: A rugby player fronting a sports show may not sound like news - but this one's a woman.  Julie Welch  reports on the rise and rise of the female commentator.
fields.body:
On the face of it, it's an unbeatable combination. Take the two main focuses of male desire and obsession - sport and girls - and package them as that very modern commodity, the female sports presenter. And these days she is unavoidable. Gabby Yorath fronts ITV's football coverage, Kelly Dalglish and Kirsty Gallacher take the field for Sky, while at the BBC, Sue Barker long ago transcended such piffling issues as gender to become the reigning monarch of televised sport.

Even rugby, the boys' last bastion, is not exempt from the onward march of the monstrous regiment. The latest face of the sport is Kathleen Wood, a former Sky sports reporter currently on the showbiz beat for GMTV. On Saturday, she will start fronting Scotsport Rugby Roundup, STV's new weekly show on Scottish rugby, which she hopes will boost the flagging spirits of the sport.

While Kirsty Gallacher famously posed for Maxim magazine last month, one can assume there's little chance of Wood appearing minimally clad in the pages of a lads mag, especially not in the foreseeable future as she is eight months pregnant. When she heard the job was up for grabs three weeks ago, she had just begun maternity leave from GMTV. "I thought, damn, what bad timing. But when I spoke to the people at STV, they said, yeah, yeah, it's the most natural thing in the world. It was pats on the back and good on you, you've got the balls to do it."

In fact, "ballsy" is the word that springs to mind when you think of Wood. During her stint on the sports beat for Sky, she consistently impressed with her passion, knowledge and sheer authenticity. Now 30, she was raised in Edinburgh where, with rugby-playing brothers and a father who was a club vice president, "I spent a lot of time down rugby clubs when I was little".

In fact, the STV job has particular resonance for Wood because of her father, who died in a car crash when she was 13. "One reason I threw my hat in the ring when the job came up was him. His life was rugby. Last week, when I was doing the photocall, two photographers came up and said: 'I knew your dad.' You feel very proud, but it tugs at your heartstrings. I wish Dad was here."

She has also played the game herself, captaining a women's team at the local rugby club while living in Hong Kong, where she worked for a sports television channel and met her husband, Phil Morris, who was captain of the men's team. Playing a sport, she says, gives you an edge, an instinctive understanding. "I also think if you're passionate and enthusiastic about it, that helps make you believable. I'm quite an excitable character and you can relay that into sport more than into news."

She is honest enough, however, to concede defeat in one department. "Boys have this thing for stats," she says. "Real markers in rugby I can remember, but if someone turned round and asked me about something that happened in 1953, I wouldn't be able to answer."

Despite the fact that Wood is an attractive woman, it's obvious she got the job because she is a highly competent broadcaster, not because she is a pretty face or the daughter of a famous sportsman (like Kirsty Gallacher, daughter of Bernard, and Kelly Dalglish, Kenny's daughter). It's here that BBC sports presenter and reporter Eleanor Oldroyd thinks there is a definite difference.

"There is a distinction between the kind of girls who appear on Sky and the more serious kind of presenter," says Oldroyd, coincidentally also pregnant. "Kirsty Gallacher is lovely, stunning and a very nice girl, but she wouldn't be about to present Grandstand in the imminent future and wouldn't want to. I went to the Professional Football Association dinner last year and sat next to Kirsty, Kelly and Clare Tomlinson and thought, what the hell am I doing here? I felt like Kirsty's maiden aunt. There were all these young footballers, jaws dropping with lust for her."

But isn't it rather insulting to men to assume that the only way they'll be lured in to view is to stick a looker on camera? "I wouldn't criticise that group of girls," Oldroyd says. "They're bright and they're there to make it more glamorous and sexy. But there is a question about where you go afterward - their career progression is not so clearly defined."

Wood agrees. "Even now, some producers might think, 'Oh, a pretty face, we'll adapt her to make a sports reporter.' But you're up against it. If you don't know what you're talking about, you have to be heavily produced and with continuing staff cuts, there are fewer producers and researchers to lean on and you'll be found out."

It's nice to look at someone attractive on TV, she adds. "It's a bit annoying when someone gets a job through looks, not knowledge, but most men now don't have the balls to say women don't know what they're talking about, because women do."

Enough for women to make serious advances in commentating as well as reporting and presenting? Wood is not completely convinced. "Listening to a girl commentate is a bit difficult. Sport is a man's world still. You just don't get the mad following in female sport, though times are changing. I think it's the masculinity - men have all the testosterone. I much prefer to watch men play. When you see top level rugby, it's terrific - you see women play and it grates a wee bit. And I play it."

Oldroyd makes a similar distinction. "It depends on your role. I suspect having Kirsty or Kelly presenting is less threatening than a woman going to report. Women are OK as long as they're not giving an opinion. But I think the resistance is dwindling."

What of the future? Scottish TV have signed Wood until April; in August she heads back to GMTV. Meanwhile, Oldroyd thinks the fad for employing women in sport just because they're female has passed. "Four years ago, it was a way of getting into TV presenting and a number of the girls who were prominent then have gone on to do other things in TV, but not sport. I think we're past the boom of bimbos for the sake of it."

fields.headline: Side lines
fields.trailText: Where, dear readers, will this naked calendar nonsense end? Since those dimply WI dames surfed the stripping zeitgeist two years ago, the populace has discovered a hitherto untapped exhibitionist streak which, frankly, was better kept under wraps.
fields.body:
Where, dear readers, will this naked calendar nonsense end? Since those dimply WI dames surfed the stripping zeitgeist two years ago, the populace has discovered a hitherto untapped exhibitionist streak which, frankly, was better kept under wraps. Lifeboatmen, hunts people, women's rugby teams have all unblushingly seized the opportunity for month-mediated exposure. Meanwhile, the rest of us operate a strange sort of prudery where flesh is only fine if it's (a) advertising something entirely unconnected or (b) Just a Bit of Fun. That "all for a good cause" line never fooled us - nor the Irish clergy, it would seem. A charity calendar featuring a naked priest has just been shelved at the behest of the Bishop of Galway, who described it as "inappropriate". The offending item including a shot of 27-year-old Friar Olan Ryan, wearing only his dog collar and the Bible. Reports did not specify whether it was the authorised or revised standard version.

One particular sin of the flesh has provided a rich seam for food writer Kevin Gould, who argues, in an article for Bare magazine, that regional variations in diet have a major impact on sweat. Thus those living by the Essex coast, where large quantities of fish and shellfish are consumed, smell of fish, while Scots, he insists, smell of goats. He also suggests that hair colour may influence body odour, stating: "Natural blondes tend to smell of amber and musk while brunettes smell of wild pansies." Sidelines must protest. It is a well-known fact that brunettes smell of delphiniums, and of blue gum-trees on Tuesdays. Scots, on the other hand, smell delicious all the time, though one accepts that it takes a particularly refined olfactory palate to appreciate the scent of Laphroig mixed with batter, with top notes of Irn-Bru.

What fresh ladies' outrage is this? Writing in the Mail on Sunday, Norman Tebbit fearlessly puts the question that has been on all our lips through the wee days of January: "Surely we don't want a feminist National Trust?" Tebbit is much exercised by the appointment of Fiona Reynolds, former head of the women's unit in the Cabinet Office, as the Trust's first female director. Her agenda of evolutionary change and increased accessibility doesn't fool him for a minute. Reynolds, he predicts, will make it another branch (geddit?) of the Labour party, and feminist to boot. And a burning bra in every stately home, no doubt.

Finally, advertisements we would rather see banned than that perfume one with S***** D***. Our eye was drawn to a billboard showing a woman's face appearing in the display of a mobile phone, with the catchline "ask me anything and I'll do it". How would you explain that to a three-year-old?

fields.headline: 'Byzantine' body delays police pay rise
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, wants to revamp police pay negotiations amid fury that an offer of an extra £2,000 a year to police in the home counties has been stalled for months by a "bureaucratic and byzantine" negotiating body.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, wants to revamp police pay negotiations amid fury that an offer of an extra £2,000 a year to police in the home counties has been stalled for months by a "bureaucratic and byzantine" negotiating body.

Mr Straw badly needs to retain and recruit police in the competitive labour market of the south east. The fall in police numbers since 1997 promises to be one of Labour's most vulnerable areas during the election campaign. The latest politically sensitive crime figures will be published next Tuesday.

Mr Straw has been accused of presiding over a 2,500 fall in police numbers since the election, but he has countered that his fund set aside to improve pay should ensure police numbers rise to over 130,000 by 2002.

Mr Straw learned in November that the police negotiating board had decided not to meet until late February to consider his offer of extra cash, five months after it was initially tabled by the Home Office.

The board has now agreed to bring forward the meeting to January 22. The home secretary is incredulous that pay is settled by negotiations involving a 95-member negotiating body representing the Police Federation and various chief constables across Britain. All 95 are entitled to claim expenses but only four are entitled to speak.

Mr Straw has criticised the body as "bureaucratic and byzantine". He wants its constitution revised and the body drastically reduced in size. Increased pressure for action on police pay follows signs that the recruitment drive in the home counties is receiving only patchy results.

The Liberal Democrat MP for Newbury, David Rendel, claimed that Thames Valley police had received only eight applications to join the force following the national recruitment campaign.

webTitle: Commons debates new enforcement powers for MoD police

fields.headline: Commons debates new enforcement powers for MoD police
fields.trailText: Thousands of Ministry of Defence police will be given law enforcement powers normally carried out by local forces under a bill to be debated by MPs today.
fields.body:
Thousands of Ministry of Defence police will be given law enforcement powers normally carried out by local forces under a bill to be debated by MPs today.

The armed forces bill will enable MoD police officers to intervene directly in what a spokesman described yesterday as incidents outside military bases.

At present MoD police have jurisdiction inside or "in the vicinity" of bases, including US bases. Elsewhere they have to seek the permission of local police forces before intervening.

An MoD police spokesman said yesterday that the new powers would be limited to "life threatening" situations. What constitutes such an incident would be up the judgment of individual police officers. The move comes at a time of growing concern about the fall in number of police officers in rural areas, though the MoD insisted the issues were not connected.

Many MoD police carry 9mm Browning pistols. Those guarding bases containing nuclear weapons or nuclear reactors carry rifles or shotguns.

A spokesman cited Salisbury Plain, East Anglia and such garrison towns as Colchester in Essex as areas where the MoD police could use their new powers.

webTitle: Metro masseurs ease Paris to work with a smile

fields.headline: Metro masseurs ease Paris to work with a smile
fields.trailText: It was back to work for most of the Paris Metro's 4.4m famously ill-tempered daily passengers yesterday, but the regional transport authority, RATP, was doing its best to relieve post-holiday tension: a soothing cup of green tea and a relaxing massage awaited all those who wanted them.
fields.body:
It was back to work for most of the Paris Metro's 4.4m famously ill-tempered daily passengers yesterday, but the regional transport authority, RATP, was doing its best to relieve post-holiday tension: a soothing cup of green tea and a relaxing massage awaited all those who wanted them.

"It's the third millennium," a series of psychedelic posters announced across the network yesterday. "Time to approach life differently, to look around, to communicate. Let's dream, let's smile, let's relax, let's love ... Join us for massage and tea-tasting. Together, let's make city rhyme with stress-free."

A spokesman for RATP, whose past attempts to cosset its passengers have included perfumed passageways and classical music on the platforms, said the offer was intended as "a temporary New Year's present" from the authority to its customers, but it was proving so popular that the initiative might be extended.

"It's only the first day and our four relaxation centres are all over-run," he said. "I don't think there's any doubt that this really appeals to Parisians. They're always complaining that they're frantic and over-stretched and hassled. We're giving them the opportunity to keep cool."

The massage service is available from noon to 6pm at Miromesnil, Republique, Gare-de-Lyon and Massy-Palaiseau stations.

At the busy Republique station, New Age music was playing as tetchy travellers were offered a special blend of oriental green tea, - "soothing and refreshing for both body and mind" - revitalising algae-based biscuits, a 10-minute massage, and The Pocket Guide to Serenity, a small booklet of tips on zen and the art of taking the Metro.

"Create a natural defence," was one suggestion. "Smile! Had a nasty argument? Smile! Things not turning out as they should? Smile! A smile creates the distance that will stop you being affected, keep you cool and ensure stress does not entirely invade you."

Nearby, to the accompaniment of calming New Age music, teams of masseurs were pummelling hands, legs, backs, necks and scalps in 10-minute sessions aimed at "re-energising, re-focusing and re-invigorating through rapid, rhythmic manipulation".

Judging by the long line of commuters waiting to be manhandled yesterday, the RATP had succeeded. Even the security guards, having failed to move the crowd along, gave up and joined the queue, complaining loudly of aching shoulders and strained backs.

"You need number five," Christophe Basile, one of the masseurs, told them. "That's a more physical treatment. Massages one to four are more about clearing muggy heads."

Only Hervé, 46, a contract lawyer, was unimpressed. "You might feel great afterwards," he said, rubbing his neck. "But I'd feel greater if the service on line 9 wasn't cut every time the driver had a headache."
fields.bodyText: It was back to work for most of the Paris Metro's 4.4m famously ill-tempered daily passengers yesterday, but the regional transport authority, RATP, was doing its best to relieve post-holiday tension: a soothing cup of green tea and a relaxing massage awaited all those who wanted them. "It's the third millennium," a series of psychedelic posters announced across the network yesterday. "Time to approach life differently, to look around, to communicate. Let's dream, let's smile, let's relax, let's love ... Join us for massage and tea-tasting. Together, let's make city rhyme with stress-free." A spokesman for RATP, whose past attempts to cosset its passengers have included perfumed passageways and classical music on the platforms, said the offer was intended as "a temporary New Year's present" from the authority to its customers, but it was proving so popular that the initiative might be extended. "It's only the first day and our four relaxation centres are all over-run," he said. "I don't think there's any doubt that this really appeals to Parisians. They're always complaining that they're frantic and over-stretched and hassled. We're giving them the opportunity to keep cool." The massage service is available from noon to 6pm at Miromesnil, Republique, Gare-de-Lyon and Massy-Palaiseau stations. At the busy Republique station, New Age music was playing as tetchy travellers were offered a special blend of oriental green tea, - "soothing and refreshing for both body and mind" - revitalising algae-based biscuits, a 10-minute massage, and The Pocket Guide to Serenity, a small booklet of tips on zen and the art of taking the Metro. "Create a natural defence," was one suggestion. "Smile! Had a nasty argument? Smile! Things not turning out as they should? Smile! A smile creates the distance that will stop you being affected, keep you cool and ensure stress does not entirely invade you." Nearby, to the accompaniment of calming New Age music, teams of masseurs were pummelling hands, legs, backs, necks and scalps in 10-minute sessions aimed at "re-energising, re-focusing and re-invigorating through rapid, rhythmic manipulation". Judging by the long line of commuters waiting to be manhandled yesterday, the RATP had succeeded. Even the security guards, having failed to move the crowd along, gave up and joined the queue, complaining loudly of aching shoulders and strained backs. "You need number five," Christophe Basile, one of the masseurs, told them. "That's a more physical treatment. Massages one to four are more about clearing muggy heads." Only Hervé, 46, a contract lawyer, was unimpressed. "You might feel great afterwards," he said, rubbing his neck. "But I'd feel greater if the service on line 9 wasn't cut every time the driver had a headache."

fields.headline: When a house becomes a home
fields.standfirst: Hogwarts-style halls help Britain's biggest school manage, says Amy Cox
fields.trailText: Hogwarts-style halls help Britain's biggest school manage, says Amy Cox
fields.body:
Gryffindor, Ravenclaw, Slytherin and Hufflepuff: the idea of having "houses" within schools is a tradition that lives on at Hogwarts, where Harry Potter is the star of Gryffindor. But Stantonbury Campus in Milton Keynes has a more modern take on the idea of setting up smaller units within a large group of pupils.

Stantonbury is the largest comprehensive school in Britain, with more than 2,600 pupils. To ensure the greatest effectiveness, the students are divided into separate "halls" on the main campus site. The four halls for students aged between 12 and 16 are called Dansteed, Grafton, Portway and Saxon; each contains around 500 pupils, has around 30 staff, and its own Head of Hall. Post-16 students have their own facilities in Cooksey Hall.

This works extremely well, says John Wilkins, one of Stantonbury's two co-directors - or joint head teachers. "People think of it as a house system, but it's not some kind of artificial construct or notional thing - each hall is a building, an actual space where the students work."

The hall system was established at Stantonbury in 1988. "We felt at the time that as the largest school in the country we had to think carefully what structures were most appropriate," says Wilkins. "Our most important focal group was the students, and we felt they needed an academic and social base."

Dividing the pupils into smaller groups gives them more security, the opportunity for more individual attention and challenges and the feeling that they are not just a face in a very large crowd.

It also helps that, except in more specialised subjects, the teachers stay with one hall throughout their time at the school. It means that everyone can get to know everyone else - by sight at least.

Halls, says Wilkins, are an integral part of the way the school works. "We have an informal ethos, we are an organisation that works without obvious hierarchy," he explains.

"There is an openness in relationships throughout the school from the youngest student to the sixth form, from a part-time cleaner to the directors. The hall structure is an element of that - we make reference points smaller than the whole institution so good, effective, harmonious relationships can develop."

The benefits of being part of a hall are bolstered by a carefully-structured tutor system. Each pupil in each hall's new intake is assigned to a form tutor, who will take a special interest in them throughout their school career.

To reinforce the relationship, the year eight pupils also have a three-day residential course with their tutors during their first term at the school to allow tutors and students to get to know each other better. "The tutors are the first contact with parents and have an overview right across the student's work," says Wilkins.

"Wherever possible, the tutor stays with their tutor group throughout the next four years. Our year 11 pupils mostly have the same tutor groups that they had when they first came to the school."

Achieving a smaller scale within a large institution helps students find their feet and feel they are not just a small part of an anonymous mass. But at the same time, Stantonbury can make its size work for it. The space and resources available mean that the school has particularly good facilities for sports and the arts - in fact, it is a specialist arts college. The Stantonbury Campus Leisure Centre is run as a joint-use facility and as well as being used by local schools and sports clubs is the main focus for competitive swimming in the area. It has a professionally equipped theatre, and the Milton Keynes Music Service is also based on the campus.

Stantonbury's most recent Ofsted report, carried out last November, noted its large size and praised the school's academic attainment as well as its student support schemes and extra-curricular activities.

Stantonbury serves the full ability range, but the average CAT score at intake is below average; these pupils, notes the Ofsted report, gain ground, especially in the first two years.

"We believe very strongly that what we do in terms of school organisation and ethos should be judged in terms of success," says Wilkins. "First of all, that means exam results. But it also means the development of the whole person, and how they are prepared for adult life."

fields.headline: It could be you
fields.standfirst: You won't get a bean and the workload is serious. But if you fancy a spell as a governor, now you'll have a helpline and, if you're Welsh, a training centre.  Phil Revell  reports
fields.trailText: You won't get a bean and the workload is serious. But if you fancy a spell as a governor, now you'll have a helpline and, if you're Welsh, a training centre. Phil Revell reports
fields.body:
Post vacant. Duties include: responsibility for multi-million pound budgets; premises management; health and safety; appointment of staff; public relations; implementation of government legislation; quality control. Must have knowledge of: child nutrition; employment law; the school curriculum. Workload: heavy; hours: unlimited; salary: zilch.

Who'd be a governor? Not many people, it seems. Alongside the much-publicised teacher shortage, Britain's schools also face difficulties recruiting governors.

Sarah Miller is a parent governor at Crowland Primary School in Tottenham, north London. In a typical year her governing body will deal with 81 major items of business. Miller chairs the personnel subcommittee. "That involves interviewing and staff disciplinary issues," she explains, "along with things like the overall pay policy and equal opportunities. This year it involved the arrangements for performance-related pay."

Workload is cited by many governors as their biggest bugbear, making recruitment difficult and directing some towards an early exit.

"We've had two chairs in the past year and we have two current vacancies for parent governors," says Philip Naylo, who is a governor at Northumberland Park in Haringey, London.

It's a problem the government is well aware of. A DfEE-funded helpline, Governorline, is launched today to provide more support for the country's largest volunteer workforce. In Wales, a separate helpline will open later this year, whilst a new training centre at Swansea University aims to give the principality's governing bodies better preparation.

There are 370,000 unpaid governors, who can be parents, teachers, non-teaching staff (secretaries or classroom assistants), local education authority appointees, foundation governors or co-opted members. The exact make-up depends on the type of school, and governing bodies can include anything up to 29 people.

Governorline will provide advice for governors on a range of issues. Run by TBF, the teacher support network, which also operates the Teacher Line counselling service, it has recruited existing school governors to field the thousands of calls it expects to receive.

"Governors have responsibilities that require considerable skills and expertise," says Chris Gale, chair of the National Governors Council (NGC), which is supporting the helpline. "Governorline will provide the support and advice governors deserve."

Many of the early calls are likely to concern the current consultation process on the role of school governors. The government's consultation document proposes a raft of measures to cut workloads and reduce the potential for disputes between headteachers and governing bodies.

There has been a steady flow of high profile bust-ups in recent years, with Home Secretary Jack Straw entangled in a dispute at Pimlico School where he was a governor. Head teacher Marjorie Evans remains suspended from St Mary's Junior School in Monmouthshire, despite being cleared of assaulting a pupil. Governors insist that allegations of ill-treatment should be investigated further. The NUT have described their stance as "irrational".

Heads have long argued that governors' powers need to be cut back, and the government appear to have heeded the call. The consultation document includes proposals to simplify their duties, create smaller governing bodies, improve training and transfer some key executive powers to heads.

"I would give the government high marks for this document," says David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers. "It will go a long way towards ensuring that governors adopt a strategic role, that they concentrate their minds on the big things, leaving the management of the school to the chief executive - the head."

But Joan Sallis, the respected TES columnist who writes on governor affairs, isn't so keen. "I dislike these proposals," she told the Guardian. "Workload is a red herring. Any governor would agree that we have too much work to do, but we didn't ask for our powers to be taken away."

Sallis is particularly concerned about proposals to increase heads' powers over staff appointments. "It's a bit scary to be responsible in law but to have no input to the actual process. If something irregular happens it's governors who carry the can."

These worries aren't shared by the NGC's Chris Gale, who gives the proposals "a broad welcome". But she does see room for improvement. "I'd like to see more business governors. The chancellor could make the job much more attractive by giving tax incentives to firms who release staff."

John Carson, who sits on two governing bodies in Stockton-on-Tees, agrees that much of what the government proposes makes good sense.

"In my view governors should not be managers," he says. "They may want to be - many do want to interview staff, review budgets and oversee premises - but that needs to be left to the school management team. Take appointments: if heads can't do this on their own, are they the right person to be in the post?"

The Phoenix School in Telford serves as an example of the challenges that can face governing bodies. In May 1998 Ofsted delivered a damning verdict on the school. Inspectors identified five key issues for action - including governance. The school went into special measures and the head resigned.

The LEA's answer was to recruit three new governors. All were massively experienced in education. New chair Graham Clarke was the principal at the nearby sixth-form college, Doug Boynton was head of the local FE college and Graham Reedman had worked at chief officer level in educational administration.

"My question to the LEA was 'are you committed to supporting this school?'," recalls Clarke. The answer persuaded him to take on the job. "We had to grasp some nettles which many governing bodies are content to let slip."

The new governing body appointed John Sullivan as head. "In special measures speed is imperative," says Sullivan. "There were major cur riculum and personnel changes to be made. I appointed 14 new staff this September. With that kind of turnover governors had to trust my judgement. Where there were really serious decisions to be taken, they said 'Get on and make them'. They could have made life very difficult, especially in terms of the necessary redundancies." The new governing body organised itself into working groups to focus on the five key issues identified by Ofsted. Head and governors worked solidly for two years and, just before Christmas last year, the school came out of special measures. But couldn't an outstanding head have carried the school forward alone?

"There needs to be a check built into the system," insists Sullivan. "You have to be able to answer the question 'Why are you doing this?'"

"Without the governing body, who does the head work for?" asks Clarke. "The LEA? But they have a wider duty. It's the governing body which has one interest - this school, this staff, these pupils."

 Governorline: 08000 722 181 The free advice line is open seven days a week, from 9am to 10pm on weekdays and 11am to 4pm at weekends. See the DfEE consultation document at: www.dfee.gov.uk/governor/consult.htm

webTitle: If school is like a prison, will children behave like prisoners?

fields.headline: Space rage
fields.standfirst: If school is like a prison, will children behave like prisoners? There is a growing consensus that the built environment is crucial to classroom performance.  Gary Younge reports
fields.trailText: If school is like a prison, will children behave like prisoners? There is a growing consensus that the built environment is crucial to classroom performance. Gary Younge reports
fields.body:
The ringing of the bell at Kingsdale school in south London signals institutionalised pandemonium. A cram of pupils, full of high spirits, all trying, unsuccessfully, to squeeze through the same door at the same time; a troop of others bustle across a courtyard to assembly. A few slope off in different directions, like lost sheep hoping the shepherd won't round them up before they reach the gates. A thousand teenage bodies, countless raging hormones and just a few minutes to get to where they need to be.

Like most schools, every hour is rush hour at Kingsdale. The corridors are divided down the middle with a red line, like a dual carriageway, and there are arrows to direct the human traffic between lessons. But as in any rush hour, there are casualties.

The headteacher, Steve Morrison, says: "If you're trying to put 1,000 children through a five-foot corridor it's not going to work out whatever you do. Invariably there are going to be problems. When children get excluded it is almost always after something that happened in the corridors or in the dining area."

Like all public spaces, school buildings have their own internal, environmental logic. Things happen in a certain way because they always have. Question whether it makes sense for all lessons to start and finish at the same time or if children really need to be in school all day and the whole thing might unravel. So, like a family, the dsyfunctional becomes banal. Pockets of turf become renowned and reserved for particular types of behaviour.

Some have become apocryphal - the bike sheds for smoking and snogging, the toilets for fighting and bullying, the school gates for loitering, outside the headteacher's office for punishment. Others, such as corridors and staff rooms, hold a significance that is more practical than mythological. The aesthetic aggregate of all of these spaces is the school environment. And for all too many, it is a bleak one.

At a recent seminar, "Policy Framework for Schoolbuilding: a barrier to innovation", there were several tales of just how bad and badly built schools can be. The seminar, which brought together teachers, architects and designers, was sponsored by School Works, an Architecture Foundation project, in association with Demos.

One had an open-air bridge linking different buildings that could not be used when it rained; at another, unsupervised areas became so dangerous that teachers were equipped with rape alarms.

"Most school buildings have been designed with a 19th-century mindset," says Hilary Cottam, the project director of School Works, which concentrates on improving the school environment. "They don't take any account of how society has changed and just end up being a place to lock kids up during the day. If school looks like a prison and feels like a prison then the pupils will start acting as though they are in prison." Constraints on budgets are similarly restrictive. "The capital and maintenance budgets are separated, which makes long-term planning impossible," says Cottam.

Given all the other thorny issues surrounding education, the issue of building design may seem like a luxury. With low morale, performance-related pay, low recruitment, Ofsted and playground violence, architecture occupies a low priority for some. The last government, which invested virtually nothing in renovating schools, left almost two decades of wear, tear and disrepair. But when the present government announced that headteachers would get up to £30,000 to spend on urgent repairs, the general secretary of the National Association of School Masters/Union of Women Teachers, Nigel de Gruchy, gave it a backhanded welcome, wondering whether some money might have been kept back to help fund "the looming teachers' pay crisis".

But there is now a growing consensus that a school's built environment is central, not peripheral, to behaviour and performance in the classroom. "Even though there is nowhere near enough money, the fact that the government has even recognised the issue as a problem is significant," says Dominic Cullinan, who works with Makeover at School and has been a pioneer in this field.

The government has awarded Kingsdale £9m in order to renovate the school creatively and in keeping with designs arrived at through the School Works process. Nationwide, the government has also pledged £2bn in an investment programme this year. School Works, meanwhile, has been funded by the Department for Education to roll out its project nationally, producing a handbook for all schools about how they can adopt the process.

It is telling that there has been very little research done on the subject. What little research exists shows that where a participatory approach to school improvement has been undertaken there has been a reduction in truancy, vandalism, a greater sense of ownership and better behaviour.

At Kingsdale, which has more than its fair share of inner-city problems, Morrison believes the built environment touches too many other aspects to ignore. Sitting with his back to the CCTV camera scanning one of the corridors, he says: "There comes a stage where you think 'What have we not looked at?'. We are working on teaching and learning and staffing. We have looked at every other aspect of our working life apart from the place that we actually work in." Or as one student in Barnet put it: "Our school looks dull, old and scruffy and it makes us feel dull and boring."

Changing the environment will not put an end to deviant behaviour, insists Cottam. "If you dealt with the bike sheds then the gym might become the bike sheds. Some people will always overstep the mark and you cannot possibly police every space all the time." But what it could do is remove some of the reasons why so many children begin to overstep the mark.

Take storage space. A mixture of vandalism and expense has led many schools to do away with lockers where students can put things during the day. Where they did exist, pupils did not believe their belongings were safe and so stopped using them. Either way, lockers are becoming a thing of the past. Whatever you brought to school - PE kit, text books, coats - you had to carry around all day. In the end some children just stopped bringing things altogether. "Our backs ache, we can't take our coats off, we never arrive," said one student.

Playgrounds are dominated by sporty boys while girls and the unathletic cling to the sides. "There is no space for us, we don't really matter," said one girl.

Toilets are another problem area. Poor drainage, graffiti and filth make them no-go areas. But children still need to go to the toilet. At Kingsdale they started going home to use the loo. But then many of them wouldn't come back for the rest of the day.

And there are staff rooms. Teachers must now be one of the few graduate professions where most will never have their own desk, let alone an office, and where it remains almost impossible for someone to make an outside call or have someone contact them during the day.

While there are no easy solutions to all of these problems, some of them are far from incurable. Some require imagination. As they discovered at Kingsdale, in many subjects it makes more sense to move the teachers rather than the pupils. Some, like secure lockers and offices for staff, will cost money.

And most changes will require a mixture of both. In one school, each year group has been allocated its own toilet, which will remain its own until the pupils leave school. So if the toilets are trashed in year two, they will have to live with them for the remaining three or four years.

At a School Works seminar, one teacher raised the issue of how to keep a school secure without making it feel like a prison. One architect suggested that rather than fortifying the entire structure so that it appeared formidable, there could be an inviting "front of house" reception, as you would find in a bank, and a system for allowing certain people past a certain point.

With government money now committed, a number of changes are planned for Kingsdale, which range in scale and ambition. The plumbing in the toilets will be updated and the materials around the toilets changed to make them more resistant to vandalism. There will be just one common entrance to the school, which can be monitored, and then access around the school will be facilitated through the use of smart cards. Pupils will be able to log in and out, order their meals earlier in the day, thereby avoiding the crush during dinner time, and check equipment in and out.

Every child will have a locker, which will be located in a public place, making vandalism and theft more difficult. There will also be more passive surveillance with open-plan, transparent partitions and windows in doors, so that people can see and be seen, thereby eliminating some of the murkier corners where bullying or other misdemeanours might take place.

But more important than either, insists Cottam, is participation of the young people, teachers and support staff and the surrounding residents who will be using the school. There was an awayday for the teachers and support staff of Kingsdale, and workshops with children that incorporated dance, music and other artwork to actively involve children in imagining the school they would like to learn in. The result was a fairly overwhelming consensus as to what the problems were and some pointers as to how they might be put right. "If you don't consult with the people using it, then you are not likely to end up with something they feel part of or that meets their needs. A school must look inspirational and meet users' needs."

fields.bodyText: The ringing of the bell at Kingsdale school in south London signals institutionalised pandemonium. A cram of pupils, full of high spirits, all trying, unsuccessfully, to squeeze through the same door at the same time; a troop of others bustle across a courtyard to assembly. A few slope off in different directions, like lost sheep hoping the shepherd won't round them up before they reach the gates. A thousand teenage bodies, countless raging hormones and just a few minutes to get to where they need to be. Like most schools, every hour is rush hour at Kingsdale. The corridors are divided down the middle with a red line, like a dual carriageway, and there are arrows to direct the human traffic between lessons. But as in any rush hour, there are casualties. The headteacher, Steve Morrison, says: "If you're trying to put 1,000 children through a five-foot corridor it's not going to work out whatever you do. Invariably there are going to be problems. When children get excluded it is almost always after something that happened in the corridors or in the dining area." Like all public spaces, school buildings have their own internal, environmental logic. Things happen in a certain way because they always have. Question whether it makes sense for all lessons to start and finish at the same time or if children really need to be in school all day and the whole thing might unravel. So, like a family, the dsyfunctional becomes banal. Pockets of turf become renowned and reserved for particular types of behaviour. Some have become apocryphal - the bike sheds for smoking and snogging, the toilets for fighting and bullying, the school gates for loitering, outside the headteacher's office for punishment. Others, such as corridors and staff rooms, hold a significance that is more practical than mythological. The aesthetic aggregate of all of these spaces is the school environment. And for all too many, it is a bleak one. At a recent seminar, "Policy Framework for Schoolbuilding: a barrier to innovation", there were several tales of just how bad and badly built schools can be. The seminar, which brought together teachers, architects and designers, was sponsored by School Works, an Architecture Foundation project, in association with Demos. One had an open-air bridge linking different buildings that could not be used when it rained; at another, unsupervised areas became so dangerous that teachers were equipped with rape alarms. "Most school buildings have been designed with a 19th-century mindset," says Hilary Cottam, the project director of School Works, which concentrates on improving the school environment. "They don't take any account of how society has changed and just end up being a place to lock kids up during the day. If school looks like a prison and feels like a prison then the pupils will start acting as though they are in prison." Constraints on budgets are similarly restrictive. "The capital and maintenance budgets are separated, which makes long-term planning impossible," says Cottam. Given all the other thorny issues surrounding education, the issue of building design may seem like a luxury. With low morale, performance-related pay, low recruitment, Ofsted and playground violence, architecture occupies a low priority for some. The last government, which invested virtually nothing in renovating schools, left almost two decades of wear, tear and disrepair. But when the present government announced that headteachers would get up to £30,000 to spend on urgent repairs, the general secretary of the National Association of School Masters/Union of Women Teachers, Nigel de Gruchy, gave it a backhanded welcome, wondering whether some money might have been kept back to help fund "the looming teachers' pay crisis". But there is now a growing consensus that a school's built environment is central, not peripheral, to behaviour and performance in the classroom. "Even though there is nowhere near enough money, the fact that the government has even recognised the issue as a problem is significant," says Dominic Cullinan, who works with Makeover at School and has been a pioneer in this field. The government has awarded Kingsdale £9m in order to renovate the school creatively and in keeping with designs arrived at through the School Works process. Nationwide, the government has also pledged £2bn in an investment programme this year. School Works, meanwhile, has been funded by the Department for Education to roll out its project nationally, producing a handbook for all schools about how they can adopt the process. It is telling that there has been very little research done on the subject. What little research exists shows that where a participatory approach to school improvement has been undertaken there has been a reduction in truancy, vandalism, a greater sense of ownership and better behaviour. At Kingsdale, which has more than its fair share of inner-city problems, Morrison believes the built environment touches too many other aspects to ignore. Sitting with his back to the CCTV camera scanning one of the corridors, he says: "There comes a stage where you think 'What have we not looked at?'. We are working on teaching and learning and staffing. We have looked at every other aspect of our working life apart from the place that we actually work in." Or as one student in Barnet put it: "Our school looks dull, old and scruffy and it makes us feel dull and boring." Changing the environment will not put an end to deviant behaviour, insists Cottam. "If you dealt with the bike sheds then the gym might become the bike sheds. Some people will always overstep the mark and you cannot possibly police every space all the time." But what it could do is remove some of the reasons why so many children begin to overstep the mark. Take storage space. A mixture of vandalism and expense has led many schools to do away with lockers where students can put things during the day. Where they did exist, pupils did not believe their belongings were safe and so stopped using them. Either way, lockers are becoming a thing of the past. Whatever you brought to school - PE kit, text books, coats - you had to carry around all day. In the end some children just stopped bringing things altogether. "Our backs ache, we can't take our coats off, we never arrive," said one student. Playgrounds are dominated by sporty boys while girls and the unathletic cling to the sides. "There is no space for us, we don't really matter," said one girl. Toilets are another problem area. Poor drainage, graffiti and filth make them no-go areas. But children still need to go to the toilet. At Kingsdale they started going home to use the loo. But then many of them wouldn't come back for the rest of the day. And there are staff rooms. Teachers must now be one of the few graduate professions where most will never have their own desk, let alone an office, and where it remains almost impossible for someone to make an outside call or have someone contact them during the day. While there are no easy solutions to all of these problems, some of them are far from incurable. Some require imagination. As they discovered at Kingsdale, in many subjects it makes more sense to move the teachers rather than the pupils. Some, like secure lockers and offices for staff, will cost money. And most changes will require a mixture of both. In one school, each year group has been allocated its own toilet, which will remain its own until the pupils leave school. So if the toilets are trashed in year two, they will have to live with them for the remaining three or four years. At a School Works seminar, one teacher raised the issue of how to keep a school secure without making it feel like a prison. One architect suggested that rather than fortifying the entire structure so that it appeared formidable, there could be an inviting "front of house" reception, as you would find in a bank, and a system for allowing certain people past a certain point. With government money now committed, a number of changes are planned for Kingsdale, which range in scale and ambition. The plumbing in the toilets will be updated and the materials around the toilets changed to make them more resistant to vandalism. There will be just one common entrance to the school, which can be monitored, and then access around the school will be facilitated through the use of smart cards. Pupils will be able to log in and out, order their meals earlier in the day, thereby avoiding the crush during dinner time, and check equipment in and out. Every child will have a locker, which will be located in a public place, making vandalism and theft more difficult. There will also be more passive surveillance with open-plan, transparent partitions and windows in doors, so that people can see and be seen, thereby eliminating some of the murkier corners where bullying or other misdemeanours might take place. webTitle: On the web: the human body

fields.headline: On the web: the human body
fields.trailText: Sites for key stages 1 and 2
fields.body:
The Learning Connection

Suitable for KS2 teachers

The human body section is divided into six areas - ideas, links, resources, information, hands-on and feedback. The resources list is a goldmine. Excellent.

Human Body Questions

Suitable for KS2 teachers

A first-rate resource, covering most aspects of how the body functions. Gems such as "Why do men have nipples?" would make a great starting point for classroom discussion.

BrainPop

Suitable for KS2 pupils

A US site, but none the worse for that, looking at the body and how it works. The experiments and cartoons will appeal to primary age children.

Primary Resources

Suitable for KS1-2 teachers

A dozen or so downloadable worksheets on the body.

Neuroscience for Kids

Suitable for KS2 pupils and teachers

Fascinating explanations of the brain and nervous system, and a wealth of experiments, lesson plans and activities.

The Heart: An Online Investigation

Suitable for KS2 pupils and teachers

Plenty of material here for projects exploring the heart, including a look at how early physicians listened to the heartbeat.

<a href="http://" BBC's Body Matters

Suitable for KS2 pupils

Children take a tour of their body, with information appearing as they click on parts of the anatomy; plus advice on how they can look after their health.

Human Anatomy Online

Suitable for KS2 teachers and pupils

Dozens of diagrams of the human body, with views of the skeletal and cardiovascular system. Clicking the mouse over parts of the anatomy will take you to a more detailed diagram.

webTitle: Review: Mark Rothko, Fundacio Joan Miro, Barcelona

fields.headline: The ghost in the gallery
fields.standfirst: It's 30 years since the great abstract artist Mark Rothko killed himself in his studio. So why won't he let Adrian Searle look at his paintings in peace?
fields.trailText: It's 30 years since the great abstract artist Mark Rothko killed himself in his studio. So why won't he let Adrian Searle look at his paintings in peace?
fields.body:
I can't deal with Mark Rothko. I stick my head round the door of the room devoted to his paintings at Tate Modern and lurch out, fast. The atmosphere is too hushed, broken by stifled adult sobs and the squeak of felt-tip pens, as schoolkids, sitting cross-legged on the floor, do their studious little Rothko-ettes in purple ink. I want to run away.

When I opened Rothko's huge 1998 catalogue raisonné for the first time, the book's spine wrenched itself, with a horrible tearing sound, away from the thick stack of pages. So I slid the broken-backed behemoth back into its fancy box and never looked at it again. The damn thing has been clogging up my bookshelves ever since, accusing me. Hard on its heels came the catalogue for the American National Gallery of Art's 1998 retrospective. I didn't travel to Washington to see the show, but now I have caught up with it in the somewhat reduced version at the Miro Foundation in Barcelona. The queue went right out the door.

The Miro Foundation is a good hotel for Rothko, whose encounter with Joan Miro's semi-abstract surrealist work quickened his own drive towards abstraction. The lighting isn't great, the space is a little cramped and awkward (much of Rothko's work is just too big for its surroundings), and the exhibition layout a bit confused, so that you need to be pretty hard-nosed to follow the chronology and trajectory of his art accurately. But these are small gripes.

Rothko's early work, from the 1930s, has been largely reduced to his 1936 self-portrait and some pictures of the New York subway, which all in their way prefigure what was to come in his later art. This makes Rothko's development look clearer than it actually was. Rothko's early work (aside from his tyro efforts to ape Paul Cézanne, Jack Levine, Honoré Daumier) was a clunky but affable caricature, almost a kind of illustration.

The subway paintings may be redolent of post-Depression urban alienation, but the atmosphere down there - the horrible light, the tiles, the cast iron work, the pillars - hasn't changed significantly. The grim, sallow light in these paintings comes full circle in Rothko's final works from the late 1960s, his last paintings divided by a horizon line, though the blacks and yellowed greys are steelier, the effect unremitting, sullen, remorseless.

I don't go for Rothko's tone, his patriarchal sternness (he once even forbade his wife to take life-drawing classes, because of his certitude about the supremacy of abstraction). With Rothko, there was always a lot of wind and blather and self-aggrandising propaganda. Barnett Newman had it too, but he was also suave, and by all accounts a generous, sympathetic spirit. Rothko, on the other hand, was unapproachable, aggressive, dauntingly taciturn. He'd bite your head off, said Brice Marden.

When the young Ellsworth Kelly approached him to talk about his work, Rothko just said something like: "Don't you think I need a rest?" All that Nietzsche, the long silences, the drinking, the Valium and Tofranil, fuelled his insecurities. But who are we to expect him to be a nice guy? Rothko's own pronouncements, and his calamitous inner life, his depressions and his suicide provide torque and twist to his paintings, but that shouldn't blind us to them, even though he almost went out of his way to set us mortal folks against him. At some point the artist and the work must part company.

Much of my resistance to Rothko , however, lies in his posthumous public reputation, as much as what his paintings intimate. John Golding's recent, passionate book Paths to the Absolute wraps up with an examination of Rothko's continuing influence. Golding says that Rothko, Pollock et al "inspired others to produce many hundreds of thousands of canvases that were subsequently either destroyed or rolled up, languishing to this day in barns, lofts and studios the world over, particularly in English-speaking countries . . . A vast proportion of abstract painting and sculpture produced during the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s was destined never to be seen." Golding is, or was, a painter as well as an academic, and his paintings have been pretty much out of the public eye for some years. He speaks from experience. The moment for making such paintings is over for the foreseeable future. Golding's book concludes, however, as follows: "Profundity has been in short supply but it can and will reassert itself." He's right about that, too, but one of Rothko's lessons is that self-avowed profundity sticks in the throat.

Rothko's mature work, we must agree, is voluptuous, gorgeous, at once ample and spare. People also - as Rothko himself knew, and as Golding notes - look great in front of them. But too many people turn them into backdrops, and there are almost always too many people nowadays. The details, the pleasures of their thinly washed, matted glazes and breathy surfaces, and the time the paintings take up (they sort of eat you, and root you to the spot) are a lesson, too, about a kind of art that isn't really made any more, a kind of looking that's all too rare.

Rothko knows how to ravish, but it too often feels as if he is pawing you. I can never quite forget that the colour comes out of a tube, that painted evanescence is a matter of human skill rather than divine intervention. The surface and the space get to me, the close-toned hum, the plenitude, the slippery fading indeterminacies of the painted edges, the boundaries between his forms, the responsiveness of his paintings to the light that falls on them and the illusory light within. But I find much of it the teensiest bit mawkish and hammy. Like Golding's paean to profundity, we don't have the mental space for all that any more. Or perhaps we find the effect it has on us embarrassing. It feels kind of thespian and stagey, like listening to Lawrence Olivier doing Shakespeare.

Perhaps Rothko's theatricality, his sense of installation and the relationship between his painted space and the physical space where we stand before them, does indeed still have currency. We find it in some recent installation art, much of which he would have surely hated. But the waning of a style shouldn't be a cause for grief. A new one will be along at any moment. Who knows how it will refer back to what came earlier, how it will rejig the way we look at the art that came before, even Rothko's?

His last works, harder-edged, more overtly referential than anything that preceded them for two decades, are unavoidably close to a kind of terror-filled but otherwise empty landscape. They unavoidably recall Caspar David Friedrich, as well as, in their colour, the grimly washed studio portraits of Giacometti. They are grim, stoical paintings. Their stoicism outlasted Rothko, who committed suicide in his studio by slitting his wrists, aged 66 in 1970. You can't help but think of his last days when you look at them. But then again, the paintings are not equivalents to character, or human failings. They're better than that, and about more than despair. They invite lengthy contemplation. The trouble is, even if there's no one else in the room, Rothko keeps getting in the way. I wish he'd go away.

· Mark Rothko is at the Fundacio Joan Miro, Barcelona, until January 28. Details: 00 34 93 443 94 70 and www.bcn.fjmiro.es. Paths to the Absolute is published by Thames & Hudson, price £36.

fields.headline: News round-up
fields.trailText: Fulham, the First Division leaders, are set to make a £3.5m bid for Coventry City's centre-back Gary Breen. The Craven Cottage side's manager Jean Tigana is eager find a replacement for Chris Coleman, who broke his leg in a car crash last week, and the 27-year-old Republic of Ireland defender is the latest target.
fields.body:
Fulham, the First Division leaders, are set to make a £3.5m bid for Coventry City's centre-back Gary Breen. The Craven Cottage side's manager Jean Tigana is eager find a replacement for Chris Coleman, who broke his leg in a car crash last week, and the 27-year-old Republic of Ireland defender is the latest target.

After overcoming a persistent groin problem, Breen has been a regular in Coventry's side this season and was outstanding in their FA Cup win at Swindon on Saturday.

However, the Sky Blues' chairman Bryan Richardson yesterday insisted the player would not be moving, telling the club's website: "There's absolutely no substance to it. He's certainly not going to be going there.

"He's getting an extended run in the side and we're all delighted with his performances. He's proving what a top-class international performer he is. We won't let Gary Breen go anywhere."

They may have little choice so long as Breen, who cost Coventry £2.5m from Birmingham City three years ago, is willing to drop down a division.

But with Fulham on course for promotion - they have a seven-point lead and two games in hand over their closest challengers Bolton Wanderers - the Irishman is only likely to be playing First Division football until the end of the season.

Fulham were last week linked with Rangers' Italian defender Lorenzo Amoruso and have also expressed an interest in Newcastle United's Alain Goma.

Jaap Stam and Andy Cole will continue their comebacks from injury in a specially arranged friendly between Manchester United and Burnley tomorrow, but are unlikely to be risked against Bradford on Saturday.

Tony Pulis, sacked as Portsmouth's manager last week, has decided to appeal against his dismissal. "Tony Pulis denies any suggestions of gross misconduct and will place before the appeal convincing evidence to support that assertion," said the League Managers' Association, which will act for Pulis, in a statement.

webTitle: Wise stays at Chelsea after change of heart

fields.headline: Wise stays at Chelsea after change of heart
fields.trailText: Just as he seemed on the verge of leaving Chelsea, Dennis Wise has changed his mind and declared his intention to stay.
fields.body:
Just as he seemed on the verge of leaving Chelsea, Dennis Wise has changed his mind and declared his intention to stay.

Last week Wise informed his manager Claudio Ranieri and Colin Hutchinson, the club's chief executive, of his desire to leave. Aston Villa were the first club to react to the news by making contact. But now, it seems, he is going nowhere.

"I am staying," he said. "They all got to me. Mr Bates, Colin Hutchinson and Gianfranco [Zola] all told me how important I am to the club, and I understand that. Even my mum was upset I might be leaving and said I can't.

"I had the tea ladies in tears and the girls in Mr Bates' office were all upset. They just told me I can't leave Chelsea."

The only person likely to be disappointed by Wise's change of heart is John Gregory, the Aston Villa manager, who believed that he had found the experienced midfielder he has been seeking for so long. This, like his continuing quest for a striker, is a search that must now continue.

webTitle: When the going gets tough, or potentially expensive...

fields.headline: When the going gets tough, or potentially expensive...
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Lobbying government is a delicate issue and banks are reluctant to admit that it matters quite as much as it clearly does.
fields.body:
Lobbying government is a delicate issue and banks are reluctant to admit that it matters quite as much as it clearly does.

Most of the big institutions have their own public affairs departments, acting as the most direct link to government. But when the politico-economic going gets tough, or potentially expensive, firms turn to external advisers to navigate the Whitehall maze. Lloyds TSB is known to use Lexecon, an economic advisory with close links to Whitehall, while Abbey National has turned to Brunswick for its advice on the wider political backdrop. This will not stop other firms pitching for business, though. Among those thought likely to be preparing their pitches are:

Apco

Born out of Washington law firm Arnold and Porter, from which it derives it name, the firm has long-since severed its ties after selling itself to Grey Advertising. This gives it close links to GCI Focus, a PR firm much better known in financial circles. It is thought to have been hired by NatWest during its tussle with Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of Scotland last year.

Bell Pottinger Public Affairs

Owned by Chime, one of its latest new recruits is Chris Woodhead, the former chief inspectorate of schools - a prime exampe of the type of people called upon to try to wield power in Whitehall. Few, though, could claim the contact book of chairman Lord Bell, one half of the name of the agency, renowned for his work for the Conservative party.

Citigate Dewe Rogerson

Part of the Incepta group, it was ranked second in a poll of political lobbyists by Marketing magazine.

GJW

Able to claim itself as "independent" until last May when it was sold to BSMG Worldwide. It is regarded as one of the most politically experienced agencies.

Lawson Lucas Mendelsohn

A lobby firm once associated with "Drapergate", its founders, from which it takes its name, all have backgrounds in politics. John Mendelsohn in particular can claim close associations with this government, having worked in Tony Blair's office in opposition. It is beginning to diversify beyond lobbying to the wider communications arena. It has recently been involved in promoting the People's Lottery, fronted by Sir Richard Branson and unsuccessful in its bid to win the licence to run the National Lottery.

Westminister Strategy

Part of the Grayling Group, owned by the Havas Advertising group, it lists the General Medical Council among its recent clients. It claims to have led the way for statutory regulation of the public affairs industry.

The top five political lobbyists as ranked by Marketing Magazine in May 2000:

Shandwick

Citigate Dewe Rogerson

Bell Pottinger

GCI/Apco

BSMG Worldwide
