fields.headline: Big City guns target Westminster
fields.standfirst:
Lobbyists in the battle for control of Abbey National have begun a charm offensive against politicians of all stripes

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Peter Kilfoyle might not yet know it, but his name and his opinions matter in the City of London. The maverick Labour member for Liverpool Walton, a former junior defence minister, is typical of the key "opinion forming" MPs whose names are hurriedly being drawn up by opposing factions in the Square Mile's war of the moment - the blazing battle to win control of Abbey National bank.
fields.body:
Peter Kilfoyle might not yet know it, but his name and his opinions matter in the City of London. The maverick Labour member for Liverpool Walton, a former junior defence minister, is typical of the key "opinion forming" MPs whose names are hurriedly being drawn up by opposing factions in the Square Mile's war of the moment - the blazing battle to win control of Abbey National bank.

Forget "see-thru shareholder value", cost-centric synergies and exponential improvements on capital employed. This particular financial rumble, being fought between Lloyds TSB and its smaller, north of the border rival Bank of Scotland, will be settled in the corridors of Whitehall as much as in the cut-throat world of the City. The bankers involved believe their number-based arguments with their investors - aimed, that is, at cutting costs and increasing scale in a fast consolidating sector - are relatively straightforward. But they also know that it is the politicians, the civil servants and, of course, consumer groups of every conceivable flavour, which will tip the balance on one way or the other.

Nobody mentions the concept of "stakeholders" but that, in effect, is the unpredictable target market in a deal which is literally worth billions to the victor.

So any MP with a reputation for causing trouble - particularly in the field of financial services - can expect a call. Over the coming months, along with key civil servants inside the competition-related bodies such as Graham Winton - the case officer handling this latest round of bank bids - and others inside the DTI and the Treasury, voluble or impressionable MPs face a deluge of facts and figures from the three banks engaged in the £20bn stand-off. It is case of getting them to make a noise or keeping them quiet.

The stakes are high. Lloyds TSB, veteran buyer of other banks and building societies, is on the attack. It wants to add Abbey to its black horse stable, having been stirred into action by Abbey's own half-formed plan to merge its own business with Bank of Scotland.

The argument boils down to one about the creation of a "fifth force" on the high street, a combination of Abbey and Bank of Scotland which might be completed if Lloyds TSB is kept at bay - versus one about creating something akin to a "national champion" by allowing Lloyds to take over Abbey and, in the process, enabling the new entity to become Britain's most powerful bank in terms of its number of current account customers.

As the first of the building societies to convert to a bank more than a decade ago, Abbey has warned its investors that the competition authorities may intervene in a bid by Lloyds TSB. It is anxious to keep its arguments factual, but some bankers believe it could argue that consumers will continue to suffer in an environment where the so-called Big Four simply tighten their grip on the nation's finances.

Lloyds, meanwhile, which could find out by February 3 whether the office of fair trading will refer its takeover plan to the competition commission - triggering a full blown inquiry - is reckoned to be preparing to argue the exact opposite. This little island simply has too many banks. Consolidation is inevitable and, in any case, related cost cuts will feed through into cheaper and better services for customers. There is both value and beauty in size, so the argument goes.

First up are the competition lawyers, the hotshots at Clifford Chance for Lloyds TSB and Slaughter & May for Abbey National. Along with the investment banks advising the protagonists - JP Morgan for Lloyds TSB, and UBS, Lehman and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter for Abbey - the lawyers have already prepared the stastistics on respective market shares and the precedents set by previous takeovers.

Political expedience

The lawyers agree that on pure economic arguments alone, there is little to suggest that a bid for Abbey by Lloyds TSB would force a referral to the competition authorites. Vocal opposition, or political expediency, is another matter. Therefore, quite naturally, the gong-laden ranks of non-executive directors on both banks' boards may also be called upon to make their own, discreet impressions.

"It's the politics that are difficult to judge. The economics are pretty clear... Any referral to the competition commission would have to be a political case. There isn't an economic case," one senior banker says, bluntly. Another points cynically to the high street clearers' eventual readiness to bankroll the Post Office-based universal bank: "Remember the government is very sensitive to being lobbied. It doesn't like it, it has to be subtle," one industry source said.

But these are not just nervous times for bankers. A new director general at the office of fair trading, John Vickers, is facing his first real test. The nerve of government, particularly the embattled trade secretary Stephen Byers, who will decide whether the bid should be cleared, is also being stretched. With a general election just months away, Labour will find itself caught between being seen to provide a fair playground for the City but at the same time reacting to the threat of, say, 20,000 lost jobs

To the discreet band of public relations specialists retained to advance the banks' conflicting messages, the influence of politics on the City is no big surprise - and an "evil good" for that matter.

"You can see the political input into mergers and acquisitions as quite a strong corporate discipline, as politicians and political judgements can affect the commercial interests of a company and ultimately the structure of a market," said Tamsin Rosewell, head of competition at Westminister Strategy, one of the lobby experts likely to be deployed in the battle.

The subject has particular resonance in the light of last week's shock decision by Mr Byers to block Belgian beer group Interbrew's acquisition of Bass Brewers. The banks know the brewing industry's fate is a lesson in how not to lobby government. In the summer of 1999, for instance, Punch Taverns was able to snatch Allied Domecq's pub estate from the grips of Whitbread when the Mr Byers blocked Whitbread's agreed takeover on competition grounds. "Whitbread was complacent and its shares have never really recovered," one adviser to that deal said yesterday.

Second guessing the competition authorities in public or ignoring their influence is something the bankers want to avoid. "It's much more about making sure the right people are aware of the right background. It's about enabling a debate among civil servants, economic advisors and public officials," one banker with a few City campaign medals said.

While City strategists quibble over the supposedly all-important 25% market share threshold seemingly breached by the combination of Lloyds and Abbey, lobbyists continue to fret over the "mood" within government. Even though Mr Byers has made much of his decision to "take the politics out of mergers", handing more influence to the OFT and the competition commission, most lobbyists believe the effect has been to increase the political influence.

"The competition authorities and the regulators are essentially political tools. I would not argue that they are party political, but they are certainly making political judgments. They are set up in a certain way, with defined duties that complement government policy. For instance, much of the comment from the competition commission and the OFT is about protecting the interests of consumers. What does that mean, exactly? Who has defined precisely what is in the consumer interest and what isn't? The commission itself was set up through legislation. That makes it intrinsically linked to the political process through which that legislation was enacted," says Ms Rosewell.

Consumer focus

According to one City adviser, Labour's focus on consumer interest is why MPs can expect to be courted if the OFT recommends to Mr Byers that a competition investigation is required.

This is what Don Cruickshank - the banking "tsar" who was commissioned by the chancellor to review competition in the banking sector - wanted to take place. So far his advice has gone unheeded, and a number of large deals have been completed without any competition interference, notably Royal Bank of Scotland's takeover of NatWest and Barclays' acquisition of the much smaller Woolwich. The big banks are already embroiled in a competition commission investigation into small business banking which has tested their relationship with decision makers.

But a growing body of opinion says the way the competition commission is structured makes it much easier for pressure from MPs or consumer groups to push for an inquiry. Some even believe that the easiest option for Mr Byers - so close to a general election - is to refer the deal to the competition commission.

All the indications are, then, that Peter Kilfoyle and his colleagues should prepare to be charmed.

People of influence

Graham Winton, a senior civil servant buried in the bowels of the office of fair trading, will be the first man the bankers involved in the tussle over control of Abbey National will want to reach.

One of the anonymous mandarins inside the OFT, Mr Winton is the case officer for the initial investigation. The opinions he gathers will be crucial to the advice given to Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, about whether to refer any bid by Lloyds TSB to the competition commission.

Mr Winton will not make the decision alone, however. Officially the advice is handed to Mr Byers by John Vickers, the new and increasingly powerful director general of fair trading. Andrew White, a senior member of the OFT staff who heads the merger division, will also be an important barometer, as will another senior civil servant - Margaret Bloom - the divisional director who overseas competition in general and will be a crucial decision maker.

She is often chair of the shadowy merger panel, which offers the final sounding board to the OFT.

The banks have to make detailed submissions to the OFT - and will probably already have done so. Opinions on Lloyds TSB's potential bid for Abbey must be received by January 19, the day after Mr Byers is due to rule on whether the Bank of Scotland and Abbey National deal needs a competition review. Under the timetable, Lloyds TSB should hear by February 3 whether it is clear on competition grounds to launch a bid.

It is understood that the micro-economic background of Mr Vickers has encouraged the banks to put submissions to the OFT which break down market shares in to their tiniest parts.

The final judgment on whether to refer the decision rests with Mr Byers. While he has pledged to follow the guidance given to him by Mr Vickers, he is able to decide on "public interest" grounds to take a different view.

This is where lobbying from consumer groups, particularly the Consumer Association's boss Sheila McKechnie will be used. It is likely to be at the core of any attempt by Abbey to get the bid referred. The National Consumer Council will also be targeted. Finance union Unifi, which fears job cuts, has made no secret of its desire that the bid should be referred.

Industry sources believe there are 100 or so backbench MPs who will also feature on lobbying hitlists drawn up by banks. Vocal MPs such as Peter Kilfolye might top this list together with the dozen MPs on the influential treasury select committee, chaired by the New Labourish Giles Radice, and Martin 0'Neill, chairman of the trade and industry committee.

Liberal Democrat Vincent Cable, so vocal over the Equitable Life debacle, might also be called on to help put forward arguments. Martin Salter, the Labour MP who as head of the cross-party banking committee, meets the high street lenders, will be kept abreast of the action.

Besides MPs, New Labour's influential advisers will also be targeted. In the DTI this would see Dan Corrie, a policy aide, and press officer Jo Moore likely to be sounded out. Kim Howells, the consumer affairs minister, and noted free-marketeer who has been given a high-profile role by this government, is also likely to be an important figure inside the DTI.

The Treasury, while not directly involved in decisions about mergers, will also be used as a weapon by the banks hoping to mould the arguments or to get a feeling for ministers' preferences.

This is the government department with which many have their closest relations as a result of the special role banks play in the economy. One reason that bankers might feel cherished by the Treasury is the "cooperation" lenders have offered economic secretary Melanie Johnson in helping with the government's social exclusion.

Ultimately, Gordon Brown, the chancellor, the minister who set Don Cruickshank on the banking sector, will also be regarded as an important influence in any debate about whether Lloyds TSB should take over Abbey National.

Jill Treanor

fields.headline: Tour firms warned on 'rip-off' charges
fields.standfirst: Office of fair trading threatens court action over holiday cancellation penalties of up to 90% which are said to be highest in Europe
fields.trailText: The office of fair trading yesterday threatened legal action against the big four travel companies over "rip-off" cancellation charges which are said to be the highest in Europe. UK holidaymakers can pay up to 90% of the total cost if they cancel a fortnight before departure.
fields.body:
The office of fair trading yesterday threatened legal action against the big four travel companies over "rip-off" cancellation charges which are said to be the highest in Europe. UK holidaymakers can pay up to 90% of the total cost if they cancel a fortnight before departure.

The OFT complains that Airtours, First Choice, JMC and Thomson have refused to give financial details to justify the charges. The firms argue the charges accurately reflect the costs of cancellation. This has led to deadlock after 14 months of negotiations between the OFT and tour operators, prompting the threat of a high court injunction.

An OFT spokesman said: "We are concerned that the way cancellation fees are calculated is unfair. In Sweden, for example, you only have to pay 50% right up to 24 hours before departure. We believe the charges are too high, particularly as tour operators are often able to resell the holidays."

Experts estimate cancellation charges affect hundreds of thousands of British tourists every year and are now the biggest single source of holiday insurance claims.

There is a further blow for the big operators today with the publication of a survey of 10,000 readers of Holiday Which? magazine which judges them to be among the worst performers in the industry. Small independent firms claimed the six highest ratings.

Airtours, Cosmos, First Choice and Unijet all languish at the foot of the ratings, while JMC, launched in 1999 by Thomas Cook with a promise to "deliver what really matters to consumers" comes bottom out of 55 companies.

Of 532 JMC customers in the survey, fewer than one in four said they would recommend the company to a friend. At the other end of the table, all 50 of the holidaymakers who travelled with Greek island specialist Laskarina said they would have no qualms about urging friends to use its services.

Of the big four operators, only Thomson managed to stay out of the group of 10 worst performers, although only around half of its 1,180 customers who were surveyed said they would "definitely" recommend its holidays.

Holiday Which? also found that previously high-flying in dependent firms provided a poorer service when they were taken over. The four major travel companies now own almost half of all tour operators. Among them, Simply Travel, which specialises in villa holidays in Europe, dropped from its top of the table position in the last survey after being bought by Thomson.

Swiss Travel Service, which had featured in the "premier league" of best performers in every survey since 1993, also dropped into the survey's "first division" after being bought by Airtours in 1998.

Patricia Yates, editor of Holiday Which?, said: "This survey clearly shows a preference for the smaller independent specialists when it comes to delivering the quality of service they are looking for.

"Over the past two years, the large operators have significantly increased their ownership of these companies. We are concerned that this will not only drastically narrow consumer choice but that the quality of service holidaymakers are entitled to expect will suffer."

The most crucial factors to holidaymakers when choosing a tour operator was accommodation, followed by convenience of travel arrangments, value for money, brochure description, and the services of a representative.

Holiday Which? also warns that the biggest charter airlines are the worst offenders when it comes to delays on holiday flights. Airtours and JMC performed poorly on nearly all of their routes analysed in a survey of UK airports.

Airtours is introducing a stand-by aircraft to cover both long and short haul flights this year, while JMC blames its poor performance on the delayed delivery of two aircraft, resurfacing work on the runway at Gatwick and forest fires in Corfu.

Top for punctuality came British Airways, its subsidiary Go and franchise partner GB Airways, all of which are scheduled services.

webTitle: Classical: Evelyn Glennie, the Mad Queen

fields.headline: Evelyn Glennie, the Mad Queen
fields.standfirst:
BBCCO/Wordsworth/Glennie
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
*
fields.trailText:
BBCCO/Wordsworth/Glennie
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
*
fields.body:
There may be no more complete package in the classical music world than the percussion-playing phenomenon that is Evelyn Glennie. From the stylised theatre of her performances to the logo of her website - emblazoned across prominent instruments onstage - everything about Glennie speaks of total professionalism.

The same goes for many of the more than 100 percussion concertos Glennie has commissioned. The BBC Concert Orchestra accompanied Glennie in two recent works: Dave Heath's African Sunrise/Manhattan Rave and Nebojsa Jovan Zivkovic's Concerto of the Mad Queen, a London premiere.

Both concertos are designed to show off Glennie's musical and theatrical talents. Heath's piece allows Glennie to luxuriate in the warmth of marimba melody, while an orange glow makes the sequins of her outfit glimmer. Then, in the Manhattan Rave section, Glennie moves to another percussion set-up of metal instruments. The piece culminates in a cacophonous cadenza for Glennie and her scrap metal.

Zivkovic's concerto casts Glennie as the Mad Queen of the work's title. She is enclosed by the instrumental exotica of specially-invented "Earth-plates" and other percussive rarities, and bathed in a purple and green murk.

The problem with this "new type of performance", as Glennie's biography gushes, is the compositional vacuity it produces. Focusing on the inherent drama of Glennie's percussion rigs is one thing. But allowing that single element to overwhelm a musical argument, as Heath and Zivkovic do, is quite another. The result, in both concertos, is music of showy sound and fury that signifies only the noisy intentions of composer and soloist.

Simon Jeffes' Music from Still Life at the Penguin Cafe was the over-long and anodyne curtain-raiser to the concert. At least Peter Maxwell Davies's An Orkney Wedding, with Sunrise, which closed the programme, gave a glimpse of compositional flair. The performance also included a cameo from Glennie, who played the bagpipes at the work's conclusion. Her suspect tuning will not worry any professional pipers.

Nevertheless, Glennie was resplendent in a matching waistcoat and bagpipe costume - both, presumably, bedecked in Glennie's own tartan: "The Rhythms of Evelyn Glennie."

fields.headline: The Firebird
fields.standfirst:
Unicorn at the Pleasance, London
***
fields.trailText:
Unicorn at the Pleasance, London
***
fields.body:
Traditional British and north European fairytales such as Cinderella and Sleeping Beauty are all very well, but there is a limit to how many times you can endure them. The Unicorn Theatre for Children takes us, instead, to the icy, wolf-inhabited forests of Russia for this story based on local legend and folktale.

Lack of familiarity is a bonus rather than a detraction here, and Susanna Steele's adaptation ensures that even the younger members of the party will follow this tale about the King so filled with grief for his dead wife that he neglects his daughter, Marushka. But then the golden apples on his dead wife's tree begin to go missing, mysteriously snaffled every night by an unknown thief.

With her father ever more distant, it is Marushka who alone knowing the identity of the culprit sets out in the company of the nice but dim-witted Ivan, to travel into the mountains and forests on a quest to find the mythical firebird.

Steele's script is decent enough although it sometimes remains earthbound, straining for poetry when it should effortlessly soar like the firebird itself. But this is a production lifted above the ordinary by the combination of Keith Khan's design, Natasha Chiver's lighting and Thomas Gray's musical composition and lighting design.

As well as some simple but rich ethnic-style costumes that look at times like small multi-coloured tents, Khan provides a bare playing space of stripped pine that takes you back to Habitat c1975. The surrounds also function as climbing walls, so that the stage space is used as much vertically horizontally. It provides a perfect backdrop to a wintry Russian landscape where wolves howl, ravines must be crossed and the witch Baba Yaga lurks in the heart of the forest, either offering help to travellers or eating them.

Khan's magic space is rendered even more enchanted by lighting that conjures both shadows or the fiery sunset plume of the mythical bird itself and music that makes you think of wolves at full moon, faraway peasant communities and something known but forgotten like a folk memory.

The rest of Emily Gray's production tries, and often succeeds, in living up to these other components and is at its best when it is less pantomime-like and more feral. Michael Rochester's Wolf, with his "mouthful of knives" and loyal heart, is as good as the real thing, particularly in the scene where he transports the children on his back to the edge of the world.

The princess is a little too girlish, Ivan a touch too dumb, and the ending feels somewhat sudden and contrived. But this is a piece of theatre for children that will also be enjoyed by adults and which has a suggestive power that always leaves ample room for the audience to use its own imagination.

* Until Sunday. Box office: 020-7609 8753.

fields.headline: Linbury's wild dreams of turbulent teens
fields.standfirst:
The Lost Domain
Linbury Studio, London
**
fields.trailText:
The Lost Domain
Linbury Studio, London
**
fields.body:
Even ripped apart and rewritten, Henri Alain-Fournier's novel Le Grand Meaulnes (also known as The Lost Domain) is a striking piece of work. The thorny relationships between its brooding, restless hero Meaulnes, his beloved, beautiful Yvonne and the novel's level-headed yet tender-hearted narrator François gleam with emotion. The petty rivalries and wild dreams of this teenage world beautifully capture the turbulence of adolescent life, and the way its memories are cherished in adulthood.

Alex Went and Peter Fanning's musical version keeps the main themes intact but inevitably it loses much of the richness of detail - not to mention the intensity that the reader's own mind brings to such a fairytale. Characters such as Meaulnes are always better imagined than seen, and no matter how much he contorts his face in an expression of angst, Krishan Nursimooloo does not live up to the part of this great adventurer. It does not help that his voice, although strong, lacks variety and, occasionally, tunefulness.

But then, this is essentially a student production - written, directed and conducted by grown-ups but performed by teenagers from Shrewsbury School, of whom you can forgive much. At times that is not necessary: many of the soloists have lovely voices, and it is a pleasure to watch the subsidiary characters stealing the stage. Simon Hunka, as Yvonne's lovelorn brother Frantz, brings light to the cheesiest of music; so does Kerry Fairclough, playing his lost fiancee Valentine, although the hints of Madonna in her voice suggest she would make a better pop star. The couple's reconciliation at the end of the musical, moments before Frantz and Meaulnes are killed in Went and Fanning's sombre twists to the plot, is touchingly evoked.

The performance suffers mostly from the weakness of the company: the singing is uneven, due no doubt to the fact that only the soloists wear microphones, and the dancing inconsistent in its confidence. You would see work of this ambition and quality from few other schools, but it is hard not to feel that these youngsters are exposed on the Linbury Studio's huge stage, and would fare far better in a smaller fringe theatre.

But that is Alain-Fournier's novel in a nutshell: chasing after the greatest of dreams, no matter how ruinous they might prove to be.

fields.headline: A quarter century of Iron Maiden
fields.standfirst:
Iron Maiden
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London
***
fields.trailText:
Iron Maiden
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London
***
fields.body:
At a time when heavy metal is spiralling off into ever weirder sub-species - sports metal, necro-metal and whatever camp Satan-snoggers such as Marilyn Manson fall into, to name but three - Iron Maiden feel like the guitar-pounding counterparts of Disgusted of Tunbridge Wells.

The band was formed 25 years ago (how can gents of a certain age still possess such luxuriant manes?) and are among the last exponents of heavy rock as it was, before it became the domain of Prozac-munching teenage sociopaths.

Although the current album, Brave New World, flirts with such updated subject matter as father-son relationships ("Just for a second a glimpse of my father I see, and all the wounds are reopening again," screeches Bruce Dickinson on Blood Brothers, departing for once from the usual diet of Arthurian myth and legend), Iron Maiden will forever be a reassuring bulwark against the 21st century. When the designer Stella McCartney made Motorhead T-shirts briefly trendy last year, they probably did not see the irony.

The relatively tiny Shepherd's Bush Empire is off the beaten track for a group of their (still) arena-filling abilities, so this fan-club show was just about the hottest ticket in town, amazingly enough. The scaled-down staging meant that Eddie, Iron Maiden's faithful skeletal mascot, had to stay in his cave, but the compensation is that one drinks in the sight of Dickinson's roomy shorts at uncomfortably close range.

For his part, Dickinson looks oddly like Simon Le Bon of Duran Duran fame, but sings like a Nubian castrato, scaling the peaks of Wrath Child and Two Minutes to Midnight (played at 9.20pm, of course) with operatic hysteria.

Meanwhile, the drum-troglodyte Nicko McBrain chunders out a brutal backbeat that makes every number sound like Led Zeppelin's Immigrant Song. But there is no Jimmy Page to complement him on the guitar parts, which are undertaken by three characters straight from heavy metal central casting.

The Maiden's sound is too carbohydrate-rich to be entrusted to just one guitarist, so all three play in clangy unison, never using one note where a dozen will do. One of them has a penchant for wistful solo sojourns that transform the pained Blood Brothers into Bryan Adams-esque soft rock, making the girls in the house (very few, you will be surprised to learn) close their eyes and sway along.

But displays of virtuosity are pointless when the kids just wanna rock, and Iron Maiden will undoubtedly be doing their unreconstructed thing long into the new century.

fields.headline: Freddy Kempf
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Wigmore Hall, London
***
fields.body:
Liszt's Etudes d'exécution transcendante are as daunting as their title suggests. For the listener, the sustained testosterone-charged flamboyance of the 12 Transcendental Studies, which together last well over an hour, can be exhausting; for the performer, they are an inestimable challenge of technical ability. Almost any pianist would be taking a more or less calculated risk by choosing to perform these studies, and Freddy Kempf is no exception. But this willingness to take chances is one of the things that make this young pianist's recitals so exciting.

Striding on to the platform, Kempf launched into the first, decisive major chord of the Preludio almost before the audience had had a chance to settle down. A similarly unapologetic, almost confrontational approach pervaded most of the studies - Kempf tackled them head-on to the extent that he seemed to be fighting against the thick swathes of notes rather than being the medium through which they were transmitted to the audience.

Nor did he always come out clearly on top in this battle. There were some wrong or missed notes, and at times Kempf found it difficult to project Liszt's well-hidden melodies smoothly from within these thickly written scores. Indeed, he often sought refuge in the sheer volume of the noise he was producing. His triple fortissimos were certainly powerful - the Wigmore Hall piano has rarely had that much sound drawn from it - but, with every climax pushed as far as it would go, some lost their impact and began to seem unrelenting rather than momentous. Still, a spirit of heroism prevailed, never more so than in the fourth study, Mazeppa - a lengthy, pictorial episode which sends both of the pianist's hands careering wildly up and down the keyboard, and which Kempf dispatched with bravado.

It was in the more relaxed studies that Kempf's considerable musicianship really had a chance to shine through. The melody of the third, Paysage, was picked out beautifully from the inner lines, and the fifth, Feux-follets, was offered up with graceful delicacy. The ninth, Ricordanza, was an oasis of calm, played with wistful tenderness.

The second half, shorter by far than the first, was devoted to Chopin - the Andante spianato et Grande Polonaise, followed by the Ballade No 3 in A flat. These were better vehicles for Kempf's strengths; the Polonaise was poised and radiant, while the lilting melodies of the Ballade were lyrically phrased.

It seemed that while the impassioned passages of the Liszt section had brought out latent aggression in Kempf, these Chopin pieces gave him the space to perform with his usual thoughtful spontaneity. If he could find a way to apply this subtlety and reticence to his performance of the Transcendental Studies, it might yield great results.

A similarly unapologetic, almost confrontational approach pervaded most of the studies - Kempf tackled them head-on to the extent that he seemed to be fighting against the thick swathes of notes rather than being the medium through which they were transmitted to the audience. Nor did he always come out clearly on top in this battle. There were some wrong or missed notes, and at times Kempf found it difficult to project Liszt's well-hidden melodies smoothly from within these thickly written scores. Indeed, he often sought refuge in the sheer volume of the noise he was producing. His triple fortissimos were certainly powerful - the Wigmore Hall piano has rarely had that much sound drawn from it - but, with every climax pushed as far as it would go, some lost their impact and began to seem unrelenting rather than momentous. Still, a spirit of heroism prevailed, never more so than in the fourth study, Mazeppa - a lengthy, pictorial episode which sends both of the pianist's hands careering wildly up and down the keyboard, and which Kempf dispatched with bravado. It was in the more relaxed studies that Kempf's considerable musicianship really had a chance to shine through. The melody of the third, Paysage, was picked out beautifully from the inner lines, and the fifth, Feux-follets, was offered up with graceful delicacy. The ninth, Ricordanza, was an oasis of calm, played with wistful tenderness. The second half, shorter by far than the first, was devoted to Chopin - the Andante spianato et Grande Polonaise, followed by the Ballade No 3 in A flat. These were better vehicles for Kempf's strengths; the Polonaise was poised and radiant, while the lilting melodies of the Ballade were lyrically phrased. It seemed that while the impassioned passages of the Liszt section had brought out latent aggression in Kempf, these Chopin pieces gave him the space to perform with his usual thoughtful spontaneity. If he could find a way to apply this subtlety and reticence to his performance of the Transcendental Studies, it might yield great results.

fields.headline: Tax with no return
fields.standfirst:
The Inland Revenue may collect our taxes and national insurance, but it seems to have little input into determining government policy

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Inland Revenue may collect our taxes and national insurance, but it seems to have little input into determining government policy.
fields.body:
January is a taxing month. Nearly a third of the 9m sent a tax form for the financial year that ended last April have so far failed to return it, despite dire threats of interest being added to outstanding sums and £100 fines for non-respondents. For the next few weeks a lot of people will be thinking a lot about one of Whitehall's more reticent departments, the Inland Revenue.

Formally, the Inland Revenue is part of the Treasury but it enjoys considerable autonomy over an increasingly complex tax regime. The total number of taxpayers is rising slightly while under Labour higher-rate (40%) payers have increased significantly - what was that about redistribution? None the less many of the revenue's 27m clients scarcely know it exists; some 18m pay tax automatically (painlessly?) by deductions from their pay. If they ever look at pay slips, they rarely query either their tax code or national insurance contributions, which are also now administered by the revenue.

Here is a puzzle. Tax is the very stuff of party politics, clear blue water, red sea. Perceived injustice in tax matters is one of the few issues to get people out on the streets in protest. But the department that taxes floats above the battle, unobserved. Perhaps it is taken for granted because it is perceived as bureaucratic but resolutely honest - compared with other countries few scandals have tainted the tax inspectorate, which retains an impressive if slightly masonic esprit de corps.

With the introduction of working families' tax credit, the revenue may bulk a lot larger in many households. It will need to know a lot more about the domestic circumstances of more people; it is being transformed into a "social department" in the words of a recent report. That implies we should know more about its workings.

Constitutional theory says Whitehall departments are answerable because ministers can be questioned about them in the Commons. But there would be an outcry if the minister - a junior member of the Treasury team, currently paymaster-general Dawn Primarolo - ever saw individual tax files. Meanwhile tax policy is made by the chancellor of the exchequer and the Treasury, with only marginal input from the Inland Revenue.

Things have opened up at the headquarters in Somerset House since an outsider (ie someone with no tax experience but great expertise on transport), Nick Montagu, was brought in as chairman of the board four years ago. As part of "modernising government" - the plan agreed between Tony Blair and cabinet secretary Sir Richard Wilson - departments were to invite external experts to take a look at their inner workings and (a novelty) publish the results.

The first effort, a review of the Department of Culture, Media and Sport was promising but the Cabinet Office's own "peer review" was flabby. Such reviews might have been a way of lighting the dark place of our permanent government - how policy is made. But they are themselves "reviewed" before publication and made bland. Sadly, lay people will find little in the review of the Inland Revenue.

If they notice it. Since it was published with no fanfare on the verge of Christmas, the public might have missed "Architectural engineers"*. Yet, in code, it asks some good questions. The unpaid reviewers were led by Chris Kelly, then permanent secretary of the Department of Health and if he does not sound much like an outsider that is Whitehall for you. (Mr Kelly has now gone, apparently because of a lack of personal chemistry between him and Health Secretary Alan Milburn.) They also included the genuinely dis-interested Andrew Dilnot of the Institute for Fiscal Studies and Gillian Ashmore, a consultant.

They wanted to know how far tax policy is informed by the taxpeople's expertise. An obvious port of call, you might think, would be Gordon Brown but he was not interviewed. Under him something like an administrative revolution is under way. Under Labour the tax system is supplanting social security, which puts pressure on tax officials and employers.

Another key question in this era of joined-upness is why there needs to be a separate revenue department, let alone two (customs and excise is the other). On the answer depends who should do tax policy. The Inland Revenue has data on what taxpayers think but it is rarely used by the Treasury officials who make tax policy. Or think tanks and party officials. Where was the Inland Revenue assessor on the recent high-calibre panel assembled by the Fabian Society to examine the future of tax in our market society?

Between the lines, the review team identify a gap in Revenue thinking which the Tories, if they had their wits about them, would pick up. Where, they ask, is the model of business taxation to compare with the predictive model that exists for personal tax and benefits? Lack of one has let Gordon Brown engage in jiggery-pokery with corporation tax and investment tax reliefs.

Mr Montagu wants to make the Inland Revenue more user-friendly. You can now return self-assessment forms online; perhaps in future taxpayers might be offered an explanation of where their money goes. Tax officers might be proactive - place a gentle phone call in June asking if taxpayers need any help with their forms. It would help spread the office workload and save new year anguish.

*www.inlandrevenue.gov.uk/about/peer.pdf

fields.headline: Home sales concession to MPs
fields.trailText: The government last night moved to head off a backbench Labour revolt over plans to introduce a mandatory home seller's pack to help speed up "the slowest and most inefficient" conveyancing system in the world.
fields.body:
The government last night moved to head off a backbench Labour revolt over plans to introduce a mandatory home seller's pack to help speed up "the slowest and most inefficient" conveyancing system in the world.

The housing minister, Nick Raynsford, promised Labour MPs from areas where some house prices have collapsed that he would consider exempting the cheapest homes from the duty to obtain a seller's pack, which would include a basic survey and title search at a potential cost of £300-£400. But his offer, as MPs debated the second reading of the homes bill, was made with evident reluctance. It would inevitably create scope for anomalies while denying the benefits of the seller's pack "to buyers who may be particularly vulnerable", he warned.

With Labour's Tony Lloyd (Manchester Central) and Joe Ashton (Bassetlaw), leading complaints that a compulsory pack would be an "intolerable burden" where some houses were now worth only £4,000, the minister predicted sellers might only be asked to pay for the pack when their house was sold.

Mr Raynsford also said that though conveyancing was cheap by world standards in England and Wales - Scotland has its own laws - 28% of transactions failed between the acceptance of an offer and the exchange of contracts.

Although gazumping, the abandonment of a seller's agreement in favour of a higher offer, would not be made illegal - as it was in Scotland - because that might give too much power to a buyer "deliberately dragging his feet" the government hoped its reforms would curb the practice.

fields.headline: I left without my pay
fields.trailText: I worked in telesales where I would get £125 basic a week and 15% commission of what ever I put up on the "board". I put up £4040 for my first month so I should have received £606 - but I was told I would get £40.
fields.body:
The problem

I recently lost my job due to my boss not liking me very much, but that isn't all. I worked in telesales where I would get £125 basic a week and 15% commission of what ever I put up on the "board". I put up £4040 for my first month so I should have received £606 - but I was told I would get £40.

I kicked up a bit of a stink (nothing bad - just had words with people) and my boss asked me to leave, as I did quietly. I never got paid even the basic for that week, and I never received a payslip while I was there. The citizen's advice bureau have advised me to see a solicitor since the money they owe me has to be paid.

The solution

I am puzzled by this. How did they justify your entitlement to only £40? Did they offer any explanation at all? Do what CAB suggest and seek legal advice with the aim of recouping the money you are owed.

However, your energies should really be concentrated on getting another job. Telesales is a huge growth industry so you should be able to find work out there. Put your bad experience behind you, find a reputable company and go sell yourself.

Incidentally, I can't help wondering why the boss in your last job took such a dislike to you in just a month. I am also wondering exactly what you mean when you say you 'kicked up a bit of stink'. I am not suggesting for one minute that what happened was your fault - quite clearly the company should have paid you what was agreed - but there may be steps you can take to ensure that you get on with your next boss a bit better, and perhaps handle disagreements more assertively. I suggest you get hold of my new book, Managing Your Boss in a Week, which is written for the Institute of Management (published by Hodder & Stoughton).

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).
